It must be hard for a young British band growing up as NME darlings
column4: but the Horrors seem to have handled it all rather well. They made the cover of the magazine in 2006 before having even released an EP
column5: presumably on the strength of their black cotton-candy haircuts and their media connections. And they debuted first single ""Sheena Is a Parasite"" with an equally uncommon assist from director Chris Cunningham
column6: who had previously done his unsettling
column7: special effects heavy work for more musical outliers such as Aphex Twin and Autechre.

column1: But if the Horrors' high profile debut was baffling
column2: their follow-up moves were encouraging. They spoofed themselves with an appearance on an episode of the British comedy ""The Mighty Boosh""
column3: as a band called the Black Tubes
column4: in an episode revolving around protagonist Vince Noir trying to squeeze into a pair of impossibly skinny jeans so he can join the band. They quickly shed the campy
column5: dark garage shocks of debut Strange House
column6: announced a sophomore album produced by Portishead's Geoff Barrow and Cunningham (the latter resulting in a lot of ""cinematic"" talk despite his decidedly claustrophobic small-screen style)
column7: and started stretching out their sound to accommodate eight-minute krautrock jams. This is perhaps the best you can hope for from your rising rock stars: a willingness to laugh at oneself and a will to evolve.

column1: Skying continues the evolution set in motion 2009's Primary Colours
column2: but with an emphasis on melody and pop form. This time
column3: the band recorded and produced in their own studio
column4: crafting a sound that recalls both the gothic pomp of 80s new wave and the big-screen dreaming of early-90s shoegaze
column5: just as it was beginning to transform into chart-conquering Britpop. That the record can be heard as a catalogue of influences is nothing new for this outfit. They've routinely been tagged as ""record collector rock"" for their unabashed aping of influences from the Cramps to Can-- and indeed their well-selected covers indicate a group that has spent some time in record shops. Skying isn't likely to change that perception. The insistent chorus and Badwan's breathy delivery on ""I Can See Through You"" comes off like the Psychedelic Furs run through the effects rack of My Bloody Valentine. ""Monica Gems"" nods to Suede with its decadent guitar swirl and Badwan's moaning sighs. On ""Endless Blue""
column6: a horn section pops in for the floating intro as if borrowed from a James Bond theme by way of Blur or ""This Is Hardcore"" before the song abruptly surges into an impressive rock nosedive. The debts owed here are obvious
column7: but the taste is impeccable
column8: and the application is more often than not convincing.

column1: There are moments when the band stretches out past seven minutes and opts for something more impressionistic
column2: like the hypnotic ""Moving Further Away"" and the reclining-then-softly-erupting album closer ""Oceans Burning""
column3: but the Horrors seem otherwise content to craft solid
column4: emotionally inflected rock songs here. Lead single ""Still Life"" sets the tone in that regard
column5: with an appealing bucolic stupor
column6: rhythm section keeping half time
column7: synths seeping backwards
column8: and frontman Faris Badwan singing in a low
column9: foggy voice that holds its spot high in the mix as easily as it drifts away on the chorus. That it brings to mind Simple Minds and
column10: by extension
column11: teen angst of the John Hughes variety
column12: is by no means a negative.

column1: Both Badwan's voice and the band's production have made some strides here: He sounds surer behind the microphone than ever
column2: and the band's guitars and synths are frequently smoothed of shrieks into one great blur
column3: the black eyeliner watered down and smudged into a gray cloud. So while they may have started out as all glittering surfaces
column4: the Horrors have evolved into a dependable band making wide-reaching rock music. Whether a calculated retreat or just a natural maturation
column5: the Horrors have found a sound more content with background and atmosphere
column6:
and it suits them nicely.

Nguzunguzu's nervy approach to DJing and production is best exemplified by an edit of Monica and Brandy's ""The Boy Is Mine"" that appears on their Perfect Lullaby mix from the spring. They looped producer Darkchild's synth-harp intro from that 1998 hit and let it ride for about two minutes
column3: turning it into a mediative electronic groove. The Los Angeles duo thrives on this type of sonic ""aha!"" moment
column4: finding musical cues that expose the ways that mainstream rap and R&B aren't all that different from what's going on in the more explicitly experimental underground. Producers making footwork
column5: Baltimore club
column6: moombahton
column7: post-dubstep
column8: and more are toying with minimalism
column9: repetition
column10: and noise; but the urban music on the radio can similarly blow minds
column11: and is often just as out-there.

column1: This isn't a new concept exactly (Timbaland at his peak was clearly an avant-pop genius)
column2: but Nguzunguzu are particularly skilled at bringing together disparate sounds-- as if their brains were missing the part that constructs binaries or identifies genre differences. They brought this to bear earlier this year when they stitched together M.I.A.'s demos and one-offs for Vicki Leekx
column3: making something just as jagged as /\/\/\Y/\
column4: but way more more fun to hear.

column1: The only tangible divide in their work seems to be the conscious splitting up of how they approaching mixing and producing. While their mixes and live sets confidently bounce between genres with ease
column2: their EPs (a self-titled one and Mirage from last year
column3: and now
column4: Timesup) have a different focus. Timesup's three songs and two remixes (by Kingdom and Total Freedom) don't deliver on the vibrant promise of Perfect Lullaby
column5: but they aren't really supposed to do that. The fascinating and sometimes frustrating thing about this group is the unresolved tension between their wide-eyed
column6: creative DJ mixes and their often insular original tracks.

column1: A good example here is ""Timesup""
column2: which runs on an eerie
column3: arpeggiated synth line
column4: a cracking whip
column5: and a baby cooing (homage to Timbaland's ""Are You That Somebody?"" beat
column6: no doubt). In the middle
column7: in lieu of dance breakdown
column8: there is
column9: for a few moments
column10: a vocal sample from ""Let Me Get That"" by the awesome but unknown Baltimore club producer DJ Pierre
column11: and right there is the Nguzunguzu recipe: mixing cutting-edge pop fighting with hyper-regional dance. ""Water Bass Power"" features a dark
column12: menacing synth line that gets louder and louder before circling its melody
column13: while vocal snippets
column14: the ping! of a knife being unsheathed
column15: and dub reggae noises clatter and stomp around. ""Wake Sleep"" slinks along like an Aaliyah single that never was
column16: piling on increasingly avant-garde percussive noises (an opera sample
column17: drips of water) and teasing the gorgeous hum of Art of Noise's ""Moments In Love"". It's difficult but rewarding stuff.

column1: A recent mix by the group for XLR8R however
column2: features all of the music on Timesup and places it in conversation with the world of post-global dance at large. ""Wake Sleep"" talks to a sad-sack chipmunk soul remix of ""Moments in Love"" (Jodie's ""Moments in Heartbreak (LOL Boys Edit)""); the title track provides an extended intro for ""Everyday""
column3: a Chicago juke jam from DJ Deeon; and a raucous Baltimore club-like track called ""Deep Inside Me Groove"" announces the arrival of ""Water Bass Power"". Because their mixes are so effective
column4: it's tempting to think of Nguzunguzu's standalone releases as track-oriented DJ tools. But Timesup is living
column5: breathing music that appears to be forming as it goes along. Here
column6: strange sound effects and samples are stacked on top of each other
column7:
teasing total chaos but ultimately staying on track because of the foresight of two producers who know exactly what they're doing.

column4: one (presumably) devoid of its creators voice. Instead

column10: Machinedrum's Travis Stewart approaches this trend like a glutton. Where peers like Four Tet and Jacques Greene apply these samples in precise
column11: painterly strokes

column13: he seems to suggest that their accumulation

column2: grazing drum patterns and warm keyboards holds these gobs together. Stewart manages a fair range of styles-- from the pounding

column4: detuned

column6: to the point where vastly different tracks are tonally similar. Sometimes
column7: such as on ""GBYE""
column8: he succeeds using short
column9: eager samples
column10: colliding two or three voices together dozens of times in quick succession. The tracks that stray furthest from dance music fare the best: ""Sacred Frequency"" (itself a single
column11: with excellent B-sides

column14: assertive R&B.

column1: I want to stress how many listens it takes to suss out even these differences. It's not that they're not real

Kendrick Lamar is a weird kid
column2: and rap music could always use more weird kids. The 24-year-old is a Compton native with a budding and mysterious Dr. Dre connection
column3: but there's little-to-no link to his hometown's gangsta-funk legacy in his music. Instead
column4: Lamar is very much a product of the late blog-rap era-- an introverted loner type who's willing to talk tough but is more interested in taking a Mag-Lite to his own personal failings and what he sees as the flaws of his generation. His rap style is fluid and melodic but approachable
column5: and his frantic tumble of syllables evokes the feeling when you're high enough that your thoughts arrive fast and interrupt each other. If one of the Bone Thugs guys had a dorky
column6: overly sincere younger cousin who was really into Afrobeat and Terrence Malick movies

column1: ""You know why we crack babies cuz we born in the 80s
column2: Lamar raps on the excellently emo relationship-song ""A.D.H.D.""
column3: and that's a theme that comes up over and over. Everywhere he looks

And he also recognizes self-destructive tendencies in himself: ""I used to wanna see the penitentiary way after elementary/ Thought it was cool to look the judge in the face when he sentenced me."" But it's not like he's some preacher/prophet figure; he says ""suck my dick"" often enough that it gets boring.

This is not the plug-your-ears Prurient you've come to know and possibly love. In the world of 21st-century harsh noise

column18: these songs start to sound as familiar-- and as American-- as ""This Land Is Your Land"".

column1: The jewel of the set is Marika Papagika
column2: a Greek immigrant and famed practitioner of Rebetiko (a Greek analogue of Ottoman café music) who apparently recorded over 225 records in the 1920s and eventually helmed her own club
column3: Marika's
column4: in New York. Nagoski included some of her work on his 2007 set Black Mirror: Reflections in Global Musics 1918-1955
column5: but she gets more space here
column6: and she deserves it: Papagika's voice is bold and otherworldly
column7: a high
column8: skewering whine that defies rote comparison. It feels desperate and pre-verbal
column9: like a baby crying in the middle of the night
column10: and with it Papagika communicates (un-self-consciously
column11: and with unchecked fervor) a staggering range of emotion. ""Smyrneiko Minore"" is her best
column12: strangest track; there's not much melody
column13: just Papagika howling over piano and a bit of bowed strings (probably a violin)
column14: but the anguish in her voice is unforgettable.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: it's the rawness of the performances that lingers. Tetos Demetriades' rendition of ""Miserlou""-- which Dick Dale transformed into an instrumental surf-rock staple in 1962-- is dark and ominous; Kanuni Garbis's ""Ouchak Canto Guzel Tourna"" is frantic and foreboding. There are expressions of joy here
column3: too-- D. Perperian's ""Tamzara"" (a folk dance) is giddy and bright
column4: an invitation to move.

column1: With its many moods
column2: To What Strange Place offers a small
column3: telling glimpse of the immigrant existence
column4:
using only the songs they recorded here. It feels as essential to an understanding of American music as anything else.

column2:
'Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Chemikal Underground']|2011-07-21 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:37.497633|"

So what we have here is the Scottish indie version of ""We're All in the Same Gang""
column3: a gathering of artists playing against type for a good cause. Originally an entrant in last year's Scottish Mental Health Arts and Film Festival
column4: First Edition put its roster up to the task of exploring appropriate lyrical themes. Where N.W.A and Ice-T once took on violence
column5: here James Graham (the Twilight Sad)
column6: Emma Pollock (the Delgados)
column7: Rod Jones (Idlewild)
column8: and Scott Hutchison (Frightened Rabbit) come together to promote mental health. Good cause and intentions aside
column9: there's an irony to this bunch working on such a project. The Delgados crafted their masterpiece in large part by living up to its title of Hate
column10: two of Idlewild's biggest hits are ""Little Discourage"" and ""Live in a Hiding Place""
column11: while Frightened Rabbit had to go ahead and put a song on their last record called ""Not Miserable"" because there's no way you'd assume the opposite was the case unless clearly notified.

column1: Fruit Tree Foundation is rounded out by relatively obscure (at least in the U.S.) singer-songwriter types like Alasdair Roberts
column2: Jill O'Sullivan
column3: and Jenny Reeve. And for the most part
column4: the songs here gravitate more toward their low-key and affable folkiness than the highwire bloodletting of the aforementioned. Recorded in a mere five days
column5: these are largely acoustic and almost entirely off-the-cuff
column6: showing their moving parts in an almost aggressive way: A good number of songs here begin with in-studio chatter (somewhat stilted back-and-forth about Glasgow and such)
column7: push through verses and choruses over static riffs and chord changes like they're in the progress of being written
column8: and wander off into noodly guitar solos. Undoubtedly
column9: First Edition was a fun project to record and I'm sure a welcome relief for most of those involved to sidestep the heft and expectations associated with their day jobs of supervising emotional powder kegs.

column1: But while there's chemistry
column2: there's little in the way of spark
column3: and First Edition's good intentions add up to a record that doesn't do anything upsetting. And as such
column4: it just feels like a misuse of resources. If nothing else
column5: it's proof enough that these guys are masters of technique and timbre as vocalists
column6: rather than just ones with a weapons-grade emotional arsenal. Graham's richly burnished low register in particular sounds fantastic simmering over acoustic dirges completely free of feedback
column7: yet it's worrisome that without the guitar squall and tortured
column8: punishing lyrics
column9: the Twilight Sad could conceivably veer toward the maudlin tearjerkers of the Swell Season. Likewise
column10: Pollock's contributions to co-ed bashers like ""Singing For Strangers"" recast her as a chipper cheerleader
column11: a weirdly deferential step down from her wearied but wise counterpoint to Alun Woodward. The Graham feature ""Favourite Son"" puts lumbering drums right up in the mix like the Twilight Sad
column12: and ""I Forgot the Fall"" retains Hutchison's unmistakably plaintive melodicism
column13: but both lack a crucial element of catharsis. Within First Edition's context
column14: Jones' ""All Gone But One"" is the hookiest and most forceful of the power-pop entries. Were it an Idlewild song
column15: and it certainly could be
column16: it would simply be a standard issue cut from one of their later LPs which found them getting less bookish and yet somehow also less edgy.

column1: Maybe my expectations are skewed
column2: but in a situation such as this-- basically
column3: a planned vacation from having to front such lyrically self-flagellating outfits-- you might figure it'd be embraced as on opportunity to take more chances both sonically and thematically. It's a nice enough listen and surely you'll come out of the purchase feeling much better about yourself (which is pretty much never the outcome upon listening to anything these guys have put their name on in the past). But ultimately
column4:
even the most rip-roaring of the bunch simply sounding like low-stakes versions of what we've grown accustomed to.

As L.A.-based Anticon has expanded its horizons
column2: it has slowly moved away from the navel-gazing
column3: leftfield hip-hop that made its name. Chicago rapper David Cohn
column4: who performs as Serengeti
column5: represents something of a return for the label. Following a 2009 collaborative record with producer and fellow Illinois native Polyphonic
column6: Serengeti's first solo album for Anticon is an unflinching homage to an indie-rap template that has otherwise largely gone the way of the dodo.

column1: Producing Family and Friends are enigmatic WHY? frontman Yoni Wolf and ex-Casiotone for the Painfully Alone mastermind Owen Ashworth (now working as Advance Base)
column2: who provide a sparse but sometimes gripping backdrop for Cohn's stable of strange characters-- all down
column3: a few out-- and their struggles. As an MC
column4: Cohn is part broken rambler
column5: part highly attuned people-watcher. He sounds like he could use a drink
column6: but his easy
column7: near-spoken-word delivery is nothing if not welcoming. If you're up for hearing about absentee junkie fathers or suburban malaise
column8: Cohn has a barstool ready for you.

column1: For such a conversational rapper
column2: though
column3: Cohn often makes it difficult to know exactly where you've landed in the conversation. Tracks like the free-associative ""A.R.P.""
column4: which finds the narrator taking DMT and later stubbing his toe
column5: or the cryptic ""Ha-Ha""
column6: about falling in love with the girl at the hardware store
column7: would benefit from a bit more coherence. And even when lucid
column8: Cohn frequently has trouble living up to the cleverness of his own concepts. For every moment as arresting as UFC-fighter lament ""The Whip""
column9: which pairs Cohn's workmanlike flow with spirit-crushing toy keyboard plinks
column10: there are too many where the pieces fit awkwardly. The desperate ""PMDD"" pines hazily for a girl in a pharmaceutical ad
column11: while the depressive title track echoes the famous ""Choose Life"" speech from Trainspotting
column12: but both make their points a little clumsily.

column1: Fortunately
column2: Wolf and Ashworth each prove to be positive enablers
column3: adding nuanced touches when things get a bit too ham-fisted. Base's chunky ""Ha-Ha"" could pass for a minimalist tUnE-yArDs track; Ashworth's soulful
column4: lonely ""Dwight"" features carousel music piped in from the ends of the earth. Not quite stylistic opposites but still distinctly different
column5: the two producers almost always make sure to stay on the same page
column6: taking skeletal percussive tracks and shocking them with little flecks of light. But as with much of Family and Friends
column7:
that light seems to be just out of reach.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16779/homepage_large.62974cb0.jpg|Peace Sells... But Who's Buying? [25th Anniversary Edition]|9199.0|Megadeth|['Metal']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Capitol']|2011-07-20 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:38.733303|"

Like many bands in the 1980s metal underground
column2: Megadeth were hugely successful while still essentially operating under pop's radar. Their abrasiveness
column3: speed
column4: gross-out extremity
column5: and nasty humor essentially barred them from the airwaves in the days when people called Slippery When Wet a metal album with a straight face. Like their indie-label peers who'd come up out of hardcore
column6: Megadeth built an audience by touring relentlessly
column7: and when they were finally signed to a major
column8: they became even more popular. And yet if you're reading this
column9: you're under 30
column10: and you don't consider yourself a metal fan
column11: you might not know their music at all.

column1: This is a sad thing. For the class of '86
column2: a year that gave us Megadeth's Peace Sells and Metallica's Master of Puppets and Slayer's Reign in Blood
column3: the refusal to go the Poison/Cinderella route was both a point of pride and what forever kept them cult acts. (Discounting Metallica
column4: who conquered the world only to become a joke.) They were absolutely huge cult acts-- festival draws and elder statesmen still listened to by millions-- but cult acts nevertheless. So this reissue of Peace Sells
column5: celebrating a quarter century of Megadeth's second but first truly great album
column6: is probably more a sop to those diehards than anything else
column7: but if it turns one curious party into a convert then it's worth it
column8: even in this time of bald cash-grab reissue ugliness.

column1: And there are many reasons why this album might still appeal to fence-sitters and folks turned off by extreme metal's very extremity. Peace Sells is a dead serious record that never takes itself too seriously
column2: a slab of political shock commentary that's loaded with black comedy
column3: and which treats Satan and ICBMs with the same awe because they're both great villains. Like most literate metalheads of his era
column4: Megadeth leader Dave Mustaine was deeply spooked by the supposedly imminent threat of mutually assured destruction
column5: a day-to-day possibility that those born after the cessation of Cold War hostilities might not understand. He was also plenty pissed over the non-nuclear atrocities of the Reagan years
column6: along with the kind of bleak
column7: man-against-the-universe shit that transcends presidential terms.

column1: But Mustaine also understood he was working in an idiom that invariably turned the most serious material
column2: from eschatology to existential despair
column3: into thrilling
column4: fist-pumping
column5: head-banging Grand Guignol. He believed in peace but knew thrash metal wasn't particularly suited to depicting some hugs-and-kisses utopia. Nuclear war was as shit-your-pants real as fears got in 1986
column6: but it also made for some great exploitation-flick imagery. And while the lyrics to ""Devil's Island"" make their point about death row being a sad end for any human being
column7: the music makes state-sponsored execution sound suspiciously awesome.

column1: Megadeth had plenty of the grimy intensity of the cassette-trading bands that would give birth to death metal and all that followed
column2: but they'd absorbed enough radio hard rock to not abjure things like memorable thuggish riffs
column3: big shout-along triumphant choruses
column4: and a rhythm section that could actually throw down on a groove without succumbing to the metal vice of momentum-killing displays of virtuosity. The bass hook that opens ""Peace Sells"" is so instantly memorable that everyone who watched MTV in the late 80s and early 90s knows it even if they think they don't. This is a thrash record of course
column5: and so there are solos galore
column6: with Mustaine deep in the throes of technical ecstasy. But while drummer Gar Samuelson is no slouch in the chops department and songs shift tempos in seconds and plenty open with those noodly sturm-und-drang intros that made 80s metal so portentously great
column7: the pummeling pace rarely lets up. ""Good Mourning/Black Friday"" takes a few minutes to rev up
column8: but then it's like everything great about hardcore
column9: plus a dose of the kind of show-off skill that makes lesser musicians' fingers bleed.

column1: There's a drunken laugh-so-you-don't-cry attitude on Peace Sells that seemingly owes as much to Flipper as to Ozzy
column2: especially on the title track
column3: but that doesn't mean Mustaine was mocking his audience. Megadeth were always a metal band first and foremost
column4: which meant never condescending to anyone for feeling helpless and hopeless
column5: or for thinking death and destruction were simultaneously kinda cool and really not-cool. Like most metal heroes
column6: Mustaine on Peace Sells identified deeply with the dead-end kids who bought his records
column7: even if he could play better than 95% of them. The raw live set appended as a bonus disc to this reissue-- there's also a multi-disc version that features many different mixes of the original album that will probably be of interest strictly to those who've been living with it for years-- features a snarling and ferociously funny performance of ""Peace Sells"" that outdoes the album version in everything but fidelity. It's an all-time ode to feeling disenfranchised but at least knowing you can still write an epic screw-you song about that fact. Mustaine knew there was no point to making this stuff sound like a drag. Because if you did manage to survive another day
column8: there was always another beer and another awesome metal record waiting for you
column9:
and sometimes that was enough.

Gucci Mane has lowered expectations considerably in the past year. In addition to the rapper's recidivism issues and garish facial tattoos
column3: his Brick Squad guest spots have been as inspiring as a game-six LeBron James performance. But by almost any standard
column4: Writings on the Wall II is a major comeback. There are no weak tracks or unfortunate production choices
column5: and Gucci's delivery
column6: if not his lyrical content
column7: retains its distinctive character. Musically
column8: he's adapted his unique songwriting approach to a more aggro era
column9: welcoming Brick Squad mixtape mercenaries Lex Luger and Southside to the fold.

column1: The new sonic strategy works as quick sleight of hand to distract from what could otherwise be some repetitive moments on a 70-minute rap record. It helps that the ever-versatile Drumma Boy produces the bulk of the record's back end. Drumma's highlight here
column2: ""Translation""
column3: ratchets up tension with simple
column4: ascending piano lines
column5: a trick the producer has used before. Few beatmakers can create a larger variance of ideas and moods with such minor modifications of a simple formula. (It may be no coincidence that Gucci's lyrical approach functions in a similar manner). His beat for 50 Cent feature ""Recently"" throws out the rulebook completely. A walking bass line transforms into a mind-warping rumble during the chorus
column6: while an organ riff hits at unpredictable rhythmic angles
column7: giving the entire song a frenetic tension. Southside takes some unexpected liberties
column8: too
column9: most impressively on ""Major""
column10: where lightly tapped snare and exhaled background vocals create an odd sense of ominous delicacy. Fat Boy's ""Camera Ready""
column11: the tape's standout
column12: bears more similarity to recent Brick Squad tracks like producer Prince's epic ""Like a Dream"" than the typical Fat Boy sound (""Wasted"").

column1: Lyrically
column2: Gucci is considerably more generic now than during his memorable 2008-2009 run. Even when his flow hits its double-time stride
column3: he's still falling back on trap-rap clichés. Missing are the moments of narrative power
column4: like his verses on ""Frowney Face""; gone is the must-rewind imagery that used to dominate his tapes. Gucci acknowledges on ""Gucci Talk"" that he has returned to the ""no pad
column5: no pencil"" style of his earlier work. But when 2008's No Pad No Pencil came out
column6: everything Gucci was releasing seemed to push hip-hop's possibilities in new directions. Writings on the Wall II instead consolidates several song structures he has done before
column7: wedding them to some (stunning) contemporary production. Gucci's lyrics weren't celebrated for their complexity
column8: although he deployed that strategy on occasion. His lyrics' power stemmed from the imagery and humor he used to render in full color a world that for most rappers exists only in black and white. To the tape's considerable credit
column9:
Gucci disappoints here only when compared with himself.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16777/homepage_large.acd3fe27.jpg|FRKWYS Vol. 7|29756.0|Borden
column2: Ferraro
column3: Godin

Halo & Lopatin|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rvng Intl.']|2011-07-20 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:40.644684|"

The concept for RVNG's FRKWYS series-- meetings between young experimental musicians and veterans-- is nothing revolutionary
column5: but so far the results have been quite rich for one-off collaborations. That trend continues with Vol. 7
column6: for which the label first approached Daniel Lopatin
column7: aka Oneohtrix Point Never. Together they brainstormed a project involving minimalist composer David Borden. The latter's résumé is wide-- even including a mostly-unused score for The Exorcist-- but he's best known for founding the synth ensemble Mother Mallard's Portable Masterpiece Company. That group began in 1969 playing Moog versions of pieces by Terry Riley
column8: Philip Glass
column9: and Steve Reich. Soon they began composing their own music and experimenting with newer electronics
column10: something they continue to do today.

column1: Such openness to sounds and ideas comes through on the five pieces here
column2: which are impressively varied despite being pretty uncomplicated. Part of that variety is due to the participants Lopatin brought into this session last August-- James Ferraro
column3: Laurel Halo
column4: and Samuel Godin
column5: all open creative minds on their own. But what's most impressive about Vol. 7 is how it never sounds like a mess of piled up activity
column6: or five voices elbowing for room. If someone told you this was made by one person
column7: you'd probably believe them. So it's not too far-fetched to guess that
column8: for two days in the studio
column9: these five became of one mind
column10: joined by a simple sonic vision.

column1: Perhaps Borden is just that forceful a musical personality
column2: steering his comrades toward a very distinct set of goals. However these tracks came together
column3: the unity of purpose is evident throughout. It starts from the very first seconds of opener ""People of the Wind Pt. 1""
column4: a 12-minute drone that constantly builds and expands
column5: marrying airy etherealness to dense guts in a way that recalls Stars of the Lid's best epics. From there
column6: the ensemble winds through a range of moods and timbres. ""Internet Gospel Pt. 1"" warps like an underwater wedding processional; ""People of the Wind Pt. 2"" adds a sense of galactic transmission to Pt. 1; and ""Twilight Pacific"" fuses Lopatin's flowing repetitions to Borden's Terry Riley-ish all-night-flight inclinations. All of this can get pretty spacey and drifting; you'll need some predilection for things like OPN
column7: Emeralds
column8: or the early Kranky roster to fully dig into such synthed-out pieces.

column1: Stick with it
column2: though
column3: and you'll get rewarded by closer ""Just a Little Pollution""
column4: whose rippling synths and haunting Julee Cruise-like vocals-- presumably provided by Halo-- make it a kind of otherworldly pop song. It's as if these sonic sculptors spent the previous five tracks chiseling away at a big block of sound until it produced this shiny little gem. It's remarkable enough that this one-time alliance produced so much good improvised music
column5: an approach so dependent on listening and communication that it can take years of trial and error to create the right working situation. But the fact that they also made that music build to an album-ending peak gives Vol. 7 a shot at being a record that holds up over time
column6:
regardless of how impermanent this group itself may be.

"|15654.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15654-frkwys-vol-7/|7.7|Marc Masters

This year
column2: producers like Clams Casino
column3: Araabmuzik
column4: DJ Burn One
column5: and Main Attraktionz' Squadda B have been turning out amorphous beats that sound just as good (and especially in Clams' case
column6: better) without someone spitting over them. The music they're making is beguilingly strange
column7: and although much of it carries bits and pieces of J Dilla's legacy
column8: most sounds far removed from his dusty knock. Dilla set a precedent for the producer-as-auteur movement
column9: but his influence is less apparent in the twisted synths and borrowed trance figures of this year's most interesting beatmakers.

column1: Of course
column2: there are still plenty of people carrying Jay Dee's torch in 2011: a good deal of the soul stable in Stones Throw
column3: for example (J-Rocc
column4: Oh No
column5: Dilla's spiritual cousin and fellow innovator Madlib)
column6: as well as California's Sam Baker
column7: aka Samiyam. His second long-player
column8: Sam Baker's Album
column9: is being released by Brainfeeder
column10: Flying Lotus' label-- another artist whose early work was heavily indebted to Dilla (though creatively
column11: he's in a much different place now). Compared to the futurist glitch work that's been released on Brainfeeder as of late
column12: Sam Baker's Album sounds quite formalist in execution
column13: right down to the last delayed beat-drop.

column1: Still
column2: this isn't exactly a ""real instrumental hip-hop
column3: naw'mean"" traditionalism. Tart
column4: whinnying keyboards abound
column5: as well as a fair share of oozing bloops. But there's an enticing familiarity to what Samiyam is doing here
column6: even if its own tiny eccentricities and abstractions take a few listens to wholly unpack. The stoner-giggle vocal samples scattered throughout only accentuate the record's sticky
column7: loping feel; needless to say
column8: there's a certain smoky atmosphere this music was almost tailor-made for. When he leaves the arena of sampled hip-hop signifiers and heads toward more abstract pastures
column9: however
column10: the material loses itself in its own towel-under-the-door haze.

column1: Baker's early EPs (especially his 2008 Return EP for Hyperdub) were smothered with melodic wooze
column2: which made the relatively straightforward boom-bap snippets on that same year's <i>Rap Beats
column3: Vol. 1 LP seem a little rote and old-head by comparison. Sam Baker's Album continues on the latter path
column4: but with a little more attention paid to the use of empty space. In other words
column5: it's ""Sam Baker's album"" by name and ownership
column6: but it's also another beat tape in a very crowded field
column7:
one where it's easy to get lost amidst the increasingly innovative producers working now.

column1:

Over the course of an EP and two albums
column2: Glasgow's Sons and Daughters wedded punk's charged menace to a much older macabre spirit lurking in the musty back pages of folk
column3: pop
column4: and rockabilly. It's <span>a neatly evocative trick
column5: but one that gloomy post-punk icons like X
column6: the Mekons
column7: and the Birthday Party already pulled off in the late 1970s and early 80s. Another quarter-century removed from greasers
column8: torch singers
column9: and murder balladeers
column10: Sons and Daughters' resurrections had a tendency to feel like kitsch
column11: but really fun kitsch. Their antiquated influences eliminated the need for reverence
column12: so the band could concentrate on cranking out absurdly enjoyable slices of breakneck nastiness.

column1: Sons and Daughters' third full-length
column2: Mirror Mirror
column3: mostly trades one brand of pillaging for a duller one. The moroseness and death obsession remain (one song's about the Black Dahlia)
column4: but instead of using dark concerns as a springboard for sick thrills
column5: Sons and Daughters have gotten hung up on the precise craft of emulating gothic post-punks like Siouxsie and the Banshees
column6: Joy Division
column7: and Bauhaus. Mirror Mirror is impressively spot-on in its reenactments
column8: from doomy synths and cavernous drums to guitars that are practically always whirring
column9: grinding
column10: or shooting out lonely shards and tendrils; in fact
column11: much of the album's merit is textural. But that's a dispiriting realization considering how great Sons and Daughters have previously been at crafting arresting
column12: immediate hooks. And what happened to the tempos? Even the band's most ardent supporters would concede their previous albums were a tad relentless in their barreling pace
column13: but too much of Mirror Mirror is either plodding or static. Only a few times
column14: most notably on ""Breaking Fun"" and ""Rose Red""
column15: do Sons and Daughters really get pulses pounding.

column1: All this atmosphere and portent would be fine if the band displayed the presence to sell it. Instead
column2: engrossing lead singer Adele Bethel cedes too much of the mic to counterpart Scott Paterson
column3: who has been effective in call-and-response settings but isn't distinctive enough to carry songs himself. No matter who's taking the lead
column4: neither singer seems to be having much fun
column5: which used to be a constant for Sons and Daughters regardless of how bleak or blood-soaked their lyrical fixations might have been. Mirror Mirror smacks of a band struggling to be taken more seriously
column6:
but simply settling on a more stone-faced form of pastiche isn't the way to do it. All they've really done is trade a Halloween party for a history lesson.

Back when the Cool Kids first made the rounds a few years ago
column3: it was still pretty weird-- revolutionary
column4: even-- for a new group to build a buzz and an audience without relying on a physical product. The Chicago retro-rap duo seemed like they sprang fully formed from the Internet. They lived their lives one blog-bait mp3 at a time
column5: releasing another dose of icy-cool 808 thud whenever the time felt right. For this group
column6: the idea of an actual full-length album was almost beside the point. If they could tour-- and play lucrative corporate-sponsored shows-- without the benefit of an album
column7: then why bother? It wasn't like the Cool Kids were bursting with artistic ambition; they rapped about their sneakers and cars and haircuts
column8: not exactly the sort of thing that extends well over an hour or so. And though they've been promising the imminent arrival of honest-to-god debut album When Fish Ride Bicycles for a few years now
column9: the release remained stuck between record labels
column10: and it felt perfectly reasonable to assume that it would never show up.

column1: The album has now shown up
column2: but it's not some sweeping cohesive statement. Fish has a few big names attached
column3: but it's not an onslaught of guests. If you've been paying attention to these guys over the past few years
column4: almost everything here will sound familiar. The production
column5: mostly from Cool Kid Chuck Inglish
column6: is straightforwardly spacey
column7: a crisp and bright take on minimal mid-1980s drum-machine boom. Inglish and Mikey Rocks have voices so flat that they usually sound bored
column8: and they're less interested in punchlines than they are in matter-of-fact situational boasts
column9: many of which have a weird patina of nostalgia to them.

column1: When Fish Ride Bicycles is out on Mountain Dew's Green Label Sound imprint
column2: but it's not like the Cool Kids are rapping about sipping on Code Red or anything. Instead
column3: the album illustrates the absurd things a rap group has to do to release an actual wide-circulation retail album in 2011. They've made the leap to corporate patronage with their personalities totally unchanged; the move hasn't audibly affected their personality as a group. (It does have to be said
column4: however
column5: that the gigantic Mountain Dew logo on their cover art is a pretty bad look.)

column1: The real move that the group makes on When Fish Ride Bicycles is a slight step away from minimal 80s rap toward squelchy 1980s funk. Most of the tracks here come with gooey Zapp-sounding keyboards
column2: a slick melodic sound that gives their tracks an extra dimension. It's a sound that works for them in small doses
column3: but when they go back to it a bit too often
column4: the trick robs their simple
column5: affectless sound of some of its power. Melody and warmth aren't Chuck Inglish's strong suits; he sounds best when he's stripped his tracks back to their barest elements
column6: as he did on The Bake Sale EP.

column1: But these flourishes are nowhere near enough to drown the album. The Cool Kids' greatest asset is that their music is fun; it sounds good at parties
column2: or on summer-afternoon drives
column3: or at corporate-sponsored live shows. That doesn't change with When Fish Ride Bicycles. These guys still know who they are
column4: and their lines still show some serious linguistic style without going out of their way to impress: ""She wanted me to beg
column5: but I beg your pardon/ I'm Park Place
column6: you're Marvin Gardens"". For a couple of tracks
column7: they link up with the Neptunes
column8: the producers whose dizzy Triton experiments probably showed them what a resourceful mind can do with a drum machine. Ghostface Killah and Bun B roll through
column9: sounding grizzled and authoritative
column10: their mere presence implying a sort of legitimacy. Asher Roth pops up on the unnecessary posse cut ""Roll Call""
column11: but he gets out of the way without doing any serious damage. The whole thing makes for a solid
column12: low-impact listen. It's not going to change your life or even
column13: most likely
column14: your day. But it might make 39 minutes pass by more quickly
column15: and that's all it seems to want to do. The Cool Kids have now proven that they can make an album
column16:
but they haven't proven that they ever needed to make an album.

"|15628.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15628-when-fish-ride-bicycles/|6.9|Tom Breihan

It's weird to think of a Christian Fennesz record as ""comfort food
column2: but that's what living with an experimental artist's work will do. In the late 1990s and early 2000s
column3: the Austrian avant-guitarist and corrupted software whiz trafficked in the harsh and unpredictable ""glitch"" sound of his benefactors at the Mego label. But as he began to play openly with the surf's-up sound of 60s pop on 2001's Endless Summer
column4: listeners not usually into grating improvised noise began to find a way into Fennesz's world. He became one of the 21st century's more improbable crossover figures
column5: and one of its most inventive advocates for bringing the guitar into a brave new laptop world.

column1: Fennesz's music hasn't shied away from darker places since
column2: but his love of twisted beauty allows people a chance to become familiar with
column3: even soothed by
column4: a sound that seems decidedly not-for-everyone on the surface.  A four-track EP
column5: Seven Stars is Fennesz in an almost purely placid mode
column6: not too dissimilar to what he was exploring a decade ago. The least comfortable moments here
column7: like ""July""
column8: aren't all that different from the dark ambient the Aphex Twin was exploring circa SAW II. Even the metallic buzz that rises like the sound of insects on a summer night stays on just the right side of being shrill. Tracks like ""July"" and the cinematic ""Shift"" are about as uncomfortable as music can get while remaining immersive rather than alienating.

column1: The last few years have seen a glut of day-at-the-beach acts using digital tools to capture a sense of summertime fun. Aside from the fact that he arguably got there first with Endless Summer
column2: Fennesz's music is never quite so glib or obvious
column3: attempting to capture the vibe of bands like the Beach Boys without the aid of quotes
column4: hooks
column5: harmonies
column6: or even the stable ground of pop song structure. On ""Liminal"" and the title track
column7: he evokes the heartsick string arrangements of the Pet Sounds era with unnatural swells of computerized sound that nonetheless have a real low-key emotional punch. And while his guitar is both bright and sad
column8: a pure 60s balladeer tone
column9: his playing still follows an improviser's inscrutable logic. Seven Stars is a welcome if not surprising dose of what Fennesz has been doing well for a decade now
column10:
playing on the thin edge between familiar pleasures and the truly out-there.

"|15650.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15650-seven-stars/|7.1|Jess Harvell

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16771/homepage_large.e7fe2609.jpg|Pearls & Embarrassments: 2000-2010|29494.0|Siriusmo|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Monkeytown']|2011-07-19 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:43.782459|"

However you divvy up the spectrum of electronic dance music
column2: Siriusmo is an outlier. A Berlin producer with a penchant for French-sounding electro-house
column3: he infrequently performs live
column4: even though his slick touch on the keyboard is a big part of his appeal. Ambivalent about scenes
column5: he released singles on many different imprints before finally showing
column6: on 2011's Mosaik
column7: that he could work beautifully on a larger canvas.

column1: Issued by similarly genre-averse dance duo Modeselektor on their Monkeytown label
column2: this career-spanning 2xCD compilation finds Siriusmo cleaning out his closet. It turns out that the ratio of pearls to embarrassments is impressively favorable. Many of these 42 tracks are available in digital form for the first time
column3: and eight of them
column4: such as the Vitalic-style grinder ""Hello DJ""
column5: are previously unreleased. Covering the first decade of the 2000s
column6: the set bears ample French-touch traces
column7: often evoking a more musical Mr. Oizo
column8: an earthier Daft Punk
column9: or a much airier Justice. Siriusmo's remixes and compilation appearances for Ed Banger and Kitsuné Maison make this Parisian connection as close as he comes to a scene affiliation.

column1: Still
column2: the hot-blooded
column3: jammy aesthetic here is more like a bundle of personal predilections than a membership application. Siriusmo loves to set scampering funk
column4: meaty saw-wave synths
column5: and hammy vocal samples against percussion so crisply pounding it edges into rock territory. Clean-cut verses and choruses
column6: connected by extended
column7: unlooped instrumental solos
column8: enhance the live feel-- the electric guitar on ""Last Dear""
column9: for instance. Some of the sample choices loaded into Siriusmo's Korg Trident lean toward pop
column10: such as a brief Stevie Wonder/Jackson 5 horn flourish on ""All the Girls"". Others are more obscure: Early electronic pop pioneers Perrey-Kingsley supply the protoplasm for ""Blaue Sonne"".

column1: At nearly two-and-a-half hours
column2: Pearls & Embarrassments is a lot to take in
column3: and the reliability of Siriusmo's craft causes the songs to run together after a while. But that's just the nature of this sort of housecleaning. You really can dip into the compilation at any point and find something appealing. Siriusmo works in essentials: Key in on the effective groove and the stirring harmonic idea
column4: and jettison the rest. In a way
column5: he's a throwback to a time before limitless soft synths gave producers limitless choices. ""Sometimes
column6: he told one interviewer
column7:
""it's good just to have your one synthesizer or one piano and your drum and you can play like you're in a little band.""

"|15648.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15648-pearls-embarrassments-2000-2010/|7.4|Brian Howe

The veneer of mystery around London's Vondelpark has gradually eroded since last December's Sauna EP. The London trio has been stepping out
column3: remixing others and working on collaborations. During an appearance at the Independent Label Market in London a couple of months ago
column4: Lewis Rainsbury cut a slight
column5: red-haired figure
column6: complete with a ""Vondelpark"" badge for identification.

column1: Capitalization quirks aside
column2: nyc stuff and nyc bags is mostly a clearer vision
column3: too. Sauna's smeared sonics have given way to something more refined. On ""TV""
column4: Vondelpark even pushes the vocal more to the center
column5: though it's still bathed in warmly romantic production. With synth strings and a vocal that has a bit of R&B drama
column6: ""Camels"" is similarly sensual
column7: as guitar chords stab at the fringes of languid bass and a clipped garage sample. Vondelpark's production still feels happily self-contained
column8: but the smaller details-- thin bongo rhythms
column9: a jagged sample hit in the right channel-- help make for a more focused track.

column1: Where Sauna put elements of UK garage and bass music in a bedroom setting
column2: nyc stuff and nyc bags is a more confident
column3: summer-drenched listen. Take ""Feat B""
column4: for instance: a Balearic-leaning cut complete with dubby horns
column5: bongos
column6: and a blissed-out female vocal. Anyone missing Air France could do worse than find comfort food here. While this second effort shows no great leap forward in terms of quality
column7: it only underscores that Vondelpark are one of the more interesting UK production groups to emerge lately
column8:
mysterious or not.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16760/homepage_large.4a0b9dd1.jpg|Staring Into the Sun|29804.0|Olivia Wyatt|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sublime Frequencies']|2011-07-19 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:44.836613|"

In 2009
column2: filmmaker/photographer Olivia Wyatt traveled to Ethiopia to document a music and dance event called the Festival of 1000 Stars. Things didn't quite go according to plan. On her arrival in the country
column3: Wyatt discovered the Ethiopian government had canceled the event. So Wyatt instead headed out to visit 13 tribes
column4: whose performances Staring Into the Sun documents in a DVD
column5: a CD
column6: notes
column7: and photographs. It's an extraordinarily careful
column8: comprehensive package
column9: featuring stories about close calls with authorities
column10: comments on the distinctive qualities of each tribe
column11: and details about the various instruments used in the recordings.

column1: The hour-long DVD is the best way most of us will have to witness the music of the people Wyatt visited. With visuals as hypnotic as the performances
column2: she deftly illustrates how music seeps into many different parts of life. The opening scene is one of the most spectacular
column3: showing members of the Borana tribe in southern Ethiopia chanting a cyclical polyphonic song as they pass up buckets of water from a multi-level well; Wyatt's shots skillfully match the repetitive nature of this backbreaking work. Scenes of spiritual possession and ceremonial whipping further demonstrate music's role in ritual practices. The sheer breadth of styles in the film also extends to more commercial fare-- often featuring keyboards and synthesized drums-- shot directly from TV sets. One clip even features a band decked out in military garb and posing with guns. That stands in stark contrast to the the scenes of the Tsemay tribe
column4: where kids and adults bounce around in a circle to an uplifting song. The big highlight here is the discordant synchronized panpipe playing of the Dirashe tribe in the Great Rift Valley; the music feels like it could career out of control at any moment
column5: but it never does.

column1: The accompanying CD is less essential than the film
column2: though it just about works as a standalone item. Listing no artists or tracks
column3: the disc is simply a collection of recordings Wyatt made. Some of them feature the trilling female vocals that are a staple of the region; others are built around an open-ended structure of loosely handclapped rhythms. The masterfully off-kilter panpipe players of the Dirashe tribe resurface in a nearly eight-minute excerpt of a piece that presumably stretched on far longer. The disc's common thread comes through its ceaselessly looping vocal chants
column4:
which are mesmerizingly easy to get lost in-- just as the performers themselves may have done to reach such a trance-inducing state. Staring Into the Sun shows how that kind of loosening is simply one of many purposes music can have for a group of people.

"|15636.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15636-staring-into-the-sun/|7.2|Nick Neyland

'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2011-07-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:45.473547|"

Nothing is sacred to the Men. For one
column3: this Brooklyn quartet's name is pretty much identical to that of fellow New Yorker JD Samson's active post-Le Tigre project
column4: MEN. Their 2010 sophomore release
column5: Immaculada
column6: featured a caterwauling noise-punk thrasher called ""Oh Yoko"" that had absolutely nothing to do with the classic John Lennon song
column7: or Ms. Ono herself
column8: for that matter. Their new album swipes its title from a legendary record by New York's most famous punk band
column9: the Ramones. And part way through the obliquely titled mid-album track ""( )""
column10: when the band realize they're ripping off the fuzz-bomb riff to Spacemen 3's ""Revolution""
column11: they just go ahead and swipe a line from the song too
column12: and cap it with another quote from Spacemen's ""Take Me to the Other Side"" for good measure. And yet: For all the cheeky references and inside jokes at play on the Men's Leave Home
column13: you'd be hard-pressed to find a purer
column14: no-bullshit
column15: serious-as-a-heart-attack rock record released this year.

column1: Listening to Leave Home feels a lot like living inside of Michael Azerrad's 1980s indie-rock tome Our Band Could Be Your Life
column2: variously bringing to mind Sonic Youth and Dinosaur Jr.'s SST stints
column3: Sub Pop-vintage Mudhoney
column4: and Touch and Go-era Butthole Surfers (who surely would approve of a song title like ""Shittin' With the Shah""). Tellingly
column5: Azerrad's book ties up its narratives the moment its subjects signed to majors-- partly because
column6: technically speaking
column7: they ceased to be indie rock at that point but
column8: more importantly
column9: because those artists produced their most enduring
column10: groundbreaking music while recording for independent labels. Leave Home is likewise a frozen tableau of that tipping point
column11: imagining a parallel universe in which your favorite first-wave indie-rock bands never had to sign on corporate letterhead
column12: never got anywhere near MTV
column13: never toned down their act
column14: and never got old-- they just kept on blowing minds at the peak of their powers in perpetuity.

column1: Where the discographies of those aforementioned influences can more or less be plotted on a straight line from chaos to control
column2: the Men's modest catalogue thus far presents no such linear evolutionary trajectory. Immaculada may have introduced folky acoustic guitar passages and extended doom-metal instrumentals to their post-hardcore attack
column3: but rather than continue to explore those stylistic detours
column4: Leave Home sees the Men return to the full-torque distorto-rock of their 2009 debut EP
column5: but blow it up on a grander scale with a more intense batch of songs. And rather than try to upgrade the fidelity to accommodate the more epic execution
column6: the unapologetic corrosiveness of the sound is ultimately what gives it its power and heft.

column1: So that means Leave Home's boldest gesture-- the seven-minute opener ""If You Leave...""-- is also its least typical
column2: not just for its tsunami-sized shoegaze haze
column3: but for its open-hearted candor
column4: as its lone
column5: repeated lyric (""I would die"") provides a surprisingly affecting answer to the title's open-ended suggestion. The song is every bit as surprising coming from these guys as the similarly miasmic ""Farewell"" was on Boris' 2006 album Pink
column6: showcasing the respective bands' abilities to be as blissful as they are bludgeoning. But where ""Farewell"" anticipated the Japanese doom demigods' eventual drift toward melodic accessibility
column7: ""If You Leave..."" is a calm-before-the-storm misdirection. By the time Leave Home's side one winds down with the grueling
column8: hoarse-throat howls and torturous
column9: slow-motion squall of ""L.A.D.O.C.H.""
column10: you'll be wondering if you're still listening to the same band.

column1: But on Leave Home's second half
column2: the Men's dual affinities for brute punk-rock force and bad-trip psychedelia fuse together to brilliant effect
column3: with a searing series of songs that refuse to relent even as they encroach on the five-minute mark-- in particular
column4: the storming ""Bataille"" suggests Sonic Youth's ""Hey Joni"" as recorded by Funhouse-era Stooges
column5: while the closing ""Night Landing"" effectively blurs the line between krautrock and punk in fine Neu! '75-style. Of course
column6: with a name like the Men-- and reference points like these-- it's all too fitting that this album will undoubtedly appeal to a certain subset of record-collecting dudes. But the Men's treatment of their well-curated influences is less akin to that of fan-boys playing in a tribute act and a lot more like an irreverent hip-hop producer's approach to breaks-- key in on your sources' coolest moments
column7: change the context
column8:
and ride that perfect sound forever.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16757/homepage_large.cbc9180a.jpg|Thee Physical|9778.0|Pictureplane|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Lovepump United']|2011-07-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:46.185849|"

The hands-across-the-void cover art that accompanies the proper sophomore effort from blasted-electro producer and Denver scene magnate Travis Egedy's Pictureplane project
column2: Thee Physical
column3: brings to mind a few things: fictional Spinal Tap album Smell the Glove
column4: the ""kid who found the severed hand"" statue in ""Arrested Development""
column5: and Magic Eye artwork with all the eye-straining already in place. In reality
column6: the image ties into the album's loose themes of human touch and technological eroticism. This dorm-room theorizing also shows up in selected song titles: ""Trancegender""
column7: ""Post Physical""
column8: ""Body Mod"".

column1: Listeners who approach Thee Physical probably aren't showing up for Egedy's flimsy personal-political philosophizing
column2: though. They're here for his frayed
column3: ear-bleeding take on 1990s diva-house and electro-- disembodied leather hands be damned. Pictureplane's 2009 label debut
column4: Dark Rift
column5: was a statement of purpose
column6: packed with both thrilling moments (""Goth Star"") and drifting provocation (nine-minute closer ""True Ruin""). On Thee Physical
column7: the approach is considerably more refined
column8: with HEALTH's Jupiter Keyes helping lend a new
column9: immediate sonic appeal. Keyes knows a thing or two about tempering industrial-tinged aggression with sugared sensuality (see last year's HEALTH single ""USA Girls"")
column10: and on Thee Physical that balance is more present than it's ever been in his main gig.

column1: Further contributing to the album's accessibility is Egedy's move from staticky speaker-pounders toward honest-to-god pop songs. Early album offerings ""Real Is a Feeling"" and ""Post Physical"" ably showcase his steps toward electro approachability; other songs feature Egedy engaging as an in-the-flesh sideman to the snippets of throaty vocal samples strewn throughout. This man-machine relationship was prominent on Dark Rift
column2: too; Thee Physical does it better. What's more
column3: Egedy's inherently thin voice sounds stronger in its surroundings here.

column1: And yet
column2: for all the improvements
column3: there are times when Egedy's handmade beats seem slightly out of rhythm with everything else that's going on around them (an issue that's especially apparent on ""Black Nails""). And when the album's most vibrant hook shows up
column4: on ""Trancegender""
column5: it's quickly buried in favor of the murky atmospherics that jam up the album's second half. Thee Physical wants to mosh in the punk club as much as it wants to throw on some lip gloss and hit the town
column6:
and it's frustratingly enticing to imagine how the record would have turned out if Egedy had leaned on the gas towards the latter option.

"|15635.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15635-thee-physical/|7.0|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16765/homepage_large.13f4b44c.jpg|Night Dolls With Hairspray|28709.0|James Ferraro|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Olde English Spelling Bee']|2011-07-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:47.035736|"

Two years ago
column2: David Keenan of The Wire coined the name ""hypnagogic pop"" for a strain of lo-fi
column3: 1980s-centric psychedelia
column4: or ""pop music refracted through the memory of a memory."" Though Ariel Pink's AM-radio concoctions made him a godfather
column5: Keenan placed James Ferraro-- previously known as part of the noise duo Skaters-- at the center of this ""movement."" In Keenan's article
column6: Ferraro's first quote went like this: ""I've always viewed my music as just sort of plugging into a matrix of human-alien culture
column7: through plugging into a world broadcast of media entities that jump out of the screen and merge with life via people internalizing them as soundtracks for life temples.""

column1: Ferraro's music can be as confusing as that rambling proclamation. Yet there's a weird
column2: hermetic kind of logic to both. Whatever a ""life temple"" might be
column3: you can imagine it when you hear his mysterious
column4: hyper-referential sound. He relies on samples
column5: loops
column6: and the textures and aura of 80s pop-- the kind heard on worn-out VHS tapes and glitchy video games. And he turns cheesy clichés-- preset keyboard melodies
column7: phasey riffs
column8: falsetto choruses-- into something hypnotic and almost cyber-spiritual
column9: like a photocopy blurred by generations of reproduction until it becomes a Magic Eye painting.

column1: Often
column2: this approach can produce remarkably catchy music. Night Dolls with Hairspray in particular is filled with hooky gems. Its plunging bass lines
column3: warped guitar riffs
column4: and crooning vocals bounce around the stereo space like lasers in a hall of mirrors. Listening feels like peeking into the mind of a pop-culture-addled 80s teen-- an effect enhanced by lyrics about adolescent concerns sung in a pre-pubescent whine. Hissy
column5: muffled
column6: and oddly funny
column7: Night Dolls can get pretty dizzying. Some might even find its sheen nauseating
column8: much the way audiences left The Blair Witch Project more sick from the shaky camerawork than scared by the plot. But for anyone enchanted by Ariel Pink
column9: there's lots to love in Ferraro's murky pop.

column1: Just don't wait around for him to tone it down. More often
column2: in the massive discography he's built
column3: he turns the queasiness up to 11. In the resulting swamps of noise
column4: ghosts of pop songs
column5: movie soundtracks
column6: TV ads
column7: and other fleeting ephemera stew and rumble
column8: but never quite break through the stubborn surface of his dense mix. That's the mode that Ferraro is in on On Air
column9: first issued as a limited CD-R on Olde English Spelling Bee and recently pressed onto vinyl by Underwater Peoples. Here
column10: he seems to man a black-hole radio station
column11: mixing in surreal announcements and static-laden transitions. Snippets of melody and blasts of noise slam into each other
column12: with single tracks often containing four or five chunks of what could be songs on their own. Maybe Ferraro's own trippy titles explain it best: ""Electrocuted Hair""
column13: ""New Waver From Hawaii Saturn""
column14: ""Virtual Sumo Bubble Gum""
column15: ""Cyber Shock Headtroplolis"". Those could all be the names of Boredoms outtakes
column16: and On Air's arty mess recalls that group as well as Yamantaka Eye's even nuttier Hanatarash.

column1: Much the way that listening to a lot of Boredoms can alter your perception of what music is and how it works
column2: making it through On Air is a bit of a brain-altering experience. By the end of it
column3: you might understand Ferraro's Wire quote a little better
column4: whether or not you can explain why. Plugging in
column5: jumping out
column6: merging with life-- on paper they sound like discarded New Age platitudes
column7: but in the hands of James Ferraro
column8:
those ideas regain the electric charge of epiphany.

"|15643.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15643-nightdolls-with-hairspray-on-air/|7.9|Marc Masters
