column9: like a photocopy blurred by generations of reproduction until it becomes a Magic Eye painting.

column1: Often
column2: this approach can produce remarkably catchy music. Night Dolls with Hairspray in particular is filled with hooky gems. Its plunging bass lines
column3: warped guitar riffs
column4: and crooning vocals bounce around the stereo space like lasers in a hall of mirrors. Listening feels like peeking into the mind of a pop-culture-addled 80s teen-- an effect enhanced by lyrics about adolescent concerns sung in a pre-pubescent whine. Hissy
column5: muffled
column6: and oddly funny
column7: Night Dolls can get pretty dizzying. Some might even find its sheen nauseating
column8: much the way audiences left The Blair Witch Project more sick from the shaky camerawork than scared by the plot. But for anyone enchanted by Ariel Pink
column9: there's lots to love in Ferraro's murky pop.

column1: Just don't wait around for him to tone it down. More often
column2: in the massive discography he's built
column3: he turns the queasiness up to 11. In the resulting swamps of noise
column4: ghosts of pop songs
column5: movie soundtracks
column6: TV ads
column7: and other fleeting ephemera stew and rumble
column8: but never quite break through the stubborn surface of his dense mix. That's the mode that Ferraro is in on On Air
column9: first issued as a limited CD-R on Olde English Spelling Bee and recently pressed onto vinyl by Underwater Peoples. Here
column10: he seems to man a black-hole radio station
column11: mixing in surreal announcements and static-laden transitions. Snippets of melody and blasts of noise slam into each other
column12: with single tracks often containing four or five chunks of what could be songs on their own. Maybe Ferraro's own trippy titles explain it best: ""Electrocuted Hair""
column13: ""New Waver From Hawaii Saturn""
column14: ""Virtual Sumo Bubble Gum""
column15: ""Cyber Shock Headtroplolis"". Those could all be the names of Boredoms outtakes
column16: and On Air's arty mess recalls that group as well as Yamantaka Eye's even nuttier Hanatarash.

column1: Much the way that listening to a lot of Boredoms can alter your perception of what music is and how it works
column2: making it through On Air is a bit of a brain-altering experience. By the end of it
column3: you might understand Ferraro's Wire quote a little better
column4: whether or not you can explain why. Plugging in
column5: jumping out
column6: merging with life-- on paper they sound like discarded New Age platitudes
column7: but in the hands of James Ferraro
column8:
those ideas regain the electric charge of epiphany.

"|15643.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15643-nightdolls-with-hairspray-on-air/|7.5|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16769/homepage_large.928fda6d.jpg|Hello Cruel World|5557.0|Sole and the Skyrider Band|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fake Four']|2011-07-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:47.781275|"

Back in the early half of the last decade
column2: when Anticon was more of an abstract-rap collective and less of an experimental indie pop label
column3: Sole was arguably the crew's most intriguing figure-- a self-lacerating prophet figure who jumbled the personal and the political into a blur of half-formed conceptual syllable-spray. He rapped so fast that you actually needed the lyric sheet he'd helpfully include in his albums
column4: and those lyrics would be so dense and jangled that you'd also need the little mini-essays he'd pen about each song and its inspirations. Self-seriousness was his thing
column5: and it could sometimes be a weakness; it's a big part of the reason he came out on the losing end of a terrifically entertaining beef with El-P (El: ""I feel like Selena
column6: the president of my fan club trying to kill me""). But that intensity also turned him into a compelling figure. ""The white man's the fucking devil
column7: he almost-famously roared in 2003. And yes
column8: he's white. Obviously.

column1: But the twisty
column2: blown-out form of indie rap that helped birth Sole (and El-P
column3: and everyone else in that scene at that time) has largely disappeared from the map
column4: sending an entire generation of underground rappers scrambling to figure out ways to remain relevant. On his new Hello Cruel World
column5: Sole tries harder than most. As he has on most of his recent releases
column6: Sole teams up with Arizona's multi-instrumentalist trio the Skyrider Band. But together
column7: they chase a different sound this time out: the sort of diffuse synthetic soul that's slowly taking over the rap mainstream. The beats on Hello Cruel World are full of simple
column8: understated new-wave melodies and empty space. Sole has largely curbed his frantic
column9: out-of-control
column10: sometimes-arrhythmic rap style
column11: going for a measured and controlled thing instead. There are song where Sole sings. There are songs were Sole sings through Auto-Tune. At times
column12: he sounds like a dreadlocked
column13: anarchist-bookstore version of Drake. It's a truly odd album-- and in its own way
column14: it's a brave one.

column1: ""Bad Captain Swag"" is the best song here
column2: and the one that best encapsulates the sound Sole chases all throughout the album. I'm not even really sure what ""Bad Captain Swag"" is about-- credit card debt or something. But with its truly unexpected Lil B guest verse
column3: the song works as a summit meeting between two very different generations of indie rap
column4: and it shows that the two rappers may have as much uniting them as they do separating them. These are two messy artists
column5: and both verses have their goofy moments. The Based God is in his spaced-out
column6: the-world-is-crazy mode. Sole
column7: meanwhile
column8: offers up this as a boast: ""You don't wanna battle me; you're better off enlisting in the upcoming war against China."" (He also becomes maybe the first rapper to ever use the word ""stagflation"" in a rhyme.) And yet there's a sort of outsider-art chemistry at work here
column9: with the weirdly catchy zoned-out synth track and the airily crooned hook from Denver electro-noise producer Pictureplane. It's nuts-- and not in a bad way-- that Sole and Soulja Boy are now just one degree removed from each other.

column1: Nothing else on the album touches that track
column2: but it's intriguing to hear Sole push his old style in different directions. Hello Cruel World is an album that flirts with accessibility
column3: but you're not exactly going to crash radio playlists with lines like this bit of anti-Red Cross invective
column4: from ""We Will Not Be Moved"": ""Want me to donate? We gave helicopters to Israel
column5: free health care to the Middle East. Now who's gonna fix my teeth?"" And things get downright silly when he leaves behind politics entirely and indulges in dorm-room philosophizing: ""Someday I'll leave this place
column6: be it by bullet or by rocket/ And they can use my corpse to fertilize another planet"" (from the title track). But nobody's ever going to this guy for clear
column7: concrete ideas; abstract obfuscation is what he does. On Hello Cruel World
column8: he finds some new ways to do it. They don't work out as often as we might hope
column9:
but at least he's trying.

"|15647.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15647-hello-cruel-world/|6.1|Tom Breihan

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16753/homepage_large.20a86518.jpg|Mindreading|5737.0|Singer|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2011-07-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:49.224161|"

It's best not to go looking for an explanation as to why Singer have taken so long to follow their 2008 debut
column2: Unhistories. Or what the impenetrable front and back covers mean
column3: or why the song titles appear only on a loose sheet of paper tucked inside the album sleeve. The liner notes indicate the Chicago art-rockers recorded Mindreading in April 2009
column4: with mixing later that year by Randall Dunn-- a producer for heavy-music heavyweights Sunn O))) and Earth. Meanwhile
column5: with former U.S. Maple guitarist Todd Rittman leaving to focus on his Dead Rider project
column6: Singer have slimmed down to a three-piece: ex-U.S. Maple drummer Adam Vida; his brother
column7: Ben; and former 90 Day Men bassist Robert A.A. Lowe (who also records solo as Lichens). Beyond that
column8: their new album's as mysterious as Lowe's brief collaboration with TV on the Radio.

column1: The air of inscrutability surrounding this band helps align Mindreading with some pre-internet Drag City releases. It's reminiscent of something you'd stumble across in the racks of a record store and take a chance on
column2: perhaps because of the label or a familiar name credited on the back sleeve. Even the enigmatic covert art might be enough. The musical offerings inside continue that theme; it's never really clear who's singing
column3: what the words are
column4: or which instruments were used. The sighing falsettos that rise and fall against stuttery percussion and chunky analog keyboard runs on opener ""Sister's Mane"" will be familiar to anyone who remembers Unhistories
column5: but there the similarities mostly end. Guitars are on the backburner for much of this recording
column6: with condensed synth tones pushed firmly to the fore.

column1: ""Voices from the Tapes"" flicks back and forth between a serene central groove and great piles of ugly electronics. On the following ""Wi(s)tches""
column2: the group's vocals battle with analog sounds that reach a piercing screech as the song dawdles to a close. There are germs of good ideas here: For instance
column3: the woozy
column4: multi-layered singing in ""Dial ""M"" for Mother"" edges close to the kind of work Doseone occasionally hits on in Subtle. Too often
column5: though
column6: Singer are on a journey with no particular destination in mind
column7: especially when they lurch from the ugly liquid funk of ""Gabbing"" into the unfocused crooning of closer ""Bitter'd Moon"". It's a shame
column8: because the track records of everyone involved suggest Mindreading could have been a different proposition. Instead it's all untethered strands of work loosely floating around
column9:
with occasional moments of clarity that might make this a record worth returning to when another three years have passed.

"|15631.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15631-mindreading/|5.8|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16763/homepage_large.cef586f4.jpg|I'm Gay (I'm Happy)|28900.0|Lil B|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['BasedWorld']|2011-07-14 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:49.712197|"

It's possible not even Lil B knows how much music he's released in the past four years. Spend 15 minutes trying to sort out how much he's made in the past four months and you'll feel in your stomach just how deep the Internet goes. More than any other musician
column2: the Bay Area rapper has adapted his creative behavior to resemble the rippling action of your RSS feed-- an unceasing
column3: pellet-dispenser flow of new content.

column1: It's a self-contained musical universe
column2: located at the vanishing point on the ""all-or-nothing"" spectrum
column3: and its cult of faithful has been steadily building to the point where the mainstream rap industry has been forced to contend with him. The result was a hip-hop comedy of manners: as XXL included him on their Freshmen 2011 list alongside industry non-entities like Mac Miller and Lil Twist and Lupe Fiasco publicly congratulated himself for ""getting it
column4: B basically continued whistling his tune
column5: collaborating with Lil Wayne and Jean Grae and Tony Yayo and rapping over How to Dress Well instrumentals. And then he announced at Coachella he was going to name his next album I'm Gay.

column1: With this single statement
column2: Lil B calmly detonated a flower-power land mine in the center of what is arguably rap's most tortured
column3: combustible political arena. Whatever his motivations (it probably had something to do with his philosophy of universal acceptance and self-love
column4: but his manifestos don't survive close analysis)
column5: he guaranteed that the album's audience would be exponentially larger than anything he'd done before.

column1: I'm Gay appeared on iTunes last week
column2: and by convenience or design
column3: it's his most coherent
column4: cohesive
column5: and accessible single release to date. His followers may debate whether Rain in England or 6 Kiss or Illusions of Grandeur or Bitch Mob: Respect Da Bitch is better (Lil B has a flair for titles)
column6: but for the uninitiated
column7: I'm Gay does a great job of articulating his ethos and appeal in the space of one album. If you're intrigued by Lil B but shrink from the commitment of keeping pace with a human data stream
column8: it might be the only record you'll ever need.

column1: That's not to say that I'm Gay contains all of Lil B's personae. The album finds him securely in his dazed
column2: child-like observer mode
column3: where he peers at the world as if for the first time and wonders aloud. He has many other faces-- occasional boom-bap traditionalist
column4: tweaker of boom-bap traditionalism
column5: uncomfortably personal YouTube diarist-- but this side is easily B's most relatable and endearing. The production
column6: by frequent collaborators Clams Casino
column7: 9th Wonder
column8: and others
column9: reinforces the mood of naive reverie: ""Gon Be Okay"" samples an orchestral flourish from the soundtrack to Hayao Miyazaki's Spirited Away
column10: while ""Unchain Me"" is built on a loop of ""Cry Little Sister"" from The Lost Boys soundtrack. ""I Hate Myself"" is a woozy
column11: pitched-down loop of Goo Goo Doll's ""Iris"" in which the drums hit like down pillows. You're unlikely to find a more guileless or gentle hip-hop record this year.

column1: Lil B's stream-of-consciousness lyrical approach remains uniquely suited to this sort of cosmic contemplation. Composing your thoughts on the fly has obvious downsides
column2: and Lil B's YouTube channel is littered with examples of times he hit ""record"" and the muse failed to follow. But here
column3: he's consistently focused and has a knack for articulating universal sentiments in seemingly artless wording: I can't think of anyone else who could say things like
column4: ""The people die for a piece of paper
column5: it's so stupid"" or ""If God's real
column6: then why'd my friend have to die?"" or ""Don't wanna go to school because the teacher's too simple/ I just wanna know where I come from
column7: just tell me
column8: and prompt contemplation instead of laughs.

column1: But then
column2: reproducing lines like these in print doesn't do them justice. Lil B's music draws on spontaneity as its wellspring; you hear him stumble
column3: pause for breath
column4: abandon a line of thought and start over. So when he happens across a searing image like ""Mental slavery/ Niggas hangin off trees in the woods
column5: and roams his way to ""I'm nicer than Grandma with a cup of iced tea"" a few lines later
column6: there's a charge of discovery in the air-- the conviction that you're hearing music and expression being born raw.

column1: ""I'm ready to give up/My old thoughts...Everything I seen was a lie/I'm not ready to die/I love myself"" he declares on ""I Hate Myself
column2: a vague but powerful manifesto that suggests why Lil B has inspired such fervent devotion. He projects fearlessness
column3: which can take many forms: it can mean deciding to name your rap album ""I'm Gay"" out of thin air. (The subtitled ""I'm Happy"" was a deflating backward step
column4: it's true
column5: but it was hard to get riled considering how little motivation he had to choose the name I'm Gay in the first place). It can also mean posting the album for free to your quarter-million Twitter followers hours after it was made available for purchase. It can mean sharing every half-baked scrap and warty throwaway you record
column6: trusting your fans to decide what's worth keeping. So while I'm Gay isn't a definitive statement
column7: it is an especially compelling point on a bizarre trajectory
column8:
one that feels worth keeping around.

"|15641.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15641-im-gay-im-happy/|8.1|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16764/homepage_large.840e1ae3.jpg|Red Hot + Rio 2|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['E1']|2011-07-14 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:50.165108|"

The Red Hot Organization was founded in 1989 with a noble if idiosyncratic mission: to fight AIDS through pop culture. At the time
column2: the general public was just beginning to understand what AIDS actually was and how it could be transmitted. Red Hot's decision to raise money for AIDS research by selling themed albums featuring prominent musicians helped raise awareness as well as funds
column3: and its first compilation
column4: 1990's Red Hot + Blue
column5: featuring David Byrne and Tom Waits
column6: among others
column7: covering Cole Porter songs
column8: sold more than a million copies and made millions of dollars for AIDS-focused non-profits.

column1: Twenty-one years later
column2: Red Hot + Rio 2 is the 12th Red Hot title
column3: and the organization has released nine other compilations (including No Alternative and Dark Was the Night). The math is a little different these days. Not as many people buy CDs
column4: and the idea of selling a million of these seems almost quaint (2009's Dark Was the Night still managed to raise more than a million dollars
column5: though). AIDS awareness is also in a very different place-- in an odd way
column6: people in the United States seem to have almost forgotten how bad the pandemic really is
column7: and how crushing it is in a lot of societies
column8: especially in Sub-Saharan Africa. AIDS has become something that's just there
column9: in the background
column10: and we may know a few people who have it
column11: but the aura of public health crisis has fallen away from it in our media. So in that way
column12: building awareness is just as important as ever.

column1: Red Hot + Rio 2 is a follow-up to the 1996 Red Hot + Rio installment
column2: which was focused on an update of 60s bossa nova sounds. This moves on to a contemporary take on Tropicália
column3: and the list of collaborators involved includes a few original Tropicálistas: Rita Lee (solo)
column4: Os Mutantes (with of Montreal)
column5: Tom Zé (with Javelin)
column6: and Caetano Veloso (solo and with David Byrne). It also features Beck and Brazilian singer Seu Jorge doing a version of the former's own ""Tropicália""
column7: and a mix of other artists doing covers of original Tropicália songs and new tunes written in descended styles. These artists
column8: working alone and together in various combinations
column9: come from at least four continents
column10: and you'll hear Brazilians singing in English
column11: Americans singing in Portuguese
column12: and all sorts of other oddities. Sonically
column13: this is aimed in a strange place
column14: somewhere near the middle of the road
column15: but not quite there-- it edges into too-smooth territory on the John Legend and Twin Danger tracks
column16: but also into funky surrealism on the Os Mutantes/Of Montreal update of ""Bat Macumba"" and into heady jazz on Madlib's collaboration with veteran Brazilian singer Joyce Moreno.

column1: Some of the best tracks either feature Tropicálistas or their songs. Gilberto Gil's classic ""Aquele Abraço"" gets a propulsive
column2: percussion-heavy funk reworking courtesy of Forró in the Dark
column3: Brazilian Girls and Beninese singer Angélique Kidjo. David Byrne and Caetano Veloso sound great dueting on ""Dreamworld/Marco De Canaveses""
column4: backed by spooky synths and strings. Veloso's simple ""Terra"" also sounds good getting picked apart by Prefuse 73 and remade as it plays from a spare acoustic song into a gently dissonant orchestral work.

column2: the mainstream benefit LP no doubt plays a delicate balancing act
column3: trying to be interesting enough musically to connect with adventurous listeners
column4: but broadly appealing enough not to drive off more casual listeners who want to contribute to a good cause while buying one of the very few CDs they'll purchase all year. There's a sweet spot in between that Red Hot + Rio 2 comes close to hitting over the course of its two discs. Some of it will be a little too out-there for some people
column5: and some of it will be a little too harmless for others. But overall
column6: it's an interesting assemblage of artists
column7: and the music is good
column8:
covering just enough ground that you can feel the variety but no one's likely to be overwhelmed.

"|15642.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15642-red-hot-rio-2/|7.2|Joe Tangari

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16759/homepage_large.fe8c2f14.jpg|Nupping|29803.0|Dope Body|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['HOSS']|2011-07-14 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:50.757766|"

Dope Body are one of the only underground bands in existence brave enough to claim Rage Against the Machine as a formative influence. The Baltimore-based noise-punk quartet embraces the signature sounds of the alternative nation
column2: but uses pedals
column3: loops
column4: and off-kilter rhythms to pummel its teenage heroes into blurry abstraction. Borrowing from punk-funk and nu-metal as much as spazz-core and pigfuck
column5: the group plays Dr. Moreau with a decade's worth of MTV buzz clips. It's telling that Dope Body's debut album
column6: Nupping
column7: has a song called ""The Shape of Grunge to Come.""

column1: Bro-rock and Boredoms mash up better than you might think. Live
column2: Dope Body are a mosh-worthy mess of sweat and blast beats. Frontman Andrew Laumann alternates between punker grunts and animalistic yelps
column3: his shirt rarely staying on his chest for an entire performance
column4: while guitarist Zach Utz makes hairpin turns between stoner chugging and modem noise. Nupping does an admirable job of capturing the band's spastic onstage energy.

column1: Album opener ""Enemy Outta Me"" wiggles to life with the band playing around an off-time loop
column2: but it quickly makes a left turn into scorching riff-rock. Utz pulls double duty
column3: answering each of his chugging stoner riffs with a bevy of electronic gurgles. When it's time for the big guitar solo
column4: he instead opts for some balloon-on-hair squelches. ""Bangers & Yos"" pogos around on a rubber-band riff that's just far enough removed from ""Bulls on Parade"" that Rage's lawyers won't have grounds to sue.

column1: Like Philly sludge-punkers Pissed Jeans
column2: Dope Body have a special gift for draining the air from muscle-head music. Pissed Jeans do this mainly through lyrics
column3: imbuing early 80s hardcore with a narrative of manly anguish. Dope Body pull at the sounds of dude-rock like taffy-- tugging guitars out of key
column4: building up big walls of heavy rhythm only to belch in the face of fist-pumping catharsis. Utz's expansive pedal board and glitchy deconstruction of Tom Morello riffs may hint at arty pretensions
column5:
but Dope Body still smell punk.

"|15637.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15637-nupping/|7.8|Aaron Leitko

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16756/homepage_large.9c07051a.jpg|Dorus Rijkers EP|29625.0|Ratcliffe|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Atlantic Jaxx']|2011-07-14 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:51.333189|"

Basement Jaxx's Simon Ratcliffe and Felix Burton have long used Atlantic Jaxx to release material that's too club-focused
column2: instrumental
column3: or experimental to fit onto their radio-leaning albums. As official Basement Jaxx releases have grown slicker in their attempts at perfect pop pastiche
column4: the side projects and outtakes issued on the duo's label have come to seem even wilder. With no guest singers and zero hooks
column5: Ratcliffe's new solo EP is another chance for these one-time house barbarians to remind people why their unconventional spirit once made dance classicists turn up their noses.

column1: Dorus Rijkers unleashes live-sounding rhythms that twist
column2: turn
column3: and feel like they don't want to do what their producer tells them to do. Opener ""Tightrope"" sounds like Ratcliffe tried to lay down a fat
column4: funky
column5: straightforward breakbeat
column6: but then his cheekiness got the better of him
column7: with the boom-bap quickly mutating into a loony jazz-metal hybrid. On much of the EP
column8: the squealing synths and ultra-bright electro riffs aren't too far off from the kind of arcade-game mania and tortured g-funk beloved by Zomby
column9: Rustie
column10: and their peers. In fact
column11: the frenetic
column12: densely layered ""Mindset"" makes the post-dubstep crew sound almost staid
column13: while its fried fuzz-bass and general noisy mayhem shame the Ed Banger crew and similarly brutal French house producers.

column1: The second half of the EP is calmer
column2: but just as surprising. ""Flying by the Sun"" essentially applies the methodology of disco edits to an old electric jazz record
column3: compressing a half-hour of free-flowing improvisation into a deranged four-and-a-half-minute jukebox single. But even in shortened form
column4: this kind of knotty jazz-funk isn't for everyone. Neither is Dorus Rijkers as a whole
column5: even at just four tracks
column6: which is probably the perfect length to avoid burning out on music this dense and convoluted. If you think that Basement Jaxx have been too buttoned up lately
column7: then you'll probably appreciate the way Dorus Rijkers sounds like a man unleashing a lot of fuck-you intensity. Throw it on looking for the glossy roller-boogie bounce or Euro-pop sheen of Crazy Itch Radio or Scars
column8: though
column9:
and the drums alone will slap the expectations right out of you.

"|15634.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15634-dorus-rijkers-ep/|7.0|Jess Harvell

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16767/homepage_large.b75849c8.jpg|Wayward Fire|29770.0|The Chain Gang of 1974|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Modern Art']|2011-07-14 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:26:51.909109|"

The Chain Gang of 1974 is the kind of band name that is so obviously apropos of nothing that it pretty much begs to be met head-on. So let's just get some painfully obvious housekeeping out of the way: Kamtin Mohager's glossy synth-pop project sounds absolutely nothing like a chain gang and even less like 1974. Instead
column2: the album stresses familiarity
column3: easy nostalgia
column4: and an eagerness to please
column5: laying down its dividing lines like the ""80s Night"" at your local undergrad bar: If you can somehow find novelty in that sort of thing in 2011
column6: you'll have yourself a blast
column7: whereas anyone who thinks the decade had more to offer than doing tequila shots to ""Hungry Like the Wolf"" while Pretty in Pink plays in closed captioning are gonna feel like killjoys through no real fault of their own.

column1: I'll give Mohager this: The dude knows how to write a hook. The arc of the melodies
column2: the word choice
column3: the decision of when to crank the reverb and when to lay off-- all are indicative of someone who's broken down the hits of his childhood into formulae
column4: their moving parts charted and graphed. Nearly every track on Wayward Fire makes some sort of ascendant grab at a brass ring
column5: and displaying a skill that's often underrated
column6: Mohager can string together fairly basic rhymes in a way that gives just enough meaning. And he can lose himself in whatever guise is appropriate to get his point across. ""I get so high when the devil comes to take me/ I get so high when the devil is a lady
column7: is delivered by an agitated disco infiltrator
column8: while a New Romantic on the verge of emotional overload promises
column9: ""I will run
column10: I will fly
column11: I will see you in a matter of time."" That sort of thing.

column1: Problem is
column2: there's a lot of Wayward Fire that takes place between those choruses. More to the point
column3: there's a lot of Wayward Fire period: at nearly an hour long
column4: it surpasses audacity into the realm of pure self-defeat. There are pleasures to be had here
column5: but every single track could comfortably shave about a minute and a half and still deliver them. It's less of an issue when he's courting bedside melodrama as opposed to dancefloor seduction since Mohager sounds more comfortable navigating verse/chorus structure than a vamp. And when he tries dance music
column6: his idle hands mostly get the better of him. Wayward Fire continually misses a sweet spot between being lean and dirty enough to aerodynamically groove and being maximalist to the point where it opts out of that mode completely. And as a result
column7: there's always that one last addition to the mix that sticks in your craw.

column1: I suppose that it's a sign of where we're at
column2: that an LP so steeped in 80s signifiers feels so completely... normal. But while certainly dedicated to its source material
column3: Mohager's lack of commitment to any sonic or lyrical identity unintentionally confirms the old stereotypes that kept this stuff out of indie rock in the first place-- that it can't be made personal and that its ultimate goal is to be fashionable and disposable. Though clearly precocious with melodies
column4: Mohager never presents himself as more than collector
column5:
which is why Wayward Fire ends up less like a living celebration of the past and more like a display case of your favorite synth-pop action figures in their original packaging.

The cover of Lifes Rich Pageant features the handsome forehead and full eyebrows of drummer Bill Berry

column7: writing love songs

column11: the mysterious painted figures and roughly sketched symbols in the liner notes presented the album as something more akin to folk art than folk rock.

column1: In direct conflict with that visual impression
column2: Lifes Rich Pageant was R.E.M.'s most pop-oriented and accessible album up to that point. Recording frequently and touring almost constantly
column3: the band had been nurturing a grassroots audience throughout the early 1980s
column4: and Pageant is a pivotal album in their career

column6: strangely

column8: with songs addressing environmental crises and political malaise. Rather than sounding sanctimonious
column9: however
column10: such dissent energized R.E.M. and injected more pep into Berry's drumbeats
column11: more incisive jangle into Peter Buck's guitar
column12: and more charisma into Michael Stipe's performance. The album barrels along in just over 30 minutes
column13: lending the songs a sense of purpose. This is music that has to be somewhere.

column1: Lifes is celebratory rather than commiserative
column2: with tense tempos fueling heraldic choruses and shout-outs to Woody Guthrie (""Cuyahoga"") and Cole Porter (""Begin the Begin""). Stipe's lyrical dodginess
column3: such a formidable weapon on previous albums

column5: ""Cuyahoga"" mails postcard dispatches from a museum where rivers and plains are artifacts
column6: consigned to diorama and memory rather than reality. ""Fall on Me"" mixes spiritual and consumerist language to deliver a knotted ecological message that takes some unpacking: ""Buy the sky and sell the sky
column7: Stipe sings
column8: then changes the Wall Street phrasing: ""Lift your arms up to the sky. Ask the sky and ask the sky
column9: don't fall on me.""

column1: Maybe that's why the band chose to close with Mike Mills-sung cover of the Clique's ""Superman"". Seemingly out of place on such a serious-minded album and certainly jarring after the Civil War fever dream of ""Swan Swan H""
column2: it's been derided as R.E.M. at their most superfluous. But that's how they must have felt at the time-- like supermen taking on the world's problems and finding they had unknown powers. In that regard
column3: they're aided significantly by producer Don Gehman

column5: who nearly made a muddle of their previous album

column7: he emphasizes the muscle in Berry's beats and the intricate interaction between the rhythm section. No wonder the drummer's on the album cover: Berry's responsible for the furious pace of the album and enables its abrupt detours into salsa and Nuggets pop.

column2: reinforcing the balance between excitement and gravity that illuminates these songs. It also makes the second disc of demos all the more intriguing

column4: then punctuates the end with a sing-songy la-la-la. He tries out a harmonica solo on an early version of ""Bad Day""
column5: then uses the instrument to cover for forgotten lyrics. This is R.E.M. at their most ramshackle
column6: a vibe that makes Dead Letter Office a fan favorite even today.

column1: Lifes is R.E.M.'s first transition album

column5: between underground and mainstream
column6: between rhythm and melody
column7:
between outrage and hope. That in-between quality still sounds invigorating so many years later.

With apologies to Radiohead and My Morning Jacket

column1: Though they'd probably be better off rehashing Bring It On's supplicant roots-rock in the current climate
column2: Whatever's on Your Mind begins with a fumbled acoustic strum
column3: and after exactly three seconds of human touch
column4: you get all the elbow grease
column5: brow sweat
column6: and rock'n'roll heart of a dubstep record. Cut Gomez and they bleed Purell. The title track and ""Our Goodbye"" are Larry Crowne on wax: chipper and conflict-free calls to let go of the burdens of modernity

column8: on ""Equalize""

column1: Of course

column3: lending a deadpan absurdity worthy of Dipset to lyrical jewels like this one: ""Light the match/ Burn me down/ Bite the hand/ Bite the sound/ Where's the good in pushing trains from the rail?/ What's so bad about breaking bread going stale/ You hammer the nail."" Meanwhile
column4: Ben Ottewell manages to be the more distinctive singer of the two with a soul-papa bray that recalls Joe Cocker or Eddie Vedder at their most agitated. When he subjects cliché to endurance trials such as ""Please hold on to your heart of gold/ While you struggle against the cold/ You keep dragging that heavy load/ Just let it go
column5: it's as transfixing as watching a pitcher in the middle of a perfect game.

column1: Most of this stuff comes from the first half of the record
column2: by the way. But it goes on like that
column3: to the point where you could play a dangerous Whatever's on Your Mind drinking game where you take a shot every time Gomez mix metaphors (""a brick wall's falling apart at the seams"") or string together at least two consecutive clichés and render each completely meaningless (""Kill with kindness is what you do/ Flowers in winter bloom""). Seriously
column4:
let's all try to stay safe this summer.

column5: Biosphere's Geir Jenssen made an album inspired by the architecture and potential instability of Japan's nuclear power plants. A month later
column6: a huge earthquake and tsunami caused the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster. It's healthy to be skeptical about such claims to prescience

column8: N-Plants' sleek contours and foreboding atmosphere easily bear out his theme. Having noted the eerie coincidence
column9: we can dispense with it and let the best Biosphere album since 1997's definitive Substrata stand on its own.

column1: Widely regarded as an ambient milestone
column2: Substrata represented a thoughtful dilettante hitting the reset switch. A period of fertile miscellany followed
column3: from the processed Debussy loops of Shenzhou to the long-tone sci-fi marathon Autour de la Lune. Like Substrata
column4: N-Plants is both a consummation and a palate-cleanser. Fully in ambient-house mode
column5: Jenssen fashions together hazy drones
column6: filtered synthesizers
column7: microhouse percussion
column8: and haunting vocal samples over classically plumb lines. Like Kate Simko's 2009 soundtrack for The Atom Smashers
column9: the album can evoke particles of energy swarming through elegant
column10: hulking metal curves. But this one-time archaeology student has never given up his field's patient curiosity and long view
column11: and N-Plants can't be fully constrained by modern context. Ages of ice and stone drift through it
column12: and the Arctic Circle is a looming presence.

column1: Each process on N-Plants
column2: be it a glinting synthesizer motif or a low-scudding bass line
column3: logically catalyzes the next. Where Substrata delved deeper and deeper
column4: N-Plants glides over level
column5: endlessly scrolling surfaces. The tracks don't essentially change. At most
column6: they metastasize
column7: as on ""Sendai-1""
column8: where a synthesizer plays iridescently through an aquatic atmosphere; at minimum
column9: cycles of loops perpetually revolve
column10: as on ""Genkai-1"". Either way
column11: blissful hypnosis ensues. N-Plants is a master craftsman's reaffirmation of a fundamental but lapsed tenet of electronic ambient: You set up a conversation between the machines
column12:
and then you step out of the way.

Kevin ""The Bug"" Martin has been a strong advocate for Jamaican music over the past 20 years in his work as both artist and curator. But it's his adventurousness that makes him so valuable. Beginning with the Macro Dub Infection compilations he put together for Virgin in the 1990s
column2: Martin has been just as interested in the way Jamaican pop has been reinterpreted
column3: mutated
column4: and even perverted by outside influence as he is with tracking its history at home. Martin assembled this year's Invasion of the Mysteron Killer Sounds with Stuart Baker
column5: the head of Soul Jazz
column6: a UK label that is itself a longtime champion of Jamaican sound system culture. The two discs work as a whistle-stop tour of post-digital Jamaican music
column7: but they also highlight the ways dancehall has spread around the globe
column8: twisting itself into almost unrecognizable shapes along the way.

column1: Built largely around instrumentals
column2: Mysteron jumps from Jamaican dons cranking out essentialist beats to U.S. producers like Diplo making tracks for a wired worldwide audience. While the minimalism of some tracks might test the patience of those who aren't already beat freaks
column3: Martin and Baker's selection is a perfect way to learn about the outlandish
column4: shouldn't-be-this-funky things Jamaican producers (and their far-flung acolytes) have been doing to rhythm for almost three decades now. With its delirious beat clonking from one headphone to another
column5: Andre ""Suku"" Gray's ""Sign Rhythm"" sounds both tribal and cybernetic
column6: and you can marvel at the way Gray has made these super-heavy drums dance around the mix. The ""Sign Rhythm"" also has a hook that sounds like a tea kettle's whistle or a broken kazoo
column7: which is a pretty good indicator of how far-out Jamaican producers will go in search of texture. Firehouse Crew's ""No False Hair"" has a sprinkle of familiar Caribbean steel drums
column8: but good luck hearing them fighting their way out of the riot of gabba-grade drums
column9: game-over effects
column10: and (because it wasn't deranged enough) a slide whistle. One of those cuts is from the 00s
column11: the other from the 90s
column12: both unique and at the same time utterly dancehall.

column1: Mysteron is no history lesson
column2: but it should give new-to-ragga listeners a sense of dancehall's evolution
column3: even if they have to puzzle it out through repeat listens. The 80s cuts collected here
column4: from when reggae and dub giants like King Tubby (""Fat Thing"") and Prince Jazzbo (""Great Stone"") went digital after the genre-changing success of Wayne Smith's ""Under Mi Sleng Teng""
column5: still have plenty of reggae's skank; they squeeze as much of the old live-band swing as possible from drum machines and synthetic bass. By the 90s
column6: beats like Fat Eyes' ""Steel Plate"" and Steely & Clevie's ""Streetsweeper"" had become strange and strident
column7: full of ominous negative space. By the 21st century
column8: Jamaican producers were searching even further afield for fresh sounds
column9: whether the agitated double-dutch clapping of Lenky's ""Diwali"" or island acid house of South Rakkas Crew's ""Red Alert"". Mysteron tends toward the tense and fierce
column10: but there's room for chill beauty
column11: too. Kickin Productions' placid but driving ""What You Gonna Do""
column12: for instance
column13:
is a merger of old-school reggae and new-school rhythm programming that looks both backward and forward while being totally captivating. Which is a pretty good way to describe Mysteron as a whole.

Zomby's early records weren't always aggressive

column1: His first proper album

column4: hardcore rave. The album sounded far more fine-tuned-- and far less cheap-- than most of the hardcore tunes it paid homage to. But it also suggested Zomby wanted nothing to do with the kind of listener who throws on an electronic album as unobtrusive background noise. If his not-quite-dubstep peer Lone brings the pacific and beatific side of early rave into modern UK beat culture

column5: and least dance-friendly record he's released yet. It's hard to say to whom Dedication is aimed-- certainly not hardcore dubstep fanatics-- and that's part of its perverse charm

column8: its choppy transitions and abrupt shifts in mood means it doesn't always flow the way we expect of albums or even home-listening DJ sets. In a way it reminds me of the same hermetic and stuck-between-worlds sound Boards of Canada were mining circa Geogaddi

column10: the kind made by a studio loner stringing together little oddities. So maybe call it Zomby's private reels made public

column12: something to marvel over if never quite immerse yourself in.

let alone all of them.

column3: Slumberland re-established themselves as the label destination for indie-pop bands fusing together clanging distortion and bright

column1: Here
column2: the breathy vocals aren't buried in the mix so much as lightly blanketed
column3: and the thin singing is naturally overpowered by the clang of the instruments instead of one vocal track being dominated by seven layers of recorded guitars. Opener ""Hey Dan"" sets the pace for an album that is more diaphanous than its predecessor

column5: fried guitars

column7: summery chord progressions into an autumnal haze

column1: Ultimately

column3: regardless of exploring a different sound. A lot of the songs are so similar to the ear that it's hard to differentiate most of them between each other; confusing ""How Much Younger"" and ""Hitting Traffic"" is a particularly easy feat. The album's clear highlight is ""Back to the Tricks""

column1: In the context of Slumberland

column3: neither as capital-P Pop as the former nor as brazenly psychedelic as the latter. While they're still a talented band

you can't help but wonder how much more memorable they'd be if they applied as broad a sense of dynamics to their albums as their labelmates.

John Maus first gained notice while collaborating and playing with fellow Cal Arts classmate Ariel Pink more than 10 years ago. Though both have since developed cultish followings by releasing distinctive takes on murky lo-fi
column3: Maus has steeped his music in new wave signifiers
column4: an association furthered by his deep
column5: commanding voice. Whether he's evoking Joy Division's Ian Curtis or Bauhaus' Peter Murphy
column6: Maus opts to abstract the genre
column7: inserting noise into unexpected places and walking the line between sincerity and surreality.

column1: From the beginning
column2: he's been an artist fascinated by the parameters
column3: paradoxes
column4: and possibilities of pop. Earlier this year
column5: Maus took a walk through New York's Central Park Zoo with a journalist from Self-Titled. ""I didn't realize that the music I was making was especially weird
column6: he says in the piece. ""Honestly
column7: I thought I was making Top 40 kind of stuff. It wasn't until people kept telling me so that I realized my work was thought of as something 'other' than that."" If you're at all familiar with the Minnesota native's swampy retro-futurist synth-pop
column8: you may understand why he might place emphasis on the word ""other."" One experience with his body of solo work (or brave live performances) makes clear that his could be categorized as ""outsider"" art
column9: but it's difficult to say that without also seriously considering why. He makes thought-provoking music that's disguised as something else.

column1: We Must Become the Pitiless Censors of Ourselves
column2: his latest full-length
column3: is the most vibrant and toothsome expression of Maus' pursuits yet. He keeps his vocals awash in gothic reverb and echo-driven effects
column4: blurring the lines between what he's saying and emoting. Sometimes
column5: as on ""Cop Killer""
column6: a Jan Hammer-indebted number on which Maus sings over an iced bed of keys
column7: the results are outlandish and oddly funny at the same time
column8: in the way that certain scenes in David Lynch films can leap from chilling to comically exaggerated. (""Cop killer
column9: let's kill the cops tonight/ Cop Killer
column10: kill every cop in sight
column11: he sings.) And then there's ""Matter of Fact"" immediately thereafter
column12: a song whose staccato
column13: orc-like chorus line is ""Pussy is not a matter of fact."" They're not the kind of earworms you want to find yourself singing aloud in public
column14: but it might happen anyway.

column1: Sonically
column2: Maus works a minimal
column3: primitive setup: sputtering drum machines and an arsenal of 1980s-vintage synth presets undercut his lyrics just as much as those exaggerated
column4: often grotesque vocal turns do. Sometimes
column5: these songs seem to exist solely to pose questions: Top 40 cheese or ironic cool? High-brow or low-brow? Honesty or posturing? Artifice or reality? But what makes We Must Become his finest full-length yet is how fluidly he communicates it all by foregrounding melody. On ""Keep Pushing On""
column6: Maus' monastic
column7: cellar-level singing lends the song the feel of a Gregorian chant-led exercise tape. Though the vocals and basslines on arpeggiated fever dream ""Quantum Leap"" mirror Joy Division's to an almost cartoonish degree
column8: you still get a good sense of Maus' persona in the music. There's a genuine
column9: almost maniacal sense of glee in the way he seems to approach each turn.

column1: When Maus takes the stage
column2: he plays with notions of performance by singing over his own backing tracks. He pogos
column3: he screams
column4: he runs-in-place and pulls his hair and spits and sweats and clenches up until he looks like he might burst through his button-down and chinos. It's hard to look away. Now Maus has a full set of songs whose architecture is just as sophisticated and riveting in actuality as it is in theory. While earlier records have been riddled by experiments gone awry (see: ""Rights for Gays"" and ""Tenebrae""
column5: from 2007's Love Is Real)
column6: they also didn't feature the revolving parts and aerodynamic hooks of ""Believer""
column7: the closing track here and one that glitters from any angle. And although there's another vocalist at his side in the lullaby lilt of ""Hey Moon"" (songwriter Molly Nilsson
column8: who wrote and performed the song on her 2008 album These Things Take Time)
column9: the way Maus sings to the heavens makes it sound as though he's no longer alone with his thoughts. Spend a lot of time with this record
column10:
and it's hard not to feel like you're right there with him.

What happened to Vybz Kartel? In the early years of the previous decade the Jamaican DJ possessed a nimble versatility that well matched dancehall's musical promiscuity
column2: switching between slippery
column3: smoke-damaged double-time raps and hypnotic sing-song choruses with an agility that for a time seemed unmatched. But at some point in the second half of the decade
column4: Kartel may have begun to feel burdened by his own success

column6: girl-grabbing
column7: ganja-imbibing contingent.

column1: Whatever the reason
column2: on his most recent albums Kartel has dramatically switched up (or
column3: rather
column4: down) his flow
column5: increasingly backgrounding his rapping in favor of a ponderous
column6: Auto-Tune-damaged tenor moaning over deflated
column7: synth-heavy arrangements

column9: grayscale
column10: and bloody long that listening to the whole thing in one go felt like an absurd endurance test. But Kartel hasn't lost all contact with his erstwhile bad-boy self; on one-off tracks he still regularly comes as hard and fast as ever
column11: and I suspect it's these more than recent albums that have protected his position at the top of dancehall's heap. Moreover
column12: sometimes Kartel in downer mode can work fantastically. On the recent ""Coloring Book""
column13: his oddly melancholy posturing captivates
column14: as he boasts of his irresistibly tattooed skin over a gorgeously bittersweet concoction of piano chords and descending strings.

column1: But ""Coloring Book"" doesn't grace Kartel's new album
column2: Kingston Story
column3: and there's precious little here that is nearly as enticing. It's as if Kartel has consciously rejected anything that's too dense
column4: too wordy
column5: too clearly casting him in the mold of DJ-as-rapper rather than universalist singjay. Which is a shame
column6: because while Kingston Story is less exhaustingly morose than Pon Di Gaza
column7: it's also more tepid
column8: a conscientiously inoffensive collection both lyrically and sonically.

column1: The thematic and stylistic range is established well enough on the first two tracks
column2: the atmospheric and reflective ""Jamaica"" and the clattering dance-pop of ""Beautiful Girl"". If the becalmed stasis of the former signals Kartel's desire to transcend the role extroverted dancehall host
column3: the latter just as clearly underscores the goal of seducing Western ears. This would all be well and good if these tunes were merely opening gambits on an album that struck a variety of poses
column4: or at least continued to push these divergent directions into new territory. Instead they mark the outer limits of the venture
column5: and while it's a compact album by dancehall standards Kingston Story starts to feel repetitive long before it winds down.

column1: Subjected to the torments of Auto-Tune
column2: Kartel's singing voice-- already somewhat weak and raspy
column3: though that's hardly unusual for dancehall-- becomes a mournful
column4: choked-up whimper
column5: all the more incongruous for bleating out otherwise-upbeat protestations of sexual prowess. At times there's something compelling about this: On ""Breathless""
column6: Kartel moans and whispers over a stark
column7: beautiful arrangement of shimmering synths
column8: ominous bass
column9: and ghostly backing vocal effects
column10: sorrowfully treading the sex/death tightrope where the flush of desire coincides with chilling presentiments of mortality. But for the most part Kingston Story is neither powerful nor distinctive enough for this sense of vulnerability to have much purchase.

column1: Such timidity is particularly disappointing because it coincides with the most enthusiastic upswing in dancehall's embrace of the weird and the wired in nearly a decade. Dancehall's new trends need Kartel
column2:
who's always had the gravitas to keep his head and his flow even in the most arcane settings. He'd do well to rediscover his insouciance for a while.

Since 2007
column2: Hessle Audio has played host to a smattering of singles from UK bass music's most exciting names
column3: including James Blake
column4: Untold
column5: and Blawan. The label has also released work by its co-owners: David Kennedy (Pearson Sound/ Ramadanman)

column1: This approach has led to a rupturing interpretation of dubstep and techno that often concedes beauty or charm but has not precluded curiosity or exploration. The label hosted what is arguably Blake's most progressive work (The Bells Sketch EP)
column2: and Kennedy has also been instrumental in electronic music's adoption of the footwork sound (an influence that pervades Addison Groove's ""Fuk tha 101"" and Pearson Sound's ""Stifle"" here). 116 & Rising

column1: The label's tendency to sequester itself in 12""s
column2: as well as its notoriously stingy release schedule
column3: makes the retrospective portion particularly valuable. Presented at dance-friendly tempos
column4: these 12 tracks are split among only seven producers
column5: forfeiting range for tense
column6: agile deployment. The tracks are not about establishing a mood; they concern themselves first with bass and second with the ways rhythm can aid
column7: embellish
column8: circle
column9: and attack that bass. Blawan
column10: the label's most exciting young product
column11: enacts this most clearly on ""Fram""

column13: ugly but undeniably neat.

column1: The disc of new materials suffers both in comparison to the classic material and from a frantic energy never properly corralled. Still
column2: there is plenty to digest: Untold takes his Duplo-block chords and applies them to Chicago house on ""Cool Story Bro"". Addison Groove's ""Fuk tha 101"" proves the artist also known as Headhunter has plans for the footwork sound grander than the indelible ""Footcrab"". Pangaea continues an uninterrupted run of excellent singles with ""Runout""
column3: a tart
column4: acidic current of noise. (A ""Second Version"" of Blake's ""Give a Man a Rod"" feels sadly like an attempt to include a ""New James Blake track!"")

column1: 116 & Rising offers a clearer vision of where Hessle has been than where it's going. It's OK to care less about such visions and more about a collection of kickass tracks (of which 116 offers many)
column2: though Hessle's cautious nature suggests that coherence matters. That the new disc includes some producers-- D1
column3: Peverelist
column4: Randomer-- that the label considers kin indicates that the close-knit
column5: communal aspect of Hessle isn't going away. At a bare minimum
column6: 116 provides a third totem (after Hyperdub's 5 and Hotflush's Back and 4th) for anyone requiring a quick primer on the last half-decade of progressive bass music. It is a tech-y
column7: aggressive totem
column8:
but don't conflate that aggression and lack of expanse with a dearth of creativity.

column3: the Brooklyn-based guitarist who calls her solo project Noveller

column5: drone
column6: and ambience. But Glacial Glow is a leap forward. Confident and consistent

column2: where once they could get blurred in echo. There's still lots of atmosphere here

column3: Loren Connors. Her sound is certainly busier than his
column4: but you can hear Connors' painterly fortitude on ""Alone Star""

column6: a little Papa M in the pastoral strings of ""Tuesday Before Poland""
column7: a little of Explosions in the Sky's cinematic drama in the lilting ""Glacial Wave"". But often when an artist gets stronger

column1: What most distinguishes the album is Lipstate's boldness. Every song steps forward even as it envelops
column2: and most have short titles that eschew irony or indecision. Take the closer

a work in which she's fully earned the right to be considered completely on her own.

column3: Seek Magic strikes me as a great album made by someone who really doesn't care much for the format. It's understandable since Dayve Hawk's prior gig Hail Social released a couple of LPs of timely
column4: danceable indie rock while perpetually hemmed in between positive notice (SPIN Band of the Day
column5: a deal with Polyvinyl) and a legitimate breakthrough. I can't imagine being too enthusiastic for the obligations of the traditional album cycle after all of that. Hawk's subsequent release of singles
column6: remixes
column7: and other one-offs under a clutch of confusingly similar names (Memory Tapes
column8: Weird Tapes
column9: Memory Cassette) announced his newfound artistic direction as a cry of freedom
column10: and he didn't show much interest in performing live either. But more eyes are on him than ever for Player Piano
column11: and he's still got a thing for demurral. He's already claimed his third record to be almost done
column12: allegedly a collection of Black Sabbath-influenced dirges. You would think such diffuse focus would eventually catch up with him
column13: yet Player Piano finds him more concentrated and economical than ever. Unfortunately
column14: it comes off more like complacency than conviction
column15: that Hawk's either holding back on us
column16: misreading his true strengths
column17: not recognizing the need to rise to the occasion
column18: or possibly all three.

column1: While the individual songs on Seek Magic were excellent themselves
column2: what made that record stand out was its comprehensiveness. Whether you enjoyed Hawk's laconic and fuzzy melodies
column3: gelatinous electronic textures
column4: or pulsating dance music
column5: you weren't too far from any of those at a given time (and you could find them all on ""Bicycle""). Player Piano lacks that crucial cumulative effect
column6: and instead Hawk presents himself more as an able if indistinct singer-songwriter than a molder of pure sound. And it isn't any sort of reactionary statement against chillwave: He stood out in my mind as the most forthright vocalist of his peers to begin with
column7: his feminized coo relying more on elegant melodic curvature than foggy evocation.

column1: He gets a proper showcase with single ""Wait in the Dark""
column2: on which Hawk is a true frontman rather than a texture over a streamlined arrangement. This shift makes Memory Tapes successfully come off like a sleek rock band than a home-bound project. Though he's comfortable doing true pop music
column3: as opposed to pop determined by immediate context
column4: his more extroverted moments can be as cloying: ""Sunhits"" rousts Player Piano from a mid-record plateau
column5: but the overly chipper guitar doodles and Hawk's dodgiest and most clearly enunciated hook (""Nothing's a dream if you never wake up""-- he's never been a lyrics guy) strain too hard to fulfill the prophecy of its title. And how ""Today Is Our Life"" hits me depends almost entirely on my current mood: There are times when I find it to be a genuinely buoyant tambourine-shaking shimmy of breathless hooks; there are others where that cornpone guitar solo and sitar-laced coda are the stuff of shopping mall karaoke booths.

column1: It cuts to what's really troubling about Player Piano
column2: how such a committed studio geek like Hawk delves into production-intensive 60s sunshine pop and ends up with such a weirdly distracting 2-D sound that leaves it sounding unfinished
column3: demo-level
column4: even. Its mood lighting is similar to that of Seek Magic
column5: but the underlying instrumentation is often flat and airless
column6: sucked dry of his typically evocative detailing. Paradoxically
column7: the tracks that are proudly sample-free and reliant on acoustic instrumentation are the ones that are the least dynamic and eerily evoke the disembodied artificial intelligence of keyboard presets. ""Yes I Know"" submerges its carnivalesque pinwheels and Hawk's vocals in a waterlogged muffle that you expect to lift at some point
column8: but it goes relatively hi-fi still without coming up for air. The same goes for ""Offers"" and ""Worries""
column9: nice enough experiments in bubblegum funk and digitally retouched Nuggets Farfisa-rock that lack any sort of immersion or fluidity. And the instrumentals no longer feel like they're on equal footing
column10: not that they do much to make themselves noticed. ""Humming"" is a palate cleanser of skittering drum machines and languid atmosphere begging for a longer work to play a part in
column11: and while the first half of ""Fell Thru Ice"" finds Hawk exploring newly unmoored song structure
column12: Part II is simply a lesser replay of Seek Magic tricks. It gets chased with ""Trance Sisters""
column13: which deserves some credit as a buzzer-beating freak-out of maximalism
column14: even if it's basically a compressed version of ""Bicycle"".

column1: All of which makes Player Piano a curiosity more than a flop. In fact
column2: the sturdy hooks and thin arrangements make it ripe for remixes
column3: and considering the similar wavelength he was on with Andorra
column4: I wonder what Dan Snaith might be able to do with the raw materials here. But while I'd love to say Hawk's ear for melody or texture is what differentiates Player Piano from the dozens of agreeable but wholly unremarkable electro-pop records that get a pass
column5: truth is
column6:
it's ultimately the comparison to Seek Magic that makes it such a letdown.

column3: for example

column7: who is featured heavily on the LP

column1: Importantly this makes the album greater than the sum of its parts. ""Dubstep dude with a bunch of singers"" becomes something much more collaborative and cohesive. SBTRKT is ultimately a colorful and highly enjoyable future-pop record

Atari Teenage Riot existed at a previously unimaginable fulcrum of genres
column5: using every ingredient they could find to come up with an ecstatically assaultive squall. Their twisting
column6: roiling blare had elements of pounding industrial
column7: of mouth-foaming hardcore punk
column8: of brutally fast hardcore rave
column9: of scraping electronic noise
column10: of thrash-metal bombast
column11: of wriggling drill-n-bass
column12: of Bomb Squad-style attack-beats. Their specific chaotic combination added up to German-accented ridiculousness (""Deutschland! Has gotta! Diiieeee!"") screamed over hyperspeed 808 pounds and digitally treated guitar fuzz; it seemed scientifically engineered to annoy as many people as possible. It was impossible to dance or talk or read or drive or do anything else while they were playing. I tried so hard to like them
column13: and I mostly succeeded
column14: even though my friends would give me tons of shit anytime I played their records.

column1: For a brief moment in the mid-1990s
column2: the group seemed like the future. They released records on Grand Royal
column3: they opened the much-touted Rage Against the Machine/Wu-Tang Clan tour
column4: and they spearheaded their own little mini-scene with their Digital Hardcore label. But after 11 years of inactivity
column5: it's pretty clear that they didn't exactly change the conversation. You can detect pieces of their style in a few musical movements that have come along since: the Teutonic-accented confrontationalism of electroclash
column6: the low-budget rabble-rousing computer-pop of early M.I.A.
column7: the squealing brickwalled dance-metal of Justice. But Atari Teenage Riot didn't transcend their moment. So their new album
column8: Is This Hyperreal?
column9: is a curious thing indeed: a nostalgic work that evokes an idea of the future that turned out to be absurd. Listening to it is like watching a remake of Johnny Mnemonic.

column1: The reconstituted Atari Teenage Riot of 2011 isn't really the same group from that mid-90s moment. Unhinged hypeman Carl Crack died in 2001. Lead screamer Hanin Elias is long gone
column2: though replacement Nic Endo sounds almost exactly like her. There's also a new member: laughably clumsy American MC CX Kidtronik (sample lyrics: ""My fist! My fist! I bang my fist! Against a concrete wall!""). But even with a ton of membership turnover
column3: Atari Teenage Riot sound very
column4: very similar to what mastermind Alec Empire first unleashed a decade and a half ago. Then again
column5: it's not like those early records left a whole lot of room for aesthetic advancement (what
column6: were they going to find a new genre of noisy assault music to incorporate?). But it's still pretty weird that this band's overwhelming fury has not mellowed in the slightest since they've been away. They're not teenagers anymore
column7: but you'd never know it from listening to them.

column1: That's not exactly a compliment. Teenagers experience politics in absolutes; red-faced sloganeering makes a lot more sense to a human ball of hormones than nuanced discourse ever could. But when a grown man roars
column2: ""They want to turn the Internet into their personal global chessboard!"" it just sounds goofy (who's they?). Some of the lyrics on Is This Hyperreal? push those tendencies to dizzy extremes. Consider
column3: for example
column4: this: ""Capitalism
column5: you're a little fat man in a big expensive car hanging over a ravine here!"" Or this bit of anti-Internet agitprop: ""When the authorities catch up with us
column6: and they will
column7: it's not such a good idea to leave traces and expose your whole network at once!"" (Yes
column8: Atari Teenage Riot have their own iPhone app. Why do you ask?) Musically
column9: too
column10: it's the same hyperspeed noise-blast format they've been working forever
column11: beyond the odd moment of Crystal Castles-style mutated video-game bloop. When ""Shadow Identity"" turns into deeply pretty M83-ish epic synthpop for a minute
column12: it's a legit shock: This band learned a new trick! But it's just for a few seconds at the end of the song
column13: and then it's over.

column1: Redundant as it may be
column2: though
column3: Is This Hyperreal? succeeds simply as unintentional nostalgia
column4: at least for someone who experienced the band the first time around. Opening track ""Activate!""
column5: for instance
column6: is pretty much Crystal Method-style big beat
column7: but with more guitar fuzz and screaming
column8: and it's just fun. The fact that Atari Teenage Riot still exist in any form
column9: and that they're still making these sputtering tantrums
column10: is almost admirable. They're gloriously silly anachronisms
column11: and I'm not sorry to have them back in my life. My friends probably aren't too happy
column12:
though.

Eric Copeland's music sometimes gets lumped in with chillwave or hypnagogic pop
column3: presumably because of how he chews up old sounds and spits them out in new shapes. It's like building sculptures out of thrift-store finds and junkyard debris
column4: so naturally some of his collages can sound nostalgic. But associating Copeland with anyone besides himself or his group Black Dice feels wrong. He really inhabits his own universe
column5: one he started before current cut-ups took to scouring VHS tapes and video games for source material. And his fractured rhythms
column6: which can approach bouncy hip-hop loops
column7: are as close to the Bomb Squad or J Dilla as Washed Out or Ducktails.

column1: In fact
column2: where those latter artists often deal in blurry memories of decades past
column3: Copeland's music reminds me more of a specific 1980s moment-- the scene in Ferris Bueller's Day Off where Matthew Broderick's character plays ""Blue Danube"" on a keyboard programmed with coughs and wheezes. Back then
column4: the thrill of using synths and samplers came in making any sound into a note
column5: and making any string of noises into a song. Copeland still seems fascinated by that simple idea and the unlimited potential it implies. On Waco Taco Combo
column6: his latest LP
column7: that fascination results in some of his catchiest songs to date.

column1: What makes them so catchy is also what makes them simple-- hard
column2: straight-ahead beats. Which is not to say that any song here is straightforward. They all creak and groan with lopsided motion. Drops of noisy oil leak out and loose screws rattle as Copeland's musical jalopy sidles down the street. But each track eventually digs into a bumping groove
column3: which becomes glue that holds all the rickety parts together
column4: or a magnet around which Copeland's furry filaments align into body-moving tuneage. It's a pretty singular pleasure to nod your head to such cartoonish music-- it's as if Copeland stole Wile E. Coyote's ACME bomb kit
column5: and turned the explosions into beats.

column1: On side two of Waco Taco Combo
column2: all the string and tape that Copeland uses to hold his sounds together finally snaps
column3: and a bunch of sonic detritus comes spilling out. In one side-long track
column4: ""Spangled""
column5: Copeland's beats become more random and less fluid
column6: his scenes fused via random jump cuts rather than smooth dissolves. Some might see ""Spangled"" as a doggie bag
column7: filled with leftovers whose connections are hard to see. How appetizing you'll find this stew depends on your tolerance for collage as an end in itself. To me
column8: it's a nice contrast to the album's smoother songs. But even if you can't stomach all 17 minutes
column9:
there's more than enough nuggets on Waco Taco Combo to sink your teeth into.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16731/homepage_large.5d2bc8d2.jpg|OX 2010: A Street Odyssey|4522.0|Vast Aire|['Rap'

column4: The Cold Vein
column5: continues to stand as an indie-rap masterpiece. The duo's members
column6: Vast Aire and Vordul Mega
column7: had something to prove. Definitive Jux label head El-P
column8: who produced the album
column9: was fired up to define himself post-Company Flow. And underground hip-hop was at the perfect point to accept a new vanguard for post-Wu-Tang spiritual headknock. But bridges have been burned
column10: beefs over business have gone down
column11: and all the players have been left to their own devices. The more time that passes
column12: the easier it is to wonder how well the sum of CanOx's parts could survive independently of each other.

column1: For a while after the release of 2008's Dueces Wild
column2: it looked like Vast Aire was finally starting to shift the conversation from ""when's the next CanOx album?"" to ""when's the next Vast album?"" But any feeling of momentum from that release has vanished on OX 2010: A Street Odyssey. It takes 35 seconds for the space-age triumphalism of ""Nomad"" to get to this cornball lyric: ""And even though I do yoga/ Trust me
column3: Vast Aire has never been a poseur."" Over a beat evoking some sort of futurist celestial majesty
column4: that head-slapper of a punchline is only the first of several moments where it feels like Vast is stuck somewhere between badass and goofball. In splltting the difference
column5: he just sounds stilted.

column1: Other verses tread a similar line. ""My dad is a Magnum/ I'm a son of a gun
column2: Vast jokes on ""2090 (So Grimmy)"". The wicked-carnival scenario of ""Merry Go Round"" has just the minimum amount of dignity to keep it from seeming like a bid for Juggalo crossover fandom. And the goopy wuv-rap of ""Horoscope"" is way too treacly from someone who once poured his heart out on The Cold Vein's devastatingly sincere ""The F-Word"". The most cringeworthy moment comes in closer ""Battle of the Planets""
column3: where Vast actually recycles the refrain from ""Scream Phoenix""
column4: turning The Cold Vein's most life-affirming moment into a grudge taunt at the expense of former Weathermen crewmate Cage. His deliberate
column5: heavily enunciated growl underlines every embarrassing lyrical decision in red pen.

column1: At least OX 2010 doesn't feel entirely like one MC stranded in his own malaise. The beats are serviceable
column2: with some unostentatious boom-bap from the likes of Kount Fif
column3: Harry Fraud
column4: and Ayatollah. And the guest verses range from complementary mediocrity (Cappadonna treading water on ""I Don't Care"") to complete upstagings (Guilty Simpson going berserk on ""The Verdict""). Unfortunately
column5: the album's most headline-grabbing collaboration-- a brief reunion with Vordul on ""Thor's Hammer""
column6:
with a re-used Raekwon verse from Blood on Chef's Apron taking the first slot-- is also its biggest disappointment. There are plenty of ways to get people to stop clamoring for a Cannibal Ox reunion. This album's the saddest one.

Alongside the roaring Harlem rapper Vado
column2: Rhode Island native AraabMuzik has been one of the key figures in the re-emergence of Cam'ron
column3: Dipset's language-bending figurehead. After a long period of complete disappearance
column4: Cam's been going through something of a comeback lately
column5: aided in large part by tracks like Araab's punishing ""Get It in Ohio"". Araab's work for Cam
column6: and for other freelance clients
column7: sounds dollar-store cheap but knife-edge tense; it reminds me of Steve Jablonsky's score for Friday the 13th. He makes ferocious
column8: diamond-hard gangsta rap beats with a pervading sense of dystopic anxiety. Araab's sense of vision comes through even more strongly in the web videos he's been releasing
column9: in which he shows off his MPC virtuosity and slices up samples of
column10: oh
column11: say
column12: Cannibal Corpse. Like fellow underground rap visionaries Clams Casino and DJ Burn One
column13: Araab makes freelance beats that hint at a fully developed personal aesthetic. And like those guys
column14: he's now striking out on his own
column15: making instrumental music that brings that aesthetic to the forefront.

column1: Electronic Dream is Araab's first commercially available album
column2: but it works more like a collection of remixes. Rather than creating his own tracks from scratch
column3: Araab spends his debut album dismembering a series of cheesed-out hairgel-house superclub anthems: DJ Nosferatu's ""The Underground Stream"" on ""Underground Stream""
column4: Jam & Spoon's ""Right in the Night (Fall in Love With Music)"" on ""Golden Touch""
column5: Starchaser's ""So High"" on ""Feelin So Hood"". This is
column6: to put it mildly
column7: an unexpected direction for Araab. With a little bit of Googling
column8: you can find plenty of online screeds from fans frustrated or even enraged at Araab for making an album based on this music
column9: or for dishonoring his sample sources by leaving large pieces of these tracks unchanged while neglecting to properly credit the original producers. But Araab's changes
column10: relatively minor though they may be
column11: turn a sound built on populist uplift into something darker.

column1: It's tough to imagine the tracks on Electronic Dream getting any play in any dance club in the world
column2: and it's virtually impossible to picture anyone rapping over them. Instead
column3: this album is a genre unto itself-- ominous future shit that creates an atmosphere but never bleeds into the background. Araab's snare-hits resonate like eye-punches
column4: and his drum-programming is pure
column5: unrelenting rap shit. But he's applying that sensibility to songs where the melodies shine even when Araab's using a screaming sound effect as part of the rhythm track. The end result is a truly weird little album-- something at once anxious and euphoric.

column1: As hard as his drums punch
column2: though
column3: Araab still let the textures of these anthems shine through. And in Araab's hands
column4: these melodies work differently; the anonymous dance divas wailing ecstatically over their original beats become lost
column5: lonely souls
column6: anxiously whispering to themselves that everything will be OK. Araab's music doesn't allow for dizzy buildups and cathartic breakdowns; instead
column7: it's all murky tension
column8: all the time. At times
column9: his tracks can sound a bit like the woozy bass music of L.A.'s Brainfeeder scene
column10: but Araab is always more direct and more ferocious than those guys. And yet the sugary beauty of those melodies sound like they belong on his tracks; nothing is out of place. ""Got a feelin' so high
column11: the singer on ""Feelin So Hood"" coos
column12: and the drums beat that feeling down while the gorgeous ripples of synth lift it back up.

column1: There's something truly fascinating about the entire LP: An up-and-coming hardcore rap producer leaving his genre behind so that he can twist and scramble this hands-in-the-air big-room sound. And in peeling back its excesses and substituting in his own eccentricities
column2: Araab uncovers a primal emotional force in this music
column3: one that fits beautifully with his own air-raid siren aesthetic. Electronic Dream is pretty
column4:
but it's pretty like the morning sun twinkling off of a dangling machete blade-- you don't want to fuck with it.

"|15566.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15566-electronic-dream/|8.2|Tom Breihan
