After a few scattered 7""s
column2: Pure Ecstasy decided to up and change their name to Pure X for their debut full-length. But Pure X are hardly suffering from a personality crisis-- a San Francisco cover band already had the former handle copyrighted
column3: so the abbreviation occurred out of necessity. For those of us who heard something special in loose
column4: wandering tracks like 2009 B-side ""You're in It Now"" or ""Voices"" a year later
column5: nearly everything on Pleasure will feel like a welcome distillation of the elements that made those songs sound promising. In turn
column6: the band's new moniker should seem completely fitting: No longer just a kick-around project from three Austin dudes
column7: Pure X have become the refined and elemental version of their former selves.

column1: Fans of those early singles don't need to worry too much. Pure X remain very much attached to their singular style. Jesse Jenkins' bass still sounds peanut-butter sticky
column2: while Nate Grace's guitars showcase pond-ripple textures and Mideast-tinged tones one moment and hemorrhage syrupy feedback the next. Like grunge for beachcombers or shoegaze for people happy to be alive
column3: Pleasure is all about texture and patience
column4: stretched to ensure maximum zoneage. Anything MDMA-related about the moniker is a total misnomer-- this sounds like music made by people who mainline Benadryl.

column1: Sure
column2: the album's blown-out guitars
column3: dusky shoreline vibes
column4: and drug-sick crawl can seem awfully familiar. But Pure X aren't just coasting on shaggy fumes. For one
column5: this is a terrific-sounding record
column6: built for headphones and high volume. Recorded live with no overdubs
column7: everything emulsifies beatifically while a disorienting quality still looms
column8: like riding in a four-door on the freeway with only the back left window down.

column1: Pure X also set themselves apart by both honoring their influences and recombining them in interesting ways. Opener ""Heavy Air"" sounds like a chopped 'n' screwed Real Estate
column2: while the new version of ""Voices"" suggests My Bloody Valentine channeling the Everly Brothers. After all
column3: these songs owe a lot to the starry-eyed romantic ballads of the late 1950s and early 60s. Instead of harnessing the rebel cool of that era
column4: Pure X get lost in the simplicity and slow-burn daydreaminess
column5: stoking these characteristics with uniquely visceral reverb and a zonked tunefulness that impart a vaporous sensuality.

column1: But the most defining and pleasurable thing about Pleasure is the guitars-- impressive for a record that doesn't care about show-off guitar shit at all. Grace lets his pedals do most of the talking
column2: gracefully sussing out emotional detail with subtle melody while still creating memorable moments
column3: like the cheap firework burnout at the end of ""Half Here"". Pure X may not be breaking new ground
column4: but as far as deadbeat summer vibes done right go
column5:
Pleasure is one killer drag.

"|15575.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15575-pleasure/|7.6|Zach Kelly

Rapping about the pressures of being famous is pretty popular right now. Kanye West and Drake
column3: in their best moments
column4: can make that weight feel like something that could apply to our jobs and relationships
column5: and Big Sean's debut album on West's G.O.O.D. Music imprint takes a similar approach. The idea seems to be that with a deal and a record in stores
column6: the Detroit MC has earned the right to complain with the best of them.

column1: While Finally Famous isn't especially nuanced
column2: Sean is an often extremely entertaining rapper. He's able to fit his elastic
column3: smooth voice in the cracks of No I.D.'s lush soul samples just as easily as he slides right over heavier
column4: more radio-friendly tracks like ""Marvin & Chardonnay""
column5: which features a verse from West. Sean often runs circles around beats
column6: speeding up his voice so that his words cram into a pileup in the end. His appeal is more in the way he plays with language than in his lyrics
column7: which go so far as to make an unfortunate ""Family Guy"" reference.

column1: On individual tracks
column2: Sean's style works well. Even the blandest lyrics are worth a rewind based purely on delivery and enthusiasm. Who knew that ""Fuck
column3: I hate to say I told you so/ So buying rounds is my way of saying I told you hos"" could sound so believably triumphant? But it's when the guests show up-- a high-profile list including not only West
column4: but also The-Dream
column5: Lupe Fiasco
column6: Pharrell
column7: John Legend
column8: Wiz Khalifa
column9: and Chris Brown-- Sean appears out of place on his own album. Clipse's Pusha T has a particularly strong verse on deluxe-edition album closer ""100 Keys""
column10: while Sean sounds helium-light by comparison.

column1: Ultimately
column2: Sean's a likable character. Still
column3: a line on ""100 Keys"" encapsulates his faults: ""Keys open doors
column4: but bricks open windows
column5: he raps
column6: recalling Clipse's ""Keys Open Doors"" except lacking their sharp wit and heavy delivery. We can only hope that for album two
column7:
Sean will step out from the herculean shadows of the artists he surrounds himself with and learn the art of subtlety.

Well before the release of 2010's sturdy
column2: sprawling Sad Sour Future
column3: Iowa rockers the Poison Control Center embarked on what they dubbed an endless tour. At press time
column4: an end appears nowhere in sight. Along their way
column5: the band carved out a little time to lay down their latest
column6: Stranger Ballet. Half as long and nearly twice as lively as its predecessor
column7: Stranger Ballet is bright
column8: boisterous
column9: and instantly appealing power-pop
column10: jammed with the kind of immediacy you hope to put across when you've only got a half-hour or so to impress and the sort of smart
column11: starchy hooks that hang with you long after they're over.

column1: Each member of the band's songwriting trio ups his own lyrical ante on Stranger Ballet. Patrick Tape Fleming's words are more charmingly sincere
column2: fellow guitarist Devin Frank's are slacker and more impressionistic
column3: and bassist Joseph Terry's are both sweeter and more surreal. Musically
column4: though
column5: their styles have grown far closer
column6: perhaps a byproduct of all those months on the road flitting through the van iPod. Hints of spindly alt-rock touchstones from Built to Spill to pre-Maladroit Weezer bump heads with glam and late-90s indie spazz
column7: but with much of Sad Sour Future's excess fat trimmed back
column8: who PCC sound like seems far less important this time out than what they sound like. Here's a band that's enjoyed an enormous confidence boost over the past couple of years
column9: and while there's still a kind of aw-shucks humility to the proceedings
column10: the giddy effortlessness of these hooks suggest that these guys know precisely how good they've gotten.

column1: As on Sad Sour Future
column2: there's nary a bad tune in the bunch
column3: but I'll call Terry's gleefully manic ""Underground Bed"" the set's highest high-- like a Thermals song with the vitriol sucked right out. That's the other thing about these guys: Except for maybe Frank's sad sour missive about ""shit and piss"" on opener ""Torpedoes on Tuesday..."" and Fleming's weepy ""Born on Date""
column4: there's never a second where the band's not having a blast making this racket. You can hear the smiles wide across their faces
column5: and that feeling's catching. Even when soul belter Mona Perkins does an awkwardly ebullient ""Gimme  Shelter"" routine on a couple of these tracks
column6: the ill-suited pairing  gets over on sheer jubilance. Nearly a decade deep into their career
column7: you couldn't blame these guys for coming off a little ragged
column8: especially after the exceedingly ambitious Sad Sour Future. But Stranger Ballet finds the PCC raring to go
column9: eager to please
column10:
and enjoying every minute of the wild ride they've found themselves on.

"|15608.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15608-stranger-ballet/|7.6|Paul Thompson

On their 2008 tour for Devotion
column2: Beach House had a t-shirt for sale at their merch table featuring the album title spelled out in the sort of gothic font you see on death-metal album covers
column3: creating a cheeky contrast between the grim presentation and the band's tranquil hazy-headed dream-pop. But those two aesthetic poles blurred into one upon hearing the striking debut single from Gardens & Villa. Ideal for summertime strolls through a cemetery
column4: ""Black Hills"" pits vibraphone chimes against an icy synth pulse overtop an unnervingly steady beat. And while ""Black Hills"" presents magisterial images of mountains
column5: seas
column6: and high tides
column7: its environment feels tensely claustrophobic
column8: with Chris Lynch's elastic
column9: androgynous voice projecting serenity and severity in equal measure. It's the sort of song you could easily imagine Beach House coming up with
column10: were they to follow-up the lushness of Teen Dream with something more sinister.

column1: But the self-titled debut album that ""Black Hills"" opens shows Gardens & Villa to be something more complex than just a Beach Hearse. That such a moody outfit hails from sunny Santa Barbara is but a surface indication of their curious qualities. With a lyric sheet that's preoccupied with nature and mysticism-- not to mention a singer who's not afraid to whip out a flute-- Gardens & Villa could easily be pegged as hippies. But they're also keen on playing up the artificial qualities of their music
column2: foregrounding synthesizers and mechanized
column3: metronomic rhythms to create a peculiar hybrid of 1960s and 80s sensibilities. (One song bears the particularly apt title of ""Neon Dove"".) As such
column4: the austerity of their sound can make them seem both sternly serious and
column5: at times
column6: rather goofy. (See: the ping-ponged synth-pop of ""Spacetime""
column7: wherein the title is repeated in a comically spooky voice
column8: as if it were the intro to some old Saturday morning cartoon.) Given their fondness for the classic and the plastic
column9: it's no surprise Gardens & Villa feel equally at home recording their album with piano-bar bard Richard Swift as touring with hipster hype magnets Foster the People.

column1: But if the ambiguous quality of their sound sometimes makes it hard to become emotionally invested in Gardens & Villa
column2: in Lynch
column3: they're blessed with a singer who has remarkable presence and poise. For all the effeminate intimations in his voice
column4: he never uses it for pure affectation or gratuitous
column5: histrionic effect. And though the band has been quick to cite the percussive funk of Talking Heads as a driving influence
column6: they truly excel at crafting atmospheric ballads: the Low-like hymn ""Chemtrails"" and
column7: especially
column8: the foreboding ""Sunday Morning""
column9: a rainy-day requiem that favorably recalls the retro-futurist psych-pop of the United States of America or Broadcast. It's hard to predict where Gardens & Villa might go from here: bombastic
column10: drum-circle-ready closer ""Neon Dove"" carries the possibility of Yeasayer-styled transition from misfits to populists
column11: while ""Orange Blossom"" suggests a desire to join Wild Beasts on the art-funk fringes. But in the flute-tootin' Lynch
column12:
they've got a pied piper worth following down whichever path he takes.

Who's your Brian Eno? The art-pop savant of Here Come the Warm Jets? The ambient theorist of Discreet Music? The prog-jazz dabbler of Nerve Net? Or the film music composer of Small Craft on a Milk Sea? Maybe you think of him mainly as a virtuoso technician
column3: an innovative pop producer
column4: a prodigious collaborator
column5: or a visionary mixed-media artist. His broad range of talents and activities makes getting your head around his catalogue about as plausible as giving him a haircut
column6: and it's natural for us to establish our own versions of what his baseline aesthetic is. Whoever the ""real"" Eno is to you
column7: he's bound to show up at least once on his second LP for Warp Records
column8: a mercilessly erratic collaboration with the poet Rick Holland.

column1: You could say with only slight hyperbole that Eno's signing to Warp last year was like the Beatles joining Elephant 6. The British label's eclectic roster-- Broadcast's cerebral electronic pop
column2: Autechre's ascetic IDM
column3: Boards of Canada's synthetic naturalism
column4: Aphex Twin's ambient techno-- could reasonably be called the Eno Diaspora. Small Craft
column5: a collaboration with Leo Abrahams and Jon Hopkins
column6: was oriented around music composed for (and rejected from) Peter Jackson's film The Lovely Bones
column7: but with its jungle breakbeats
column8: ambient drones
column9: and computer glitches
column10: it sounded like Eno refracting Warp's own history. In other words: Eno making music influenced by Eno.

column1: Drums Between the Bells retains many qualities of Small Craft
column2: including propeller-like live percussion and mildly dated whiffs of trip-hop and downtempo. The big difference is that the music is built around Holland's words
column3: read by a number of different speakers. As it doesn't rely on the ironic voice and language games of modern fashion
column4: Holland's richly imagistic poetry is well-suited to the project. The music around it is scattershot
column5: but not random: Each song is designed to complement the poem at its center. Still
column6: the record has a rather unnerving pace
column7: overpowering and retiring in quick alternation. ""Bless this Space"" opens  things inauspiciously with an electronic jazz fusion setting
column8: which is about the most unsympathetic environment for a poet imaginable. ""Glitch"" is musically livelier
column9: with a mightily abrasive climax
column10: but the HAL-like vocal treatment flattens Holland's poem into numbingly literal sci-fi boilerplate.

column1: Then
column2: abruptly
column3: a suite of meltingly lovely tracks arrives and does real service to Holland's poetry. The arctic pianos that encircle a crisp female voice on ""Dreambirds"" recall Eno's prior work with Harold Budd
column4: just as the liquid guitar of ""Pour It Out"" recalls the lighter side of the Fripp collaborations. Despite its dystopian tendencies
column5: Holland's writing has a plain-hearted tenderness that female voices seem to draw out more subtly than male ones. On these two tracks
column6: as well as ""Seedpods"" and ""The Real""
column7: Eno reacts to the female voice with great sensitivity. The result is like a gentler companion to Laurie Anderson's Homeland: no ironclad beats hammering down on the words
column8: but a gossamer web cradling them with all due reverence. The oracular hush fits Holland much better than stentorian force.

column1: Even when Drums dips into sketchy territory-- the reggae-styled ""Dow""
column2: for example-- it's hard not to be intrigued by Eno's command of sonic texture
column3: weight
column4: and spatial dimensions. Nothing feels vaguely formed. With the ability to realize microscopically precise details and effects
column5: he makes the reconciliation of extremes feel inevitable: A river of industrial slag might flow into saucy jazz horns; funk riffs might level out into a thick krautrock haze. We can count on these kinds of pleasures even from a so-so Eno record
column6: and Drums is better than so-so. The problem with it
column7: beyond a handful of unflattering genre excursions
column8: is a slight but persistent thinness of imagination. The concrete music of ""Fierce Aisles of Light"" conjures the feel of being on a train with impeccable accuracy
column9: but it's a pat setting for lyrics where trains feature prominently. When a minute of silence
column10: called ""Silence""
column11: appears near the end of the record
column12: it's hard not to feel as though you're in the presence of an incredible talent casting about for the next big idea
column13:
casually producing minor wonders in the meantime.

It hasn't even been five months since Ghostly re-released Com Truise's formative Cyanide Sisters EP
column3: and already Princeton
column4: N.J.'s Seth Haley is back with a full-length debut. That Galactic Melt has been pretty much in the can for that entire time tells you something about Haley's formidable work ethic; in addition to Truise
column5: he  operates under at least three other pseudonyms
column6: none as fully-realized but each as prodigious.

column1: Haley's rapid-fire turnover plays incredibly well on the Internet. He's something of a cottage industry
column2: dispensing original tracks
column3: remixes
column4: podcasts
column5: and accompanying boxfresh graphic designs to his blog  readership and Twitter followers with impressive regularity. By  capitalizing on the immediacy of the formats
column6: he's also charting his own  evolution in realtime. When he writes
column7: ""I thought I'd switch it up a little"" in reference to a remix he's just posted for Ana Lola Roman's ""Klutch""
column8: he's acknowledging that his listeners know what he means by ""it
column9: and how it's been switched; everything is laid out with a clear progression
column10: one small evolution to the next.

column1: The comparative slow lane of a regular label release schedule
column2: though
column3: has a  habit of slowing down the flow of music
column4: crumpling up its timelines and deforming expectations. This usually doesn't matter to the end listener; what's new to our ears is good as new. But since Galactic Melt sounds more like a polite and brotherly companion piece to Cyanide Sisters than it does a proper follow-up
column5: it's hard not to feel like the tactic of waiting to market has robbed Haley of some of some of his momentum.

column1: Part of the problem is Cyanide Sisters. As debut EPs go
column2: it was an accomplished enough turn to raise questions  about what Truise might do for an encore. The answer
column3: as it happens
column4: was
column5: well
column6: a slightly more muted version of the same. Don't get me  wrong: with its staccato
column7: bonus level synth stabs
column8: keening psychedelia  and 1980s-drenched drum sounds
column9: Melt is still very identifiably Truise. But with the exception of the banging double whammy of ""VHS Sex"" and ""Cathode Girls""
column10:
there's nothing much here to suggest that Truise has upped his game in any meaningful way. Whether you consider that a disappointment will depend on how much mileage you get out of Haley in this mode.

YACHT's second album as a duo
column2: their fifth overall
column3: fuses a utopian concept with the brand of nervy
column4: spastic electro-funk we've come to expect from the DFA label. As on 2009's See Mystery Lights
column5: Portland laptop maestro Jona Bechtolt (formerly of the Blow) and singer Claire L. Evans enjoy their smoothest sailing when they fully submit to sweaty euphoria; Shangri-La offers more than enough frantic beats
column6: fidgety bass lines
column7: spiky guitar leads
column8: soaring piano riffs
column9: delirious vocal harmonies
column10: and
column11: yes
column12: cowbells to fit in on any house-party playlist. Still
column13: its idyllic theme can be a bit heavy-handed
column14: and nothing here is quite as indelibly hooky as past single ""Psychic City (Voodoo City)"".

column1: Shangri-La continues YACHT's trajectory from blips and bloops that suggest their computerized origins to a full-fledged band sound that should translate nicely to hedonistic live shows. But the duo's sense of
column2: well
column3: fun hasn't gone anywhere. See Mystery Lights' nods to T-Pain and Desmond Dekker gives way to an end-times synth workout ""Dystopia (The Earth Is on Fire)""
column4: which shares a seven-minute video with the tropical-flavored disco-punk of album opener ""Utopia"". When the pace slows
column5: as on the spacey ""Love in the Dark""
column6: instant quotables jump out: ""I love you like a small-town cop/ Yeah
column7: I wanna smash your face in with a rock
column8: Evans sings
column9: in deadpan multi-track.

column1: Still
column2: the record tends to burden its good times with a few too many ideas that simply aren't that distinctive. Brass-boosted ""Holy Roller""
column3: which starts as a finger-snapping cousin to Black Lips' religion-minded ""Veni Vidi Vici"" and ends closer to the doomed stomp of Modest Mouse's ""Fly Trapped in a Jar"" (by way of dubstep bass-wobble)
column4: recommends not worrying about a god. James Murphy-esque dance-rant ""Paradise Engineering"" finds holiness within.

column1: The basic gist-- and despite its familiarity
column2: it's a commendable one-- is that
column3: as Belinda Carlisle once sang
column4: heaven is a place on Earth. ""If we build a utopia
column5: will you come and stay?"" asks Shangri-La's closing
column6: title track
column7: all catchy la-la-las and beatific afterglow. Paradise
column8: the song suggests
column9: can be California
column10: Oregon
column11: Texas
column12: or anywhere we choose: an appealing and valuable notion. But it's worth remembering that when new-wave forebears Blondie found ""Rapture""
column13:
it was ""toe to toe/ Dancing very close.""

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16719/homepage_large.51dde193.jpg|Evening Tapestry|28160.0|Brown Recluse|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Slumberland']|2011-07-05 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:14.526710|"

Philadelphia's Brown Recluse make music in the long tradition of indie pop that's heavy on emotion
column2: but the intimacy of these songs extends beyond just feelings. The band takes its name from a dangerous spider whose venom can cause skin lesions
column3: so the Fantastic Voyage-like concern with bodily systems here seems fitting. This focus is there even when the lyrics turn towards the surreal
column4: as when frontman Tim Meskers sings on ""Wooden Fingers"" about ""dreams still trickling from my eyes.""

column1: The vague nature of dreams and memories pervades Evening Tapestry. The lyrical narration is often indirect and distant
column2: recounting small
column3: indelible details and visions both somnambulant (the surreal
column4: cobweb-covered ""Statue Garden"") and conversational (""At Last""
column5: which details a cab ride). The music itself takes on the form of creeping psychedelia
column6: as organs sickly spin within baroque structures (the aptly titled ""Paisley Tears"") and even the simplest six-string jangle takes on a soft-focus blur. The overall approach owes something to the heyday of the Elephant 6 collective
column7: though nothing on Evening Tapestry gets as far out as the Olivia Tremor Control's ""Green Typewriters"" suite. Brown Recluse's own sunshine-blotter dabblings are more reminiscent of early Beulah
column8: or the surreal sensitivity on Of Montreal's 1999 opus The Gay Parade. You can feel what Meskers is saying
column9: even if the surroundings seem a bit strange.

column1: With all the talk of paisley and psychedelia
column2: it's important to note that Evening Tapestry is
column3: first and foremost
column4: an indie pop album (and one on the increasingly strong roster of resuscitated indie pop label Slumberland
column5: no less). That means there's plenty of jangle and winsome melodical structures
column6: recalling the dearly departed East Coast outfit Pants Yell! as much as the usual suspects: the Clientele
column7: early Belle and Sebastian
column8: indie-pop forebears the Zombies
column9: and Brooklyn newcomers Beach Fossils. Unlike Beach Fossils' compartmentalized distance
column10: though
column11: Brown Recluse sound bright and direct throughout Evening Tapestry
column12:
like light shining through their sleepy fog. Sort of like a dream? No-- better.

Ernest Gonzales
column2: aka Mexicans With Guns
column3: seems disinterested in things like nuance and pacing. Often seen outfitted in a luchador mask
column4: Gonzales clearly has a flair for the theatrical
column5: and his debut LP
column6: Ceremony
column7: strives for the cinematic. Rooted in drum'n'bass while touching on everything from 8-bit to dubstep to house
column8: Gonzales aims to assault your senses with all the subtlety of a frying pan smack.

column1: But for all its range
column2: Ceremony suffers from being brazenly repetitive
column3: relying on flash instead of substance and betraying a lack of restraint. Tracks are build around deep bass
column4: throbbing swaths of electronics
column5: and errant sound effects
column6: all of which are usually contrasted by a mercurial element
column7: like say
column8: a brief
column9: semi-melodious synth line. The resulting tracks sadly feel too truncated for the dancefloor and too monotonous for headphones.

column1: Gonzales does have a solid feel for the role of percussion in his futuristic assemblages
column2: such as the shakers and claps on the alien
column3: evil ""Jaguar"" or the riotous cowbells on ""Fields"". And despite a lack of variance
column4: Gonzales proves to be an interesting mimic at times
column5: offering a slightly less-heady approximation of a Zomby track (""Fields"")
column6: and channeling a menace-dripping Massive Attack (""Restart""). The latter gets a boost from vocalist Sasha Perera
column7: who finds herself in the esteemed company rapper Freddie Gibbs and folk-futurist Helado Negro
column8: proving
column9: if nothing else
column10: that at least the guy has taste.

column1: But Gonzales' mishandling of those guest spots and the record's frankly obnoxious second half makes for a burdening listen. Gibbs tries to craft some semblance of a song out of the wonky bluster of ""Highway to Hell""
column2: but the track is a non-starter. Everyone else is simply drowned out by the racket
column3: making Gonzales' ""look at me"" aesthetic feel even more masturbatory. (For some reason
column4: only rapper Nocando gets a pass for his appearance on ""Got Me Fucked Up""
column5: a song so hilariously awful it demands to be mentioned here.) Despite the thoughtfulness bestowed upon the Helado Negro-assisted closing track
column6: it's of little consequence-- the record's end is reward enough. So
column7: lesson learned: No matter how deep the bass is
column8:
it can't mask how shallow most of the ideas are.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16721/homepage_large.3b725c75.jpg|Lord Giveth
column2: Lord Taketh Away EP|27104.0|Statik Selektah|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['CTE'
column4: Freddie Gibbs remains locked in fifth gear at all times. He never significantly alters his rap style
column5: but that style is such a hyper-technical
column6: gangsta-rap blur that he always sounds impressive
column7: no matter the context. Peers of mine have already written off Gibbs
column8: claiming that it's a problem when he goes in the exact same way every time. I can see what they're saying
column9: but that perpetual sturdiness is
column10: for me
column11: more a strength than a weakness. He just doesn't fuck up
column12: ever. Gibbs recently signed with Young Jeezy's Corporate Thugz label
column13: and that's an awkward pairing on paper. But as it turns out
column14: the two Gibbs collabs on Jeezy's new The Real Is Back mixtape are the two most exciting tracks on the whole tape; without switching up his style at all
column15: Gibbs sounds awesome over the lurching gothic evilness that Jeezy favors. Just by doing what he does
column16: Gibbs fits into Jeezy's universe a lot more naturally than any of Rick Ross' recent Internet-rap protégés sound on the newish Maybach Music Group compilation.

column1: For the Lord Giveth
column2: Lord Taketh Away EP
column3: Gibbs dips a toe into a scene far removed from Jeezy's populist drug-rap
column4: teaming up with DJ and producer Statik Selektah
column5: a pillar of East Coast traditionalist circles and an underrated beatmaker. The two recorded the entire EP in a single day
column6: broadcasting the sessions on Ustream and selling the finished project a couple of days later. It's a quickie EP
column7: just 19 minutes long
column8: and almost every track has a guest appearance or two. But beyond its length
column9: there's little indication that Gibbs cranked this thing out as fast as possible. Every once in a while
column10: there's an awkwardly cryptic line that could've used a rewrite (""I just wanna make dough and fuck bitches like I'm a Latter Day Saint""?)
column11: but Gibbs maintains the same quick-moving tough-talk intensity that he's always displayed. If you're not sick of just hearing this guy rap-- and you probably shouldn't be-- there's a lot to like about this one.

column1: Granted
column2: nothing on Lord Giveth has the knife-edge intensity of a great Gibbs track like ""Murda on My Mind""
column3: and Gibbs doesn't try out anything beyond his most well-traveled subject matter. But he still has a way with an evocative image (""Man
column4: it's so dry out here niggas be cutting they dope with vitamins"")
column5: and his syllable-by-syllable flow remains a force of nature. Statik's tracks work as pretty good facsimiles of the classically simple DJ Premier style
column6: and Gibbs sounds just as comfortable on those as he does on Jeezy tracks. (I get the impression that nothing disturbs this guy; he could probably rap over
column7: like
column8: a Deerhoof song without blinking.)

column1: Many of the album's guests come from Statik's usual circle of collaborators
column2: gifted but grumpy East Coast guys like Termanology and Reks (the latter of whom airs out hopes ""for real MCs to kill the likes of Lil Bs
column3: which should give you some idea what cultural milieu we're working in). Gibbs sounds coolest alongside guys from other regions
column4: like Houston mainstay Trae
column5: whose muttery nihilistic fast-rap baritone is similar to Gibbs' own
column6: or Dogg Pound veteran Daz
column7: who comes off badass even when he's rotely reciting his career accomplishments. But even the East Coast also-rans have their moments. I especially liked Push! Montana's extended ""Home Improvement"" riff: ""I'm Tim Taylor with the tool
column8: man/ Play Wilson
column9: try to peek over the gate/ Soon as I see your brow
column10: I squeeze it in your face.""

column1: That clever ignorance is a small pleasure
column2: like most of the pleasures on Lord Giveth. But even if it's nowhere near his strongest release
column3:
Lord Giveth remains a solid showcase for one of our most solid rappers.

"|15599.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15599-lord-giveth-lord-taketh-away-ep/|7.2|Tom Breihan

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16713/homepage_large.1d9fb6c8.jpg|The Unanimous Hour|2559.0|Lungfish|['Rock'
column2: 'Metal'
column3:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dischord']|2011-07-01 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:16.115257|"

They say it takes only three chords to write a punk song. Lungfish did it with two. And they did it for 18 years. From 1987 to 2005
column4: the Baltimore quartet could be considered the world's leading purveyor of punk-rock-as-devotional-art. They were a band hellbent and single-minded in their commitment to ascetic thrashing
column5: with an amply bearded and tattooed frontman who came off like underground music's answer to John the Baptist.

column1: For all that
column2: Lungfish's music sounds immediately familiar. It's just a handful of cyclical guitar riffs and pulsing
column3: sea-shanty rhythms played in steady repetition. ""A person doesn't have to be Lungfish-literate to know how to hear our music
column4: singer Daniel Higgs told the Baltimore City Paper in 1998
column5: during one of the band's only extensive interviews. ""If you've never heard the song before
column6: after several seconds you have heard the song
column7: and it's gonna do that for a few more minutes."" Like the best punk bands
column8: Lungfish used common tools
column9: but created singular music through sheer force of personality.

column1: Totaling 11 albums
column2: Lungfish's catalog can be intimidating
column3: but 1999's The Unanimous Hour is a good place to start. Recently remastered and repressed by Dischord
column4: Lungfish's long-out-of-print eighth record is among the band's sturdiest statements. On first listen
column5: it sounds a lot like any other Lungfish record: Two or three chords repeat ad infinitum while Higgs belts out apocalyptic psychobabble. But this record has a special place in the Lungfish discography. It's a pivot point between the band's early years and the laser-guided minimalist riffage that would predominate its final three records.

column1: Even before the Internet sped up underground music's turnover rate
column2: Lungfish's evolutionary pace was unthinkably glacial. This is one band that never hired a string section
column3: bought a drum machine
column4: or contemplated a sudden creative left turn. Each record shed a few more superfluous notes
column5: reducing the music to its barest
column6: heaviest essence. Early on
column7: Lungfish tempered their sound with some basic concessions to pop music-- verses and choruses
column8: mainly (""Friend to Friend in the Endtime""
column9: from 1992's Talking Songs For Walking
column10: was hooky enough that it eventually wormed its way into Joan Jett's setlist). But Lungfish spent the subsequent years streamlining their approach.

column1: By the time of The Unanimous Hour
column2: the group had jettisoned conventional song structures in favor of unflagging hypnotic grooves. Opener ""Space Orgy"" barely budges from a single chugging chord that ping-pongs back and forth between guitarist Asa Osborne and bassist Nathan Bell. ""Mated"" thunders along on an unceasing two-note bass line. ""Vulgar Theories"" pushes a single fuzz-drenched riff far enough to stare down the most fully zonked Spacemen 3 tune.

column1: The Unanimous Hour also finds Higgs shifting gears as a vocalist. He further ditches the pretense of linear narrative
column2: embraces hymn-like forms
column3: and makes his words as repetitive as Osborne's riffs. The record holds some of Higgs' most subdued moments (the prayerful chant on ""God's Will"") as well as his most far-out (the hissed lyric about a mirrored
column4: ringing urethra-sprout on ""Metatron""). Epic album closer ""Hallucinatorium"" splits the difference between these two extremes
column5: with parallel lines of prose detailing a family portrait that could have been snatched from a Max Ernst sketchbook.

column1: ""Hallucinatorium"" was initially put to tape as a short-winded instrumental
column2: but upon hearing it
column3: Higgs felt inclined to lay down a few verses. The problem: The original recording was too short to accommodate all the ribcages
column4: hexagon faces
column5: and living prayers the singer hoped to mention. Dischord co-founder and Fugazi frontman Ian MacKaye
column6: who guided the recording sessions
column7: suggested simply slowing the tape down in order to buy a few extra minutes-- an idea he cribbed from hearing the Prince Far I song ""Survival"" played back-to-back with its pitched-down instrumental ""version."" So instead of picking up steam
column8: the song tumbles into a dubby dream-world. Against the screwed-down sounds
column9: Higgs' lyrics become deeper and heavier in their resonance.

column1: During the group's 90s heyday
column2: Lungfish were unfairly lumped in with the emo and hardcore scenes
column3: mostly because their music came out on Dischord. A decade removed from that context
column4: Lungfish records seem more in line with weirdo luminaries like 13th Floor Elevators or contemporary mystic-metal heads like Om. Punk's basic impulse is fairly concrete
column5: while Lungfish's inspiration is strictly otherworldly. The means of transmission
column6: though
column7: remains simple. On The Unanimous Hour
column8:
Lungfish use it to blast their message onward and outward into oblivion.

"|15592.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15592-the-unanimous-hour/|8.1|Aaron Leitko

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16718/homepage_large.aeadea33.jpg|100% Publishing|4645.0|Wiley|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Big Dada']|2011-07-01 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:16.812547|"

The last time grime godfather Wiley put out an album on Big Dada
column2: 2007's Playtime Is Over
column3: he was dropping vague hints about the release being his last solo record. Then ""Wearing My Rolex"" blew up. Everything since has been a jumble of pop moves
column4: renunciations of said pop moves
column5: double-reverse crossovers
column6: beefs
column7: mixtapes
column8: label changes
column9: and that one time last year the UK rapper/producer just up and released eleven zip files of unreleased beats for free. But Wiley also found the time to put together a completely self-contained
column10: no-interference album
column11: give it the autonomy-flaunting title 100% Publishing
column12: and get Big Dada to distribute it. It's almost like he just wanted to pick up where he left off before his chart bid.

column1: Wiley's latest succeeds admirably as a figurative reset button
column2: even as it's run through with the embattled energy and strident confidence of a creator intent on rejecting the sellout accusations that forced a stylistic reboot in the first place. 100% Publishing bristles with the reflexive jabs and on-the-spot opinions that tend to come during long-distance sparring sessions with the nebulous @-flogging masses. The single-minded focus on wrangling a complicated commercial-vs.-underground reputation can feel exhausting at times
column3: but the album's musicality makes up for it
column4: with an improved vocal delivery and a collection of beats that expand on what drew attention to Wiley's production at grime's onset.

column1: ""Some days I'm asking God
column2: but then the Internet is quicker
column3: Wiley says on opener ""Information Age"". The album's distinctly online-borne attitude leads to a lot of defensive boasts. The title track reasserts Wiley's original DIY success story
column4: and ""Your Intuition"" makes admitting past diversions and future changes into a sign of strength
column5: while ""Wise Man and His Words"" stands up for the rapper's ""dual core"" fanbase. Hints of frustration still bubble under the surface; ""One Hit Wonder"" and ""Yonge Street (1
column6: 178 Miles Long)"" thrive on the tension between braggadocio and insecurity. But the main mood is one of defiant optimism. Single ""Numbers in Action"" says it best: ""I reinvent
column7: I'm like a brand new signing.""

column1: Musically
column2: the title track and ""One Hit Wonder"" boost Wiley's vintage ""eskibeat"" style with busier melodies and suppler drums. The stripped-down boom-clap beats for ""Numbers in Action"" and ""Yonge Street"" nod toward retro-modern club rap without all the Eurobeat bombast. Even the more unusual flourishes-- the having-a-larf circus melody of ""Boom Boom Da Na""
column3: or the melancholy piano line of ""Wise Man and His Words""-- have dead-serious rhythmic pulses beneath them. Chirpy shuffle-step love track ""Pink Lady"" and instrospective
column4: R&B-tinged ""Talk About Life"" seem like they'd work better in the context of ""rhythm & grime"" project <i>Chill Out Zone
column5: but these pop-oriented cuts are the exceptions.

column1: 100% Publishing benefits from a deeper focus on the other side of the boards
column2: too. Wiley wasn't always the slickest-flowing rapper
column3: but if there's one part of his game that's really stepped up

Me Doing Standup is a perfect title for a Norm Macdonald's new album in the same way T.I.'s Fuck a Mixtape was: Both concede the nonchalance of their creators and acknowledge that artists at their level have better things to do. But while free mixtapes can boost the profile of a rapper at any level without earning a legit dime
column2: comedy records are at best peripheral income streams for their headliners and useless for most everyone else.

column1: But this release makes sense for Norm Macdonald. While he's managed to be at least on the periphery of cultural awareness over the past two decades on screens both big and small-- ""Saturday Night Live""'s Weekend Update
column2: the cult classic Dirty Work
column3: and the recently canceled ""Sports Show with Norm Macdonald""-- none of it involves him telling jokes on stage for 40 straight minutes. Not even 2006's album Ridiculous
column4: which mostly compiled skits done with his famous friends. But if you liked him in any of those guises
column5: Me Doing Standup is pretty much foolproof
column6: a likable set from a guy who's basically never had to break character in his entire career.

column1: Macdonald's delivery has a certain expressive deadpan to it
column2: a slack-sounding outsider cadence that's quietly insightful and insidiously hilarious. He imparts meaning through small gestures and inflection such as a homespun pronunciation of ""pillow
column3: or an eyebrow raise at his own recognition of the word ""defibrillator."" And Standup might be one of the few comedy records you'll hear that's quite literally timeless. There isn't one instance where Macdonald gives an indication of what year it is. Even stranger is how absorbing it can be even though Norm Macdonald
column4: the human being
column5: is all but removed from the proceedings. I can't think of a comedy album that's less beholden to the life of the actual person who made it. That his own father died from a heart attack comes off as a small asterisk to the larger point of how our own bodies are the terrorists most likely to end our lives (""He wasn't expecting it
column6: he was looking for fuckin' Arabs and shit"")
column7: and he only pledges political allegiance to officials who can eliminate death by their second term.

column1: Indeed
column2: though softened by his affability and implicit self-deprecation
column3: Me Doing Standup is almost entirely obsessed with mortality
column4: even if cancer
column5: heart attacks
column6: murder
column7: and alcoholism are namedropped with the gravity comedy usually grants to consumer products. It comes nowhere near the high-wire truth-telling of Louis C.K.
column8: nor does it really attempt to push any sort of measure of taste. Macdonald acknowledges his existence as absurd to the point where even he hardly takes it seriously. Within the first couple of minutes
column9: he pledges ""that's my goal in life-- is not to die"" even though he ""come[s] from a long line of death."" Ultimately
column10: Me Doing Standup really does end up honoring its title's definitiveness
column11: as it's something like the quintessential Norm Macdonald set: occasionally indulgent
column12: frequently hilarious
column13:
and always managing to make this strange guy come off as likeable everyman.

Your pretentiousness meter should admittedly be swinging toward the far right. Alchemic Heart is the first readily available stateside release from Vampillia

column1: We at least need Vampillia

column12: guitars grinding
column13: and voices bending and clipping. It's as if the orchestra is trying to recreate the static and squall of early black metal-- simply stretched and compressed to sound even more malevolent. Jarboe is eventually left in sudden silence
column14: repeating her mantras with resolve. The conclusion
column15: like the track itself
column16: is melodramatic
column17: but it feels warranted
column18: its impact real.

column1: Despite a similar length
column2: exploration of peak noise
column3: and quiet dénouement
column4: ""Land"" takes a much different approach from one point to another. The graceful cycles of the strings on the first piece are swapped for stunted
column5: staggered phrases here

column7: each layer occasionally syncing into enormous swells of sound. Again
column8: though
column9: Vampillia quiet down as the track nears its 10-minute mark
column10: with little pockets of Keith Jarrett-like piano splashing through an electronic haze. ""Land"" takes its time to rebuild
column11: but when it does

column13: he pulls them forward
column14: making the violins more dramatic and each changing piano chord more momentous. The music hits its crest with about four minutes left
column15: and the sound is infernal. Voices and strings and electronic bursts collide constantly. It's terrifying

It's easy to characterize Curren$y as a weed-rapper and nothing but-- Wiz Khalifa's sticky-mouthed country cousin
column2: say
column3: or a younger Devin the Dude with no singing voice and little sense of vulnerability. And it's true that Curren$y raps more about getting high than most people do
column4: and that his fluid
column5: heavy-lidded drawl does a better job evoking the experience. But Curren$y's become an interesting figure with a lot going on
column6: and to focus on his cannabis appetite is to ignore some of the things that make him one of the more dependable working rappers. For one thing
column7: he's become a workhorse. In the past year
column8: he's put out four ridiculously solid solo releases-- and that's not counting his kinda-sucky Return to the Winner's Circle mixtape
column9: his crew's Jet Life to the Next Life mixtape
column10: or his scores of guest appearances on other people's tracks. Those four solid releases paint a picture of a musical adventurer
column11: a guy who tests himself against a new style of production whenever he gets bored.

column1: On last year's two Pilot Talk albums
column2: Curren$y made his way through producer Ski Beatz' lush shag-carpet psychedelic soul
column3: a luxurious retro sound. Then
column4: a couple of months ago
column5: he released the free Alchemist-produced Covert Coup EP
column6: which gave him a chance to navigate Alc's tense
column7: broken boom-bap-- a dizzy
column8: refracted take on classic New York rap. Compared to those other records
column9: the sound on Weekend at Burnie's is remarkably warm and approachable
column10: and it brings Curren$y closer to the sound of current radio-rap than he's been in a while-- though
column11: of course
column12: he's still a long way from any serious rotation. For this one
column13: he links up with producer Monsta Beatz
column14: whose diffuse
column15: melodic synths sound like a low-key version of the smoothly emotive style that's helped turn Drake and Wiz Khalifa into stars. The music on Weekend at Burnie's drifts by in an exceedingly pleasant haze.

column1: Now
column2: Weekend at Burnie's won't turn Curren$y into anyone's idea of a star. His idea of a chorus is still something like this: ""Get paid
column3: get paid my nigga
column4: get [long pause] paaaid."" And his rap style doesn't employ the sort of attention-grabbing punchlines that leap through club speakers to grab you. Instead
column5: his delivery is more an unhurried run-on that hits various ideas and images along the way without pounding any of them home. Though the music on his albums has changed
column6: his slippery delivery really hasn't
column7: and it's remarkable how completely at home he sounds on just about any form of beat that he attempts. So maybe the best thing about Weekend at Burnie's is the way these unassuming Monsta Beatz tracks give him room to operate. You can hear the man better on this album than you can on many of his recent efforts. And that gives us plenty of room to admire his slick little turns of phrase. A line like this one deserves to be heard: ""Haters tryna deplete my shine like venetian blinds/ But son do what the sun do: rise.""

column1: In terms of subject matter
column2: Burnie's doesn't exactly push Curren$y outside of his comfort zone. You never get the impression that much is at stake for Curren$y
column3: even if this is his first commercial release since signing his new Warner Bros. deal. Protégés Trademark and Young Roddy both get plenty of mic time; beyond a single too-brief Fiend verse
column4: they're the album's only guests. We never get to hear Curren$y expressing any sort of drive or urgency or emotion; he's always happy to rhyme ""ease"" with ""breeze."" ""She Don't Want a Man"" is a fairly thin relationship-based story-rap that succeeds mostly because of a smeary cinematic keyboard sound that reminds me of Mario Winans' ""I Don't Want to Know"". But Curren$y's a rapper so sharp and confident that he never needs to leave his comfort zone
column5: and it's a lot of fun to hear him flexing his style on a sunnier sound palette.

column1: On ""JLC""
column2: near the end of the album
column3: Curren$y indulges in a bit of paranoiac drug-dealer talk: ""Through text message
column4: we plot the takeover/ Can't talk out loud 'round these chauffeurs/ Way on the outskirts of town
column5: we have slick meetings/ Lookin' over our shoulders-- muhfuckin' lip readers."" I have no idea if any of this comes from Curren$y's personal experience or if he's just spinning yarns
column6: but it's a packed-tight bit of writing
column7: and he sounds unflappable as ever delivering it. In a moment like that
column8: where you hear a guy deliver those dense lines so nonchalantly
column9: you know you're in secure hands. Weekend at Burnie's
column10: like so many other recent Curren$y releases
column11: is full of those moments. This guy is still on a very serious roll
column12:
and it doesn't seem to be anywhere near over.

Energy without insight is monotonous. Insight without humor is preachy. Humor without frustration is toothless. Frustration without humanity is destructive. And humanity without energy is defeatist. If an album operates with the purpose of being a big noisy fuck-shit-up machine
column3: missing just one of those elements can leave you with an overbearing mess
column4: where every speaker-rattling burst of noise or cathartically screamed hook turns you back instead of getting you all riled up. Sacramento punk-rap outfit Death Grips are known for starting frothing mosh pits with a style that seems in keeping with the hardcore-meets-hip-hop confluence that first ran through skate culture a few decades back. Exmilitary
column5: their free mixtape
column6: is a bludgeoning slab of hostility that plays like both sides of a circa-1987 Cro-Mags b/w Just-Ice home tape bleeding through each other.

column1: Exmilitary avoids any of the flaws outlined above
column2: but it's still a potentially alienating album: unnerving when you're not on its aggro wavelength
column3: inviting when you are
column4: and transfixing either way
column5: thanks to the aggregate work of Death Grips' core. The raspy
column6: deliberate MC Ride doesn't so much flow as bellow. Producer/videographer Flatlander and co-producer Info Warrior hit both sides of the audio-visual equation with overloaded noise (check the ""Guillotine"" video for starters). Additional vocalist Mexican Girl skulks in the background and spits venom for occasional effective emphasis. And Zach Hill
column7: the Hella drummer-- recently heard on Marnie Stern's self-titled album-- provides some of the live percussion elements. But isolating each member's specific contributions seems like a good way to make an overwhelming sound seem flimsier than it really is.

column1: That said
column2: MC Ride might be the most upfront element. His tendency to go hard in the rawest way possible with doomsayer verses has slotted him in a strange no-man's land between Southern and avant-rap. His tangled
column3: diabolical lyrics are wrapped up in lust
column4: drug panic
column5: metaphysical power-tripping
column6: and political agitation
column7: and he delivers them as if every syllable were an exclamation point. And while there's not a ton of nuance
column8: there's a surprising versatility
column9: as Ride's rhymes range from malevolent to anxious to smart-assed. Monolithic and harsh
column10: his voice sounds powerful doubling up the beats to the point where it doesn't even seem like a problem when it's halfway buried in the mix.

column1: The production does its damnedest to capture punk aggression for a hip-hop context without pushing things too far in either direction. Fuck-the-cops anthem ""Klink"" invokes Black Flag's ""Rise Above""
column2: the opening scream from Bad Brains' ""Supertouch/Shitfit"" punctuates ""Takyon (Death Yon)""
column3: and the beat to ""Spread Eagle Cross the Block"" is built sturdily around Link Wray's ""Rumble"". On sex-maniac anthem ""I Want It I Need It (Death Heated)""
column4: a devastating hijack of Pink Floyd's ""Interstellar Overdrive"" perfectly conjures up this music's intersection of choppy
column5: riff-heavy beat assault and psychedelic sprawl. Juke-inflected bangers like ""Thru the Walls"" and ""Blood Creepin"" blur Exmilitary's stylistic lines
column6: and that's good-- it means not having to worry about scene purity or crossover potential
column7:
and focusing instead on just how much ferocity you can take.

albeit one that will appeal primarily to listeners well within the core dance music audience.

column7: limited run coming to the United States earlier this year. These are the essentials. Over the past few months

column1: However
column2: Sound Kapital isn't so much an 80s throwback in sound as in its spirit of sincerity. A handful of songs on the record were inspired by the Furs' 2010 visit to Burma
column3: where they performed alongside bands who were quite literally underground
column4: forced to perform out of sight of the oppressive local authorities
column5: with minimal access to electricity

But the humbly lo-tech take-- all shuffling drum-machine breaks and squelching frequencies-- feels very true to the environment that inspired it
column7: where music is exchanged via pirate radio and the power can be suddenly cut at any moment. The more frenzied companion track ""Cheap Music"" reframes the same scene

for that matter-- suggests this heart's still got a lot left to burn.

With each successive move dubstep makes toward bass-drop bombast
column3: there's been an equal if less prominent retreat in the opposite direction-- grainy and pared back

column1: The tracks largely come from unknown producers
column2: but they're not thin or pedestrian. Instead
column3: they're rock-solid utilitarian affairs with titanic drum sounds and stormy soul samples. There are a few curveballs
column4: like the bubbling quasi-eastern No I.D. beat on ""Ready Set Go""
column5: or the dazed Flying Lotus collaboration ""Swimming"". But even with those songs
column6: the record still hangs together beautifully
column7: offering up stylistic wrinkles while mostly sticking to a basic Southern trad-rap sound. Lyrically
column8: Mike emits plenty of fury
column9: decrying the police shooting of Oscar Grant and airing out some reservations in Obama: ""We appreciate the way you delegate for Henry Gates/ But what about your people slaving in the fields everyday?"" At one point
column10: he even gets all What's the Matter With Kansas?
column11: blasting white people for voting against their own economic interests
column12: caving to the manipulation of the powerful because they've been convinced they're powerful. Smart stuff
column13: but when it comes time to dish out some lurid street-level threats
column14: he delivers: ""Have my Africans eat his face like he's some bush meat.""

column1: As Mike's persona has developed
column2: he's figured out what he's good at. On Pl3dge
column3: he caters directly to the audience he's already built
column4: going so far as to offer sequels to two of his best-loved recent songs
column5: ""That's Life"" and ""God in the Building"". And a remix to ""Ready Set Go"" even gives Mike's audience the feel-good reunion with Big Boi that they've been hoping for. But even at his most consistent
column6: Mike is still capable of surprising
column7: as on the riff from ""That's Life II""
column8: where he talks about Democrats being as bad as Republicans (""You can disrespect presidents and call 'em socialists/ But Palin and Pelosi both gon' have you broke as shit"")
column9: or Mike's decision to share the spotlight with amazing ranted promos from the titular wrestling legend on ""Ric Flair"". These aren't huge left turns
column10: but they don't have to be. Pl3dge is constructed simply as a sturdy platform for one of rap's fiercest and most incisive voices
column11:
and it achieves that goal completely.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16700/homepage_large.d562d2f5.jpg|The Miners' Hymns|2199.0|Jóhann Jóhannsson|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fat Cat']|2011-06-28 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:26.933778|"

Jóhann Jóhannsson's The Miners' Hymns is the instrumental soundtrack to Bill Morrison's dolefully spare documentary about the history of coal mining in northern England. As such
column2: it will not make a stellar accompaniment to your next barbecue.  Composed for brass ensemble
column3: organ
column4: and a light scrim of electronics
column5: the album takes you places that are woefully ill-suited to early summer; it feels perfect for a grim
column6: drizzly late autumn
column7: when wet leaves are choking gutters and the air carries the threat of pneumonia. This might not be the most inviting sound world to contemplate
column8: but Jóhannsson's confident touch with it is powerful
column9: and The Miners' Hymns creeps into your consciousness like a musty attic draft.

column1: Jóhannsson builds the album's six pieces out of a series of low tones echoing faintly across a distance
column2: like ships through fog. Extended periods of charged silence separate each burst. The structure is firmly ""EVENT-pause-EVENT""-- a meek cluster of sound
column3: an evaporation of echoes
column4: a blank band of dead space. The effect is like slipping pebbles in a pond
column5: watching the ripples distort your reflection
column6: and then waiting for the surface to clear. Jóhannsson's pacing with this material is patient unto funereal
column7: and occasionally the music appears to be just hanging there. But train your focus on it
column8: and you will sense the slowly darkening atmosphere. The lonely horn figure of ""Freedom From Want and Fear""
column9: for example
column10: gathers weight with each repetition
column11: so that when it blares
column12: halfway through the track
column13: the contrast registers like a flash of heat lightning.

column1: The album was recorded in a Durham cathedral
column2: and Jóhannsson has given the music a distinctly liturgical feel--  the descending bassline in ""There Is No Safe Side But the Side of Truth"" mimics the groaning sway of Renaissance sacred music. And when two sourly whining quarter tones give way to a gorgeously warm brass chorale in ""The Cause of Labour Is the Hope of the World""
column3: the album's final track
column4: it feels like an epiphany
column5: a generous flooding of light that casts a backward glow on all the gloom and pallor that preceded it. Suddenly
column6: the album's mood retroactively shifts. It's not a bleak autumn record; it's a halcyon autumn record
column7: bathed in inviting half-light. I am reminded of playing basketball at dusk
column8: and that imperceptible moment when you just can't see anymore and everyone reluctantly heads inside. It's a quietly exhilarating ""hallelujah"" that depends entirely on the previous 45 minutes of buildup for its weight
column9:
a nice reminder that some things are worth sticking it out for.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16707/homepage_large.20a792b2.jpg|Sagara|5718.0|diskJokke|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Smalltown Supersound']|2011-06-28 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:28.946727|"

So far
column2: Oslo-based producer diskJokke (Joachim Dyrdahl) has been the best kind of anonymous: a producer beholden to a genre (space disco) who consistently pumps out tidy
column3: form-fitting jams. His music is defined as much by its constraints-- self-imposed
column4: mostly-- as by its content (that he has worked as a mathematician makes perfect sense). But here
column5: Dyrdahl has strays from the strictures of beatific electronic music in favor of tone-poem ambience.

column1: Sagara was commissioned by Norway's Øya festival
column2: which provided Dyrdahl the resources to travel to a place of his choosing and study music. After sampling musicians in Bali and Java
column3: Dyrdahl abandoned the idea of a dance album and instead focused on incorporating the tones and modalities of Gamelan music into pillow-soft mood pieces. It's not much of a stretch: Gamelan is typically busier and noisier than Sagara
column4: but its massing of percussive sounds can lead to an ethereal blur. Dyrdahl takes that blur and spreads it
column5: jam-like
column6: over long instrumental passages.

column1: The resulting sound isn't ""new"" unless you're the type of person who owns only diskJokke albums
column2: but Dyrdahl's background as a classically trained violinist and electronic producer serves him well here. Sagara has a rich
column3: saturated ambience that deserves a fine sound system and a generous twist of the volume knob
column4: but it's uneventful in a way that suggests patience. This is nowhere more evident than on ""Mandena"" which
column5: after three minutes of bare nothingness
column6: acquires a misty palpitation and a splattering of percussive tones. At just over 35 minutes long
column7: Sagara is refreshingly unimpressed with its own concept or bigness. It is a short
column8: loving letter from Dyrdahl to a music and region that has inspired him.

column1: It's not until the final track
column2: ""Panutup""
column3: that Dyrdahl's instincts as a dance producer get the best of him. He lifts his tonal haze
column4: offers some gorgeous ringing chords and field recordings before introducing-- finally!-- a thwumping disco bassline and a steady
column5: surging kick drum. Dyrdahl spins this sudden percussiveness into a skyward
column6: uplifting Balearic anthem before fading it out again. It's a moment of such surprising and stunning motion that it's possible to view the previous 30 minutes of music as one long
column7: patient build. (There is an irony to the notion that the one time Dyrdahl really approaches the beauty and mysticism of Gamelan is when he interrupts his experiment and returns to his craft.) Dyrdahl never received enough credit for the excellent sound design of his work
column8: and while Sagara seems nothing more than an interesting detour
column9:
his careful ear and sense of structure are here in spades.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16690/homepage_large.60d59e95.jpg|Black Up|28847.0|Shabazz Palaces|['Rap']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2011-06-27 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:29.634879|"

Shabazz Palaces emerged two years ago with an air of carefully cultivated mystery: Two EPs appeared
column2: identified only by the Arabic patches on their covers. The music was some of the most exploratory hip-hop of the year
column3: an enticing batch of fragmented raps and woozy
column4: disorienting beats. You could find precedents for this stuff-- the amorphous wanderings of cLOUDDEAD
column5: the jazz rap of the early 1990s-- but these EPs were largely on some sui generis shit: Nothing else out there sounded quite like Shabazz Palaces.

column1: The Shabazz Palaces and Of Light EPs featured an MC going by the name Palaceer Lazaro
column2: and he introduced an alternately glittering and gritty urban noir taking place in the unlikely setting of Seattle. That the reedy yet resonant voice behind Palaceer's raps was readily identifiable as Ishmael ""Butterfly"" Butler of downtempo rap collective Digable Planets (and
column3: later
column4: Cherrywine) did little to lift the shroud. Butler declined interviews and dodged photographers
column5: and when he did speak
column6: his answers were as evasive as his raps were richly
column7: if obliquely
column8: illustrative.

column1: His reticence was an attempt to let the music speak for itself and avoid comparisons to his previous acts (adding some alluring intrigue didn't hurt). And some comparisons are inevitable: The EPs continued the darkening trend that occurred in between Digable's unlikely breakthrough Reachin' (A New Refutation of Time and Space) and thornier follow-up Blowout Comb
column2: and which developed further with the sinister funk of Cherrywine. But if Shabazz Palaces' first phase was about building a mystique
column3: their Sub Pop debut is the product of opening up. Black Up lets some sunlight in
column4: breathes fresh air
column5: and finds Butler returning to an occasionally lighter flow
column6: the most unburdened he's sounded since the world first heard him. Which is not to say that these are easy
column7: uncomplicated songs. Butler continues to eschew traditional verse-chorus structures in favor of tracks that unpredictably diverge and then pool into lone
column8: evocative words or concise chants. And if some of Butler's rhymes and sonics are breezier than before
column9: his tracks still retain their moody
column10: hard-thudding
column11: and sometimes psychedelic atmospheres.

column1: Most of these tracks end somewhere very different from where they begin. ""Free Press and Curl"" opens the album with a down but defiant rap (""Musically and bitch-wise
column2: too/ I lost the best beat that I had"") delivered over stuttering crunching drums and bass vibrations. Three minutes in
column3: the tempo slows into a kind of galley song
column4: a murky drift over which Butler fires off a couple of final
column5: biblically imperative (""thou shalt..."") verses. ""An echo from the hosts that profess infinitum"" (the album's track titles throughout are fascinating) begins as a playground chant stretched and smeared into a queasy loop over muffled kick and grainy snare. But then after a minute
column6: everything drops out for a spooky mbira solo from Shabazz sideman and percussionist Tendai Maraire. ""Youlogy"" starts as a busy
column7: druggy swirl-- a heaving bass
column8: a synth wobbling in one ear
column9: voices cut and pasted
column10: echoing asymmetrically
column11: everything dropping out on the word ""high"" in ""to get you HIGH""-- and then breaks for some jazz trumpet and snippets of stylized dialogue
column12: before proceeding as an altogether different
column13: relatively cleared-out
column14: bass-and-drum track.

column1: That Shabazz Palaces' songs follow such inscrutable routes makes it all the more striking when they coalesce around a repeated word or phrase. ""Free Press"" builds up to the rousing chant
column2: ""You know I'm free!"" over a ghosted gospel chorus. On ""Are You... Can You... Were You? (Felt)""
column3: Butler exclaims
column4: over ringing piano notes
column5: wafting strings
column6: and one great tinfoil handclap that swings in just half a beat later than expected
column7: ""It's a feeling!"" ""Recollections of the Wraith"" glides in on two of the album's most effortless choruses
column8: Butler first proclaiming/promising
column9: ""Tonight!"" over a swooning
column10: oohing female vocal
column11: and then requesting
column12: ""Clear some space out/ So we can space out."" That last one is about as involved as any chorus here gets-- these are hooks boiled down to their most essential.

column1: Even forays into traditional structure end up typically idiosyncratic. The album's lone loverman song comes out a treatise-- well
column2: actually
column3: ""A treatease dedicated to The Avian Airess from North East Nubis (1000 questions
column4: 1 answer)"". It's birds and bees rendered as bop poetry
column5: working up to an insistently smooth come-on line that turns from astral to anatomical with the addition of one little two-letter word: ""I want to be there/ Let me be in there."" The record's dis track
column6: ""yeah you""
column7: snarls and bites but it also laments and ends as a breathless
column8: headlong exorcism. All this is both in keeping with Butler's track record and indicative of his status as a hip-hop elder
column9: an MC with some well-earned gray in his goatee. And it's deeply refreshing to hear an artist who exudes such depth and consideration.

column1: Still
column2: Butler is hardly yelling the kids off his lawn-- in fact
column3: two of Black Up's best moments come from young guest stars THEESatisfaction
column4: a similarly ""afro-eccentric"" female duo with whom Shabazz Palaces have been collaborating for much of the past year. Cat Satisfaction lends her rich singing voice to the dusty
column5: repurposed jazz of ""Endeavors For Never (The last time we spoke you said you were not here. I saw you though.)""
column6: while partner Thee Stasia raps over the hard
column7: roboticized boom bap of album closer ""Swerve... The reeping of all that is worthwhile (Noir not withstanding)"". That the last sound you hear on the album is one of THEESatisfaction's voices echoing out into the ether feels like an anointment and a look ahead (news that Sub Pop signed the duo leaked back in February).

column1: For all his recent (relative) forthrightness
column2: Butler is still fascinated by art's ability to communicate what conversations cannot. ""I can't explain it with words/ I have to do it
column3: he raps on one song; on another
column4: he delivers one of the album's catchiest
column5: most motivating maxims: ""If you talk about it
column6: it's a show/ But if you move about it
column7: then it's a go."" Beyond the ""just do it"" swooshing of these lines is a meatier paradox: that Butler uses a lyrical form to decry the limitations of words and exalt the meaningfulness of action. In Shabazz Palaces
column8: Butler enacts the union of these opposites-- words as action
column9:
action into words-- and it's no exaggeration to call this transmutation what it is: magic.

"|15570.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15570-black-up/|8.8|Eric Grandy

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16691/homepage_large.8582641b.jpg|Blanck Mass|29644.0|Blanck Mass|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rock Action']|2011-06-27 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:30.088525|"

The sheer maximal strength of Fuck Buttons' second album Tarot Sport was something to marvel at. It felt as if the duo of Benjamin John Power and Andrew Hung were shifting around vast tectonic plates of noise
column2: daring one another to see how much detail their music could retain while pushing the volume firmly into the red. That love of scale remains firmly intact on Power's debut album under his Blanck Mass moniker
column3: although he's purposefully tempered its overall feel with a more reflective bent. This is a themed work
column4: based around ""cerebral hypoxia and the beautiful complexity of the natural world"" according to the Blanck Mass Bandcamp page. At times it crosses paths with the folksy elements of the Ghost Box aesthetic
column5: where creepy electronics are twisted to produce the kind of deadened atmosphere found in old horror flicks like Witchfinder General. It sometimes shares that film's lack of refinement
column6: with Power allowing his sounds to loop over vast expanses of time
column7: matching Fuck Buttons' prowess for chiseling crude beauty from repetition.

column1: Much of this music is rooted in the ambient tradition; there are no beats
column2: and Power often leans heavily on a wash of wave-like noise similar to what Brian Eno cultivated on ""Alternative 3"" from Music for Films. On first glance it can feel like there's little structure underpinning the glass-like inflections of ""Sifted Gold"" or ""Chernobyl""
column3: but dig a little deeper and subtle shifts in tone and mood gradually unravel. It demonstrates how adept Power has become at adding and subtracting layers of gentle abstraction in his music. Blanck Mass also shows how well he can foster an atmosphere of unease without pushing everything skyward all the time. Occasionally it threatens to topple over into a Fuck Buttons-style morass of jagged edges
column4: but on songs like ""Sundowner"" the prickly distortion dissolves into clear digital glitchiness. The track has a woozy atmosphere
column5: causing it to feel like Power and his table of instruments are rocking back and forth on a creaky old ocean liner.

column1: Elsewhere the Blanck Mass sound sinks into introspection. ""Sub Serious"" is a densely layered piece full of twinkling loops and percussion elements that make it sound like it was recorded in the middle of a rain forest. The mood subtly slides from pessimism to dejection throughout; on ""Sub Serious"" it's the former
column2: while the similar ""Land Disasters"" and ""Icke's Struggle"" use great swells of synth to generate an air of sadness. The latter two songs both use sampled birdsong
column3: one of the few overt attempts to maintain the natural-world theme. Occasionally Power steps close to his other band's territory
column4: particularly on ""Land Disasters""
column5: where he channels that wall of gnarly distortion again and sets it to the kind of icy interference that dominated ""Sundowner"". Those two tracks feel like distant cousins here
column6: both feeding off the same kind of ultra-frosty banks of towering electronics that Power was clearly obsessed with creating during the making of this record.

column1: Blanck Mass reaches its apex in the form of the extraordinary 13-and-a-half minute ""What You Know"". The shifts in tone encompass many of this album's contrasting styles
column2: including the glacial pile-ups of noise and the dips into impossibly quiet reflection. At its close there's even a hint of groove as a bass synth expands and contracts
column3: ultimately blocking out the rest of Power's palette and opening up new lands for him to explore with this project. The air of serenity shouldn't come as a surprise to anyone familiar with Fuck Buttons' work-- in many ways Blanck Mass functions as a continuation of the bittersweet emotion pulled out of the closing Tarot Sport track ""Flight of the Feathered Serpent"". But this mostly feels like Power taking all his musical impulses and tunneling inward toward a more nuanced spot. The shadow of his other band always feels like it's on his shoulder
column4:
but that tension between his past and present guises is what makes this work so well. Blanck Mass is all about Power excavating new domains while still working within that great glut of voluminous space he's already mapped out.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16672/homepage_large.a6fc6ef6.jpg|Thora Vukk|23762.0|Robag Wruhme|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Pampa']|2011-06-27 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:30.639620|"

A veteran of Germany's electronic music scene
column2: Robag Wruhme released one of minimal techno's more idiosyncratic albums
column3: Wuzzelbud ""KK""
column4: in 2004. Since then he has quietly issued a handful of singles. In January
column5: Wruhme-- né Gabor Schablitzki-- put together a sly
column6: melodic mix for Cologne's Kompakt
column7: followed in April by Thora Vukk. Released on DJ Koze's increasingly impressive Pampa imprint
column8: Wruhme's second LP is an elegant
column9: eminently listenable blend of chirpy beats
column10: homespun voices
column11: and sighing keyboards.

column1: Wruhme's music has taken a path similar to that of one of his contemporaries
column2: Isolée; tracks that once feasted on funny noises and unexpected pops have been smoothed over
column3: like practical jokers settling into masters of the quip. Thora Vukk also has something in common with Nicolas Jaar's Space Is Only Noise; both are albums of modest treated-keys beauty
column4: though Wruhme's music is deeply rooted in house traditions and tempos that Jaar's plays fast and loose with (or
column5: more accurately
column6: slow and loose).

column1: Thora Vukk is a sunrise album
column2: one that sits lightly. Its tracks don't build and peak so much as arrive and taper. ""Brucke Eins""
column3: already a placid interlude featuring dollops of organ
column4: ends with someone calmly pecking at a keyboard. Wruhme uses voices sparingly but memorably; ""Pnom Gobal"" features a back-and-forth between casual scatting and a string section. The closest Thora Vukk comes to cresting is a breakdown during ""Tulpa Ovi""
column5: in which a skittering break comes to a stop for joyful call and response between a performer and a child audience.

column1: It's telling that Thora Vukk's most memorable moment occurs when the music all but drops out
column2: but it's also misleading. Wruhme's sound design is careful and deep; the album's homespun feel is in tone only (it would be lazy to compare it to the sweet
column3: sepia-toned photograph on the album's cover
column4: but
column5: well
column6: yeah). He leaves plenty of space between the muted chirps of his drums and those lovely velvet keys
column7: and there's lots to be gained by playing the record loudly on a good system. Wruhme's career path and stature make Thora Vukk the type of album that never escapes the clutches of house connoisseurs
column8:
but fans of Jaar and even Four Tet will find a lot to like in its pacing and beauty.

column3: Brooklyn electronic artist Laurel Halo's King Felix gained significant notice among fans of murky electronic pop. The EP secured official release by the end of the year through Hippos in Tanks
column4: and the increased attention Halo was drawing made sense. King Felix prominently featured Halo's expansive vocal range (also exercised on Ford & Lopatin's Games-era cut ""Strawberry Skies"") doing curly-cues and loop-de-loops above beds of tickled
column5: arpeggiated synths; the results recalled Dirty Projectors' disjointed acrobatics as much as the cosmic analog odysseys of Brooklyn pal Daniel Lopatin's Oneohtrix Point Never. As the electrifying cover art of the Hippos in Tanks re-release suggested
column6: the music possessed a strange
column7: swarming quality
column8: originating at a central point and covering everything in its path.

column1: King Felix sounded like a blueprint for something larger and more sweeping
column2: a hint at greater potential not quite realized. But on Halo's latest EP
column3: Hour Logic
column4: she takes a sharp left turn
column5: largely ditching anything that resembles conventional melody for dark
column6: propulsive rhythms where her beats run wild. As heard here
column7: Halo's version of dance music comes over as sterile and inert-- the beats are there
column8: but they never coalesce into anything in particular. When they're not static (as they are on the constant drip of ""Aquifer"") they wind up lost in the clutter. She moves through some intriguing ideas-- the acid squiggles that surface near the end of the title track
column9: ""Speed of Rain""'s dewy beat-broken opening-- but there's a lack of momentum and the tedium disrupts Hour Logic's flow.

column1: For all its relative experimentation
column2: the EP's most impressive moment takes place during  ""Constant Index""
column3: which finds Halo's distant cries submerged in synth washes and long stretches of delay. It's no coincidence that Halo is at her best when returning to-- and refining-- the ideas presented on King Felix. So Hour Logic ultimately seems like an intermittently interesting misstep
column4:
a bold experiment that doesn't quite come off.
