Graham Wright plays an often-overlooked role (keyboardist) in an often-underrated band (Tokyo Police Club)
column2: so it's not like his solo bow comes with a lot of the usual baggage. Hell
column3: even when the Hold Steady's ivory-tickler Franz Nicolay embarked on a similar side project
column4: certain expectations came with the mustache. All we know is that there's label machinery legitimizing Shirts vs. Skins as more than just downtime with Bandcamp
column5: that it's deemed worthy of our attention by more than just the guy who made it. So what does Wright have to say?

column1: Well
column2: to find out
column3: you have to get past ""Chucklefucks""
column4: which unwisely decides to incorporate its title-- one of the least euphonious not-quite words in the English language-- into Wright's prickly
column5: pitter-patter melody. It just piles on from there. Soon come the skittering drum machines and lyrics that lean heavy on signifiers instead of insight (""the party kids
column6: ""the party
column7: ""pockets overflowing with designer drugs"")
column8: the sort of things usually found on the relationship-altering demo CD your friend made that you'll never unhear.

column1: But after that mercifully brief 80 seconds
column2: ""Heaven's Just for Movie Makers"" is a comparatively welcome respite
column3: hewing more towards TPC's modes of zippy tempos
column4: generously upfront vocals
column5: and sharp
column6: concise hooks. It's also more indicative of Shirts vs. Skins as a whole. The album hangs looser than Wright's main gig
column7: however
column8: dabbling in rootsy singer-songwriter fare
column9: giddy synth-pop
column10: and too-cute saxophone skronk. The lyrics also lack TPC leader Dave Monks' cryptic
column11: literary bent. They tend toward straightforward girl talk laced with proper nouns
column12: recalling the ""like K-Ci & JoJo
column13: like Sonny and Cher
column14: you're Tina but I'm not Ike"" kicker from ""Favourite Colour""
column15: off of Champ
column16: the 2010 album by Wright's main band.

column1: All of which means that if you can trust I'm using the phrase ""Welcome Interstate Managers-era Fountains of Wayne"" as a sales pitch rather than an exit cue
column2: this might be in your wheelhouse. Shirts vs. Skins does feel weirdly out of time in 2011
column3: its power-pop classicism and sense of irony having a decidedly mid-1990s vibe that values kitsch over actual nostalgia. ""Soviet Race""
column4: in particular
column5: could've found refuge in the buzzbin. Its narrative about astronauts and international espionage doesn't mean much upon the slightest inspection
column6: but it's all prelude to Wright's biggest chorus
column7: which takes obvious pleasure at stressing
column8: ""I was shitfaced!"" while serving a softball to the egghead critics who generally eat this stuff up (""I read your book... I give it three stars out of a possible five"").

column1: To Wright's credit
column2: Shirts vs. Skins actually manages to be catchier in a more straightforward way than either Champ or its 2008 predecessor Elephant Shell
column3: two records that certainly didn't lack hooks. Whether or not you want these songs to stick in your head is another matter entirely
column4: and it'll be largely based on your tolerance toward the standard options in the power-pop package deal-- namely
column5: the stilted dialog and single-serve plots that make it feel more like a collection of sitcoms than songs; the overbearing pursuit of cleverness; and the weirdly dismissive attitude toward females that often reduces them to a single crush-worthy quirk or some incorporeal straw-woman that dumped your sorry ass.

column1: You might end up taking the latter's side on ""Leftovers""
column2: which stretches a single relatable image way too far. ""Something Stupid"" quotes Uncle Tupelo but is mostly an unspoken homage to Fountain of Wayne's ""She's Got a Problem""
column3: or any other song that disguises wimpy condescension as actual concern. Likewise
column4: ""Canadian Thanksgiving"" poses as brotherly advice to a moony-eyed teen but more or less turns into a bro's tall tale about a pretty girl who gets a few drinks in her and inevitably ends up embarrassing herself in a restaurant bathroom.

column1: Despite all of the above
column2: this album might still hold a huge appeal for listeners. This stuff's not unlike gangsta rap-- you come for the formalism and escapist pleasures
column3: not for the nuanced take on gender relations. But for such a casual record
column4: Shirts vs. Skins can occasionally strike at a deeper discussion. Power-pop of this sort is often overlooked
column5: but it can also be stifling taken in large doses-- Wright's clear talent and occasional charm notwithstanding. The wacky neighbor POV wears pretty thin
column6:
but ultimately more oppressive is the glorification of generic heartbreak. It makes allowances for juvenile self-absorption that actual romance never does.

The story of Suede splits well into two acts: the first version of the band
column2: with guitarist Bernard Butler
column3: and the second version of the band
column4: with Butler gone and replaced by Richard Oakes
column5: as well as keyboardist Neil Codling. The first version of the band released two albums
column6: the crackling
column7: sexually aggressive debut and the grotesque
column8: brilliant
column9: and dark follow-up
column10: Dog Man Star
column11: made as Butler and the rest of the band were pulling apart. The original version of the band fed on the tension between its two songwriters
column12: Butler and vocalist Brett Anderson
column13: and the records it made were harrowing and complex
column14: both musically and lyrically.

column1: When the band reconstituted after its messy split with its guitarist
column2: Anderson was in no mood to make another Dog Man Star. It's a difficult kind of record to follow up-- to come back with something that aimed for the same epic sweep and catharsis of that album would have ensured failure. Instead
column3: when Anderson began to write with his new partners
column4: he sought to change almost everything. The new Suede would be a very different band from its predecessor
column5: even though it had the same singer and rhythm section. The new pieces had a lot to say about that. Oakes and Codling immediately began writing new material for the band
column6: and Anderson found that what they were writing fit well with the new direction he hoped to take the band in.

column1: It wasn't a clean stylistic break
column2: necessarily. Oakes had found his way into the band by sending a demo tape to the Suede fan club; when Anderson overheard drummer Simon Gilbert listening to it
column3: he thought it was an old Butler demo
column4: and the 17-year-old guitarist vaulted to front of the long line of people auditioning to be Suede's newest member. Codling came to the band more conventionally: He was Gilbert's cousin
column5: and the new songs they'd been working on immediately after Oakes joined required keyboards
column6: so he was hired. This new three-way creative partnership was considerably less volatile than the Anderson/Butler pair
column7: and partly as a result
column8: the music lost its dark edge.

column1: Back in the band's early days
column2: Suede were heralded as one of the banner acts of the UK music media's new Britpop obsession-- a fact that chagrined and even disgusted Anderson-- and Dog Man Star had in some respects been Anderson's attempt to show that Suede were something distinct from Britpop. The band's next album
column3: Coming Up
column4: released in 1996
column5: feels somewhat like Suede jumping back on board the movement it helped launch. At the very least
column6: it finds the band returning to its glam-rock roots
column7: and it's about the most day-glo rock record this side of Ziggy Stardust
column8: with an intentionally garish Peter Saville sleeve to match. It vaulted the band back to massive commercial success in the UK
column9: selling over a million and a half copies and spawning five top 10 singles.

column1: Listening today
column2: the album's biggest shortcoming is its lack of low-end. Producer Ed Buller chose to highlight the vocals
column3: guitar
column4: and synths over the band's formidable rhythm section
column5: a decision that unfortunately leaves the album's roughly 50/50 mix of bouncy pop songs and melancholy ballads sounding a little thin. Coming Up is still a very good album
column6: though. Anderson's lyrics are considerably more superficial and humorous than they had been in the past; this would eventually become a problem
column7: but on uptempo
column8: fluorescent rock songs like ""Beautiful Ones"" and ""Trash"" it works because these songs are just so damned catchy. And there is a lot of depth in the ballads. ""By the Sea""
column9: actually written by Anderson during the Butler years
column10: is simply beautiful and heartbreaking
column11: while ""Saturday Night"" works perfectly as a long exhalation at the end of the album's long and disorienting party.

column1: The album is reissued with all of its contemporary B-sides
column2: minus the Neil Codling demo ""Digging a Hole""
column3: which is omitted without explanation. This is very important
column4: because there's a whole second album on disc two that's easily as good as Coming Up itself. The epic slash of ""Every Monday Morning Comes""
column5: the relentless dub stomp of ""WSD""
column6: the grinding descent into debauchery of ""Europe Is Our Playground""
column7: the exhilarating pop rush of ""Sound of the Streets"" and Anderson's baritone-voiced lead on the scuzzy
column8: Dog Man Star-ish rock song ""Have You Ever Been This Low?"" are all essential to understanding just how versatile this band was at this point in its career
column9: and that's just a sampling of the 19 B-sides included on this set. This is an important theme of this reissue campaign
column10: and one that will become even more important later.

column1: The huge success of Coming Up left Suede in a position to do basically anything they wanted with their next album
column2: but it took three years for the band to put together the follow-up. Codling was at times bed-ridden with chronic fatigue syndrome after the grueling 18-month world tour in support of Coming Up
column3: and Anderson had fallen deeper into drug addiction
column4: especially crack. Bassist Mat Osman
column5: who along with Simon Gilbert has always been a source of stability and reason for the band
column6: recalls Anderson's drug buddies hanging around a lot during the sessions and generally ruining the atmosphere. The UK music press interpreted the long wait between albums as a sign that things were going wrong and that the next LP might be another Dog Man Star. When Head Music finally came out in 1999
column7: anticipation was so high in Britain that Virgin Megastores all over the country changed their name to Head Music for a day on the release date.

column1: The album wasn't another Dog Man Star
column2: but it was considerably darker and thornier than Coming Up. The band worked with producer Steve Osbourne to get a much heavier
column3: more groove-oriented sound
column4: and Codling's synths moved to the center of the sound. Head Music is neon to Coming Up's day-glo
column5: and it's aged well sonically-- it is easily the band's most underappreciated album. Part of the reason for that is Anderson's lyrics
column6: which on certain songs were simply terrible. ""Savoir Faire""'s notorious opening couplet
column7: ""She live in a house/ She stupid as a mouse
column8: is the worst offender
column9: but the slide toward superficiality that began on Coming Up accelerated here
column10: with Anderson sounding more like a bored observer than participant in the nightlife he sings about.

column1: Most of it sounds splendid
column2: though. ""She's in Fashion"" is a simply effervescent and weightless pop song; the mysterious orchestral swirl of ""Indian Strings"" is captivating; ""Hi-Fi"" has a chunky electro bounce that still sounds modern; and the slinking pop noir of ""Asbestos"" easily forgives the sometimes clunky lyrics. The band's attempts at stomping
column3: punky rock on ""Can't Get Enough"" and ""Elephant Man"" might have been better replaced by breezy fluid B-sides ""Leaving"" and ""Let Go""
column4: though
column5: and Anderson's solo acoustic stab at political commentary on ""Crack in the Union Jack"" is expendable. Perhaps reflecting the band's unsettled state at the time
column6: the period B-sides overall aren't the world-beaters of the past
column7: and they're spread across different producers (here again
column8: a Codling-sung B-side
column9: ""Weight of the World""
column10: has been left off).

column1: Suede's final album
column2: A New Morning
column3: is almost an afterthought in the context of the band's whole career. In his liner notes
column4: Anderson wonders whether it even should have been made and imagines a much different tracklist from what actually went on the album. The disc of B-sides here is very important
column5: because it's easily better than the proper LP-- it's the reason I'm rating this reissue higher than I did the album on its original release. The band was coming apart as it made the record. Codling had left due to his illness
column6: though he still contributed some songwriting; he was replaced by Alex Lee
column7: the former keyboardist for good-but-forgotten Britpoppers Strangelove. For his part
column8: Anderson had kicked drugs and isolated himself to write songs.

column1: The record that came of all this is Suede's sunniest and most organic
column2: but also its least substantial. On ""Lonely Girls""
column3: Anderson outright repeats himself-- the song is a list of girls
column4: coupled briefly with something that each of them does
column5: which makes it a virtual re-write of the old B-side ""Young Men"". His voice was also worn by years of abuse
column6: and he sounded a little ragged singing the otherwise buoyant hooks of ""Obsessions"" and ""Positivity""
column7: though it's hard to begrudge him the brighter outlook he displays on those songs. Listening to all the music here
column8: though
column9: it's easy to hear how
column10: by bringing songs such as the stately ballad ""Simon""
column11: the strangely haunting acoustic singalong ""Campfire Song""
column12: and the unusual
column13: slightly psychedelic ""Instant Sunshine"" out of B-side exile
column14: they could have pieced together a better album from these sessions. Still
column15: A New Morning is not a bad record
column16: and it sent the band out on a hopeful note that was strikingly at odds with much of what had preceded it.

column1: The five-piece Anderson/Codling/Gilbert/Oakes/Osman version of Suede has reunited and is touring
column2: and a few years ago Anderson and Butler reconciled and made an album together as the Tears. Anderson has a budding solo career but has left the door open to a possible Suede album sometime in the future. If it never happens
column3: so be it-- the band's legacy is already sealed. These three albums
column4: and Coming Up in particular
column5:
show a band that picked itself up remained creative and worthy in the wake of what could have been a fatal loss. These releases give us that whole run in all its messy imperfection.

Tamer Animals
column2: the sophomore release from the Stillwater
column3: Okla.
column4: five-piece Other Lives
column5: is meticulously written and arranged and
column6: at  times
column7: vividly cinematic. In the wrong hands
column8: this music could feel labored or overstuffed
column9: but thanks to the makeshift orchestra's shaggy ringleader
column10: Jesse  Tabish
column11: these wistful Americana-styled tracks (influenced by Tabish favorites Sigur Rós and Godspeed You! Black Emperor) rarely feel forced. Instead of the big studio sound of their self-titled debut

column1: Other Lives fits nicely with the pastoral richness of Fleet Foxes (whose influence is felt in the vocal harmony arrangements here) and the elegantly wasted music of Kurt Vile. On ""Landforms""
column2: crestfallen strings swell with Tabish  singing about the ""oceans and plains
column3: and you can almost taste the  salted air. The dark
column4: hymn-like ""Weather"" is similarly visual
column5: but  prophetic and baleful. ""The sun is getting closer to the world
column6: sings  Tabish
column7: clearly not talking about soaking up rays.

column1: Tabish has enlisted a group of players that holds these intricate pieces in place. It's not as if the songs here feel heavy or overloaded-- in fact
column2: most of them are positively buoyant
column3: thanks to the richly colored interplay of all the instruments and the spacious production. Nearly every member pulls double and triple duty on cellos
column4: violins
column5: clarinets
column6: keys
column7: trumpets
column8: and drums
column9: and in a live setting
column10: the band constantly shifts and repositions to hit every  mark. On record
column11: these professional assets come through even stronger.

column1: Still
column2: Tamer Animals isn't without its flaws
column3: the quality of the vocals chief among them. For something so painstakingly made
column4: it's strange that most vocal takes-- including some of those terrific  harmonies-- sound oddly flattened. On an album about  leaving behind the things you love

column1: But that grandiosity makes it feel as if Other Lives are coming from a million different directions at once. ""Old Statues"" has the whispery endlessness of a spaghetti western soundtrack; the string draws nicked from Radiohead's ""How to Disappear Completely"" impart a deeply haunted vibe to the provincial lope of ""For 12""; ""Woodwind"" channels the magical spook of a Grimm fairytale. Even if the emotional intent often feels recycled from other records

Tamer Animals is a record that takes you places.

column2: the Mountain Goats' John Darnielle explained why he chose Bellafea as an opening act: ""I took out good bands I liked! It's really as simple as that. I really wanted people to see Bellafea especially. I think you don't see a stage presence like Heather McEntire's more than a few times in your life. She's unbelievable."" Five years later

column7: country
column8: and gospel sounds. Those are

column10: the hallmarks of the bustling North Carolina scene-- one of the most interesting and active in the country right now-- but this new sound is a perfect setting for McEntire

column1: That voice is the ideal conduit for McEntire's lyrics-- or perhaps the lyrics are the ideal vehicle for her voice. She writes in a direct style that manages to incorporate interesting turns of phrase

column6: McEntire slyly subverts love-song conventions to write a declaration of love's opposite: ""A mouthful of bees couldn't stop me from whisperin'
column7: 'I don't love you

column9: right before the handclaps come in. Her repulsion is just as intense and wild as the attraction and excitement of first love.

column6: St. Vincent

column10: chiming guitar theme on ""Lament"" gives her something to lean on. The music isn't as distinctive as the singer

column11: ""you know

no whiplash.

A lot has changed since Digitalism debuted with Idealism in 2007. France's Justice and their blog-house followers took peak-hour rave rock to its breaking point and left it limping by the side of the road. Electronic dance music cycled back through more traditional and frequently more mellow strains of disco and house. And everyone more or less stopped talking about once hopelessly hot labels like Ed Banger and Kitsuné.

column1: All of which actually leaves the Hamburg duo poised for a big second act. Idealism showed clear pop aspirations
column2: from the Cure-repurposing of ""Digitalism in Cairo"" to the streamlined vocal number ""Pogo"". With thumping house beats still a big pop presence
column3: now might be as good a time as any to realize such a crossover. But <i>I Love You
column4: Dude doesn't shake off the confines of genre to reveal a shiny new pop act underneath. Nor does it meaningfully improve on Digitalism's previous formulas.

column1: Instead
column2: Dude is a mere rehash
column3: as its title's similarity to 2009 Paul Rudd-Jason Segel bromance <i>I Love You
column4: Man
column5: would suggest. Lead single ""Blitz""
column6: with its filtered
column7: circling synth lead
column8: effectively recreates some of the glitzy appeal of Idealism's ""Zdarlight""
column9: but with no moment quite as catchy as that song's effervescent guitar break. ""Antibiotics"" sort of recalls Tiga's Soulwax collab ""What You Need""
column10: with its pitched-down exhortations giving way to jabbing drum machines and distorted synth. Neither track is more essential than its predecessors.

column1: The songs that go for the pop jugular don't have much better luck. ""2 Hearts""
column2: with its eighth-note keyboard builds and buzzing
column3: sidelong synth stabs
column4: comes off like a pale echo of Phoenix's ""1901"". The album's collaboration with the Strokes' Julian Casablancas is a slight improvement
column5: its chorus rising almost gracefully out of its dull lumbering verses. But if naming your album <i>I Love You
column6: Dude is perhaps guileless
column7: then what would you call having Casablancas sing the chorus (""And so you run
column8: he yelps) and then calling the track ""Forrest Gump"" (because
column9: you know
column10: Forrest ran)?

column1: The rest of the album is one undistinguished track after another of grinding
column2: growling synths and digitally clipped drum machines
column3: from the impotent fanfare of ""Stratosphere"" to to the distorted plod of ""Miami Showdown"". There's a reason that
column4: a single here or there aside
column5: the Hype Machine hive mind collectively burned out on blog-house
column6: and it's that all the super-compressed synth noise just gets to be physically exhausting to take in after a while
column7:
whether over the course of a club night or a long-playing album.

WU LYF are for the children. Thus far
column3: World Unite Lucifer Youth Foundation have taken equal inspiration from A Clockwork Orange and fellow Mancunians Happy Mondays to play out that adolescent fantasy of having every bird-flip rewarded by authority figures they're meant to offend. The British rags will help you fill in the rest
column4: but here are a few talking points: getting a cold  call from Michel Gondry only to ignore it; charging desperate A&R's  50 pounds for a demo; telling the UK press to fuck off
column5: only to have  them respond with statements like
column6: ""they're reinventing the wheel."" Their web presence is so cryptic
column7: they make Dead Air Space look like Lil B's Twitter feed. The band's incomprehensible frontman
column8: Ellery Roberts
column9: is an experiment  in rock vocal abstraction
column10: and yet sold-out crowds sing along to every proto-linguistic grunt. But the centerpiece of Go Tell Fire to the Mountain-- a stunning lockstep of drum rolls
column11: tart guitar chords
column12: and a maddening  chant for raising beers and clenched fists-- makes it clear: This is  life-affirming music
column13: repulsed by hype and cynicism. The name of the song? ""We Bros"".

column1: The first word of the title is the important thing: Go Tell Fire celebrates togetherness. Approach the record with no context whatsoever
column2: and it's fairly trad  indie rock for crescendo junkies that could be laid over just about  anything-- a stirring football highlight
column3: your morning commute-- for  instant widescreen effect. Dissatisfied with the sound they were getting  in traditional studios
column4: WU LYF self-produced in an abandoned church
column5: which could once again be sniffed at as another publicity stunt. But  they needed every bit of open airspace to capture their sound in full
column6: and the building itself acts as an active participant. Silvery
column7: melodic  guitar lines are given extra dimension with decay and release
column8: and a  pipe organ draws lengthy sustain. And man
column9: what it does for the  percussion: the term ""crash cymbal"" has rarely sounded so literal
column10: and a critical mass of reverb pushes the kick drum's natural tone to its limit on ""Dirt"" and ""14 Crowns For Me & Your Friends"".

column1: But underneath all that bouncing room echo
column2: you hear a band trying to  live up to its own hype
column3: unglamorously woodshedding until every  arrangement was tight as hell. It's danceable in the same way older  Modest Mouse is-- a sweet spot that feels more limber than rock and too  jittery to congeal into a groove like funk
column4: but always in the service of  some sort of physicality. Even the ballads rarely feel settled: The  opening piano chords of ""Concrete Gold"" echo around a kick drum beat
column5: before a call-and-response chorus that evokes the melodicism of D.C. hardcore.

column1: So while musically it connects the divergent anthem-fashioning of Explosions in the Sky or Wolf Parade
column2: Roberts' vocals evade just about  any facile comparison. Attempts to classify it have ranged from Captain  Beefheart to a variety of feral animals or malfunctioning household  appliances
column3: all making the same point
column4: more or less: this is a trial by  fire. He's screaming ""I love you forever!"" on the first track (""L Y F"")  while revealing an alternate translation for their band name
column5: yet in the  urgency of Roberts' voice
column6: you can see the matted fur and gnarled teeth of an endearingly ugly stray that you're still hesitant to love back (see also: his performance on the aptly titled military funeral march ""Such a Sad Puppy Dog"").

column1: And yet
column2: similar to the way Jónsi applied the rhythms and phonetics of Hopelandic to convey an immutable
column3: beatific divinity
column4: Roberts lives within WU LYF's musical viscera as a vocal embodiment of  animal instinct
column5: projecting from the primitive part of the brain that  can sense danger and react before it even acknowledges the source. You  can occasionally make out his marching orders on ""Cave Song"" and ""Dirt""
column6: but Roberts and WU LYF match up spasm for spasm to make  their point clear: keep your head on a swivel
column7: move. Do something. WU LYF bark out the title of ""Spitting Blood"" repeatedly over heraldic organ
column8: and it's an evocative image leaving its completion up to the  listener. On the chorus
column9: Ellerby and crew yell ""we are so happy! Happy to see...
column10: the intelligibility fittingly cutting off right there.  After all
column11: what is the phrase Go Tell Fire to the Mountain besides an open-ended call to arms?

column1: Closer ""Heavy Pop"" might be the only time WU LYF actively and clearly suggest what they're getting at (indeed
column2: a dispatch on the band's mailing list describes the album as ""10 tracks of true heavy pop""). But Go Tell Fire rarely scans as ""pop music
column3: and at times
column4: it's content to give into pure  texture and drift. Rather
column5: this ""heavy pop"" translates to me as populism of real heft. More artistically rewarding records have been made this year
column6: but when I think about WU LYF in the manner of Iceage or Odd  Future as musicians that have made me genuinely excited about their  potential impact on listeners
column7: the same things that make them seem  juvenile-- the artistic and personal volatility
column8: the semblance  of a roving gang more than a band
column9: the invitation to indulge in your most disturbing impulses and yet feel morally superior to an ill-defined majority-- are the same things that feel totally galvanizing. And it's easy to imagine Go Tell Fire to the Mountain giving disaffected listeners the promise of an entry to something beyond themselves in a way that James Blake or Bon Iver can't. Maybe you've grown past that sort of thing
column10: but what about a record of exhilarating expanse and passion that sounds like indie rock and yet feels way bigger? Well
column11:
Go Tell Fire to the Mountain is that too.

Matthew Barnes had a pretty good 2010. Not only did the UK producer known as Forest Swords release the Dagger Paths EP (twice)
column2: he was able to spend a whole year watching adventurous music fans slowly come around to his vision. What initially sounded like the dubby musings of a post-rock acolyte eventually revealed themselves to be much more: treatises on voice and memory
column3: half-remembered R&B
column4: and haunting guitars. The reissued Dagger Paths included six early Forest Swords tracks

column6: again)
column7: with proceeds now going to Red Cross tsunami relief.

column1: This pre-Dagger Paths work shows that while Barnes' vision was already mostly developed
column2: his toolbox was noticeably lighter. The six tracks here rely almost uniformly on slow
column3: powerful drumming and a thick guitar assault that has way more in common with
column4: say
column5: early Flying Saucer Attack or Codeine than
column6: well
column7: Timbaland or Four Tet
column8: whom Dagger Paths at its best could evoke. Barnes works in layers
column9: his tones distorted but his pace measured. Fjree Feather sounds sinister as a result

column6: those drums no oomph-- as if it's being played underwater. Dagger Paths was notable for its use of sampled
column7: garbled voices. Fjree Feather features just the barest hints of that. ""Trust Your Blood""
column8: the most forward-thinking track here

column10: its rhythms resisting the urge to putter to a stop.

column1: Fjree Feather finds a nice middle ground; it's sometimes a well-executed leftfield guitar album and other times a primer for the ghostly lean-tos on Dagger Paths. But Barnes is most exciting for where he might be going
column2: not necessarily where he's been. With Forest Swords' back catalog presumably now exhausted

we can return to awaiting his next move.

White Hills are a prolific
column2: freewheeling sort of band. The New York space-rock explorers have stamped their name on more than a dozen releases from about half as many labels in the past six years. But they're at their best onstage
column3: where they're loud
column4: exhilarating
column5: and unhinged
column6: playing strings of songs as long as most bands' full sets. Though they're generally that way on record
column7: too
column8: I've never gotten the same feeling from White Hills through my own stereo speakers as I have through some bar's PA.

column1: The same holds for H–p1
column2: a 72-minute
column3: nine-track album that's often invigorating but sometimes just seems endless. White Hills are at their best when they're at their busiest
column4: as on the closing
column5: 17-minute title track
column6: with misanthropic lyrics
column7: a jagged riff
column8: and expansive solos. It's complicated and exhausting
column9: but it succeeds through sheer momentum. Moments like these make the band's second album for Thrill Jockey worth at least one trip. Similarly
column10: ""The Condition of Nothing"" is a moody anthem with a squealing
column11: instrumental midsection; it's nasty and noisy
column12: a passage that a band with less of a filter might have omitted. Meanwhile
column13: ""Monument"" evokes claustrophobia through power electronics and stacked
column14: broken rhythms. It's intensity is compelling.

column1: But that lack of restraint cuts both ways. Elsewhere
column2: White Hills include entire experimental sections that would have been better left in the practice room. Synthesizer study ""Hand in Hand"" is a jam with little movement
column3: an exercise without an idea. ""No Other Way"" rumbles quickly to a doomy churn
column4: with Ego Sensation's bulbous bass tone serving as ballast for Dave W.'s guitar and synthesizer builds
column5: but then it spends its last three minutes whirring and droning through an Amon Düül II haze. It seems like an attempt to make an art-rock statement
column6: but it mostly just thwarts the trio's thrust. Similar tones work much better during ""Paradise""
column7: a krautrock heater (assisted by Oneida drummer Kid Millions) that lets up only in the last of its 13 minutes; by then
column8: it's actually time for the band to exhale.

column1: Despite White Hills' plentiful output
column2: pacing remains a problem for the group. Live
column3: as they run marathons around a riff
column4: that's less of an issue; you're surrounded in the moment
column5: lost in the feeling. On H–p1
column6: though
column7:
it means you spend half of your time waiting to reach the crest.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16684/homepage_large.e2706af0.jpg|Fania Records 1964-1980: The Original Sound of Latin New York|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Strut']|2011-06-23 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:39.116174|"

In 1962
column2: Johnny Pacheco got divorced. One of the partners in the firm that represented him during the proceedings was Jerry Masucci. Pacheco was a bandleader; born in the Dominican Republic
column3: he moved to New York with his parents when he was 11
column4: studied percussion at Julliard
column5: and started his own band in 1960. With this band
column6: he was working on a fusion of all the Caribbean styles that could be heard in New York at that time
column7: bringing together the related traditions of Puerto Rican
column8: Dominican
column9: and Cuban music to plant some of the seeds that became salsa. Pacheco and Masucci formed a much deeper connection than the average lawyer-client bond
column10: and in 1964
column11: they founded the Fania label
column12: initially selling records out of the trunk of a car in Spanish Harlem.

column1: Pacheco and Masucci signed many of the brightest young lights on the New York Latin scene
column2: and over the next 15 years
column3: the label became essentially synonymous with the emerging salsa movement. Pacheco was the label's house producer and from 1968
column4: led the Fania All Stars
column5: a supergroup of some of the label's best musicians. But Masucci was more than just the business end of things. He attended sessions
column6: bought lunch for the musicians
column7: and with his brother Alex
column8: encouraged the development of the music. Strut's new Fania compilation documents that development over two packed discs
column9: with key tracks by Willie Colón
column10: Rubén Blades
column11: Héctor Lavoe
column12: the Fania All Stars
column13: Celia Cruz
column14: Ray Barretto
column15: Mongo Santamaria
column16: Joe Bataan
column17: and others.

column1: It's a good introduction to the Fania sound and stable of artists
column2: steering refreshingly clear of songs where the funk beat has taken over. In fact
column3: one of the central tensions of this music is the way the musicians work to incorporate some of the groove of funk without surrendering their own rhythmic heritage. Caribbean music (and much other Latin American music as well) is built on a very different concept of rhythm and harmony than most North American music. The African elements of North American music come to it less directly than the African elements of Caribbean music
column4: which were preserved more strongly. Where rock
column5: R&B
column6: funk
column7: soul
column8: and even classical music tend to think in terms of a beat or pulse that is determined separately from the key the song is in
column9: Caribbean music is constructed around a different rhythmic concept called the clave
column10: which covers both the rhythmic drive and tonality of the music.

column1: So you'll hear plenty of cycling
column2: hypnotic piano figures
column3: locked in with simple bass lines
column4: underpinning these songs
column5: while an arsenal of percussion defines and accents the different parts of the rhythm. It gives even the slowest
column6: mellowest songs an undeniable momentum
column7: as one bar pours effortlessly into the next
column8: with vocals and horns syncopated on top. Most of the songs are sung in Spanish
column9: though there are exceptions. Fania artists tended to be bilingual
column10: with Caribbean heritage and American upbringing
column11: but frankly
column12: Spanish is the language better suited to the music.

column1: A substantial jazz influence can be heard in some of the playing as well-- check Willie Colón's nicely phrases trombone solo on ""The Hustler""
column2: or the way Ray Barretto's swirling ""Indestructible"" seamlessly builds the clave around a series of jazz chord progressions. Mongo Santamaria's ""O Mi Shango""
column3: by contrast
column4: displays a heavy Afrobeat influence and rides a drum kit that plays with a sort of proto-disco accent on the upbeats. But that's the exception. For the most part
column5: this set functions as an ace introduction to salsa music in all its brassy
column6:
undulating glory.

'True Panther']|2011-06-22 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:39.263636|"

Perhaps we'd all be better off if it was always ""all about the music
column3: man."" But until recently
column4: most discussion of Unknown Mortal Orchestra understandably went from lauding the unshakeable hooks of ""Ffunny Ffriends"" and ""How Can You Luv Me?"" to wondering why
column5: true to their name
column6: they remained anonymous. Protracted mystery can cause as much skepticism as the most overt press blitz
column7: and information had been scarce since they popped up last year with a Bandcamp page of intriguing and untraceable songs. Some time after
column8: those songs started being performed live by human beings who do mundane things like wear Baja drug rugs
column9: live in Portland
column10: and maintain an active Twitter feed. But there's still something eerily extraterrestrial about their debut LP
column11: as if it were something that fell from the sky completely intact. You wonder if it might be an artifact from some psych-rock acid casualty
column12: a long-forgotten Kiwi-popper
column13: or an Elephant 6 offshoot. You want to poke at it
column14: prod it
column15: and try to carbon date it.

column1: None of the ambiguity would matter if UMO didn't spring to life from the first happily bopping seconds of ""Ffunny Ffriends"" and provide a half hour of rich analog sizzle that extends far beyond its meager recording budget (seriously
column2: try and find it on vinyl
column3: if possible). Though obviously more camera shy than Sleigh Bells or Cults
column4: UMO represents a similar merger of simple and catchy melodies lovingly marooned in a raw
column5: buzzcut production that puts an emphasis on the beats. The major difference for UMO is that their grit radiates from the inside out. Funk too often comes off as a jittery affectation or genre exercise even for rock bands who are pretty good at it. But for bandleader Ruban Nielson
column6: it feels like a natural songwriting mode. The tortured but deceptively joyous hook from ""How Can You Luv Me?"" does plenty to draw you in
column7: to the point where it might take the fifth listen to focus on just how limber the rhythm section is. It's hardly alone in sounding like a readymade breakbeat
column8: so it's not surprising that the cratedigging likes of El-P
column9: ?uestlove
column10: and Das Racist have all taken to tweeting UMO's praises.

column1: But the sound wouldn't matter without songwriting. When a singer gets praised for incorporating his or her voice like another instrument in the mix
column2: it's usually a reference to texture. And while Nielson often works in an androgynous
column3: bristling tone that's certainly ingratiating on its own merits
column4: it's more remarkable for its sophisticated approach to melody. Whether gripping the thrilling hairpin turns of ""Bicycle""
column5: arranging complex lattices of syncopation on ""Thought Ballune""
column6: or simply doubling down on his own leads on ""Ffunny Ffriends""
column7: he converses with the inventive guitar playing like he's making a sales pitch. The riffs tell you what you're gonna hear
column8: the vocals respond
column9: and they link up in a way that makes everything so welcoming and familiar by the middle of the song itself. Combined with an expert use of space rare for such a lo-fi record
column10: UMO manages a unique immersive and psychedelic quality without relying on the usual array of bong-ripping effects.

column1: As with Treats or Cults
column2: it's easy to view the band's ability to do just a few things very well as a potential liability. But many of UMO's charms come while they jab at their limitations. ""Little Blu House"" dots its airy landscape with harmonies that seem to change color with each stacked layer
column3: and closer ""Boy Witch"" indulges in some intriguing post-punk guitar damage that could indicate a future direction. That said
column4: the track stuffed with the most experimentation ends up being the weakest. ""Nerve Damage"" is part envelope filter-hotdogging and part goony thrash
column5: but pretty much all filler
column6: ultimately. But hell
column7: being able to recognize Unknown Mortal Orchestra's imperfection
column8: however minor
column9:
lends their debut some humanity. As does being able to see a press photo of the shaggy but high-functioning space cadets who made it.

Jon Pritchard aka Young Montana is a 20 year-old beat-fiddler from Coventry in the UK-- a small city most musically famous for its two-tone ska scene in the 1980s
column2: headed up by the Specials. Although Pritchard's production shares way more in common with Californian beat-makers Flying Lotus and Daedalus
column3: there's a fidgety energy at the core of his debut album
column4: Limerence
column5: that aligns itself with small town boredom and restlessness.

column1: ""Sacré Cool"" emerged last year and still sounds fresh and vital
column2: with its low-end pumping against a wonky beat culled from Chemise's ""She Can't Love You"". Pritchard's retooling of that sample is full of left turns as he pulls the beat this way and that
column3: but still keeps enough of a solid centre to nod along to.  Indeed
column4: no matter how deeply Young Montana dives into noodly
column5: intricate production on Limerence
column6: there's still a party edge propping things up.

column1: Most of the record drips pretty heavily with the influence of beatmakers like FlyLo
column2: Madlib
column3: and Prefuse 73 but there are some nicely unexpected nods in Pritchard's production too. The start of ""Mynnd"" errs towards the type of glacial
column4: icy sound of Boards of Canada as analog-sounding synths sprawl on top of each other before being overtaken by typically skronking beat.

column1: With grimey synths and a swarm of exaggerated sounds
column2: ""Legwrap"" is probably the most uncompromising production on the record. Propelled along by a clattering beat
column3: a collection of outré sounds jostle for attention in the mix. The rattle of drums eventually falls in on itself
column4: giving way to a stark
column5: wobbly synth interlude. It's an example of pretty meticulous beat-mapping and might be a bit alienating if not for a gorgeous end section that Pritchard ushers in out of nowhere. The passage recalls Prefuse 73 at his more playful with a smooth soul sample chopped and spliced with subtle horns and cut-up vocals.

column1: The sudden change in direction at the end of ""Legwrap"" is something Montana pulls on quite a few of these tracks
column2: lending the whole record the feel of an endlessly tuning radio
column3: flickering from station to station. It adds a kind of broken
column4: wonky dynamic that makes things feel slightly intangible. But occasionally these interludes add an interesting context to beats just at the moment they almost lose steam. Take ""Midnight Snacks"" for instance
column5: a track that pumps with robotic
column6: destroyed threads and a concealed vocal sample repeating
column7: ""Can't take my eyes off you
column8: until late on when Montana flips things again
column9: delivering the sample back to its original old-timey roots.

column1: Moments like that
column2: while not exactly groundbreaking
column3: are nice touches that contribute to the overall sense of careful craft that exemplifies Pritchard's production. While his seamlessly stitched-together beats aren't quite as meticulous or obsessively compulsive as something like Prefuse 73's glitch-hop epic One Word Extinguisher for instance
column4: there's still an impressive attention to detail. His thorough and restless production helps Pritchard transcend the efforts of many other bedroom producers by sheer virtue of his work ethic. Coming from a town like Coventry
column5: one imagines you have to make your own fun
column6:
and that's exactly what Young Montana does on Limerence.

The garish album art for BOBBY's self-titled debut features two identical boys in their tighty-whiteys
column2: one blank white and the other a photo-negative shadow; on the back
column3: the theme is repeated with a black cat and a white cat nuzzling into an implied yin and yang. This art-folk group
column4: comprised of recent Bennington grads (including Mountain Man's Amelia Randall Meath)
column5: are fascinated by opposites and negatives
column6: by the sharp disparities between ambient and rhythmic
column7: airy and earthy
column8: restive and tranquil
column9: male and female. For their self-titled debut
column10: the circle of friends holed up in a tiny Massachusetts hamlet to arrange these dozen songs (most written by de facto frontman Tom Greenberg)
column11: then recorded them in Woodstock
column12: New York. Spacier and less Americana-based than those settings might suggest
column13: the result is an intriguing marriage of familiar sounds in new settings
column14: sounding variously like a nodding-off Joanna Newsom or tUnE-yArDs with the caps toggle off.

column1: BOBBY's songs float loose and untethered
column2: occasionally nudged along by percolating percussion. The contrast between drift and momentum are intriguing
column3: especially on ""Sore Spores""
column4: which pits an emphatic female vocal on the verses with a smoother
column5: slyer male vocal on the chorus. The transition between them is intentionally jarring
column6: suggesting a he said/she said account of a relationship. With its sleepy-eyed bassline and whispers of guitar
column7: ""Nap Champ"" lives up to its title
column8: then rouses itself
column9: upping the tempos and setting the guitars on high shimmer. Neither half would work without the other
column10: but together they form a dynamic whole.

column1: Sprawling to seven members
column2: BOBBY take advantage of their inclusive roster by indulging many ideas
column3: from the slightly menacing basslines to the great yawns of synths to the wordless vocal flourishes that adorn several songs. Opener ""We Saw"" knots up a melody that crescendoes with each steady repetition of its central phrases
column4: the harmonizing voices moving against instead of with the plateauing chord changes. Few songs on BOBBY are quite so assertive
column5: although the arrangements are often busy and mercurial: ""It's Dead Outside"" changes shape almost constantly
column6: yet maintains its murky drift across seven minutes.

column1: At times
column2: the extremes are too extreme
column3: with too much dead air abutting too many busy passages. Mid-album instrumental ""Loading Phase"" lulls BOBBY to sleep
column4: while closer ""The Shed"" marries a churchly organ theme to a small chorale of voices
column5: suggesting a cathedral in miniature-- or a shed
column6: perhaps. The idea is more intriguing than the music itself
column7: yet the idea is appreciated
column8: as is the ambition to mix sounds together in subtly new ways. In that regard
column9: BOBBY intently evoke that drowsy space between wakefulness and sleep. It's lively in its drowsiness
column10:
which may be the album's most compelling and distinguishing contrast.

What does ""deep"" mean? House music has been earnestly applying its wiki brainpower to this question for a couple of years now
column3: processing decades of house and disco tropes and rendering an endless stream of variations upon the theme. Record after record aspires to the ideal type
column4: with just the right balance of disco breaks
column5: vintage-sounding drum machines
column6: blocky piano chords
column7: and suggestively yearning vocals. This goes for a lot of crappy records
column8: but it also holds for some of the good ones
column9: too. The debut album from Scotland's 6th Borough Project feels
column10: in many ways
column11: like a quintessentially of-the-moment dissertation on deepness; fortunately
column12: it falls to the worthwhile end of the spectrum.

column1: I don't think that 6th Borough Project-- the duo of house producers Graeme Clark
column2: aka the Revenge
column3: and Craig Smith-- would dispute their role as a certain kind of revivalist (or
column4: better
column5: caretaker
column6: preservationist
column7: gene-splicer). It's right there in the introduction to ""Deep C""
column8: where a stoned-sounding voice intones
column9: ""Nothing is original. All human expression is really just endless variations. There are only a limited number of stories you can tell
column10: but there's an unlimited number of ways to tell the same story.""

column1: Their story is a kind of idealized version of classic
column2: disco-infused house
column3: chock full of soul samples as super-saturated as old Polaroids. (I realize that we used up that metaphor on chillwave
column4: but it does beg the question: Is house music's current retro fetish a manifestation of the same rearview-yearning currently running through indie music? Possibly.) They've definitely got a certain formula down: Tracks start off demurely
column5: with a simple boom/clap drum pattern and a bass line
column6: maybe a flickering loop of voice or guitar; then they swell about the middle
column7: adding layers of keyboards and carefully daubing on more samples
column8: like horn and voices. The climax often consists of a clipped phrase unrolling itself to its full length
column9: a pocket in time before the groove kicks back in and the track disassembles itself
column10: piece by piece. It's music made with a DJ's sense of sequencing
column11: which is also a way of saying that it's largely about balance. And
column12: make no mistake
column13: it can be thrilling
column14: especially when they slow down and linger on the contours of their source material
column15: luxuriating in the wobble of a drum fill or the silvery arrow of a delay chain.

column1: 6th Borough Project and the Revenge are often counted as adherents to a slow-mo tendency in house music (along with Mark E
column2: John Talabot
column3: Nicolas Jaar and the Wolf + Lamb crew
column4: and Prins Thomas and his Internasjonal label
column5: among others)
column6: but not everything here is quite so downbeat. Perhaps half the tracks could fit into the second hour of any dance party-- or even the 11th
column7: depending upon the club. ""Find a Way"" is a driving filter-disco number
column8: all jangly guitar and throaty exhortation
column9: that could crack the cinderblocks in a basement dive; the percussive ""Iznae"" is spacious but powerful
column10: with bass and drums that thump your sternum
column11: sampled snares leaning forward into the beat. (The album's least typical cut
column12: it's also one of the best.) But ""If the Feeling's Right"" and ""Deep C"" both sink into wonderfully woozy territory
column13: with blurry disco samples and synthesizers congealing around stumbling 4/4 kicks and handclaps. With its synths and vocoders
column14: ""Deep C"" sounds like an experiment in new wave disco
column15: maybe with a touch of Mike Oldfield's ""In High Places""; ""If the Feeling's Right"" shuffles along the border between exhaustion and ecstasy
column16: spurred on by keening vocal loops.

column1: Back to nostalgia: the guys in 6th Borough Project know what they're doing. The name itself falls in line with classic house and disco monikers like Terrence Parker's Seven Grand Housing Authority and Began Cekic's Brooklyn Express; it gives off the same scent of sun-baked concrete and sweaty basements. It's not an original image of urban America
column2: but then
column3: nothing is original. 6th Borough Project repeat themselves sometimes
column4: but they've got a solid grasp of the story they've chosen to tell. Somewhere
column5:
someone's writing a variation on one of their variations right now. The parts of this album where they depart from the script are enough to make me curious about how they'll respond.

Pitchfork's Stephen M. Deusner summarized Cry-Baby
column2: the album Norway's Ungdomskulen released in 2007
column3: by pointing out that it crammed in ""eight long songs with as many digressions
column4: tangents
column5: and asides as possible."" Anyone deterred by such extravagance may find something more palatable to chew on in Gimme Ten. But this is indulgence of a different kind. Here the band has simply stripped everything down and produced an album of 10 songs that are each around one minute long. The entire record breezes past in less time than it takes the average krautrock jam to hit its stride. The band members are doubtless prepared for people to wave this album away as a gimmick without actually hearing it
column6: but to do so wouldn't entirely be fair. There's definitely an air of novelty about it
column7: but there's still as much care and attention put into these songs as there is in their other material. Those ""digressions
column8: tangents
column9: and asides"" are all still intact-- they've just been vacuum-packed into an impossibly tiny space.

column1: That level of detail maintained by Ungdomskulen recalls other artists who have worked in a vaguely similar manner
column2: such as the earliest material by Glasgow's the Yummy Fur or Manchester post-punkers bIG fLAME. This album also borrows heavily from the same stylistic mien as the latter. Much of it contains elements of the syrupy-funk undertow that bands like Orange Juice and A Certain Ratio were dabbling in during the 1980s. There's a spikiness to the guitar sound and a playfulness to the lyrics that also recall that era. ""Elle"" contains most of those elements
column3: with its jerky stop-start rhythms and liquid bassline combining to do some pitch-perfect Gang of Four cloning. Some of these could be decent off-kilter pop songs if they were allowed to spread their wings a little-- ""It's Official"" and ""Number One"" cover the kind of ground that Franz Ferdinand and Queens of the Stone Age were respectively delving into with some success in the past decade.

column1: But therein lies a big part of the problem with Gimme Ten. Too many of these sounds and directions have been thoroughly regurgitated and explored in recent years. Ungdomskulen are certainly well drilled at taking those ideas and condensing them down into bite-sized chunks; it's just a shame they couldn't have chosen some less picked-over territory in which to perform this experiment. There are flashes of inspiration
column2: but the nature of this record makes it a frustrating listen at times. ""Silver or Bronze"" matches synthesized handclaps with some wickedly lumpen rock riffing at one point
column3: and ""Take It Back"" almost bears a chant-along chorus to go with its buzzsaw guitar. Ungdomskulen are more than capable of packing such short songs with plenty of belief
column4: but too often it feels like they're straining under the weight of it all. With so little room to function
column5: the rush to get to where they're going causes any genuine flashes of insight to be discarded with indecent haste.

column1: Despite such reservations
column2: it's to their credit that Ungdomskulen have taken to this task with considerable zeal. There are 10 videos
column3: one to go with each song
column4: and the audio files are available for free download from the band's website. They even prove the worth of the one-minute format a couple of times. ""Walking the Dog"" works just fine as an impossibly brief pop track interrupted by quirky burping noises reminiscent of Elastica's ""Line Up""; ""Your Soul"" filters in post-hardcore yelling that's well suited to such claustrophobic expanses. As an exercise put out into the world for free
column5: albeit with a decent amount of love and perspiration
column6: Gimme Ten provides fleeting moments of enjoyment. But instead of really inhabiting its restraints and taking them somewhere revelatory
column7: much of this album serves to highlight why it's not a very good idea to deliberately impose shackles on musical notions that are on the cusp of heading somewhere stimulating. If they're looking for a quickie follow-up project
column8: it might be worth filtering these songs through the same kind of ambition they demonstrated on Cry-Baby
column9:
just to see whether all this abstraction can congeal into something more substantial.

"|15554.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15554-gimme-ten/|5.2|Nick Neyland

Before Ty Segall recorded ""Girlfriend""
column2: a gem from last year's Melted
column3: he channeled sounds we don't normally associate with humans. Through polluted streams of distorted guitar
column4: you could hear him convulse
column5: spitting wordless sounds as a bubblegum drumbeat took hold. It was evil
column6: it was scary
column7: and it sounded like demons were controlling his organs and limbs. ""Girlfriend"" was a glorious blast of fuzz

Puns work on ""The Daily Show""-- especially when there's a shamed congressman involved. But when it comes to mashups
column2: such wordplay has lost all of its charm. In fact
column3: a punned-out title can now act as an active deterrent for listeners. James Drake-- a half-hour mix that combines the songs and sounds of
column4: yes
column5: James Blake and Drake-- is an exception to the lame-name rule. This is even more impressive since the twentysomething Philadelphia producers/DJs behind it
column6: Bombé (Tim Shaw) and Mr. Caribbean (Luis Angel Cancel)
column7: started with the title. ""Luis is constantly thinking up pun-based ideas like this
column8: wrote Shaw in an e-mail
column9: ""and the James Drake concept was just too perfect.""

column1: The match really is well-suited beyond rhyming monikers
column2: in part because Drake and Blake are both masters at the art of loneliness. Along with his right-hand producer Noah ""40"" Shebib
column3: Drake has perfected the after-party comedown; he's moody
column4: he's drunk
column5: and he desperately needs to talk to someone about about how he's getting vertigo from being at the top. Blake
column6: of course
column7: is a bit more elusive and introverted in his confessionals
column8: but the core sentiment is similarly down and wary. There's not a huge gap between Blake singing
column9: ""I don't know about my dreamin' anymore/ All that I know is I'm fallin' falin' fallin'
column10: and Drake's
column11: ""What am I afraid of?/ This is supposed to be what dreams are made of."" Both artists' uneasy sense of disillusionment cuts deep.

column1: Not only did Shaw and Cancel pick a wisely like-minded duo
column2: they treat their creation more like a DJ mix than a traditional mashup. This isn't just 30 minutes of Drake verses pasted over Blake's willowy keyboards and stuttering bass. Both music and vocals are cherry-picked from each artist
column3: and the mix is Blake-heavy
column4: with Drake's unmistakable hum buzzing in on only a few tracks. And even when we do hear the rapper
column5: his voice is often slowed down or fucked up; Shaw and Cancel manipulate Drake's vocals the same way James Blake often messes with his own croon
column6: resulting in an even more symbiotic pairing. On ""Fear Logic Freestyle""
column7: Drake is screwed as he repeats
column8: ""Gotta lift the doors/ Blades choppin' through the city streets/ Liquid swords""-- close your eyes tight enough and it's not hard to imagine the same passage showing up on a legit Blake release (give or take a GZA reference). It's hard to tell where Drake ends and Blake begins.

column1: The men behind James Drake also shy away from simply pimping out their subjects' hits
column2: instead seeking more natural combinations. ""Fall for Your Man at 9 a.m."" gets its pulse from the Blake obscurity ""Give a Man a Rod""
column3: while Drake's early mixtape collaboration with Lil Wayne
column4: ""Ransom""
column5: is used to backbone highlight ""Ransom Money Youth"". Shaw and Cancel also use effects and processing to smear the lines between songs
column6: and they add a touch of original production to the mix
column7: though
column8: according to Shaw
column9: ""We tried to keep it minimal as far as major edits and let the two different voices speak for themselves."" Along the way
column10: we learn just how little difference there is between those voices; James Drake's title might be facepalm-worthy
column11:
but its execution is anything but.

If Silkie's City Limits Volume 1 had an immediate identity
column2: it was dubstep's more upfront tendencies dialed into a somewhat upscale frequency-- tasteful without being bland
column3: busy without being messy. Headphone music that worked just as well filling rooms
column4: his material had a strong sense of rhythmic pull and intricate density. And while Silkie augmented his developing sound with occasional detours into ""purple"" bass and evergreen boogie funk
column5: what stood out was an overarching style that didn't see a mutual exclusion between cocktail-lounge ambiance and tons of wobbly bass. At times it skewed closer to the pop-gloss sophistication of late-90s UK garage than the escalating bassbin arms race of crossover dubstep.

column1: Follow-up City Limits Volume 2 isn't as immediately gratifying or revelatory-- it's a logical progression
column2: reliability replacing novelty. But it also explores the possibility of connecting on a level simultaneously nostalgic and contemporary
column3: right down to the decades-past pirate-radio evocations of its song titles: ""Get Up N Dance""
column4: ""Rock Da Funk"". Repeating themes seem intent on sparking flashbacks

column1: The synth sax that drove the melody of Volume 1 track ""Beauty"" is a more prominent component here

column3: wringing jittery force out of the old ""Amen"" break and dousing it with a choppy yet liquid 303 bassline. And whenever a voice breaches the surface

column5: Roger Troutman talk-box warbles (""New York City"")
column6: or a distorted
column7: pitched-up note or two from a rave diva (""Snowed In""). Even the synth and piano melodies that drove some of the more compelling hooks on Volume 1 sound more comfortably worn and identifiable from eras past
column8: like the rollerskate-jam electro of ""Boogie Boy"" or the Junie Morrison-esque g-funk extrapolations in ""Lucky"".

column1: The catch is that once Silkie gets ahold of these vintage signifiers
column2: he pushes them all the way into the red with the pedal-down immediacy of current bass music. Even with the obvious nods to dance music's past
column3: from rave to garage

column5: hi-hats
column6: and kicks will just wind up causing dizziness; some of the beats are so stuffed with counter-rhythms and jostling emphases-- even before the buildups and breakdowns shift the topography-- that it's almost easy to lose track of just how supple they are. The bass feels a bit more aggressive
column7: too. There are some points
column8: such as late-album tracks ""Taxi Mi Get"" and ""Only For You""
column9: where it takes on the hissing crackle of a shorting-out amp
column10: and others where the wobble shakes things out until rich
column11: individual notes turn into frenetic
column12: staccato trembles. It's bracing stuff when all the elements click-- ""Selva Nova""
column13: the cheery prog-funky of closer ""Outlook""

column15: which pulls off a great double-paced slow-stride/fast-scramble momentum. And if this album's status as the final City Limits installation marks the end of an early career-defining phase
column16: it suggests a good transition for Silkie: The body of work he's put together so far proves that the man knows his roots

and he knows where to follow them.

Bruno Pronsato is getting more ambitious. Despite cementing his reputation in 2008 with Why Can't We Be Like Us
column2: one of the late decade's finest documents of minimal techno
column3: Pronsato has spent the proceeding years taking risks. He made his debut on DFA as half of NDF with the entrancing ""Since We Last Met"". Most impressive was 2009's The Make Up the Break Up

column5: Nico-sampling single/EP/album that spun off into salty psychedelia. Not content to develop his ideas over the course of compartmentalized
column6: 10-minute tracks

column8: Lovers Do

column1: Simply put
column2: Lovers Do aligns Pronsato with artists like Terre Thaemlitz and Theo Parrish

column4: emotionally charged canvases. Pronsato isn't quite as Art-focused as those two-- from its title on down

column6: rich world. He seems to ignore the genre's most confident ingredients (heavy four-to-the-floor beats
column7: jacked-up sloganeering) and focus on the insular: snatches of jazz
column8: mournful Rhodes keyboards
column9: dubby rhythmic patter. He employs no divas
column10: just a cast of mumbling insomniacs. On the album's second track
column11: over a surprising amount of marimba
column12: you are reminded repeatedly: ""Anybody else/ Anybody but... you."" There are moments-- as during the amorphous
column13: copper-mouthed ""Trio-Out""-- that Lovers Do seems to have more in common with
column14: say
column15: Brooklyn beat-manglers Excepter than Berlin techno.

column1: Impressively
column2: Lovers Do manages to be tonally dark without being foreboding or sinister. ""Noir"" probably applies
column3: but not just the rainy vistas and shadowy alleys that term normally conjures. Think also of waking up in strange rooms
column4: or characters floating in and out of focus. You could certainly stare out at the skyline with Lovers Do as your soundtrack
column5: but its darkness is born out of moments of isolation and doubt we all experience. This happens because Pronsato takes great care not to suffocate listeners. Lovers Do is long-- too long
column6: quite frankly-- but it offers plenty of outs. Its structures are smoky and ill-defined. Pronsato is reticent to let any one element dominate the mix: The vocals weave in and out
column7: the drums flutter to sudden stops
column8: and the electric pianos thumb through just a few notes at a time.

column1: Lovers Do picks up steam as it ends. The title track
column2: which closes the album
column3: sounds fittingly optimistic opposite the heavy-lidded opener
column4: ""Lovers Don't"". There is a structure and logic to Lovers Do; it is immersive and artful but Pronsato went to great lengths to ensure that it not be overwhelming. Working again with muse Ninca Leece
column5: Lovers Do acquires a femininity that suggests Lovers Do is a conversation
column6: not an invective. Lovers Do casts this conversation into a diffuse cityscape
column7:
one whose darkness feels only temporary.

The guy who recorded an album alone in the woods. This line might end up on Justin Vernon's tombstone. There's something irresistible about the thought of a bearded dude from small-town Wisconsin retreating
column3: heartbroken
column4: to a cabin to write some songs-- especially when the result is a record that sounds as hushed and introspective as Bon Iver's 2007 debut
column5: <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/10709-for-emma-forever-ago/"" target=""_blank"">For Emma
column6: Forever Ago. These days
column7: Vernon is more likely to poke fun at the image
column8: but it endures because it fulfils a fantasy for us as listeners. Even if we don't care for the outdoors
column9: most of us occasionally want to escape our lives
column10: be alone with our thoughts
column11: and see if we can tap into something true. In a time of easy distraction
column12: the idea of heading into a cabin at the edge of the world to create is alluring. By tying the intimacy of that image to Justin Vernon's music
column13: we're able to take the trip with him.

column1: Since that album's release
column2: Vernon's approach to writing and recording has changed. ""I don't find inspiration by just sitting down with a guitar anymore
column3: he recently told Pitchfork. ""I wanted to build a sound from scratch and then use that sound to make the song."" That difference is clear on Bon Iver. Instead of something that scans as ""folk
column4: the music here is more like rustic chamber pop with an experimental edge that makes careful use of arrangement and dynamics. And rather than being tied together by a central theme of loss
column5: Vernon has fully shifted into a more impressionistic mode; these songs are broader and more musically sophisticated than those on For Emma at every turn.

column1: But the thread between this album and its comparatively skeletal predecessor is Vernon's voice
column2: an instrument that feels warm and personal and close regardless of setting. Now that we've heard him singing hooks with Kanye West and taking the lead with Gayngs on songs that touch on R&B and soft rock
column3: the general sphere of Vernon's voice is clear. He simultaneously evokes the grain and expression of soul music along with the mythological echoes of folk. But more importantly
column4: no one else sounds like him. The Beach Boys have been the primary touchstone for layered vocals in indie music for years
column5: but Vernon's timbre comes from somewhere else entirely. Where ""Beach Boys harmonies"" have a spiritual undercurrent that brings to mind a choirboy's dream of perfection
column6: Vernon sounds like a man who has outgrown such ideas. His voice is earthy and wounded and
column7: despite his astonishing upper register
column8: not something you would describe as ""angelic.""

column1: ""Holocene"" contains one of this album's many virtuosic vocal performances. ""Part of me
column2: apart from me
column3: Vernon sings early on
column4: and those six words hold a lot. The evocative nature of his diction is apparent even in a simple line like ""I was not magnificent."" He sounds centered and clear while taking stock and allowing memories to be mixed in with the details of the present. His conflicted vocals trigger a half-dozen feelings all at once before releasing the tension with a refrain that finds the fleeting moment where the world seems right: ""I could see for miles
column5: miles
column6: miles.""

column1: Vernon posted Bon Iver's lyrics shortly after the album leaked last month
column2: but they're not easy to parse-- the storytelling here is oblique. But there are connections. The song titles reference actual places (""Calgary"") and places that sound real
column3: but aren't (""Hinnom
column4: TX""
column5: ""Michicant""); they're less about geography and more about putting a name to a state of mind that mixes clarity and surrealism. And the deeper you sink into these tracks
column6: the harder it becomes to extract specifics. One recurring element is intoxication-- lines about being drunk or high that come with recounted details. Which makes sense
column7: because the album deals with escape and the struggle to get outside yourself. The narrator takes in what's around him
column8: mixing those thoughts with memories of where he's been. Sometimes the lines have a startling specificity (""Third and Lake it burnt away
column9: the hallway/ Was where we learned to celebrate
column10: on ""Holocene"") and sometimes they contain words that seem to function more as sound (""fide"" or ""fane"" on ""Perth""). Throughout
column11: there's a strong sense of an observer taking things in and processing confusing images
column12: trying to figure out what can be learned.

column1: If you caught Vernon live after For Emma
column2: you gradually saw him putting more and more emphasis on his band
column3: moving Bon Iver from that solitary project into something that felt more like the work of a group. And Bon Iver
column4: with its rich and layered arrangements
column5: extends that development in a striking direction that's both logical and surprising. Blending natural instrumentation supplied by recruited players-- such as string arranger Rob Moose (Antony and the Johnsons
column6: the National
column7: Arcade Fire) and a horn/woodwind section that includes versatile saxophonist Colin Stetson-- with an array of electronic and treated sounds
column8: the album combines varied textures in ways that are ambitious and unusual but often subtle enough to miss on first glance.

column1: At points
column2: Bon Iver draws on the experiments of Volcano Choir
column3: Vernon's side project with the post-rock outfit Collections of Colonies of Bees (members from that group play on the album). Freed from conventional verse/chorus/bridge/chorus structure
column4: the songs become more like tone poems
column5: patient explorations of moods that proceed deliberately but unpredictably. The holistic style is evident on opener ""Perth""
column6: which builds from total silence into a crashing peak over the course of four short minutes. And there's an uncanny moment on the breathtaking ""Michicant""
column7: a song in part about childhood
column8: where a bicycle bell rings twice
column9: pulling you deeper into Vernon's reverie. It's a simple
column10: brief effect
column11: but it's indicative of how the album uses elemental sounds in unexpected ways.

column1: Vernon has taken that voice
column2: and these arrangements
column3: and crafted an album that unfolds like a suite. The structure is flawless right up to its conclusion
column4: ""Beth/Rest""
column5: which has been much remarked upon for its unabashed and unironic embrace of 80s adult contemporary pop sounds. If you've spent any time in the vicinity of a radio tuned to light rock
column6: you hear the keyboard tone that opens the song and you think Lionel Richie
column7: Richard Marx
column8: and ""No One Is to Blame"".

column1: It's almost naive of Vernon to think he could pull this off. Yet
column2: heard in context
column3: it stands as one the record's bravest and most deftly executed moments-- not just because it lays bare Vernon's stated admiration for artists like Bonnie Raitt and Bruce Hornsby
column4: but because it's executed to perfection. And while the production attempts to wring something new from a long-maligned sound
column5: the song and voice remain true to Bon Iver as an idea. As a closer
column6: ""Beth/Rest"" is more about finding comfort and resolution after a musical experience that asked more questions than it answered. The song draws a line in the sand for anyone with a deep investment in cool
column7: and Vernon stands behind it with confidence. His belief in himself and in the power of his music is something that encourages us to transcend labels and preconceptions.

column1: After the closeness and austerity of For Emma
column2: Vernon has given us a knotty record that resists easy interpretation but is no less warm or welcoming. You can feel it even as you don't completely understand it-- a testament to its careful construction and Vernon's belief in the power of music to convey deeper meaning. It's a rare thing for an album to have such a strong sense of what it wants to be. Bon Iver is about flow
column3: from one scene and arrangement and song and memory and word into the next-- each distinct but connected-- all leading to ""Beth/Rest"". On the way there
column4: the music moves like a river
column5:
every bend both unpredictable and inevitable as it carves sound and emotion out of silence.

In any discussion about the new-on-the-scene Queens rapper Action Bronson

column3: and (2) he loves rapping about food. Both of these things are entirely true. Like Ghost

He's not a rip-off artist; he's got none of Ghost's emotional streak and little of his vividly violent storytelling impulse. But the mere grain of his voice is similar enough to provoke the momentary sensation every time a new verse starts that you're actually hearing Ghostface.

column1: Similarly

column1: Bodies of Water

column5: disco

but quite possibly all the same thing.
