Time-stamping the name of your group might seem counterproductive in a musical climate that clamors for all things new and exciting. Shine 2009's name is destined to date unpredictably primarily because it refers to a recent and quite unremarkable year (a quick digest includes swine flu
column2: the birth of chillwave
column3: and the death of Michael Jackson). But even a cursory listen to Shine 2009's Realism shows how deeply the band is committed to the allure of dated sounds.

column1: The Balearic-leaning drum breaks and keys of opener ""Graduation"" nod toward the early 1990s
column2: and indeed that decade's pop music legacy looms large over most of the record. Wistful shades of Air France also emerge on that track
column3: which has a pleasant collage feel with beachy ambient sounds lending a bit of texture and character. Singer Sami Suova's straight-laced vocals sound like a cross between a more lackadaisical Bernard Sumner and the slightly angelic tinge of 1990s European boybands-- ""Pray"" by Take That comes to mind here.

column1: The kitsch dynamic is even more heavily pronounced on ""So Free""
column2: as a frozen-in-time Paula Abdul contributes backing vocals on top of Suova's blissed-out chorus. She ramps up the camp factor
column3: almost ad-libbing on top of cheap-sounding electronic piano stabs and synth strings. As a pastiche it has a certain charm
column4: and while it's easy to be carried away by the light-hearted fun at its core
column5: there's a nagging feeling that Shine 2009 don't move much beyond playing dress up.

column1: The moments where the group looks to update the conversation
column2: as on ""New Rules""
column3: sound far more persuasive. That track in particular bounces with a hypnotically looping synth pattern and clubby drums
column4: and it feels a little less studied. The shades of darkness in the textures and vocals in particular make for an interestingly sunburnt take on the Balearic sound. The directive of ""I'll tell you how to do it/ Get ready for the new rules"" also comes across as unexpectedly creepy in this context and makes for an oddly gripping narrative.

column1: The title track is another intriguing moment
column2: layering a delicate
column3: monastic chorale on top of sliced keys and what sounds like a synthesized didgeridoo. As on ""New Rules""
column4: there are enough leftfield elements and sounds to make for an interesting and evocative collage of material. But ultimately these moments of subversion are outnumbered by Shine 2009's more hollow imitations-- the worst being ""One""
column5: a song played way too straight
column6: its wah-wah laced guitar and glockenspiel synth sounding like the type of tacky chillout music played in an upscale cocktail bar. Suova's unassuming voice becomes part of the malaise instead of the laid-back counterpoint it plays on the record's stronger moments.

column1: At their best Shine 2009's backward-leaning pop songs make for a lighthearted
column2: fun listen. But the problem with the remodelled nostalgia of Realism is that it's hard to recommend it over the real thing
column3:
beyond the sensation of kitsch novelty that the record invokes. Dig any deeper and the pastiche feels a little empty; it can't hope for the kind of memories conjured up when you are caught off guard by a song you used to know and love.

Neil Young spent the 1980s making more headlines than hits. He defended Ronald Reagan in interviews
column2: skewered Pepsi and Budweiser in a video banned by MTV
column3: and fought off lawsuits from his label
column4: Geffen
column5: over a string of stylistically divergent albums. One of these was Old Ways
column6: a traditional-country throwback that wasn't too many cornfields removed from Young's star-making 1972 release
column7: Harvest. After some twists and turns that included 1982's synth-pop transgression Trans and 1983's goofy 50s rock homage Everybody's Rockin'
column8: a radically revamped Old Ways eventually came out in 1985
column9: between a couple of tours backed by a crack live band of country-music veterans called the International Harvesters. This short-lived group included longtime Young collaborators Ben Keith
column10: Spooner Oldham
column11: and Tim Drummond.

column1: The International Harvesters may not hold the same exalted status in the Neil Young story as Crazy Horse or the Stray Gators
column2: but they get their proper due on the latest installment of Young's Archives Performance Series
column3: which continues to defy all laws of chronology and numerical order. (A Treasure
column4: the sixth set released in the series
column5: is classified as Volume 9; it follows 2009's Dreamin' Man Live '92
column6: aka Volume 12.) So far
column7: the Archives Performance Series has mostly featured embryonic performances of what would become Young's best-known work; A Treasure is the first entry to put the spotlight on a less celebrated stretch of his career. As such
column8: this choppy compilation of Harvesters tour highlights allows us to reassess some of Young's 80s output outside its contentious context.

column1: Among all of Young's 80s genre exercises
column2: the Harvesters country detour was the most musically in tune with his canonical turn-of-the-70s work. But Young shot that music through with a persona every bit as calculated as the skinny-tied humanoid heard on <i>Trans
column3: or the ersatz Elvis seen on the cover of Everybody's Rockin'. For the Harvesters tour
column4: Young wasn't so much playing country music as playing the role of a country-music singer: taking the stage in a Harley-Davidson ballcap
column5: spouting over-the-top pro-America rhetoric in the press
column6: and booking the band to play state fairs
column7: rodeos
column8: and variety TV shows instead of the usual big-market concert halls.

column1: Only Young knows how genuine his new image really was
column2: but the recordings on A Treasury capture a very real desire to leave behind Geffen-- and the increasingly corporatized rock world-- by taking refuge in the heartland. Helped by the frenzied fiddling of Rufus Thibodeaux
column3: the Harvesters transform Harvest warhorse ""Are You Ready for the Country"" from FM-radio road-trip anthem into an advertising jingle for their own Nashville-bound sound. (Yes
column4: Old Ways' ""Get Back to the Country"" is included here
column5: too.) And if Young's label and old fans were frustrated by his Music City makeover
column6: the middle American audience ate it up. Auto-industry address ""Motor City""
column7: from 1981's Re-ac-tor
column8: may have originally been written in cranky character
column9: but on A Treasure
column10: an enthusiastic crowd receives its made-in-the-U.S.A. boosterism as gospel.

column1: However
column2: unlike previous Archives Performance Series issues
column3: A Treasure's set list pulls from a diverse
column4: career-spanning range of sources. The collection stands less as a specific document of an elaborate ""fuck you"" directed at Geffen and more as a testament to Young's undiminished reputation as a fiery
column5: inventive live performer-- even when he was releasing the weakest albums of his career. The standouts here are a pair of reworked obscurities: a gorgeous rendition of the Buffalo Springfield chestnut ""Flying on the Ground Is Wrong"" (written by Young but originally sung by Richie Furay) and a show-stopping charge through ""Southern Pacific"" that upgrades the Re-ac-tor version's sluggish boogie into a banjo-powered barn-burner.

column1: A Treasure also boasts five previously unreleased tracks. Some of them could have easily been left in the bootleg bin
column2: such as the cheeky tear-in-my-beer ballad ""Let Your Fingers Do the Walking"" and swinger ""Soul of a Woman""
column3: which predicts later Young band Bluenotes. But others handily transcend the datedness of so much 80s Neil. The sweet serenades ""Amber Jean"" and ""Nothing Is Perfect""
column4: for instance
column5: could sit comfortably among the timeless
column6: low-key classics on 1978's Comes a Time
column7: while the closing rager ""Grey Riders"" anticipates 1989 return-to-form Freedom. All of which suggest that Young's greatest affront to Geffen in the 80s wasn't making subpar
column8:
""unrepresentative"" albums. It was not giving the label the satisfaction of releasing his better efforts from the era.

column3: Malcom Lacey sings on ""Tearing Up Old Asphalt""

column5: Plantation. With his soft voice awash in electronic hums and next to a tranquil piano line

column1: Many different touchstones flow into one retiring mood. Opening instrumental ""In Old Theaters"" has the stately drive of M83. The standout ""Tiny Little Boy"" nods to R&B with splashy mechanical drums and a soulfully lilting vocal performance. A techno influence becomes more pronounced in the back half: On ""Blinds with You""

column8:
figuring out on his own what can be made of it all.

column3: any conversation about the music of Matt Valentine (MV) and Erika Elder (EE) is eventually going to touch on their prolific output. The Vermont duo's constant production has simply become one of its defining facts. In addition to a steady stream of studio albums for Ecstatic Peace!

column10: ominous pulse

column1: 1|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16653/homepage_large.3bc356c4.jpg|What I Became|26648.0|MV & EE|['Rock'
column3: any conversation about the music of Matt Valentine (MV) and Erika Elder (EE) is eventually going to touch on their prolific output. The Vermont duo's constant production has simply become one of its defining facts. In addition to a steady stream of studio albums for Ecstatic Peace!
column4: MV & EE have continued to release small-batch recordings on their own Child of Microtones label
column5: including a Dick's Picks-style series of live recordings on the offshoot Heroine Celestial Agriculture subsidiary.

column1: Over the course of this massive discography
column2: MV & EE's music has ranged through overlapping regions of pastoral psych-folk
column3: cosmic country and blues
column4: and expansive
column5: Crazy Horse-inspired guitar jams that occasionally cozy up against what was once known as grunge. As with many such prolific acts
column6: the duo's work can strike a balance between the deeply rewarding and the exasperating
column7: as each listener is bound to choose a favorite from among the different aspects of their sound. When fatigue sets in
column8: there seems to be little harm in sitting out a few albums and waiting for them to cycle back around again.

column1: MV & EE have now rewarded such patience with two fine new studio albums
column2: Country Stash and What I Became
column3: the latter of which is nominally a Matt Valentine solo album. On each album
column4: the musicians have drawn in the fences just enough to sharpen their focus on a specific portion of their overall sound. Longtime fans will find much to savor on both albums
column5: or
column6: failing that
column7: will almost certainly fall heavily for one or the other.

column1: It might sound strange to call an album that features multiple nine-plus-minute jams ""restrained
column2: but that nevertheless is how Country Stash can feel. Despite the extended guitar solos
column3: the album is one of MV & EE's most tuneful and song-oriented collections to date
column4: and their most immediately likable since 2006's Green Blues. Not too surprisingly
column5: the duo has found a kindred spirit in Woods' Jeremy Earl
column6: who contributes harmony vocals on ""Foxy One"" and ""Crash Palace of Records"". And though MV & EE have never been prone to creating the type of melodic hooks that actually prove hummable
column7: both of these tracks have the amiable spirit and loose-limbed energy that are familiar features on Woods records.

column1: MV & EE's albums have frequently benefitted from guest appearances
column2: including such notables as J Mascis and Sunburned Hand of the Man's John Moloney. Country Stash features perhaps their most unlikely collaborator yet in Andy Ramsay
column3: best known for his work with Stereolab and the High Llamas. Ramsay's high-precision style seems a counterintuitive match for MV & EE's improvisational wandering. But the pairing works surprisingly well
column4: with Ramsay providing atmospheric electronics
column5: percussion
column6: and production for ""Tea Devil"" and ""No There
column7: There"". ""Tea Devil""
column8: which has appeared on at least one previous MV & EE release in a different form
column9: is here rendered with a brooding
column10: ominous pulse
column11: as Elder delivers a smoldering vocal performance to craft an instant highlight in the group's catalog.

column1: Matt Valentine takes a largely different approach on What I Became. The album's solo billing is a little misleading: Elder contributes vocals to one track and Jeremy Earl adds percussion in several places
column2: while throughout MV applies a delicate lacing of acoustic and electric guitar overdubs. In other words
column3: this release doesn't seem that different from a proper MV & EE album
column4: and it achieves a sound that is more introspective than solitary.

column1: It is
column2: however
column3: one of Valentine's more folk-oriented albums in a good while
column4: and it should be a welcome sight for those who've been missing that side of his playing. On refreshing opener ""Continuing the Good Life""
column5: Valentine offers a reminder of what an expert acoustic picker he can be. On such tracks as ""PK Dick"" or ""Ave. B""
column6: the electric and acoustic instruments seem to descend upon the same spot from opposite directions
column7: illuminating the songs in hazy silhouette. Valentine's effects-heavy vocals tend to shy from the spotlight without Elder there for assistance; his voice often seems there as much to provide an atmospheric backdrop as to deliver his whispery lyrics.

column1: Both albums have been issued in nice-looking vinyl editions
column2: which is fitting. For as many cassettes and CD-Rs as MV & EE have released
column3: the immersive qualities of vinyl make it a natural format for the duo. Pressed in limited runs
column4: these albums might prove a little more difficult to track down
column5:
but by now MV & EE fans should be used to exercising patience.

Wet Hair have a long and long-winded history as some of the Midwest's reigning vibe merchants. The Iowa City duo's members-- percussionist Ryan Garbes and keyboardist/vocalist Shawn Reed-- used to play in Raccoo-oo-oon
column3: a sorely missed noise-rock group that released three records and a handful of rambling
column4: live-to-tape jam sessions before disbanding in 2008. Since then
column5: Reed in particular has established a heavy underground presence
column6: both through his Night People label (Peaking Lights
column7: Dirty Beaches
column8: Pocahaunted) and his hieroglyphic-style visual art.

column1: Where Raccoo-oo-oon went heavy on spastic syncopation and post-punk guitar skree
column2: Wet Hair have followed a mellower path. By patching rinky-dink synths through a bevy of effects
column3: they work up vintage krautrock haze on a DIY budget. The band's two albums have been heavy with luxuriant lo-fi drones and unhurried eight-minute bliss-outs. This time around
column4: they've opted to rein in the jams a little. Wet Hair's third LP
column5: In Vogue Spirit
column6: is its most straightforward batch of songs yet. Garbes and Reed temper their open-ended improv with the traditional stuff of rock: guitar riffs
column7: deep bottom end
column8: and propulsive rhythms.

column1: Album opener ""Echo Lady"" flows forward at full speed
column2: powered by fuzz-bass and motorik percussion beneath a wall of dizzying keyboard textures. It's In Vogue Spirit's immediate
column3: head-bobbing moment. After that
column4: things only get weirder. On ""Tarantula""
column5: a web of interlocking melodies spins over the distant rattle of a junk-shop drum machine. Reed delivers his lyrics in a cool-headed
column6: Alan Vega-worthy whisper
column7: which is then further obscured by a cloud of echo.

column1: In their previous output
column2: Garbes and Reed took heavy inspiration from the German electronic psychedelic music of the 1960s and 70s
column3: but added a layer of ear-scorching grit inherited from the mid-00s noise scene. On In Vogue Spirit
column4: their reference points have drifted toward the dreamy pop moves of Silver Apples and Spacemen 3
column5: as well as contemporary psych-droners like Moon Duo and Sun Araw. The headier compositions
column6: ""Liquid Jesus"" and ""Cosmic Radio""
column7: forgo distortion in favor of lush and dreamy texture.

column1: In both Raccoo-oo-oon and Wet Hair
column2: Garbes and Reed have been uncompromising in their pursuit of the outer limits. They set up a table full of banged-up doodads
column3: set the controls for the heart of the sun
column4: and let it rip. That hasn't changed. But with In Vogue Spirit
column5: Garbes and Reed have delivered a more consistent
column6: considered record. Space is still the place
column7:
but they've found shortcuts to getting there.

Early promo copies of Mercury Rev's Deserter's Songs were mailed out to press in a cardboard-replica postal packet
column4: complete with a stamp and a postmark advertising its release date. This was no random act: In 1998
column5: a new Mercury Rev album could have felt like a postcard from a long-lost
column6: old friend. Unlikely beneficiaries of the post-Nirvana major-label cattle call
column7: Mercury Rev initially overcame the inter-band acrimony that fueled their first two brilliantly frazzled albums (1991's Yerself Is Steam and 1993's Boces)
column8: only to slip further into oblivion with the more refined but commercially ignored 1995 release
column9: See You on the Other Side. A subsequent improvised recording released under the name Harmony Rockets (1995's Paralyzed Mind of the Archangel Void) suggested the band was forsaking populist ambition to delve deeper into the psych-noise underground. Aside from a songwriting credit for Rev ringleader Jonathan Donahue on the Chemical Brothers' Dig Your Own Hole
column11: Mercury Rev had effectively vanished.

column1: The arrival of Deserter's Songs on the nascent V2 label was a brow-raiser in and of itself; but that sense of pleasant surprise turned to dumbstruck disbelief once the CD was dropped in the player. Mercury Rev had flirted with symphonic flourishes and sentimental balladry before
column2: but usually delivered them in a haze of distortion (Boces' ""Something For Joey"") or cheeky
column3: irreverent arrangements (See You on the Other Side's ""Everlasting Arm""). Deserter's Songs' opening track
column4: ""Holes""
column5: however
column6: was something else entirely: Never before had Donahue left his helium-high croon so vulnerable and exposed
column7: and never before had the band's densely textured arrangements been deployed to such moving emotional effect
column8: with the song's eye-welling surge of orchestration and weepy bowed-saw lines perfectly complementing Donahue's crestfallen lyrics.

column1: And while there were always themes of New York state iconography running through the band's disjointed discography-- the Coney Island Cyclone
column2: the Rockettes
column3: Bronx cheers-- Deserter's Songs projected an especially vivid sense of place
column4: casting a set of intimate
column5: romantic narratives against the staggering natural beauty of the band's upstate New York surroundings. Credit producer/bassist Dave Fridmann for foregrounding certain agrarian classic-rock influences-- namely
column6: Jack Nitzsche-era Neil Young
column7: the Band
column8: and Brian Wilson-- that were heretofore buried behind the band's wall of squall; Mercury Rev even went so far as to solicit guest contributions from Levon Helm and Garth Hudson for some authentic Big Pink flavor.

column1: In a sense
column2: Deserter's Songs practically functions as a tourist brochure for the Empire State
column3: with the stirring centerpiece track ""Opus 40"" referencing both the titular stone-sculpture garden in Saugerties and the looming Catskill mountains
column4: while ""Hudson Line"" pays tribute to the train route that provides an upstate escape from New York City. I had always written off the latter track as Deserter's Songs' most frivolous-- owing to Hudson's supper-club-smooth sax line and the meek vocal courtesy of guitarist Grasshopper-- but in it
column5: we hear the album's guiding philosophy: ""Gonna leave the city
column6: gonna catch the Hudson Line/ You know I love the city
column7: but I haven't got the time.""

column1: Deserter's Songs was likewise a necessary act of retreat for a band that had long been defined by chaos and turmoil
column2: and its peaceful
column3: back-to-nature ethos felt all the more radical at a time when the harsh
column4: mechanized sounds of big-beat electronica and nu-metal dominated the airwaves. The album's considerable critical success practically spawned a sub-genre of its own
column5: with subsequent releases by the Flaming Lips (The Soft Bulletin
column6: also recorded by Fridmann at his Tarbox Studios)
column7: the Delgados (The Great Eastern; Fridmann again)
column8: and Grandaddy (The Sophtware Slump) all hewing to a similar balance of lyrical intimacy and orchestral expanse. And while Mercury Rev's spotty track record since Deserter's Songs has currently driven the band into the same sort of limbo in which they found themselves prior to recording the album
column9: you can still hear a distinctly Deserter's mix of the rustic and the epic in contemporaries like Fleet Foxes
column10: My Morning Jacket
column11: and Arcade Fire.

column1: Hopefully
column2: this 2xCD reissue will serve to raise the band's stock once again
column3: and that could very well be the true impetus behind this package; tellingly
column4: Mercury Rev have chosen to mark their 20th anniversary not by re-releasing their 1991 debut
column5: but rather the record that has effectively allowed them to survive for two decades. Collectors of Deserter's Songs' singles will know that
column6: for B-sides
column7: the band often resorted to its deep arsenal of covers
column8: but none of these is represented on this issue's bonus disc (presumably because many of them were already compiled on the 2006 best-of collection
column9: Stillness Breathes). But we do get a batch of rough yet illuminating demos that help connect the dots between Mercury Rev's experimental roots and Deserter's Songs' immaculate conception. The Tascam takes on ""Endlessly"" and ""Tonite It Shows"" sound closer to early-70s Lennon than their more Disneyfied final versions
column10: and the sax-less ""Hudson Line"" feels much less anomalous in this setting.

column1: Most remarkable of all is an embryonic version of ""Goddess on a Hiway""
column2: both for its crude
column3: tape-decayed presentation and its original recording date: 1989. That Donahue was sitting on Deserter's Songs' lead single for almost 10 years could be seen as proof of the early Mercury Rev's preference for the anarchic over the affecting. Or maybe he just needed to wait for his band's darkest
column4:
most uncertain hour to sing that chorus-- ""I know... it ain't gonna last""-- with the conviction and desperation it demands.

column2: 'Experimental'

column7: which pairs contemporary and classic electronic artists. Barwick drew Ikue Mori of the seminal no-wave band DNA
column8: who has ably kept up with new technology
column9: evolving from trap sets to drum machines to computer software. The four extended
column10: improvised movements that compose FRKWYS Vol. 6 are familiar turf for Mori
column11: but a whole new world for Barwick.

column1: The music was recorded in New York's White Columns gallery last fall-- half with the musicians each isolated in a cubicle; Mori with her laptop and Barwick with her looping console. (A video documenting the performance can be found here.) Right away
column2: with ""Dream Sequence""
column3: fans of Florine and The Magic Place will find themselves in new territory. Barwick's voice is lightly scattered amid an array of computerized slide whistles and metallic resonance-- not an enveloping presence
column4: but a thing among things. Several minutes elapse before she unleashes one of her trademarked melodious shrieks. Playing against Barwick's usual placidity
column5: it's almost chaotic
column6: but still has a clear build
column7: climax
column8: and resolution.

column1: Mori's music comes from machines but evokes the natural world
column2: pulling in sounds like dripping water
column3: crackling electricity
column4: and warped chimes. This is consistent across all four tracks
column5: though each has a singular arc and feel once you get past the uniformly distressed surfaces. On ""Stalactite Castle""
column6: Barwick's voice competes with mechanical vortices that call to mind Ellen Allien and Antye Greie. Then she takes a more leading and openly songful role on ""Rain and Shine at the Lotus Pond"" and ""Rejoinder""
column7: with an almost choral home stretch bringing the record to an arresting close.

column1: Barwick fans may feel an initial wave of disappointment that this doesn't bash you over the head with holiness the way her records do. And those who appreciate her music through the filter of Enya
column2: rather than Brian Eno
column3: may find Mori's haywire electronics simply indigestible. It's not the sort of thing you just throw on in the background
column4: as The Magic Place could be. But taken on its own terms
column5: it's a sneakily bewitching record that bodes well for Barwick's future. Until now
column6:
we knew that she was very good at one thing-- FRKWYS Vol. 6 is an encouraging sign that she's willing and able to branch out.

column5: say

column3: eats cold soup

DeCicca seems to be toying with country conventions here-- especially the earnest-seeming spoken word stuff-- but there's a deep tradition-steeped reverence to it as well. What seems a bit staid and straightforward at first reveals a subtle richness over time.

column3: sometimes averages out  into nonchalance
column4: and some of the black humor in these lyrics is a bit  funnier on paper than on the record itself. But he's always been sort of  a tricky read as a singer

column11: too
column12:
is Don't Blame the Stars.

Finland's Jori Hulkkonen and Jerry Valuri come from a long line of electronic musicians who
column2: instead of focusing on either dance or experimental music
column3: choose to put more emphasis on using traditional structures to craft dream-lit pop songs. On Change Is Gradual
column4: their second full-length release as Processory

column6: but like contemporaries the Tough Alliance

column8: accessible songs with an unusual bent

column1: There's something wonderfully familiar about these songs; you could swear that any number of subtle synth hooks and vocal turns have been patched-in from some reimagined Tears For Fears or Spandau Ballet track. Dramatic
column2: distant and oddly sexual

column10: this strange final cosmic arc somehow manages to take you somewhere very far away.

column3: and there's no getting around the fact that it can be daunting. But Hulkkonen and Valuri do their best to break up the frozen detachment
column4: offering a few groove-centric detours. ""Take Me to Your Leader"" is a smoky
column5: Balearic-tinged body-rocker
column6: and ""Recovery Measures"" glides and jukes with an appealing foreignness.

column1: As if that weren't enough
column2: Change Is Gradual comes supported by three separate EPs
column3: featuring remixes from heavy-hitters like Hercules and Love Affair
column4: CFCF
column5: and Aeroplane. The result is yet another full hour of music. Fortunately

column10:
and it sometimes feels as if all this music has just mushed together in your brain. But Processory's ambition and hard work ultimately trumps the album's exhaustive length.

column2: McCartney and McCartney II are the first two post-Beatles albums to be credited solely to Paul McCartney
column3: without Wings or Linda McCartney. In that respect

column1: Wings had no John Lennon to play foil to McCartney. Lennon and McCartney

column11: was certainly genuine
column12: but he wrote this eventual FM-radio staple as a classic

column14: Paul McCartney never did-- even in this intimate setting
column15: his songs remain extroverted and devoted to achieving some measure of pop accessibility.

column1: The highlights of McCartney's later solo albums were often uptempo rock songs
column2: or big
column3: show-stopping tunes
column4: but here
column5: apart from ""Maybe I'm Amazed""
column6: the peaks include two versions of the same quiet song
column7: ""Junk"". The sparse vocal version features McCartney accompanying himself with acoustic guitar and a bit of bass and percussion
column8: ticking through a nostalgic inventory of disused objects. McCartney later reprises ""Junk"" in a ""singalong"" instrumental version
column9: with mellotron and piano joining in for a pretty waltz. I'd be surprised if Elliott Smith didn't learn something from it. Much of the rest of the album was written and recorded off the cuff
column10: and it shows-- McCartney plays with Latin rhythms (""The Lovely Linda"")
column11: a bit of blues (""That Would Be Something"")
column12: and some bounding
column13: half-time country pop (""Man We Was Lonely""). ""Teddy Boy"" is sentimental storytelling
column14: and closer ""Kreen-Akrore"" is McCartney experimenting in his weird
column15: humorous way with oddball drum patterns and sound effects.

column1: That sort of experimentation and lack of polish was something McCartney didn't often allow himself on later solo efforts. As the 70s moved on
column2: he got back to consciously crafting big hits
column3: and he scored quite a few. Ram
column4: Venus and Mars
column5: and Band on the Run rank among the best Beatles solo albums
column6: and all exhibit the kind of studio perfectionism that was absent on McCartney. On McCartney II
column7: the polish is there
column8: but that's partly down to improvements in home recording technology-- McCartney did much of the recording on his own at his farm in Scotland
column9: and there's a similar low-pressure
column10: anything-goes vibe to the final product. That said
column11: this album is likely to be jarring for an unsuspecting McCartney or Beatles fan. It's largely experimental
column12: devoting most of its songs to eccentric synth-pop that's just as weird as anything from the early days of new wave
column13: and not all of it is compelling.

column1: McCartney II's opener and first single
column2: ""Coming Up""
column3: wastes no time getting right into this startling territory
column4: with a guitar part that could have been lifted from a Talking Heads song
column5: buzzy keyboard hooks
column6: and vocals that find McCartney singing through a filter and backing himself up with quirky falsetto. McCartney's discography is actually filled with strange little one-offs and experiments
column7: including late-period work with Super Furry Animals and Fireman
column8: but this one is unusual for the way he presented it as a central part of his output rather than a side project.

column1: Elsewhere on the album
column2: McCartney remains similarly difficult to pigeonhole. If I told you the instrumental ""Front Parlour""
column3: with its tinny drum machine and sunny keyboard melody
column4: was a 2009 blog hit by a lo-fi synth act
column5: you'd likely believe me. And then there's ""Temporary Secretary""
column6: a frankly irritating but still interesting song that combines frenzied synth programming with a self-consciously bizarre vocal-- McCartney sings as nasally as possible on the refrain
column7: and tweaks it to sound robotic. Other songs turn away from this type of maximalist approach. ""Summer's Day Song"" is pretty and sparse
column8: featuring just McCartney and a few keyboards. TLC-presaging single ""Waterfalls"" is even more bare
column9: only McCartney and an electric piano
column10: with a tiny dollop of synth and acoustic guitar.

column1: Two other songs stand out on McCartney II
column2: and they're as distinct from each other as this record is from McCartney. Album closer ""One of These Days"" is simply great
column3: benefiting from a rudimentary approach that strips away the synths and drum machines that dominate McCartney II. Bonus track ""Secret Friend""
column4: included on the second disc of this reissue
column5: is also pretty jaw-dropping-- a 10-minute
column6: beat-driven synth opus that shares plenty in common aesthetically with dance music a decade its junior. Though relegated to the B-side of the ""Temporary Secretary"" single
column7: ""Secret Friend"" is among the most forward-looking things McCartney has recorded in his post-Beatles career.

column1: Those McCartney II extras stand in sharp contrast with the bonus material for McCartney
column2: which is largely inconsequential-- the live tracks are 1979 performances with Wings
column3: hardly illuminating where McCartney was as an artist at the time he made the album. Still
column4: McCartney is a very good record and deserves another look. And this is just about the perfect time to take another look at McCartney II
column5: despite its flaws. Parts of the album sound oddly current; it's difficult to gauge whether McCartney II had any real influence on the synth-pop of the 80s
column6: but its diffuse and slightly wobbly atmosphere certainly aligns with a great deal of recent music made on synths and drum machines. Though an odd couple in many ways
column7: these two albums represent often-overlooked corners of McCartney's music
column8:
and they're worth rediscovering.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16659/homepage_large.be54e9b5.jpg|Castlemania|5758.0|Thee Oh Sees|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['In the Red']|2011-06-15 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:55.848529|"

Over the past decade
column2: San Francisco's Thee Oh Sees have morphed from a showcase for skronk-savant John Dwyer's sensitive side into the hardest working band in garage-rock. Their output is prolific and their live show combustible. But on Castlemania
column3: Dwyer opts to go it alone. With the exception of live-band regular Brigid Dawson-- who
column4: along with the Sandwitches' Heidi Alexander
column5: contributes some backing vocals-- the shaggy-banged songwriter handles almost all of the instruments. Drummer Mike Shoun and Guitarist Petey Dammit aren't out of the picture permanently. They're just off-duty until the fall
column6: when Thee Oh Sees are scheduled to release yet another full-length record.

column1: Castlemania is a fairly introspective affair
column2: at least by Oh Sees standards. It's Dywer's most melodious batch of songs since 2006's mostly acoustic Cool Death of the Island Raiders. Without the heavy full-band artillery he leans toward skewed bubble-gum pop
column3: fleshing out the guitars and drums with flutes
column4: bells and thrift store synths. It was recorded
column5: at least in part
column6: at Dywer's former group house. ""This here is the last record worked on at 608c Haight Street in San Francisco (very near and dear to my heart and heavy in my memories) before control was assumed by rich assholes
column7: he writes in the liner notes.

column1: Not that this is Thee Oh Sees' answer to Nebraska. Even at his most reflective
column2: Dwyer's songwriting retains a sinister
column3: ""Sesame Street""-on-LSD sensibility-- simple melodies and creepy lyrics
column4: frequently delivered in a whacked-out monster-voice. ""It don't feel too good to be dead in the 21st century/ I am dirt but I can be/ A home for wayward hungry seeds
column5: Dwyer growls on ""I Need Seed""
column6: deploying a Looney Tunes-worthy narrative in a song about death. It's summery retro nuggets pinned into the red
column7: shot through with a healthy dose of drugs and dread
column8: while ""Pleasure Blimps"" finds him singing of machines stripping away flesh over shimmering glockenspiel lines and 12-string guitars.

column1: All in all
column2: Castlemania is a fairly loose and scattered record. There are plenty of oddball tangents
column3: including a stripped-down and spooky cover of West Coast Pop Art Experimental Band's ""I Won't Hurt You"" and the forlorn mellotron and sax instrumental
column4: ""The Horse Was Lost"". Songs frequently melt down into racket rather than stop on a dime. But it's good to hear Dwyer step away from his backing band's big guns
column5:
if only for a moment.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16621/homepage_large.a4c4c104.jpg|Locussolus|29721.0|DJ Harvey|['Pop/R&B'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['International Feel']|2011-06-15 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:56.273801|"

Harvey Bassett has had a long and idiosyncratic career in dance music
column3: one that speaks as much to the necessity of scene and tastemakers in that sphere as actual musicians. At least partially responsible for the spread of influential house and disco sounds to England
column4: the Cambridge-born Bassett spent the 1990s booking DJs like Larry Levan in London and holding supposedly awesome residencies at a handful of influential clubs. These days
column5: Bassett resides in Los Angeles where he hosts his epic
column6: invite-only Sarcastic Disco parties. Suffice to say that if it was dance music and it was created in the 1980s or 1990s
column7: Bassett was on that shit before you.

column1: Not that Bassett wasn't making music as well; he was just doing so sporadically and seemingly in deference to his career as a party-starter of unimpeachable taste. DJ Harvey Presents Locussolus represents the first time in Bassett's 20-year career that a full-length CD of his work will be available (he released a Late Night Sessions mix for London's Ministry of Sound in 1996). (It's a fitting title
column2: ""Locus Solus"" being the private estate of a mad scientist in Raymond Roussel's novel of the same name.) It's not a proper album-- not even particularly close-- rather a collection of the three Locussolus 12""s he has released since 2010. One new track
column3: ""Bloodbath""
column4: and remixes by the likes of Andrew Weatherall and Lindstrom & Prins Thomas round out the collection.

column1: Sequenced cleverly
column2: Locussolus actually functions well as a long player. If you close your eyes and forget the track titles
column3: the fact that ""Gunship"" is just one track removed from a remix of itself makes it sound more like a variation on a theme rather than CD padding. Bassett is all over the dance music map
column4: but he mostly sticks to the sounds of mid-80s electro and house
column5: with heavy doses of Ze Records hippie-dust. It is a beguiling and slippery mix. During Weatherall's dubby ""Gunship"" remix
column6: as a lunatic rants about hams in the middle of the street (20 listens later and I'm still flipping a coin to decide if this is a metaphor)
column7: I am certain I am listening to electronic music and that DJ Harvey made this music
column8: but little else. Locussolus isn't immersive; rather
column9: it commands your attention without making a fuss about it. ""I Want It"" checks of most of the ""classic house"" boxes-- thick
column10: salty basslines
column11: insistent kick drums
column12: reverberating synth pads-- but Bassett's banal
column13: circular back-and-forth with a female voice gives the track life as it morphs into a (G-)funky strut. ""Tan Sedan"" steams forward as a sci-fi floor-filler
column14: its UFO-synths jamming languorously over its lock-step bassline.

column1: Bassett isn't a sonic radical
column2: just a hip
column3: studied craftsman unafraid to let his freak flag fly. For those of us not privy to Harvey's parties-- old or new-- Locussolus is a treat: a document of one of dance music's behind-the-scenes/decks all-stars. That's where Harvey made his name
column4: but this set proves that he has plenty to offer as a producer as well. A late-career burst of activity would be welcome
column5: but there's no use getting ahead of ourselves. Enjoy Locussolus for its loose
column6: loving swagger
column7: a rare transmission from inside Bassett's private
column8:
mad utopia.

"|15501.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15501-locussolus/|7.3|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16658/homepage_large.79e52d79.jpg|The Errant Charm|4520.0|Vetiver|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2011-06-15 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:56.742861|"

Saying a record makes great background music is usually taken as damningly faint praise at best. Sure
column2: the music sets a mood-- so what? But for something to fade gracefully into the scenery
column3: it has to be finely crafted enough that nothing snags or jars. Unobtrusiveness isn't always a fault
column4: nor is attention-grabbing necessarily a virtue. I realized this one afternoon last summer at a BBQ
column5: where Vetiver's 2009 album Tight Knit was playing at low volume from another room
column6: providing the perfect sonic wallpaper for the day: gentle folk songs drifting into not-quite-yacht rock-- wooden ship rock
column7: maybe. The album didn't grab your attention so much as gently hold your interest
column8: complementing rather than interfering. Paradoxically
column9: half-listening to the album revealed something that giving it full focus did not. It was like some ""Doctor Who"" creature that you could see in peripheral vision but which disappears when you look directly at it.

column1: Vetiver's new album
column2: their fifth (and second for Sub Pop)
column3: pulls off much the same trick. This is part sound design:The drums are muted
column4: often no more than a muffled kick pulse; the guitars are finger-picked acoustic or else electric with the edges slicked entirely off; and singer/songwriter Andy Cabic holds his vowels long and lofty
column5: sighing his lyrics as much as singing them. It's also part songwriting: Cabic's melodies are impeccably understated
column6: and his leisurely lyrics set an undeniably easy-going mood. This sort of thing has been Vetiver's lane since their anomalously freak-folky debut
column7: and there's not much here in the way of either deviations or dramatic leaps forward; if Cabic and longtime producer Thom Monahan have tinkered with the band's sound
column8: their improvements are subtle enough as to be imperceptible.

column1: Of course
column2: given time
column3: the best background music insinuates its way into your foreground
column4: and after about a week with The Errant Charm
column5: a few of its highlights will work their way into a listener's head: the way Cabic's vocal traces the guitar scale on the chorus of ""Worse for Wear""; the cruising JJ Cale vibe of ""Ride
column6: Ride
column7: Ride""; the deck chair-ready guitar glide of ""Fog Emotion""; the soft organ trill and backbeat to ""Can't You Tell"". Best of all is ""Wonder Why""
column8: an upbeat and unreservedly catchy number
column9: driven by bright guitar picking backed by piano
column10: bobbing bass
column11: chords that rev up to the chorus
column12: and the album's most straight-ahead
column13: snare-hitting drumming. Over the top of it
column14: Cabic harmonizes and hums
column15: world-weary and a little worried
column16: but still sounding largely optimistic.

column1: Presumably if Cabic-- formerly of dub percussionists Tussle and frequent touring sideman of Devendra Banhart-- just wanted to make an ambient drone album
column2: it would certainly be within his powers
column3: and it would probably be fine. But his songs as Vetiver
column4: for all their breezy lightness
column5: seem to aspire to something more like the spotlight
column6: or at least the talking-stick spot at the campfire. The Errant Charm doesn't entirely succeed in that regard
column7: but it remains a pleasant listen
column8:
perhaps just a bit too subliminally so for its own good.

"|15537.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15537-the-errant-charm/|6.4|Eric Grandy

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16642/homepage_large.437e1219.jpg|Ways of Meaning|28249.0|Kyle Bobby Dunn|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Desire Path']|2011-06-15 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:57.420099|"

For a drone artist
column2: the differences between one release and the next are often subtle. It comes with the territory. You make subtle music to begin with
column3: and like any artist you feel the burden of not wanting to repeat yourself. Kyle Bobby Dunn clearly feels this burden. He's been making drone records since 2002
column4: and since 2005 he's released a fairly steady stream of albums
column5: EPs
column6: limited cassettes
column7: and other small-run recordings. So he's covered a lot of ground within his style already.

column1: Ways of Meaning sticks to what we already know Dunn does well: patient drone. But it does it differently from anything he's released before. It's his least varied and most musically active album
column2: though that's not quite as paradoxical as it may sound. Here
column3: Dunn is focused on a certain type of rounded
column4: pillow-soft tone that has the feel of cold
column5: clear air
column6: or in its more active moments
column7: the play of light underwater. But there's a lot you can do with those types of sounds
column8: and Dunn does a lot over 40 minutes. With one exception
column9: he keeps the pieces short and homed-in on a single idea
column10: leaving behind both the rougher
column11: organic tones and the longer structures of much of his past work.

column1: The album opens with a pair of pieces that move in opposite directions to explore dissonance and consonance. No music made with the sounds Dunn uses could ever be described as harsh
column2: but ""Dropping Sandwiches (in Chester Lake)"" manages to make them slightly unsettling by combining them in strange harmonies. The purity of the tones and half-empty texture of the music have a strange effect on the dissonant harmony
column3: though-- rather than coalescing into a sour chord
column4: the notes seem to hang next to each other in gentle disagreement. Tones overlap on ""Canyon Meadows"" with a rhythm roughly equivalent to wind chimes-- there appears to be no set meter for the comings and goings of individual tones
column5: but the clamor as they emerge and disappear still constitutes a harmonious whole.

column1: The one long track
column2: ""Movement for the Completely Fucked""
column3: essentially stretches the rest of the album's approach across 15 slowly drifting minutes. ""Drifting"" is really the right word for it
column4: too. When I think of more ballasted drone music
column5: like that of Stars of the Lid

column7:
because those sounds seem like they'd take some effort to move. But these feel like they might blow away and drift forever if you let go. Ways of Meaning is drone music with a light touch and the gravity turned off.

This Bakesale reissue is actually part of Lou Barlow's second unexpected reunion of the last decade. The first
column3: of course
column4: was his thought-it-would-never-happen rapprochement with longtime estranged partner J. Mascis in Dinosaur Jr. And then Sebadoh
column5: the one-man-project turned full-blown band
column6: found its second and best-loved line-up coming together again late last decade. The early Sebadoh records were purposefully fuzzy
column7: mumbly things
column8: full of raw pop yearning that was sometimes pretty hard to make out through all the hiss and crackle. Though they were key documents in the rise of lo-fi as a distinct movement in 1990s American indie
column9: it's probably not coincidental that the word ""weed"" appeared prominently in several of the band's early releases
column10: which often literally sound like the product of a baked mind and a four-track
column11: flip-flopping between silliness and vein-opening.

column1: As Sebadoh became more of a democracy
column2: the clashing urges of the various songwriters (Barlow
column3: bassist Jason Loewenstein
column4: second guitarist Eric Gaffney
column5: who left before Bakesale) turned the full-band's first few records into sometimes frustrating (the CD skip button was made for these sort of jumbles) and sometimes beguiling (they had a real way with an anthemic pop-punk hook when they wanted to) collisions of styles. Pure indie-pop instincts fought with an urge toward experimental cassette tape fucking around. Bouncy power-chord jams rubbed up against shameless acoustic mopery. By Bakesale in 1994
column6: they'd already written a couple of undeniable anthems with ""Gimme Indie Rock"" and ""Brand New Love""
column7: the latter an instant-classic covered by peers like Superchunk in what seemed like seconds after it's release. But Bakesale was the first Sebadoh album where the power-chords and anthems seemed to win out. It was
column8: and remains
column9: their most focused and purely pleasurable record.

column1: The early- and mid-90s were great years for albums that brought punk's two-minute punchiness together with the earnest relationship laments that briefly defined that slippery terrain known as indie rock. And Bakesale is one of the era's best. If it's got fewer romance-gone-wrong epics than Superchunk's Foolish and lacks the emphatic guitar-snarl of Archers of Loaf's Icky Mettle
column2: it combines bits of both tendencies into 15 songs that rarely outstay their welcome. Unlike Sebadoh's scattershot early albums
column3: it works as a brief
column4: memorable whole. The band probably wasn't trying to make a statement-- that sort of ran counter to the whole aesthetic back then-- but by tightening up and aiming for clarity
column5: they managed one anyway. ""Feels good just to bitch about it
column6: from ""Magnet's Coil""
column7: is one of those lines that defines a certain part of early indie's appeal
column8: where kids-like-you kvetched about their foibles and fears in an unpretentious way. But the album's frantic pace
column9: where even the slow songs feel like urgent expulsions of heartbreak
column10: defines the other side of indie's appeal. At its best
column11: all that emoting was delivered with a healthy shot of energy that felt necessary given the sluggish tempos of alt-rock radio at the time.

column1: Bakesale sounds a little brighter on this remaster
column2: though this isn't an album where you're really looking for crisp and distinct-in-the-mix instrumental interplay. Its opening three-song blast
column3: all tumbling drums and jittery-but-beefy noise-pop guitar
column4: is an obvious attempt to grab the attention of a new generation of kids who'd sprang up to embrace feelings-and-feedback. But even the somber stuff
column5: like the ""Not a Friend"" to ""Dreams"" run early on
column6: features strong
column7: clear hooks instead of burying things in murk. This isn't to say the album is clean
column8: at least not in the way indie records routinely are these days. But it's also not ""lo-fi"" in the indistinct or noise-obliterated way we've come to know. Without sacrificing the music's rough edges
column9: the band was up enough on its hook-game that ""Rebound"" briefly hung around modern rock radio
column10: Barlow's first unexpected minor-league hit until Folk Implosion's ""Natural One"" became the really unexpected hit a few years later.

column1: So Bakesale itself remains a strong and lovable essay on 90s indie's charms. But what of the expected and extensive bonus material? Well
column2: in bearing-down to make a no-filler album
column3: it's pretty clear that Sebadoh's goof-off and boo-hoo sides went into the singles
column4: EPs
column5: and ancillary material from the same era. Tunes (using the word very loosely) like ""MOR Backlash""
column6: ""Foreground""
column7: and ""Drumstick Jumble"" sound like the ""wacky"" bedroom sound-collage filler they would have been if they'd been included on Bakesale
column8: and acoustic demo takes of ""Not a Friend"" and ""Mystery Man"" prove how quickly charming sensitivity can give way to unfortunate sad-sack territory when you strip away the electric oomph of the album versions. (Though the acoustic ""Magnet's Coil"" and ""Rebound"" prove they could hit you without any amplification.) Despite a few strong songs like ""Punching Myself in the Face Repeatedly
column9: Publicly"" and ""Sing Something/Plate of Hatred"" that can almost stand with the album's best
column10: these Bakesale add-ons will mostly be of value to those who loved Sebadoh's first few years of all-over-the-place wildness
column11:
but it's not as if their second-disc inclusion can dull the parent album's punch.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16637/homepage_large.acb40c9a.jpg|An Empty Bliss Beyond This World|29716.0|The Caretaker|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['History Always Favours the Winners']|2011-06-14 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:27:58.898151|"

An Empty Bliss Beyond This World sounds like a collection of edits of prewar parlor-room music because that's what it is. ""This Caretaker album is built from layers of sampled 78s and albums
column2: James Kirby told me in an email recently. ""Things have been rearranged in places and other things brought in and out of focus. Surface noise""-- which is abundant-- ""is from the original vinyls.""

column1: Kirby is an artist whose concepts are sometimes more fun to engage with than his music. As V/Vm-- a project he started in the early 1990s-- he made grotesque edits of soft-pop songs and released an entire 7"" of the sounds of pigs feeding. His albums as the Caretaker have been comparatively more subdued
column2: tending toward ambient music made from preexisting recordings.

column1: Bliss was inspired by a 2010 study suggesting that Alzheimer's patients have an easier time remembering information when it's placed in the context of music. What makes it unique isn't that Kirby resuscitates old but vaguely familiar source material; it's how he edits it. Several of the tracks here take pretty
column2: anodyne phrases and loop them mindlessly; several stop in what feels like mid-thought; several reach back and then jump forward. They never feel filled-in from start to finish
column3: and they tend to linger on moments that feel especially comforting or conclusive: the last flourishes of a song
column4: maybe
column5: the pat on the shoulder
column6: the part when we're assured everything is drawing to a close. Kirby isn't just making nostalgic music
column7: he's making music that mimics the fragmented and inconclusive ways our memories work.

column1: Unlike Kirby's last few albums
column2: whether as the Caretaker or Leyland Kirby
column3: Bliss isn't dissonant or heavy-handed. Nobody has to remind me that losing my memory is upsetting
column4: or that I'm losing it as I type
column5: or that the loss will probably accelerate as I get older
column6: or that I'll probably spend my final hours sitting by a window repeating myself. What I like about Bliss is that
column7: as the title suggests
column8: there's something at least metaphorically beautiful-- even slightly funny-- about living inside a locked groove
column9: dancing with nobody.

column1: The last five years or so have been filled with music that feels haunted by an unresolved moment or looks at the past from a crooked perspective. The Ghost Box label has been consistently good at making jigsaw puzzles from cultural memories; Ariel Pink's grotesque soft-rock finally has an audience-- even music by a producer like Burial relies on the intrusion of a voice that sounds more part of history than the present
column2: something reaching forward from a time we thought was gone. Kirby isn't unaware of what he's doing here-- everything he's put out in the past few years plays around with these ideas directly
column3: down to his choice of titles (2009's <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/13891-sadly-the-future-is-no-longer-what-it-once-was/"" target=""_blank"">Sadly
column4: the Future Is No Longer What It Was being the most impressively gymnastic). Even calling himself ""The Caretaker""-- a reference to the endlessly recurring ballroom parties of The Shining-- feels like an effort to suss out the inherently psychedelic properties of memory.

column1: Bliss reminds me of Ekkehard Ehlers' ""Plays John Cassavetes 2"" and Gavin Bryars' ""Jesus' Blood Never Failed Me Yet""
column2: two pieces that transcend high-concept nostalgia. ""Cassavetes"" is a layered loop of the opening string figure from the Beatles' ""Good Night""
column3: and the Bryars piece-- which was explored in a column here last year-- is a loop of a homeless man singing a hymn as an orchestra gradually builds behind him. In both cases
column4: the actual amount of musical material is relatively small
column5: and the ""work"" done on the part of the composer is minimal-- even Bryars' 30-minute build consists mostly of consonant drones.

column1: Bryars' and Ehlers' conceptual leap was to wear their moments out as completely as possible. Repetitive music has a way of dissolving a listener's ability to pay attention to it: by the end
column2: Ehlers' and Bryars' pieces sound different from the beginning
column3: but there's no part I can point to in them and say
column4: ""here
column5: here's where things change for good."" They're constantly changing. They're also constantly returning. With Kirby
column6: the effect is even more subtle and confusing. ""Libet's Delay""
column7: sounds like it confuses its end for its beginning (or vice versa)
column8: and ""Mental Caverns Without Sunshine"" appears twice
column9: with a two-minute song in-between: It's as though Kirby is trying to trick you into experiencing déjà vu. In all three cases
column10: the source material is music designed not only to comfort
column11: but to sound like it existed before you: hymns
column12: love songs
column13:
lullabies. Bliss is eerie because it takes the seduction of those forms and turns it slightly askew; there's something unsettling about the musical equivalent of a permanent smile.

Depending on which article or news story you read
column3: Holy Other could hail from Manchester
column4: Gothenburg
column5: Stockport
column6: or Berlin. The fact-shy producer is apparently now settled in Manchester
column7: but there's a sense of disconnection that remains integral to his ghostly productions. There's a strong sense of loneliness in the swarm of sampled vocals that make up the spine of the tracks on With U
column8: reflecting both in the way Holy Other treats his sources and the mixture of genres he pulls from.

column1: Take the title track
column2: which shuffles out from a poppy
column3: electronic piano sample in a motif that is at once disarmingly gentle and slightly creepy. As skittering rhythms pan from left to right
column4: a pitched-down vocal bathes the track in darkness
column5: and ""with you"" is the only discernable lyric as the sample repeats. The track has a yearning sound
column6: each element working to intensify that feeling
column7: from the off-kilter piano line to the vaporous layers of reverb. That echoing atmosphere is abundant on the EP and has a knack for making Holy Other's production seem tantalizingly half-solid and transient.

column1: ""Touch"" uses the same kind of tricks with a lithe vocal line at the heart of the track. This time
column2: the voice sounds closer to the kind of manipulations Burial mined so successfully on Untrue. That kind of skewed affectation has been a common device in electronic music since then
column3: but something about Holy Other's cloud of overlapping vocal samples gives it a different
column4: more romantic feel. While that busier vocal work makes up the bulk of the track
column5: an ominous bass line thunders deep in the mix
column6: gliding slowly from note to note. The drop is one of the more noticeable signifiers from witch house and aligns Holy Other more strongly with other Tri Angle Records artists Balam Acab and oOoOO.

column1: The glacial drag of those artists is reflected again on closing track ""Feel Something""
column2: with its starkly contrasting bass and trebly keys. It shares the listlessness and detached atmosphere common in this scene
column3: but once again Holy Other's use of vocals pulls the track somewhere unexpected. This time
column4: the sample hews closer to its native pitch and feels all the more striking for it. Transplanted out of its original context
column5: the latent sensuality and drama in the vocals are squeezed down to their stark essence.

column1: On first listen
column2: the haze of With U can seem pro forma
column3:
but diving deeper beneath the surface reveals a deceptively fragmented record made up of enticing titbits and interesting juxtapositions. It's a strangely affecting synthesis of sounds and marks Holy Other's short debut out as a darkly oppressive but ultimately rewarding piece of work.

In a certain dark corner of the music universe
column2: Aesop Rock was a very
column3: very big deal. As arguably the biggest name on the Definitive Jux roster
column4: Aesop made for an unlikely star
column5: but I can vividly remember the hordes of hoodied
column6: stubble-headed
column7: tough-looking suburban and outer-borough kids who'd cram into clubs and roar along with his bent
column8: cluttered
column9: wriggling lyrical abstractions. Aesop was and is a born cult figure
column10: his sleepy stoner charisma intersecting just right with his berserk linguistic flights. And in the Def Jux world of clattering psych-rap production and elaborate sci-fi packaging
column11: he did more than fit in; he stood above.

column1: The Aesop era seems like it's been over for a few years
column2: and there are a few reasons for that. Rap moves fast
column3: and we're seeing a whole new wave of Internet-borne young rap iconoclasts; old cults give way to new ones. Definitive Jux
column4: a label built at least partly on gorgeous packaging and object fetishization
column5: wasn't built for today's world; it effectively closed up shop last year. But mostly
column6: Aesop just hasn't been around. He released his last album
column7: None Shall Pass
column9: and where he once guested on virtually every album that his scene produced
column10: his verses have become less and less frequent. So it's truly refreshing to see Aesop return in pleasantly low-stakes form
column11: as one of three guys in the new group Hail Mary Mallon. On Are You Gonna Eat That?
column12: Aesop and co-conspirators Rob Sonic and DJ Big Wiz don't exactly let up on the brain-addling lyrical and musical density. But the album isn't some grand statement. They sound exactly like what they are: three guys off in a room somewhere
column13: making rap music and having fun doing it.

column1: Rob Sonic is an old Def Jux labelmate of Aesop's
column2: and to say they've got chemistry might be understating things a bit. For stretches of the album
column3: they practically sound like the same person. Rob's been getting Aesop comparisons for years
column4: and his style is truly similar; like Aesop
column5: he raps in tumbling nasal syllable-clumps
column6: blasting us with one obscure image and then moving onto another before our brains have caught up. His delivery is a bit less guttural and more straightforwardly laid back
column7: but he's got the same commitment to fucking with our collective head. (The first line of Rob's first verse on the album: ""Leopard print Speedo on the FDR
column8: saying 'Follow that car!'."") Rob and Aesop jointly produced the album
column9: and their combined style is a psychedelic knock familiar to anyone who ever paid attention to Def Jux: fuzzed-out guitars fighting for space with sputtering cluster-bombs of drums. But there's also a variation to it; the album's over in 41 minutes
column10: and the tracks jump restlessly from one idea to the next. Choruses are rare; Big Wiz's precise
column11: musical scratches usually play that role. And there's not a single rapping guest on the album; this is strictly a family affair.

column1: At times
column2: they sound like they're having too much fun; the absurdist 808 thud of ""Grubstake"" and the intentionally annoying chipmunk voices of ""Breakdance Beach"" were probably more enjoyable to record than they are to hear. But there's real joy in hearing Aesop and Rob compete to see who can come up with the most inscrutably memorable turn of phrase. (Aesop wins on ""Garfield"": ""Document the war of the department-store Santas from the POV of cameras hid in the dog's antlers."") About a decade after the Def Jux boom
column3: it's almost comfort food to hear these guys slip-sliding over bent beats like these
column4: but it's still a heady
column5: potent experience. And it reaches a peak on final track ""Plagues and Bacon""
column6: on which Aesop tries out a double-time flow over a twisting speedball of a psych-dance beat. These guys may not be back in their ambition-heavy fighting form on Are You Gonna Eat That?
column7: but they're back to rapping just for the fuck of it
column8: and that can be a beautiful thing to hear. And hearing the album
column9: it's immediately apparent that Aesop is still a major talent
column10: someone who can do whatever the hell he wants and get away with it.

column1: Aesop's next album might be a collaborative thing with Moldy Peaches member Kimya Dawson
column2: and that's a confounding prospect but also an intriguing one. Are You Gonna Eat That? is a retrenchment move
column3: but that's OK. But once Aesop returns to full-on bent-experimentalist mode
column4:
that's when he could really become a force again.

An Horse frontwoman Kate Cooper spends the band's second album
column2: Walls

column4: ""Trains and Tracks""

column6: plaintive vocals and the music's ripping uptempo blur. Even with more space to breathe
column7: though

column9: taking a more ruminative but still rousing emo-indie tack on ""Dressed Sharply"" and ""Know This
column10: We've Noticed""
column11: songs that show you why the band made a worthy opening act to Death Cab for Cutie in 2008.

column2: and the results are accordingly hit or miss. Her heartsick complaints can grab you by the throat when the band's pleading too

column8:
""Ian Curtis said it would tear us apart.""

Junior Boys started out making ridiculously complex music that had the intimate feel of a bedroom-based indie project. They'd mastered the intricate rhythmic syncopations of UK garage and Timbaland-style R&B
column3: genres that had turned inventive and impossibly tricky rhythm programming into a game of pop oneupsmanship. Which is hardly the sort of thing that you'd want to hear an amateur's take on. But JBs' music was presented as if it were something fragile
column4: homespun
column5: made on a shoestring
column6: full of negative space where the pop fizziness should be. It added an interesting
column7: affecting friction to a sound that had defined glossy marquee pop around the turn of the millennium
column8: like the difference between a love song written to please millions and one aimed at a special someone.

column1: Pretty quickly
column2: though
column3: on 2006's So This Is Goodbye and especially 2009's Begone Dull Care
column4: the JBs music started sounding like a million bucks
column5: whatever it cost to make. This wasn't necessarily a bad thing. There had always been an element of slick soulful 1980s synth-pop in their sound
column6: and when they jettisoned the new millennium R&B touches
column7: it was shocking and enjoyable to find out they actually had the production chops to mimic that 1980s opulence.  But what about that one-on-one intimacy that had originally made them stand out? In that sense
column8: It's All True sounds like the album the Junior Boys have been moving toward their whole career. It's got the same low-key mixtape-from-a-lover charm as Last Exit
column9: but sacrifices none of the appealing slickness of their last few albums.

column1: Opener ""Itchy Fingers"" is actually a bit of bait-and-switch. It's the most deliriously dense tune on the album-- multiple basslines
column2: stuttering R&B breakdowns
column3: Art of Noise vocal stabs
column4: zapping rave riffs
column5: gleaming Japan/Duran-style guitar-- a master class in just how much you can squeeze into a track without its seeming cluttered. It recalls the carefully plotted textural overload of UK funky producers like Ill Blu
column6: even if the feel is still more disco-house smooth than frantic Jamaican ragga. But ""Itchy Fingers"" is more or less an anomaly. It's All True mostly dials back the sonic excess in favor of more streamlined grooves. Thankfully
column7: the album also corrects the lack-of-hooks problem that occasionally plagued Begone Dull Care. ""Second Chance"" is still stuffed with whirling video game noises
column8: and some glorious creamy vocal multi-tracking
column9: but what stands out on first listen is that naggingly catchy bassline. Plus Jeremy  Greenspan gives us his best batch of choruses in quite a while
column10: and good thing
column11: too. While this is still headphone music par excellence
column12: all those gleaming little sonic gewgaws and sneaky ear-worm off-beats are often pushed to the back of the mix
column13: meaning the bright lounging-on-the-yacht electro hooks and Greenspan's voice both have to do a lot more work here.

column1: Greenspan's singing is the best it's ever been on It's All True
column2: proving the band's mixing desk skills aren't the only thing that's matured over the past eight years. Where he initially sounded wounded and winsome
column3: almost hiding his voice behind the stark beats
column4: here he displays a bouncy
column5: strident sense of playfulness. Just check the ecstatic peak-after-peak outro on ""Banana Ripple"". There's also a new subtlety to his breathy just-out-of-bed tenderness that weirdly reminds me of Sam Prekop
column6: no faint praise considering Prekop is the reigning master of this sort of thing. And speaking of subtle and tender
column7: along with the large helpings of dancefloor joy
column8: some of the album's most immediately arresting moments are its sparsest and most fragile. ""The Reservoir"" is an ultra-delicate experiment in seeing how far a rhythm can be stripped back-- something that would have fit perfectly on Last Exit
column9: though it sounds far richer  here
column10: with Greenspan pulling off a falsetto he never would have been able to in the old days. Despite a few curveballs
column11: like the pinpoint precise homage to Kraftwerk and the bleep techno Kraftwerk inspired on ""Kick the Can""
column12: there's not much ""new"" here if you've been following the Junior Boys' sound over the last decade. But considering they seem to have perfected that sound here
column13: it's hard not to feel like they should keep making albums like It's All True for a long
column14:
long time.

column2: psych-folk
column3: and electro-glitch all share a root context

column8: hi-hats
column9: and claps that sound culled from a dozen long-buried sources

column1: The other two originals debuted last year as a digital single

column8: spectacular things with drum breaks.

column1: Out of three additional remixes

column4: overstuffed remix of ""Def Surrounds Us""-- show just how tacky contemporary drum'n'bass bombast can be

Lobelia

column1: With a careful mix of banjo
column2: guitar
column3: field recordings
column4: and electronics

column6: bittersweet scenes of domestic life. ""Summer Street"" might be an appropriate title for a lithe
column7: summer-of-fun jangle

column9: it's the score for waves of heat rising from blacktop

column12: hazy guitar notes fall through tape fuzz and slide guitar moans

column16: comfortable melody above the hum. Even the most threatening sights feel like home

column18: with predictable images warped by the very personal contexts of the messages scribbled on the back. Like Alessandro Stefana's Poste e Telegrafi

column1: In instrumental music

I want to live Jackie-O Motherfucker. I want to quit my pretty good downtown job and follow the band around Europe. I want to trade poorly recorded tapes with other superfans and scoff mightily at the non-believers. This is the type of devotion JOMF should inspire. To date
column3: the long-running Portland collective's scabrous interpretation of Americana has been appropriately grimy and confrontational: Bandleader Tom Greenwood is the odds-on favorite to shiv a Fleet Fox. Lately
column4: though
column5: the band's increasingly tame albums haven't lived up to its reputation.

column1: Earth Sound System is structurally similar to recent JOMF offerings-- Valley of Fire
column2: Ballads of the Revolution-- in that it features a handful of tracks split between extended improvisations and disarmingly straightforward electric balladry. JOMF have remained noisy
column3: but tragically
column4: they've discovered organization. The first track on Earth Sound System
column5: ""In the Willows""
column6: features Greenwood mumbling over bent chords
column7: like a grounded
column8: broken-winged Spiritualized. The next track
column9: ""Raga Joining""
column10: is a scraping jam
column11: a drum machine bursting out of a flute in a rug warehouse.

column1: The songs
column2: especially
column3: sound cursory. Perhaps this is due to familiarity
column4: once-fresh ideas that now seem rote. But I don't think so. JOMF used to build tracks around ideas
column5: around snippets of speech or old hymns: They had ties to history
column6: a history that JOMF were either besmirching or honoring (or both) with their treatments. Valley of Fire
column7: for instance
column8: featured two long tracks
column9: one tethered to a ramshackle funk sermon and the other a tribute-- however tenuous-- to a Public Enemy song. But Greenwood's voice
column10: a distinctly 1990s strain of off-key alt-troubadour
column11: offers no such tether to the past.

column1: The concepts that were brilliantly muddled in Greenwood's mind-- noisenik gristle
column2: folksong
column3: skronky improvisation-- are now compartmentalized. The impulse is understandable: Greenwood is hardly the first artist to appropriate traditional songcraft before wanting to try his hand at it. But the songs on Earth Sound System lack the purpose of their inspiration. They lack even the dark hippie rhetoric the band is most capable of. When the band attempts bracing garage rock on the closing ""Where We Go""
column4: they suck their air out of the room with their hoary posturing.

column1: Earth Sound System offers a different vision of JOMF
column2: but a lesser one. Greenwood and co.'s impulses have grown disappointingly easy to dissect. The result is music that
column3: by any definition
column4: remains experimental and difficult
column5: but the invigorating internal tension between the ordained simplicity of American musics and the free-will noise jams has evaporated. It's possible to appreciate Earth Sound System merely for its mossy overgrowth
column6:
but I'm not quitting my day job.
