There comes a time in every rock'n'roll band's career when they have to decide whether to get out of the garage or stay mired in the grease. Black Lips seem to want it both ways. With the release of their fourth studio album
column2: 2007's Good Bad Not Evil
column3: the Atlanta rockers saw their audience expand well beyond the garage-punk underground
column4: thanks to a new alliance with Vice that yielded fawning New York Times profiles
column5: Conan O'Brien appearances
column6: and Virgin Mobile ad placements. At the time
column7: a Hives-sized crossover success didn't seem out of the question
column8: but the Lips seemed to handily kibosh that possibility with 2009's 200 Million Thousand
column9: a sprawling mess that seemed designed to prove Black Lips could still out-scuzz and out-slop the lowest of the lo-fi.

column1: The band's decision to record Arabia Mountain with Amy Winehouse producer Mark Ronson is surprising
column2: not because they're at odds aesthetically-- the two camps do share an affinity for 1960s retro recording techniques-- but because of the timing: hooking up with an A-list producer is the sort of move that would've made more sense two years ago
column3: to capitalize on Good Bad Not Evil's mainstream-breaching momentum. But whether they're responding to Vice's vocal dissatisfaction with 200 Million Thousand or following the example of their late friend Jay Reatard-- whose 2009 swan song Watch Me Fall saw him cleaning up his buzzsaw-pop sound without compromising his essence-- Black Lips seem more eager to play ball this time around. And unlike previous cautionary examples of garage-rock bands teaming up with Top 40 hitmakers (the Hives and Pharrell
column4: the Mooney Suzuki and the Matrix)
column5: Ronson thankfully doesn't try to make Black Lips into something they're not.

column1: Though an early single had the loaded title ""New Direction""
column2: Arabia Mountain sticks to the same Nuggets-style playbook that's governed all previous Black Lips releases. Ronson
column3: who produced nine songs and mastered another two recorded with Deerhunter's Lockett Pundt
column4: simply gives the band the most faithful faux-60s production money can buy. If anything's changed here
column5: it's Black Lips' point of emphasis on the Nuggets spectrum: Arabia Mountain draws less from the sinister psychedelia of the 13th Floor Elevators or the deranged blues of early Beefheart
column6: and more from the toga-party-rockin' likes of the Sonics and the Premiers. So it favors the more amiable aspects of 60s garage-- frathouse-rocking saxophones
column7: songs inspired by comic-book superheroes and baseball mascots
column8: and grooooovy singing saw-- over anti-authoritarian attitudes and fuzzbox abuse.

column1: Black Lips have never been shy about showing off their playful side
column2: but in the past
column3: these moments (Let It Bloom's poignant
column4: poor-boy ballad ""Dirty Hands""
column5: Good Bad Not Evil's outsider anthem ""Bad Kids""
column6: 200 Million Thousand's sober-up pledge ""Starting Over"") nicely complemented their more raucous rave-ups
column7: revealing a sincere softer side to the band's notorious delinquent image. With Arabia Mountain exuding a mostly cheeky and cheerful demeanor
column8: you do lose some of the oppositional tension between innocence and insolence that always distinguished Black Lips from the garage-punk pack. And with a somewhat bloated 16-song tracklist
column9: the album's abundance of open-roof Thunderbird anthems-- ""Go Out and Get It""
column10: ""Time""
column11: ""New Direction""-- starts to feel somewhat interchangeable.

column1: But Arabia Mountain's chiseled production and considerably tighter songcraft provides a better forum for showcasing the band's subversive sense of humor. The best songs here play up the dichotomy between their retro sound and modern preoccupations: bad acid trips at the Louvre (the Yardbirds-ish freakbeater ""Modern Art"")
column2: exotic fad diets (the breezy Beach Boys-via-Ramones romp ""Raw Meat"")
column3: and post-recession survival tactics (the spot-on country-Stones send-up ""Dumpster Diving""). And in anticipation of those old-school fans who might view Arabia Mountain as a calculated act of careerism
column4: the Lips throw a late-game curveball with the queasy closer ""You Keep on Running""
column5: a creepy haunted-house trawl that finds Cole Alexander issuing the title's warning in a high-pitched squeal that's equally unnerving and silly. Its inclusion sends a none-too-subtle message to anyone who thinks they've got Black Lips all figured out: Arabia Mountain may be poised to push this band further over-ground
column6:
but they're not going up without a fight.

that won't be the case much longer.

Buzzcocks were a different kind of punk rock band. Though inspired by the savage fury of Sex Pistols
column2: the Manchester-based quartet founded by Pete Shelley and future Magazine leader Howard Devoto directed that energy toward explosively melodic songs that located their punk politics not in universal slogans or transgressive gestures but in personal anxieties. And Buzzcocks are still different today. The buzzsaw-sharp songs from the band's late-1970s peak have aged better than most
column3: continuing to influence new generations of musicians. The group's more recent reunion albums and tours
column4: moreover
column5: have done nothing to diminish that formidable legacy.

column1: A Different Compilation
column2: which brings together new studio recordings of 24 of Buzzcocks' most vital songs
column3: can be seen generously as another example of the band's willingness to stand apart. ""The original records now sound like demos
column4: Shelley explains in the press materials. ""These new versions
column5: honed by years on the road
column6: showcase the songs as we know they should be
column7: the way we know audiences love to hear them."" On the other hand

column9: and anyone unfamiliar with the band would still be better off starting with 1979 classic Singles Going Steady; diehard fans wanting to hear newer recordings of the old songs
column10: meanwhile
column11: might already be content with 2007's 30 or other Buzzcocks live albums. Plus
column12: there's a whole mixed history of artists re-recording their hits
column13: from the unfortunate K-Tel oldies remakes to Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy's more imaginative Greatest Palace Music. Just in 2008
column14: also on Cooking Vinyl
column15: college rockers Camper Van Beethoven had to re-record a few songs for a best-of compilation due to label conflicts.

column1: Hand-wringing aside
column2: this is a well-chosen set of compelling songs
column3: and if new recordings can probably never match the charm of Buzzcocks' originals
column4: there's still a certain modest appeal to hearing one of punk's most celebrated catalogs given a brawny
column5: contemporary treatment. Where Singles sets out iconic singles like ""Orgasm Addict"" and ""Ever Fallen in Love (With Someone You Shouldn't've)"" next to their B-sides
column6: A Different Compilation also delves into Buzzcocks' often-underrated album tracks
column7: from Ralph Nader-nodding Another Music in a Different Kitchen opener ""Fast Cars"" (here shorn of its introduction quoting the 1977 Spiral Scratch EP's ""Boredom""
column8: ostensibly because that track now precedes it) to guitarist Steve Diggle's Dookie-predicting ""When Love Turns Around""
column9: originally from 1993's Trade Test Transmissions.

column1: Then again
column2: though these hard-hitting versions of such memorable punk-era nuggets as ""Harmony in My Head"" and ""Why Can't I Touch It?"" start from only the strongest source material
column3: A Different Compilation lacks the adventurous spirit that helped make the band so worth compiling in the first place. Buzzcocks are often credited with inventing punk-pop
column4: but that genre's modern-day conventions weren't so solidified then-- think of the difference between early disco records and the disco of Village People and Saturday Night Fever-- and there's little here musically you might not hear from some of the band's lesser descendants. And
column5: too
column6: it's not exactly as if there's a huge audience clamoring for re-recordings of late-70s and early-80s Martin Hannett productions (Joy Division
column7: New Order)
column8: which is what we're given here in the form of ""Boredom""
column9: fellow Spiral Scratch track ""Breakdown""
column10: and Diggle-fronted former B-side ""Why She's a Girl From the Chainstore"".

column1: So while A Different Compilation definitely isn't a starting point for newcomers to Buzzcocks
column2: it's nothing more or less than a novel document from one of punk's defining bands-- and one of the few from punk's first wave that's still a going concern
column3: at that. ""When people put punk rock records on in 1976
column5: they had to rethink their whole lives
column6: Diggle told Pitchfork's Patrick Sisson in a January 2009 interview. ""It changed your consciousness
column7: the way you looked at the world
column8: just like powerful records should."" This latest compilation probably won't do that
column9:
but it might help point you back to the records that did-- and could again.

These Trails was recorded in Honolulu in 1973 and originally released in a small private pressing
column3: and it is one of those rare albums whose backstory is almost wholly audible in the music. Primarily written and performed by singer-songwriters Margaret Morgan and Patrick Cockett
column4: the album has long circulated among fans of obscure psych-folk
column5: and it has been reissued several times in perhaps-not-entirely-legit versions. The album's reputation is well-earned
column6: as These Trails is a lovely and incredibly evocative slice of Pacific folk-rock
column7: and Drag City has performed a good service by finally reissuing the album in a handsome new authorized edition.

column1: The musicians behind the creation of These Trails were never even officially a band-- they played no professional gigs together and made no other recordings. (Which is why there are no outtakes or bonus materials included with this reissue.) Margaret Morgan and Patrick Cockett lived together in Hawaii in what sound like idyllic circumstances
column2: writing and playing songs based largely on the majesty of their natural surroundings.  The duo was joined in the studio by singer-guitarist Carlos Pardeiro and Dave Choy
column3: a studio engineer who embellished the group's acoustic material with what was then a state-of-the-art Arp synthesizer. The addition of these vintage electronics helps to give the album a slightly off-kilter wobble
column4: creating an otherworldly atmosphere that would echo decades later in the work of Stereolab and Broadcast.

column1: For the most part
column2: however
column3: the music on These Trails sounds as though it could have been created only in its own specific time and place. Like many of the best psych-folk documents of the era
column4: the album seems to have been produced in a completely irony-free environment
column5: and it has a sense of guilelessness that would be virtually impossible to reproduce today. Morgan sings in a voice highly reminiscent of Joni Mitchell
column6: but with a distinctive island lilt of her own. Throughout the album she harmonizes with Cockett in a manner that sounds both unique and effortless
column7: backed chiefly by acoustic guitars
column8: dulcimer
column9: and Choy's mysterious burbling Arp.

column1: Lyrically the album abounds with references to local Hawaiian landmarks
column2: flora
column3: and vocabulary.  Songs such as ""Our House in Hanalei"" or ""Waipoo"" can serve as a sort of personal guidebook
column4: with Morgan and Cockett pointing out various natural features along the trail. (""Banana leaves describe the breezes... gingers grow
column5: where white buds lay sleeping."") Especially evocative is ""Rusty's House""
column6: which describes a visit to the front porch of surfer Rusty Miller
column7: whose remote home was accessible only by foot
column8: in an account so vivid that the listener can practically feel the sunshine and taste the pot smoke.

column1: Even more transporting are the album's instrumental interludes ""Psyche I"" and ""Psyche II""
column2: on which Choy gently explores the Arp's cosmic possibilities. These mildly trippy moments aside
column3: most of the action on These Trails remains firmly affixed in the verdant Hawaiian soil. The songs are short and melodic
column4: and the musicians avoid many of the indulgences that mar so many psychedelic albums of the time period-- there are thankfully no prolonged organ solos or overt references to The Lord of the Rings.

column1: Patrick Cockett has gone on to perform with such artists as Buffy Sainte-Marie and Taj Mahal
column2: but by all evidence the enigmatic Margaret Morgan
column3: who passed away in 2004
column4: never recorded again. This fact makes These Trails seem all the more like a snapshot from an exquisite but fleeting moment in time. And though it is interesting to speculate where their music might have gone from here if the artists had continued to write and record together
column5: there is no denying that they captured something special on These Trails
column6:
and while the album plays that seems like enough.

The years preceding the American Bicentennial were especially good ones in Nashville. Not only did country music graduate from a rather large niche market to the mainstream

column3: as songwriters like Guy Clark
column4: Kris Kristofferson
column5: Donnie Fritts
column6: and Willie Nelson attracted so much attention that the scene became known as the ""New Nashville."" In practice
column7: this group of musicians raised hell all over town and wrote aching songs with unpretentiously poetic lyrics
column8: passing their compositions up the ranks for royalties and notoriety. A few became stars in their own right: Nelson's Red Headed Stranger was a critical and commercial hit
column9: and Kristofferson became the scene's sex symbol. But some of the most talented songwriters simply faded into the background
column10: with albums that were invariably praised by critics but largely ignored by listeners. Despite a robust voice and a thoughtful way with medleys
column11: Larry Jon Wilson retreated to Augusta
column12: Georgia
column13: but managed a comeback just prior to his death last year. Mickey Newbury
column14: disgusted with industry politics in Nashville

column1: Some of the scene's success can be attributed to Newbury

column4: and Kenny Rogers (if you've heard ""Just Dropped In (To See What Condition My Condition Was In)""

column7: he remains a songwriter's songwriter
column8: lionized by a new generation of musicians including Will Oldham
column9: Nick Cave
column10: and the Black Swans' Jerry DeCicca (who says he got the job producing Wilson's 2009 comeback album based on his thorough knowledge of Newbury's catalog).

column1: Drag City's new bundle of reissues-- which includes three albums plus a set of rarities from the late 1960s and early 70s
column2: released separately on vinyl and together in a 4xCD set titled An American Trilogy-- portrays Newbury as a man out of time and out of place
column3: even among his friends in the New Nashville scene. With his gently grainy voice and folksy phrasing
column4: he was country more by proximity than by sound
column5: and he incorporated jazz
column6: R&B
column7: and folk elements into his forward-thinking music. These three LPs are all heady concept albums of a sort
column8: sequenced to create and sustain a particular mood of grievous loss and precarious composure. Newbury conceived them specifically as a trilogy examining his own romantic past as well as the country's contentious history
column9: and 40 years later
column10: they sound just as imaginative
column11: evocative
column12: and emotional as ever.

column1: Looks Like Rain
column2: from 1969
column3: was actually Newbury's second album. Just a few years prior
column4: RCA had paired him with a producer who lent his songs a too-slick sheen that Newbury detested. When he re-recorded them
column5: he kept closer control on the music
column6: casting the songs as spare
column7: lonely ruminations on lost love and lost opportunities and barely masking his own depression. But there's always dignity in his despondency
column8: and there's always something rumbling in the background of these albums: the crisp guitar and ghostly doo-wop vocals on ""33rd of August/When the Baby in My Lady Gets the Blues""
column9: the otherworldly choir on ""San Francisco Mable Joy""
column10: the mournful harmonica on ""Looks Like Baby's Gone"". There's real space on these albums
column11: which are so lonesome and introverted that Newbury's flourishes of sound are less an accompaniment to his vocals than his fond memory of music half-remembered.

column1: Looks Like Rain is
column2: quite literally

column4: which reinforces the sense of back-porch reverie. It ought to be corny as hell
column5: a tired gimmick meant to literalize certain aspects of the songwriting. The effect
column6: however
column7: not only allows the album to cohere into a listen-in-one-sitting experience
column8: but reinforces the emotional alienation of these songs. Newbury liked the idea so much that he repeated it on subsequent albums-- a musical element as distinctive as an artist's signature on a canvas. Those interludes and other musical flourishes stitch these albums together as a whole effort
column9: not inseparable but certainly more powerful in each other's proximity.

column1: Another of Newbury's signatures was his fascination with old American songs. Arguably his biggest hit was ""An American Trilogy""
column2: a medley from 1971's 'Frisco Mabel Joy that interlaced ""Dixie""
column3: ""Battle Hymn of the Republic""
column4: and ""All My Trials"". It was at that time a contentious piece of music: At the tail end of the civil rights movement
column5: there were calls to ban ""Dixie"" for its slavery connotations and sympathies
column6: although Elvis Presley's over-the-top Vegas cover helped dispel some of that controversy. Newbury's arrangement is conceptually fascinating
column7: as it pairs a southern song written by a northerner with a slave spiritual imported from the Caribbean. Musically
column8: however

column10: almost quaint-- more an artifact from the period than a durable piece of music.

column1: And yet
column2: ""An American Trilogy"" reveals Newbury's complex approach to songwriting and album sequencing: Every word or line or stanza or song complements the others and shades their meanings
column3: contributing crucially to the whole. On all of these albums
column4: his songs shift and melt into other songs
column5: creating thoughtful medleys and often devastating juxtapositions-- such as the one-two punch of ""How Many Times (Must the Piper Be Paid For His Song?)"" and the gorgeous synth theme of ""Interlude"". That means songs like the relatively spry ""T. Total Tommy"" on Looks Like Rain and ""Why You Been Gone So Long"" on 1973's Heaven Help the Child stand out all the more strongly for being so self-contained. On the other hand
column6: it means Better Days
column7: a disc of demos
column8: live recordings
column9: and rarities
column10: sounds particularly jarring in this set for not cohering into a more powerful whole. The songs themselves are strong
column11: in particular a version of ""Why You Been Gone So Long"" that rivals Johnny Darrell's hit version
column12: but they work primarily as songs

column1: When he was living in Nashville and even after he headed as far west as he could go
column2: Newbury strove to capture something larger and more powerful than a song or even an album. This handsome set doesn't suggest exactly what he was trying to find

column6:
that makes these albums resonate as powerfully today as they ever did.

column5: nor can Tobin's melodies stroll for long before finding a cliff's edge. It's hard to imagine ISAM accompanying another artist's work: It is by no means gallery-pleasing mood music
column6: and its constant stops and starts are immensely distracting.

column1: Tobin used to be a dependable
column2: dedicated craftsman
column3: but he's intent on transitioning to full-on sonic artist. He has the ideas: ISAM's pieces keep wandering into unmarked industrial zones
column4: evoking broken things and blight. But this is heavy
column5: foreboding music; Tobin hasn't yet learned how to balance his robust sound-art impulses with footholds for his listeners. He'll get there-- he's frankly too talented not to-- but ISAM feels like a transitional album
column6:
for his fans if not for him.

column7:
Canta Lechuza is at its best.

column3: Sandinista!
column4: and The Shape of Punk to Come spring to mind-- but few groups in this sphere have pushed the envelope as often as Fucked Up. For the last few years
column5: they've been releasing singles as part of a series based on the Chinese Zodiac
column6: each of which usually runs over the 10-minute mark. For a 2007 charity Christmas single
column7: they managed to get James Murphy
column8: Nelly Furtado
column9: and ""Degrassi: the Next Generation""/""90210"" actress Shenae Grimes (among many
column10: many others) to appear on the same song; during a 12-hour (!) NYC concert in 2008
column11: they got moshers to smash along to Vampire Weekend's Ezra Koenig doing Descendents covers. Their reach continues unabated on their new album
column12: David Comes to Life
column13: a 78-minute rock opera.

column1: The story of David Comes to Life is fairly complicated and
column2: at points
column3: heavily meta. It concerns a factory worker named David Eliade who falls in love with a woman named Veronica Boisson. They conspire to build a bomb together and death
column4: destruction
column5: and redemption follow; along the way
column6: the story's narrator does battle with David for control of the plot. There's a long tradition of rock concept albums that aren't easy to understand
column7: and this one is no exception; but enjoying it doesn't depend on decoding the tale. The record is divided into four separate acts
column8: with a narrative focus that shifts from scene to scene-- a few songs are told from the overarching narrator's perspective
column9: while David's ex-girlfriend
column10: Vivian Benson
column11: offers her side of the story in the album's back half. While a few guest vocalists are employed to help out-- Cults' Madeline Follin and singer/songwriter Jennifer Castle represent Veronica and Vivian
column12: respectively-- the story is largely told by the band's screaming frontman
column13: Damien Abraham
column14: aka Pink Eyes. Taking into account the album's relatively limited range-- almost an hour and a half of straight-up bashing and riffage
column15: with moments like the jangly acoustic figure that opens ""A Slanted Tone"" as a rare respite-- it becomes apparent that you will need a few listens and a lyric sheet to apprehend David Comes to Life's ambition and follow its labyrinthine storyline.

column1: Or
column2: you could just sit back and let the record's dense
column3: visceral blast of guitar squall wash over you. More than any single Fucked Up record
column4: David Comes to Life is thick with walls of noisy melody. It's hard to get a handle on just how many guitar tracks are on a given song
column5: and Shane Stoneback deserves a medal for mixing the sheer bulk of the sound into something so clear. But for all the shoegazey textures and blistering sonic assault
column6: David Comes to Life is also direct and immediate. Hooks are piled on top of hooks
column7: bursting through torrents of spacey noise (""I Was There"") and peppy rhythms (""The Recursive Girl"") alike. At points
column8: the primal appeal of the blunt and effective riffing even brings to mind the bar-band rock of the Hold Steady.

column1: Out front
column2: Abraham still retains his scorched-earth bark. He's been finding ways to broaden his voice's impact
column3: and it's never sounded better than it does here. Abraham knows his range and limitations and is finding new ways to work within them while adjusting to the band's forward lurch
column4: in effect becoming another instrument in the mix. His stomping melancholia on ""Turn the Season"" feels like a gut-check
column5: while he follows up his sole quiet moment on album closer ""Lights Go Up"" by shouting amidst curled screams
column6: ""I'm still in love with you/ After all of this time!"" Besides the aforementioned appearances by Follin and Castle
column7: Kurt Vile delivers a typically slack backing vocal on ""Lights Go Up""
column8: too-- but
column9: really
column10: this is The Pink Eyes Show
column11: and it's never been so compelling to watch.

column1: That said
column2: all the howling and the album's extreme length might be a tough thing for those new to Fucked Up. For people in this category
column3: it might be best to check out Hidden World first; it's a good representation of how fun and hooky Fucked Up are when they're in the zone
column4: and in many ways it's a simpler
column5: spiritual precursor to this record. Regardless
column6: David Comes to Life is absolutely worth the commitment
column7:
a convincing demonstration of what can happen when a band works without limitations.

A few seconds into Tigerskin's remix of ""In Chains""
column3: a pro forma Martin Gore song from 2009's Sounds of the Universe
column4: there's a startling sound-- a little two-note metallic clank
column5: off-pitch but ear-grabbing in a way the rest of the track (and most of the album) isn't. It's the opening noise of Depeche Mode's 1984 single ""People Are People""
column6: or something a lot like it
column7: and it's a reminder that the band used to be about sound as much as mood and tune and personality.

column1: The first decade's worth of Depeche Mode songs were eminently remixable
column2: because they almost all had sonic signatures: You could put together a terrific version of anything on
column3: say
column4: Some Great Reward without even using their melodies or vocals. ""Personal Jesus""
column5: from 1989
column6: got over on its glam beat and a sneering electric guitar that the band treated like the coolest new gizmo they'd ever encountered. But for the past 20 years-- and especially since Alan Wilder left in 1995-- their arrangements sound more like the work of a generic band-that-uses-electronics
column7: and most of the remixers here don't replace them with anything particularly distinctive either.

column1: As its title suggests
column2: the 3xCD Remixes 2-- also available in a condensed single-disc edition-- is a sequel to another brick of a set
column3: 2004's Remixes 81-04. That collection consisted mostly of fondly remembered mixes that had appeared on Depeche Mode's 12"" singles over the years
column4: with a few newly commissioned reworkings of old favorites. Since then
column5: they've released two awful-ish studio albums
column6: whose single remixes are drawn on heavily here
column7: along with a bit of barrel-scraping for passable older stuff
column8: like Gareth Jones' 1985 remix of ""Fly on the Windscreen""
column9: and another smattering of new interpretations. There are some big names here: UNKLE
column11: Trentemøller
column12: Dan the Automator (who sadly doesn't take on ""John the Revelator""). Few of them are doing anywhere near their best work
column13: because they generally don't have much to work with.

column1: There's some good stuff here anyway
column2: probably a really solid EP's worth. Röyksopp's ""Puppets"" reaches all the way back to a 1981 album track-- it's effectively a half-rewritten cover of the song rather than a remix proper
column3: but they sound like they're having a blast. It's fun to hear the two ex-members of Depeche Mode each remixing a song written after his departure-- Vince Clarke does ""Behind the Wheel"" and Alan Wilder does another version of ""In Chains"". Digitalism's take on ""Never Let Me Down Again"" takes advantage of its one-note melody to build up a head of scalding digital distortion. And of the three mixes of ""Personal Jesus"" here
column4: one is pretty good. (That would be the one by Stargate
column5: who are big enough Depeche Mode fans that they snuck a musical quote from ""Master and Servant"" into Rihanna's ""S&M"". Their version is also one of only three tracks on these three discs to come in under the four-minute mark.) Mostly
column6: though
column7:
this is a depressing reminder of the distance between what Depeche Mode once were and what they've become.

British songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Tom Vek popped up in the mid-2000s as part of a wave of clever
column5: twitchy
column6: studio-centric punk-funk acts following on the early success of the Rapture and DFA. He wasn't necessarily part of that scene
column7: but he benefited from having a fashionable context
column8: and so his debut album
column9: We Have Sound
column10: was a modest success. After that record
column11: Vek essentially disappeared from the pop landscape as he went about setting up his own studio and gradually piecing together his second album
column12: Leisure Seizure.

column1: Waiting six years to follow up a debut record is not usually a good move
column2: but it has worked out well for Vek. Since indie music fashions have moved on since 2005
column3: he no longer comes across as being part of a larger trend
column4: and his idiosyncrasies are more apparent. He's dropped a lot of the post-punk tics of his debut
column5: but his emphasis on rhythm remains
column6: with nearly every track built around a crisp
column7: precise beat. His compositions are neat and tidy; he cycles through textures and sounds but avoids clutter and unnecessary doubling of parts. There's a ruthless efficiency to his music that can be very attractive
column8: but even at his best
column9: Vek sounds like a producer just on the verge of finding his own distinct style.

column1: Vek's voice
column2: often flat and heavily accented
column3: is alternately one of the most appealing and most off-putting elements on Leisure Seizure. He's very good at affecting a petty
column4: bratty tone
column5: and this suits the bitter
column6: confrontational character of album highlights ""A Chore"" and ""Aroused"". Vek has a limited vocal range
column7: but it's obvious that he's put a lot of thought into how to play to his strengths and switch up his technique. At some points he exaggerates his flatness for effect-- for one particularly successful example
column8: he drags out his syllables over the swinging beat of ""We Do Nothing"" to convey a sense of boredom. He's most compelling when he employs a sinister singsong on ""A Chore"" and the semi-rapped ""World of Doubt""
column9: casting himself as something of an antagonistic presence.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: Vek's voice outstays its welcome by the middle of the album. Leisure Seizure is front-loaded with its best material
column3: such that the second half of the record becomes rather tedious. ""Close Mic'ed""
column4: a slow-moving ballad
column5: is an admirable experiment in pushing for greater range
column6: but his voice just isn't fully suited to the material and ends up spoiling the track's subtle dynamics. Other cuts on the second side
column7: such as ""You Need to Work Your Heart Out"" and ""On a Plate""
column8: just feel overworked and uninspired. There's a spark missing on these numbers
column9: and the most exciting elements of Vek's style become grating as a result. It doesn't spoil the high points on the album
column10:
but it does make us yearn for a more consistent and fully realized Vek record. Hopefully we won't have to wait until 2017 for that.

Arriving in the context of 2011 dance music's taste for niche
column2: Tom Trago's new album Iris feels almost refreshing for its ""broad church"" style of eclectic populism. It wanders through a variety of dance sub-genres (admittedly all variations of house and techno) with that air of assumed ownership that used to be the hallmark of big statement dance music albums in the late 1990s. It wasn't ever thus: the Dutch producer's 2009 debut
column3: Voyage Direct
column4: was a rigorously focused throwback to lo-fi second wave Chicago house disco loops
column5: as tunnel-visioned as any purist could hope for. Whether intentional or not
column6: Iris feels like a stab at main stage crossover by comparison
column7: a short-circuit bid for the kind of statesmanship long enjoyed by Carl Craig.

column1: Iris even sounds like the kind of album Carl Craig might make if he got down with vocal house more intently. It cycles between dreamy
column2: spacey
column3: exquisitely produced mood pieces and surprisingly upfront but still painstakingly airbrushed vocal house (this time splitting the difference between first wave Chicago and brassy New York divatude)
column4: all wrapped up in a sensibility of rhythmic looseness swiped from 80s R&B. The rhythms are the album's key drawing card
column5: fluttering and flexing with delectable voluptuousness-- a surprise given the uncompromising straightness of Voyage Direct. Trago also has a light touch with gently murmuring basslines and sweeping synth chords
column6: wrapping them around his rhythms like so many layers of fairy floss. In fact it's difficult to think of a recent dance album so unabashedly pretty at all times
column7: deploying its top-shelf production nous to caress
column8: rather than impress
column9: its audience. The gorgeous
column10: delicate Metro Area shimmy of ""Being With You"" is a particular delight.

column1: All of which should make Iris pretty compelling indeed
column2: and I've puzzled long and hard over why it's
column3: somehow
column4: not. The short answer is that the vocal tunes that ought to provide the album's highlights are almost uniformly underwhelming
column5: capturing everything but the bittersweet euphoria that is vocal house's most noble contribution to culture. On moments like the stagey soul of ""Suckers For Fools"" (whose repetition of its title could move less patient listeners to acts of self-harm) or the classicist diva workout of ""Gave Me the Love""
column6: Trago is nothing if not scrupulous
column7: pulling out every possible production trick and arranging with infinite care and attention to detail the succession of melodic and sonic motifs that confirm he has studied the masters. But the key to crafting truly transcendent dancefloor anthems is to conceal within them an indefinable intensity--  physical
column8: emotional
column9: or preferably both-- that can't be reduced to their sonic signifiers. Trago comes close to this only once
column10: on the aching and undulating synth-disco strut of closer ""Corrupt"".

column1: It's not that Trago can't do intensity. Although I'm not sure that it was the superior album
column2: at its best Voyage Direct certainly generated a great deal of dancefloor friction. But his advance on the center stage takes him into territory well-worn with the footprints of giants of the form. To complain that Trago struggles to match the anthemism of Armand Van Helden
column3: the lush soul of Moodymann
column4: or the sheer physical presence of Paperclip People may be unfair
column5: but
column6: well
column7: life is short and filled with great records covering the same beat. You'd probably be better served spending your time with those records
column8: but if the prospect of inconsequential but exquisitely constructed tributes to past glories appeals
column9:
then Iris' eagerness to please probably won't lead you astray.

Frankie Valli was one of the most successful pop artists of the 20th century. In addition to a successful solo career
column2: his work with the Four Seasons resulted in an incredible 71 chart hits; more than half of these made the Top 40
column3: and eight of them topped the charts. His hit-making prowess even bucked the album-oriented trends of the Sgt. Pepper's era
column4: but there were some hiccups along the way. One of the most notable was a stint with Motown's short-lived MoWest imprint in the early 1970s
column5: where Valli found himself in a slump. After a few disappointing swings at the charts
column6: Valli tried to release ""My Eyes Adored You"" in 1974. MoWest passed on the record. Valli released the song late that year as a solo artist on Private Stock Records
column7: and it topped the Billboard Hot 100 by March of the following year
column8: ending the artist's stint on the label and kickstarting a new era of success.

column1: This story is a microcosm of MoWest's inauspicious reign as the forgotten moment of one of the most iconic labels in the history of pop. The creation of the imprint was part of Berry Gordy Jr.'s gradual shift of Motown operations from Detroit to Los Angeles
column2: away from the assembly-line production of the label's peak years. The Holland-Dozier-Holland team had already departed
column3: replaced in part by Norman Whitfield and a raft of superstar auteurs: Marvin Gaye
column4: Stevie Wonder
column5: Smokey Robinson
column6: and Diana Ross. The shift to Los Angeles also marked the end of the singular Detroit sound
column7: as the label became reliant on a rotating cast of session musicians. But even with all the upheaval
column8: it's difficult to figure out why MoWest fell through the cracks; the music contained in Our Lives Are Shaped By What We Love: Motown's MoWest Story 1971-1973 is almost uniformly great. The compilation showcases a wide range of notable artists-- a 1971 Billboard article notes the label's purpose was to ""expand Motown's musical horizons""-- at varying stages in their careers.

column1: It was an indisputably exciting time
column2: creatively
column3: for soul music
column4: in the years before disco became a codified sound. Stevie Wonder
column5: near the beginning of his incredible decade-plus solo creative run
column6: does make a behind-the-scenes appearance on this compilation
column7: producing the tracks from Syreeta's debut LP. Both are highlights. Odyssey
column8: not to be confused with the disco group of the same name
column9: contribute three songs; each
column10: but particularly the uptempo flute-laden horn-driven dance number ""Battened Ships""
column11: is a compelling example of a kind of post-hippie spiritual 70s soul. There are also early career appearances from future superstars the Commodores and Thelma Houston
column12: whose ""I Ain't Going Nowhere"" includes an inspired vocal performance. Rock group Lodi
column13: on the other hand
column14: may have marked an attempt on Motown's part to move towards a psychedelic-cum-acid-folk sound
column15: but their ""I Hope I See It in My Lifetime"" feels aimless
column16: without the kind of memorable songwriting that defines the bulk of this compilation.

column1: Perhaps the best moment on the collection is one of the record's best-known
column2: at least to American dance floors. Although still an obscure cut by any reasonable standard
column3: the Sisters Love's ""Give Me Your Love"" manages to completely reinvent Curtis Mayfield's original. With its heart-damaged vocals
column4: the song manages a rare balance of driven vulnerability over an endless
column5: inimitable groove.  It's a strong document of the pre-disco era
column6: but also an example of one way these oddities could endure (in this case
column7: seeing a resurgence in a later floor-friendly edit)
column8: whatever its chart success. The primary common denominator here is that none of these artists sold well at the time. (MoWest's one hit in the United States
column9: Tom Clay's ""What The World Needs Now Is Love""
column10: is not included.) But whatever the commercial obstructions
column11:
the music certainly holds up.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16583/homepage_large.2e0f23ec.jpg|Gloss Drop|566.0|Battles|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2011-06-07 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:15.335726|"

Let's get one thing out of the way: Gloss Drop shouldn't really be compared to its predecessor
column2: Mirrored. The sole Battles record to feature Tyondai Braxton's digitally cartoonified vocals
column3: Mirrored is now consigned to brilliant one-off status in the Battles catalog; Gloss Drop
column4: created after Braxton left the group entirely
column5: is more of a refinement and expansion of Battles' early work. In a way
column6: for fans
column7: the loss of Braxton was the best thing that could have happened to Battles. It meant they couldn't record a true follow up
column8: which might then pale (or just come off as more of the same) next to one of the most distinctive and unexpected debut LPs of the 21st century. Battles could have recorded an all-instrumental album in the Mirrored mold
column9: or they could have drafted in another singer to try and imitate Braxton's crucial contribution. Instead
column10: they forced themselves
column11: having lost their most immediately striking and divisive element
column12: to move in a new and potentially radical direction. So the important questions with Gloss Drop become
column13: ""Is this new direction interesting?"" and ""Have Battles made it thrilling?""

column1: The answers are: ""Yes
column2: and ""More often than you might guess."" Mirrored was an album that made its impact via complexity and speed and wild humor
column3: a sound that owed as much to the orchestral zaniness of classic cartoon soundtracks as the grimmer heads-down virtuosity of the metal and math-rock bands in which the Battles members made their names.  Not only could these guys pull off these wild instrumental zigzags at high velocity
column4: they made ultra-tricky
column5: computer-assisted pop-prog sound like fun. For their circumstances-dictated new direction
column6: Battles have slowed their roll a bit
column7: foregrounding both the pop and propulsive qualities of the music rather than its can-we-top-ourselves inventiveness. It still sounds like devious fun
column8: but the sort you get from a band tweaking audience expectations.

column1: Gloss Drop is the most ride-the-groove record Battles have ever made
column2: owing plenty to both the straight-forwardness of house and rock and the crazed syncopations of soca and dancehall
column3: where Mirrored's whole point could seem like leaving listeners breathless with this-could-go-anywhere prog invention. And considering Battles are possibly the tightest man-machine unit going now that LCD Soundsystem are dead
column4: you can imagine how hot these grooves burn
column5: and how meticulously they're constructed
column6: their most audacious attempt yet to make the line between ""programmed"" and ""played"" completely invisible.

column1: Of course I say these two albums shouldn't be compared
column2: but that won't stop most people from doing just that. Inevitably the starker differences between the two will leap right out on first listen
column3: but if you're worried about a complete makeover
column4: Gloss Drop still does sound an awful lot like Battles. There's the same blurring until you can't be sure what instrument is responsible for which melodic or rhythmic element of the mix: Are those steel drums all over this record
column5: or a guitar processed to sound that way
column6: or some sort of ""Caribbean"" software patch? There are still the same surging moments when you're reminded
column7: for all the band's post-human rhythmic complexity
column8: what a great rock drummer John Stanier remains. There's still the sense of thrill that comes from music where any element coming loose would mean everything falls apart
column9: and there's the surprise that music this fussed over can still hit so hard.

column1: In a way
column2: that's been the constant in their career
column3: and there's often the feeling here that Battles haven't forgotten their pre-Tyondai days
column4: where they seemed to be applying the hyper-detailed structures of math-rock to the feel of minimal techno. Battles' early EPs offered one of those shouldn't-work-but-does hybrids: prog rock
column5: with all its furrow-browed instrumental digressions
column6: that still somehow follows the straight-line pulse of dance music. The difference is that they learned how to be a (far) left-field pop band on Mirrored
column7: and there probably wouldn't be much thrill in ditching that just to look backward. Though the tone remains gleefully plastic and mechanical
column8: Gloss Drop is less forbiddingly dense
column9: chilly
column10: and opaque than those instrumental EPs. ""Sweetie and Shag""
column11: with appropriately dream-pop-esque vocals from Blonde Redhead's Kazu Makino
column12: is the most tender song the band's ever recorded
column13: not a praise term you would have previously applied to Battles. If those early records resembled an auditory obstacle course
column14: this is more of a playground
column15: strange but inviting. Not for nothing does so much of Gloss Drop resemble carnival music
column16: both in the ""rides and games"" and ""Caribbean parade"" senses of the word.

column1: Sometimes this slave-to-the-rhythm approach doesn't quite come off
column2: as on ""Futura""
column3: where trad dance-rock is just given a frosting of virtuosity. There are moments like this on Gloss Drop where you remember Battles are capable of so much more than trad anything. And there are also times when the joyous silliness that runs through the record becomes oppressive
column4: like the band's hammering you with the fact that serious music can also be super whimsical. But when it all comes together
column5: as it does more often than not
column6: it works on every level. ""Ice Cream""
column7: with vocals from dance producer Matias Aguayo
column8: is both the band's biggest and best pop moment since ""Atlas""
column9: with a real disco bounce
column10: but also totally perverse in its construction
column11: like a mutated Phoenix single. And on ""My Machines""
column12: they even call down that old (literal) tech metal thunder
column13: with the added bonus of a big drama-queen performance from Gary Numan
column14: one of their spiritual fathers in linking electronics with rock. Despite all the guests
column15: and the nods to global pop
column16: Gloss Drop will still be best enjoyed by groove heads
column17: whether they come from the rock or dance worlds
column18: but if you worried Battles would run out of surprises on album two
column19: who knew they'd find common ground between post-punk devotees
column21:
and the children of UK funky?

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16611/homepage_large.84a890c2.jpg|Suede [Deluxe Edition]|3970.0|Suede|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Demon']|2011-06-07 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:16.878162|"

There is music on these albums. Obviously. The reason I'm saying that up front is that discussion of the first two Suede albums is invariably framed in a discussion of the bigger picture
column2: both in terms of what was happening in British rock in the early 1990s and in terms of the discord within the band
column3: particularly during 1994. There are good reasons for this. Suede were at the center of the conversation that gave us the Britpop narrative that so dominated the UK in the mid-90s. They were the band on the cover of the issue of Select that invented Britpop as a concept
column4: they were massively hyped before they even released anything
column5: and their debut album was the fastest-selling in British history. They were ignored in the United States and ridiculously had to change their name in this country to the London Suede after a lawsuit by an obscure lounge singer.

column1: This stuff is all important to understanding who Suede were-- the music they made
column2: especially on their first three albums
column3: is tied closely to their story as a band-- but I really want to make sure that as I make my way through that story
column4: the music doesn't slip to the side of the conversation. Stories and meta-cultural narratives aside
column5: the music is what we have to listen to now
column6: and there is a lot of great music spread over these elaborate reissues. The whole band
column7: including once-estranged original guitarist Bernard Butler
column8: was involved in putting together these packages
column9: each of them a 2xCD/DVD featuring the original album
column10: demos
column11: unreleased outtakes
column12: every contemporary B-side (plus one non-album A-side)
column13: music videos
column14: interviews and live performances. The band's entire output
column15: with the notable exception of three early unreleased tracks
column16: ""Be My God""
column17: ""Art""
column18: and ""Wonderful Sometimes""
column19: is now available on five very well-done reissues that include all of the original artwork for both the albums and the singles. They have curated their past well.

column1: Consider the arena this band was entering when it debuted in May
column2: 1992 with ""The Drowners"". The British rock world was dominated by two waning trends
column3: shoegaze and Madchester
column4: both of which emphasized sound and vibe over personality and pomp. And here Suede were
column5: with a very bold
column6: direct
column7: and sexually charged song that had the swagger of glam rock and was focused on the voice of Brett Anderson
column8: who was powerful and distinctive. Anderson's vocals had a little of Bowie and a little of Morrissey
column9: but there was a lot more there than a simple swirling of influences. Here was a guy who could sing frankly about drug abuse and rough sex without plasticizing it or stylizing it-- actions had consequences in the world he created
column10: and wild nights had mornings after

There is music on these albums. Obviously. The reason I'm saying that up front is that discussion of the first two Suede albums is invariably framed in a discussion of the bigger picture
column2: both in terms of what was happening in British rock in the early 1990s and in terms of the discord within the band
column3: particularly during 1994. There are good reasons for this. Suede were at the center of the conversation that gave us the Britpop narrative that so dominated the UK in the mid-90s. They were the band on the cover of the issue of Select that invented Britpop as a concept
column4: they were massively hyped before they even released anything
column5: and their debut album was the fastest-selling in British history. They were ignored in the United States and ridiculously had to change their name in this country to the London Suede after a lawsuit by an obscure lounge singer.

column1: This stuff is all important to understanding who Suede were-- the music they made
column2: especially on their first three albums
column3: is tied closely to their story as a band-- but I really want to make sure that as I make my way through that story
column4: the music doesn't slip to the side of the conversation. Stories and meta-cultural narratives aside
column5: the music is what we have to listen to now
column6: and there is a lot of great music spread over these elaborate reissues. The whole band
column7: including once-estranged original guitarist Bernard Butler

column11: but he was careful not to tell you the moral of the story.

When the Coathangers formed five years ago
column3: as something of a party joke
column4: the band's four members had little musical education to speak of. But they're no joke now
column5: having since released a pair of riotous albums
column6: plus about a half-dozen trashy
column7: cheeky
column8: shrieking 7"" singles. They're also grizzled road warriors
column9: headlining bars from Fargo
column10: N.D.
column11: to Allston
column12: Mass.
column13: in between supporting gigs with the likes of the Thermals
column14: Mika Miko
column15: and These Arms Are Snakes.

column1: Somewhere in all that
column2: the Coathangers must've learned how to play. Larceny & Old Lace
column3: the quartet's third album and second for Seattle-based Suicide Squeeze
column4: carries over the chaotically hooky vitality of their previous records. But here
column5: they've added more varied songwriting
column6: (relatively) tighter instrumentation
column7: and-- for the first time-- a real studio
column8: the Living Room in Atlanta
column9: where the band reunited with producer Ed Rawls (Deerhunter
column10: Black Lips
column11: Zoroaster). Named after a Mickey Rooney-guesting ""Golden Girls"" episode that was itself named after playwright Joseph Kesselring's screwball comedy Arsenic and Old Lace
column12: the Coathangers' latest finds a notorious must-see live band finally capturing some of the energy of its shows on record.

column1: Just because the Coathangers are taking their game more seriously doesn't mean it isn't still a game. With all four members trading off idiosyncratic vocals-- ranging from guitarist Julia Kugel's Victoria Jackson chirp to drummer Stephanie Luke's full-throated roar-- there's still plenty of jagged
column2: playful aggression
column3: whether that involves damning the titular jerk of ""Johnny"" over gloomy post-punk or tearing off faces between stabbing guitar and whirligig keyboard on ""Chicken: 30"". But the Coathangers now pay more attention to detail
column4: starting with first single ""Hurricane""
column5: which veers from raspy shouts and brittle guitar riffs to zombie-apocalypse cheerleader chants and ominous whispers shaded by clacking drumsticks. They also try on more styles: Where ""Call to Nothing"" pledges ill-fated devotion through scratchy guitar and heavy bass recalling the Slits
column6: ""Well Alright"" rides a demented roadhouse blues and ""My Baby"" slows down to a loping love groove-- for stalkers. These might not be the furthest-out ideas
column7: but they're new for the Coathangers
column8: and they're executed with badass charisma.

column1: Still
column2: from the band behind such shrill yawps as ""Don't Touch My Shit"" and ""Gettin' Mad and Pumpin' Iron""
column3: there's no bigger left turn than a soft
column4: sentimental ballad. ""Tabbacco Rd."" sees the Coathangers making the shift with surprising ease
column5: poignantly following a relationship from its first Tom Collins to the wedding chapel
column6: and finally to the last goodbye. Speaking of goodbyes
column7: the kitschy-scary keyboard and cathartic howls of ""Jaybird"" make it a fine memorial even if you don't recognize the lyrical reference to the Coathangers' former tourmate
column8: the late Jay Reatard. Most impressive of all
column9: though
column10: and a should-be single
column11: is ""Go Away""
column12: a perfectly structured midtempo rocker that turns the tables on every dude who ever sang a whiny song about wanting to be more than just friends. It may have started as a simple gag-- ""Hey
column13:
I like you/ Go away""-- but it's as serious as you want it to be.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16559/homepage_large.b9b7c52c.jpg|Reflection|29478.0|Chalk Circle|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Post Present Medium'
column3: Washington
column4: D.C.'s Chalk Circle were a staple in the city's early-80s punk scene
column5: part of a group that included (but was assuredly not limited to) both Ian MacKaye and Henry Rollins (then known as Henry Garfield). But while Rollins and MacKaye built lasting legacies off the strength of their 80s work
column6: Chalk Circle have been regulated to cult-hero status
column7: revered by in-the-know punk fans-- including No Age's Dean Spunt
column8: who is responsible for co-releasing this anthology on his PPM imprint.

column1: Aside from Chalk Circle's rare live performances-- they played only four shows-- their obscurity could have something to do with the way their slippery post-punk didn't fit in with the righteous (if slightly homogenous) thrashing of their peers. Don Fleming points out in the liner notes that the band had even hoped for some releases on the increasingly influential Dischord Records
column2: but the label ultimately decided they did not fit on their roster. And while that was true for the majority of their slender output
column3: ""The Slap"" and ""Scrambled""
column4: with all their dissonance and half-shouted lyrics
column5: would have made for a perfect Dischord 7"".

column1: Built around the songwriting partnership of Sharon Cheslow and Mary Green
column2: Chalk Circle's sound fit in nicely with peers the Slits and the Raincoats
column3: all creators of an innovative brand of post-punk. Reflection opens with its title track
column4: and Green's introspective lyrics ensure it lives up to its name
column5: while Cheslow's guitar dances around Tamera Lyndsay's bassline and Anne Bonafede's polyrhythmic drumming. ""My drumming was heavily inspired by the Tony DeFranco song 'Heartbeat
column6: It's a Lovebeat'
column7: Bonafede states in the liner notes. ""As a matter of fact
column8: all of my drum riffs were variations of that song."" Just like the Slits and Raincoats
column9: Chalk Circle were ahead of their time
column10: with ""Uneasy Friend"" adopting uneasy back-and-forth vocals and a similarly jittery energy
column11: and closer ""Subversive Pleasure"" presaging not only modern punk bands such as Mika Miko and the Coathangers
column12: but the entire riot grrrl movement of the late 80s and early 90s.

column1: Perhaps due to her interest in poetry
column2: Green was a pretty remarkable lyricist in a genre where words were used primarily as rocks to throw at the glass windows of the establishment. ""The Slap"" uses the image of violence against women as a metaphor for initiation into society
column3: while ""The Look"" is an almost-satirical glance into patriarchal standards of female beauty. On ""Reflection"" and ""Easy Escapes""
column4: Green turns the lens on herself
column5: forging personal takes on romance and life. ""Love songs don't touch me
column6: Green sings on the latter. ""But is that what I really want?""

column1: With exception of ""The Look"" and the rough mix of ""Easy Escapes""
column2: the best work on Reflection has already been released via early-80s tape compilations. The previously unreleased five of the album's 12 songs were live tracks and basement demos
column3: which serve more as interesting sketches than vital documents. Peppered throughout the album
column4: they provide rough-hewn counterparts to their studio-recorded work. They're not terribly essential
column5: but they definitely provide a deeper context to the band's history.

column1: ""We wanted to have a band because we loved playing music and listening to music
column2: Cheslow states in the liner notes. ""We saw girls from N.Y.
column3: L.A.
column4: San Francisco
column5: and London playing in bands and they gave us inspiration and courage."" In 2011
column6: the notion of an all-girl band is just as important as it ever was
column7: primarily because we're still using the term ""all-girl band"" as if predominantly female rock groups were still a novelty of some sort. While women are unfortunately still fighting to be treated as equals-- even in the so-called ""liberal utopia"" that is underground rock music-- it becomes increasingly necessary to shed a light on the female bands that time left behind
column8: especially ones as prescient as Chalk Circle. Reflection offers a broadly overlooked chapter in not just the history of women in American punk rock
column9:
but the history of American punk rock overall.

EAR PWR's 2009 debut
column2: Super Animal Brothers III
column3: a neon-lit mess of Devin Booze's synth glitch smeared together with Sarah Reynold's squeaky voice
column4: was a testament to party-ready arrested development. It could also be irritating. As Pitchfork's Brian Howe mentioned at the time
column5: ""It's hard to get mad at the fun
column6: but EAR PWR often made it look easy. Fast-forward two years and EAR PWR have relocated to North Carolina and become something of a different animal. Removed from the spazzoid Wham City warehouse scene
column7: the pair almost seem ready to embrace maturity.

column1: Right from the ominous opening synth stabs on ""Mountain Home""
column2: it's apparent that something is different. Amidst the goth vibes
column3: freaky drum pattern
column4: and weird vocal melody
column5: you know that EAR PWR are making a conscious effort to create serious-sounding music. EAR PWR's sound here feels indebted to the Brooklyn outfit Glasser
column6: with the juxtaposition of tribal drum programming against celestial analog synths (Booze's are homemade) and an ethereal vocalist out front.

column1: For EAR PWR
column2: this evolution is admirable
column3: but it's hard to overlook how clumsy the molting process is. For starters
column4: Reynolds' flat delivery doesn't really work next to Booze's beefed-up (and sometimes inventive) synth work
column5: which itself is often upstaged by his overbearing drums and invasive cymbal splashes. But having Reynolds recede into the background
column6: given some of the awkward lyrics
column7: isn't such a terrible thing. All in all
column8: the record seems thin and unbalanced
column9: its disjointedness revealing how little substance there is here. What's even more frustrating are the sparks of real possibility that keep popping up: ""Geodes"" pairs the pulse of a tornado siren with twinkling synths and some thrashed-out
column10: forward-tumbling drums; ""Lake"" is the kind of shy
column11: sexy jam these two should be focusing more of their attention on.

column1: But in context
column2: these more sophisticated reflections are either draggy or misguided (""North Carolina""
column3: an ode to the duo's new home
column4: seems meant to be regal and idyllic but sounds more like theme music from The Oregon Trail). EAR PWR were once a band that refused to tie a tie or recite the silly rule-- it could be annoying
column5: but at least they were being themselves. Here
column6:
they prove how hard growing up can be.

In 2009 the Flaming Lips invited Oneida to play at a day they were curating at an ATP festival in upstate New York. That pairing felt like an inevitable convergence of like-minded talents-- two similarly wayward outfits naturally coming together. Both have gone though stages of late-career reinvention
column3: both have a fondness for repetitive psychedelic rock music played loud
column4: and both have demonstrated scant regard for conventional career trajectories. At that point Oneida were two albums deep into a proposed trilogy titled Thank Your Parents. The fact that they decided to play a 12-hour set
column5: complete with a double drummer assault from Lips sticksmen Steven Drozd and Kliph Scurlock at one point
column6: made a strange kind of sense. It felt like Oneida were in the process of untethering themselves from their own sound
column7: of cutting loose common constructs that had been threaded through their prior work. In Absolute II
column8: the third and final segment of Thank Your Parents
column9: that evolution has been taken to its most far-out point yet.

column1: Of all the strands that make up the trilogy
column2: which began with Preteen Weaponry in 2008 and continued with the triple album Rated O in 2009
column3: this is the one that makes least sense as a standalone item. It's very much a part of a greater whole
column4: a logical if somewhat obtuse and reflective way to enter the comedown phase after the wild diversity of the previous installment. With all three pieces slotted together
column5: it's easier to process the other material. The studio trickery and dub-influenced tunes of Preteen Weaponry
column6: which was split into three songs but designed to be listened to as a continuous track
column7: now feels like a perfect ease-in entry point to the sprawl of Rated O. But finding a similar way in to Absolute II takes some work. There are no drums here and barely any vocals. Anything that could be defined as ""traditional"" instrumentation is largely absent. Initially
column8: it feels impenetrable. Almost everything is locked in stasis
column9: with tiny phrases and pulses occasionally prickling to the surface.

column1: As such
column2: it's firmly rooted in the minimalist tradition. Steve Reich's ""Pendulum Music"" is a touchstone
column3: as is Philip Glass's ""1+1"". At times it bears a similar textural heft to Brian Eno's work with Harold Budd on their The Plateaux of Mirror collaboration. In terms of eyebrow-raising deviations in style it's not dissimilar to the arcane moods of Scott Walker's Tilt and The Drift. Like Preteen Weaponry this isn't an album that needed to be divided into individual tracks
column4: although there are four of them
column5: beginning with ""Pre Human"". The opening is built around a single repeating keyboard riff that's lightly distorted and sounds not unlike something Martin Rev from Suicide might have left on the cutting room floor around the time of their first album. It feels like a reflex shift out of the jagged edges of Rated O and into calmer waters
column6: especially when it relaxes into solitary organ drones and droplets of water-like piano plinks.

column1: But the mood of Absolute II oscillates somewhere between turmoil and ease
column2: with the stretched out tones of ""Pre Human"" ultimately congealing into the hostile atmosphere of ""Horizon"". Here
column3: the solitary vocal lines on the album are cut so they speak a curious un-language
column4: which is set to aggressive machine noise that feels like a feverish itch prickling away under the skin. It's the dark side of Eno's dream for ambient
column5: or the notion of Erik Satie's ""furniture music"" gone horribly wrong. Something that should sink into the background is ultimately turned on its head and shoved in your face instead. ""Horizon"" is painful at high volume
column6: and it's most likely designed to be listened to that way. From there ""Gray Area"" continues in much the same vein
column7: with its clanging guitar motif ratcheting up the inhospitable atmosphere. It's like Oneida have locked you out of their world and are making it as difficult as they can for you to re-enter.

column1: This isn't music as escapism
column2: it's music as challenge and provocation. Even the closing title track
column3: which is all hushed-out generator hum and occasional murmurs of instrumentation
column4: falls loosely into the same kind of disconcerting atmosphere as the incidental music to David Lynch's Eraserhead. Oneida are often talked about as a band that should have reached a wider audience
column5: but they won't achieve that here
column6: and they don't seem to care. They're a group whose music takes a great deal of time to sink in
column7: where the process of evaluation slowly unravels over years and months rather than days and minutes. It's the reason why their album Each One Teach One
column8: which is nine years old
column9: is only now being fully unpacked and canonized as a major piece of work. Thank Your Parents will take an equivalent span of time to reveal its secrets
column10: especially as this final part is likely to be met with a large degree of bafflement on first listen. But taken as a concluding piece of a larger body of work
column11: as this is intended to be heard
column12:
it's a fiercely individual statement to end this chapter in Oneida's unique history.

column7: she ends up sounding almost exactly like Robert Plant singing over a string quartet.

column1: She still recalls Plant here and there on W
column2: but this time around
column3: she's a bit closer to Annie Lennox
column4: another female vocalist with a confident
column5: soulful style and an androgynous tone. ""The Breaks""
column6: W's atmospheric centerpiece
column7: showcases this quality. Her voice is the most dynamic sound in the song
column8: sketching out a complex mix of conflicting emotions while the rest of the arrangement settles into a sad
column9: mellow keyboard-horn groove. It's a quietly compelling piece of music-- intensely passionate yet strangely subdued.

column1: She's even more impressive on the album highlight ""I Am Your Man""
column2: a twitchy showstopper with an ironic
column3: gender-bending perspective and an earnest
column4: love-struck sentiment. In this song
column5: masculinity is invoked more than it is critiqued. It's a celebration of being forthright and aggressive
column6: of being bold enough to pursue someone with the firm belief that you're the right person for them. It's not that different from
column7: say
column8: Jeff Tweedy singing ""I'm the Man Who Loves You""
column9: but Rostron's gender flip brings an intriguing tension to the mix. Is this the person she wants? Is this the person she wants to be?

column1: There are other fine songs on W-- the tense disco track ""Living It Out""
column2: the sultry ""Manifesto""-- but as a whole
column3: the record doesn't quite gel. The songs generally sound better out of context. This makes some sense. Though the pieces have a lot of musical similarities
column4: each comes across as a discrete composition with its own set of ideas. In that way
column5:
W feels less like a pop album and more like a gallery show.
