column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16619/homepage_large.fc8015a7.jpg|Blow Your Head Vol. 2: Dave Nada Presents Moombahton|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mad Decent']|2011-06-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:24.683925|"

Velocity is destiny: two ""new"" dance sub-genres getting attention in 2011 offer almost opposite perspectives on the effects of playing records at the wrong tempo. From Holland comes ""bubbling
column2: a jittery
column3: uptempo skitter with origins in the late 1980s
column4: born from spinning dancehall records too fast. Meanwhile
column5: in 2009 U.S. DJ Dave Nada slowed down Dutch house records to 108 beats per minute until the music (already part-Caribbeanized) uncannily resembled the throbbing pulse of reggaeton. Add cut-up Latin vocals
column6: dem bow off-beats
column7: crisp and seemingly endless drum rolls
column8: and a bevy of obvious samples
column9: and a new genre is born.

column1: ""Moombahton"" takes its name from the Afrojack remix of Silvio Ecomo and DJ Chuckie's ""Moombah"" (the ""-ton"" comes from reggaeton)
column2: but the idea is expressed most succinctly in Nada's remix of Sidney Samson's Afrojack-like anthem ""Riverside"". On the latter
column3: the original's grating siren synth attack transmuted into a bleepy melody of unbearable tension. It's tempting to assume that transcending this simple gimmick would be necessary for moombahton to produce anything of lasting worth
column4: but that's not the case. As Nada's new mix Blow Your Head Vol. 2 (for Diplo's Mad Decent label) proves
column5: there's nothing wrong with a decent gimmick.

column1: In fact
column2: moombahton works by treating everything as a gimmick. Just as big beat reduced both rap and rave to sample toolkits to be mined for maximum party hijinks
column3: moombahton usually treats its Latin and Caribbean affectations as ruthlessly as it does house records. At times it's hard to say just who is spiking whom: As well as raw source material
column4: the house components of moombahton paradoxically act as a stylistic destabilizer
column5: like a returning comet throwing the music out of orbit. Take Sabo's remix of Dennis Ferrer's strobing vocal house anthem ""Hey Hey""
column6: wherein the original's sharp counter-rhythm becomes a desultory strut around which Sabo weaves an exquisite rumpshaker groove.

column1: If anything
column2: Blow Your Head Vol. 2
column3: which gathers together a selection of tracks from moombahton's key producers
column4: is at its weakest when the tunes veer too close to naturalizing their influences
column5: and risk sounding too comfortable with themselves. Munchi's ""Sandungueo"" could easily be a malnourished
column6: thuggish dub of an actual reggaeton record. Conversely
column7: ""Gal Where Yuh Come From"" by Nadastrom (a duo of Nada and Matt Nordstrom) squeezes out just the right amount of estrangement from the music it mimics via an ominous rap from Jamaican DJ Natalie Storm
column8: whip-crack snares
column9: and a murky
column10: dub-spacious arrangement.

column1: Nada pays respect to moombahton's roots by including cuts from ancestral reggaeton rapper El General and Shabba Ranks' ""Dem Bow""
column2: but the best inclusions here work their magic by wearing these influences lightly and setting their sights more broadly. On tracks ""Masta Blasta""
column3: ""Broken Hearts""
column4: and ""Que Que""
column5: Dillon Francis has developed a bevy of tricks-- stuttering electro kicks; woozy and disorienting synth lines-- that fuse European slither with Caribbean bounce.

column1: It would be meaningless
column2: not to mention faintly ridiculous
column3: to start talking about ""sophisticated"" or ""experimental"" moombahton
column4: in part because the music is so rigorously party-focused. But there's also a stylistic restlessness that makes Blow Your Head Vol. 2 a more surprising listen than you might expect. The mix closes with Nadastrom's remix of Win Win's ""Rleleaserpm""
column5: which could be a dancefloor renegade from the latest Gang Gang Dance album (in fairness
column6: that is GGD's Lizzie Bougatsos on vocals). Crucially
column7: this gorgeously sunny number never sounds impressed with its own unexpectedness: In the middle of moombahton's no-nonsense party vibes
column8:
pretty much anything is up for grabs.

"|15500.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15500-blow-your-head-vol-2-dave-nada-presents-moombahton/|7.6|Tim Finney

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16606/homepage_large.568192ee.jpg|Outbreeding|624.0|David Thomas Broughton|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Brainlove']|2011-06-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:25.083833|"

""He's from Otley near Leeds."" This is the text in the ""about me"" section of folksinger David Thomas Broughton's Facebook page
column2: where he is listed as a ""local business.""  Above it is a picture of Broughton looking very startled. The photo and the line make me laugh and
column3: occasionally
column4: so does Broughton's music
column5: which mixes spare
column6: matter-of-fact playing with a dry sense of humor and a self-effacing willingness to improvise.

column1: Take a line like
column2: ""In the main all that I can glean is that this is the reason that this world is fucked
column3: from Outbreeding's ""Electricity"". Prim syntax and barstool frustration collide in a rich baritone. Broughton pronounces ""fucked"" fooked
column4: and the humor lies in the fact that he sings it as though it weren't funny. Thirty seconds later
column5: the song devolves into unexpectedly dissonant keyboards and snippets of prerecorded talking.

column1: Outbreeding is the most band-oriented record he's released. (For comparison
column2: he recorded 2005's The Complete Guide to Insufficiency alone in a church with the help of looping pedals.) He's said in interviews that he has a greater interest in trying new ideas than rehashing old ones
column3: which is an attitude I admire in artists
column4: especially when they can carry it off and sound curious instead of prickish.

column1: Broughton's voice is distinctive enough to anchor each track
column2: but Outbreeding feels like it lacks a central character or thread. Some songs lean toward driving
column3: structured folk-pop; some are lumbering and discordant. I like the comparatively poppy ones
column4: but mostly because they showcase an intelligent juxtaposition of brisk
column5: twinkly music with Broughton's natural melancholy. (I still love the chant-like atmosphere of The Complete Guide to Insufficiency
column6: but the more downbeat tracks here don't have the same grace).

column1: Broughton's ideas are still worth hearing though
column2: and his voice works for me (even though it might be feast-or-famine for other listeners). Like the folksinger Sam Amidon
column3: his music sometimes feels indebted to a rustic
column4: pre-Dylan past but is buoyed by a mischievous personality-- he takes something that sounds pat at first and turns it into something skewed and unusual. And like Amidon
column5: Broughton's live shows are miniature spectacles: He roams through the crowd and uses furniture as percussion. He layers sounds in slightly haphazard ways
column6: as though his songs weren't so holy that he couldn't subject them to chance.

column1: That kind of loose imagination and playfulness is not only hard to capture on record
column2: it's probably impossible. The moment dissolves by nature
column3: whereas recorded music wants to stick around forever. Broughton-- like Amidon-- will always be one of those artists probably better seen than heard
column4: though somehow I imagine that doesn't bother him. Even on its less interesting tracks
column5: there's something about Outbreeding that feels warm and content
column6:
like it was glad to be made.

"|15487.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15487-outbreeding/|6.9|Mike Powell

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16618/homepage_large.3c896c1e.jpg|Sun and Shade|27672.0|Woods|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Woodsist']|2011-06-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:25.568871|"

When I first caught on to Woods with 2009's Songs of Shame
column2: they'd already been around for a few years
column3: releasing albums in limited editions
column4: sometimes under the name Woods Family Creeps. Songs of Shame was immediately enjoyable
column5: as it spun together strands of folk-rock
column6: ramshackle indie
column7: and sunshine pop into something that felt handmade and fresh. But listening to it
column8: I didn't peg Woods as the kind of band that would keep turning out remarkably well-realized and consistent albums on a yearly basis. Maybe it was the casual nature of their time-keeping
column9: where all the songs amble at a loose
column10: oblong gait. Or maybe it was the general nature of their lo-fi pedigree
column11: where quantity of output is often prized over quality. But nothing about Woods at that time said ""consistent album band"" to me.

column1: Two years and two full-lengths later
column2: ""consistent album band"" describes Woods very well. Last year's At Echo Lake didn't have a weak song on it and showcased the strength of their songwriting on the most fundamental terms. I still find myself humming tunes from it at weird times
column3: even when I haven't listened to it in months. Now they return with Sun and Shade
column4: another very solid record that finds them returning in spots to the experimental vein explored on earlier records and in their live show. They haven't changed their sound in the least
column5: but they're demonstrating that there's a lot more to be done with it than might have been expected.

column1: The experimentation comes in the form of two longer instrumentals that take up about 17 of the album's 44 minutes. ""Out of the Eye"" is a Krautrock homage constructed from the basic ingredients of Neu!'s ""Hallogallo""
column2: but slowed down by a third and with a Middle Eastern tinge in the guitars. Where bands like Stereolab built something driving and forceful around the iconic motorik groove of the Neu! original
column3: Woods' rickety aesthetic can't help but keep human imperfection in the mix. These guys don't do ""robotic
column4: and no one will ever mistake the laid-back percussion on a Woods record for a drum machine. Which means that the shadowy steady-state psych of ""Out of the Eye"" unfolds patiently and isn't afraid to meander a little. But when it closes abruptly with a quick drum roll seven minutes in
column5: it gives the impression that the preceding was more of a sketch or one-take jam rather than anything designed for a specific effect
column6: which slightly undercuts its power.

column1: The nearly 10-minute ""Sol y Sombra"" is the other long track
column2: and it features spare hand percussion
column3: acoustic guitars
column4: and some distant electric guitar leads. It still scans as ""1970s Germany
column5: but here the basic model is the pastoral psych of Popol Vuh from the middle of that decade. They both manage to capture a mood and wring feeling out of them
column6: but ""Sol y Sombra"" and ""Out of the Eye"" sometimes have me reaching for the ""skip"" button. That's partly because Woods continue to craft such memorable tunes when working in guitar-pop mode.

column1: Like ""Pushing Onlys""
column2: the early single from Sun and Shade
column3: which has chiming guitars and a classic pop melody catchy enough to hang with 60s confections by the Turtles or the Hollies. While Jeremy Earl's cracking voice is in the long line of ""sounds kinda like Neil Young"" high tenors
column4: Woods' Aquarian Age references often lean toward the bouncy and optimistic bubblegum of the era. Here
column5: that spirit comes to the fore on the elegant shuffle ""Who Do I Think I Am?"" and ""What Faces the Sheet""
column6: which is built around a guitar riff vaguely reminiscent of ""Then He Kissed Me"". Folkier songs like ""Be All Be Easy"" and ""Wouldn't Waste"" bring to mind the sound of folk-pop heroes growing into singer-songwriters
column7: a spirit best exemplified by Graham Nash
column8: whom Woods covered on Songs of Shame. In whatever mode they're working
column9: the take-away is that Woods are good at all these sounds
column10: and they seem to be striving to get even better. Despite their ultra-slack style and prodigious output
column11: nothing about them says ""half-assed
column12: so it's another year
column13:
another fine Woods album.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16610/homepage_large.1846ee8f.jpg|Lupercalia|4644.0|Patrick Wolf|['Rock'
column2: 'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mercury'
column3:
'Hideout']|2011-06-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:26.012932|"

""Songs about love are obviously the most common theme in pop music
column4: but I wanted to approach it in a way that hadn't been done before. The title refers to the Lupercalia festival
column5: which is the ancient fertility and love festival that happens around Valentine's Day. I strive to be original-- it's one of my biggest ambitions. There can be nothing worse sometimes than a soppy love record-- imagine if I'd called it To Love: Patrick Wolf!""

column1: That's Patrick Wolf doing the heavy-lifting when it comes to pinpointing what went wrong with Lupercalia: It's clear he hasn't shaken off his artiste pretensions since the goth-folk of his early work
column2: but ever since the career peak of 2005's shadowy song cycle Wind in the Wires
column3: he seems to want pop stardom. And while the clash of those desires can lead to fascinating music
column4: it rarely happens when the artist considers himself above pop music and its consumers. And unfortunately
column5: much like he did on The Magic Position and The Bachelor
column6: Wolf is operating like someone who doesn't trust his audience to think at his level
column7: offering a subtly condescending record that leaves so little to the listener's imagination that it actually may as well have been called To Love: Patrick Wolf!

column1: At first glance
column2: Wolf's headfirst dive into new romantic pop seemed like a good move. As with ""Accident & Emergency"" or ""The Magic Position""
column3: Wolf put a good step forward on this album's lead single: ""The City"" remains an insistently kicky piece of kitsch
column4: its cheeseball horn charts and can-do lyrics about love transcending material possession successfully recalling 80s new pop. But like ""The City""'s video-- Wolf frolicking on the Santa Monica pier with a bunch of Hollister ad types-- the rest of Lupercalia is self-aware in all but one crucial aspect
column5: the ability to recognize just how blatantly it allows itself to lay it on so thick.

column1: Far be it from me to deny someone the agency to make his ""happy"" record
column2: but Wolf seems to feel as if self-consciousness grants him a license to go slumming in his most insipid songwriting impulses. The clincher from otherwise charming ""House"": ""This is the greatest peace I've ever known/ Only love makes a house a home."" Meanwhile
column3: the lesson learned on ""Together"" is ""and I can't do this alone/ But we can do this so much better together
column4: the last word harmonized just so in case you didn't get the gist. Sure
column5: it's awkward when he allows himself a little more poetic license on the string-choked ""Slow Motion"" (""before you I was living in a silverfish kitchen"")
column6: but at least it's a new way to make the same point.

column1: How the album manages to feel so impersonal is weird considering it was inspired by Wolf's recent engagement
column2: but the smug piano narrative of ""Bermondsey Street"" feels stuck somewhere between ""Our House"" and ""Born This Way"". What's frustrating is that if you strip away the unctuous lyrical gaffes
column3: Wolf gets most everything else right. During Lupercalia's first half
column4: he continues to prove himself a fine craftsman of major-key melodies
column5: and this is his most confident and convicted vocal performance yet. But like most of Wolf's records
column6: he eventually gives into sad songs and waltzes as Lupercalia progresses
column7: and studded with the same overproduction tricks of cluttered strings and processed samples
column8: ""The Days"" and ""Slow Motion"" don't offer much in the way of contrast outside of tempo.

column1: Considering how intriguing it is to think about Wolf in the abstract-- undeniably talented and ambitious as he is-- there's no reason he shouldn't be some sort of star. But his claims to originality feel increasingly misplaced-- he's not the only auteur combining glam-rock ambitions with sexually ambiguous theatrics these days
column2: and compared to Of Montreal's confrontational eclecticism
column3: Diamond Rings' nervy confessionals
column4: and Lady Gaga's full-frontal multimedia bombast
column5:
the domesticated Wolf of Lupercalia can't help but sound tame.

"|15492.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15492-lupercalia/|5.3|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16518/homepage_large.c1292064.jpg|Bury Me in My Rings|1403.0|The Elected|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Vagrant']|2011-06-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:26.578619|"

Blake Sennett was all but a silent partner in Rilo Kiley's last two LPs
column2: which suggests the title of his first solo bow as the Elected
column3: Me First
column4: was something of an in-joke. He previously explored advertently lush California sounds on 2006's <i>Sun
column5: Sun
column6: Sun
column7: but on his latest album
column8: Bury Me in My Rings
column9: Sennett has immersed himself in a definitively Golden State of mind. It's not what you think
column10: however: Sennett riffs on Silver Lake ennui and Hollywood plasticity. To properly criticize it
column11: you have to play an active role in it he seems to say.

column1: Indeed
column2: the countrypolitan aspirations of Bury Me often make it sound hollow-- there's a basis in roots music
column3: but it isn't ""rootsy"" by any stretch. Instead
column4: the clean-shaven guitars
column5: pedal steels
column6: and violins (not fiddles) achieve an eerie minimalism. Even when they're all appearing at the same time
column7: they're not overwhelming these songs or offering low-end counterpoint but playing toward Sennett's papery
column8: Elliott Smith-like vocals.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Sennett's songwriting voice has a nonchalant
column3: conversational tone. The melodies and lyrical sentiments of ""Born to Love You"" come so easily
column4: you figure it just has to be cliché
column5: until some loopy tangents about moon launches and flat-screen TV's suggest that Sennett's in on his own joke. On the whole
column6: there are enough tossed-off thoughts and broken communication to make you feel like an eavesdropper rather than a part of a dialogue. Whether addressing a seemingly doomed relationship on the string-haunted ""Who Are You"" (""You got yourself a good girl/ That's good enough for you"") or possibly former Rilo Kiley drummer Jason Boesel during ""Have You Been Cheated"" (""Is your daddy a hustler?"" ostensibly referring to his solo album
column7: Hustler's Son)
column8: there's a resigned lack of judgment
column9: which always sounds empathetic even when it feels completely accusatory.

column1: That sense of resignation can also be a weakness. It wasn't the post-Postal Service production trickery that made Me First the best Rilo Kiley project since The Execution of All Things
column2: but relatively uptempo numbers like ""Go On"" and ""A Time for Emily""-- there's an intriguing inversion in how Sennett's more aggressive music often sounds the most emotionally vulnerable. ""Go For the Throat"" approaches that sort of catharsis
column3: but not much other than a distorted vocal effect on ""When I'm Gone"" will jolt you out of the second half of this record
column4: which spends too much time with its feet up. Curiously
column5: that sort of pointedly L.A. arrested development suits Sennett-- even as he morphs sonically
column6:
on Bury Me in My Rings he stays true to detailing a life of bright prospects and a willingness to underachieve.

"|15405.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15405-bury-me-in-my-rings/|6.0|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16595/homepage_large.630d0399.jpg|Pre Serene: Thee Oneironauts|2970.0|The Most Serene Republic|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Home of the Rebels']|2011-06-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:27.639739|"

""The smartest thing a record label can do is sign a bunch of kids at 19
column2: and then trick them into documenting their lives for the next six to 10 years."" So mused Ryan Lenssen
column3: a founding member of the Most Serene Republic
column4: upon the release of the band's most accomplished record
column5: 2009's ...And The Ever Expanding Universe. Perhaps unsurprisingly
column6: Lenssen was 19 when the Most Serene Republic began releasing their take on baroque
column7: kitchen-sink pop
column8: in the process becoming the became the first non-Broken Social Scene-related project to sign to Arts & Crafts. Now they dig back into their vault to remaster and release eight tracks from Thee Oneironauts
column9: a band that Lenssen and two other members of the Republic played in when they were 18. The resulting collection
column10: Pre Serene: Thee Oneironauts
column11: is as gawky as a middle school yearbook photo: It sounds like it was made by teenagers who play immoderate amounts of Zelda
column12: like to write songs about 1980s movies that they think are really awesome
column13: and do not yet feel the artistic need to disguise or complicate either of those artistic impulses. O sweet
column14: guileless youth.

column1: Thee Oneironauts shows that even at an age when most would-be musicians are fiddling with distortion pedals and refining their teen angst
column2: current Republic members Lenssen
column3: Adrian Jewett
column4: and Nick Greaves (along with non-Republic-an Emily Hunt) were always in the business of bleeding heart earnestness and ornate compositions. Unfortunately
column5: Thee Oneironauts were unable to unite either of those things in intriguing ways
column6: and this collection of their recordings comes off as skittish
column7: cluttered
column8: and excessively maudlin. ""Today Is the Day"" sounds like the work of a young band equally enamored with the Postal Service and the fact that synths can sometimes sound like rocket ships
column9: while the tone and lyrics of the unreasonably long ""St. Germain"" aim for romantic but miss the mark. We now know that these guys would later develop into better songwriters
column10: but this record doesn't offer much evidence in support.

column1: Still
column2: Thee Oneironauts' most cringeworthy moment
column3: ""Zoltar Speaks"" (yes
column4: it's a song told from the point of view of Tom Hanks' character in Big) serves as a pithy thematic summary: This is a document of the anxieties of growing up. It's full of the sort of details and feelings that few of us sensible grown-ups would commit to tape (the lyrics to ""The Breath"" sound like facts that the band members memorized for their high school history class: ""1896: the first movie shown/ 1912: the Titanic went down"")
column5:
and there's a certain charm to a document like that. But this one is something that only very loyal fans of the band will be able to appreciate; the rest will probably be left wondering why they took these recordings out of the vault in the first place.

Though nobody's idea of the next big thing
column2: Spaceghostpurrp
column3: a 20-year-old from Miami who makes hypnagogic stripper anthems
column4: received a strange co-sign from L.A. Weekly's blog: They called him ""Odd Future's Cosmic Cousin."" To be clear
column5: Spaceghostpurrp will not make a game-changing appearance on ""Late Night With Jimmy Fallon""
column6: and outside of being another young skate kid fascinated by video games and Satan
column7: he doesn't have much in common with Tyler and company. If a comparison must be drummed-up to sell this very weird
column8: really good
column9: but inarguably niche stuff
column10: let's go with ""Clam Casino's evil druggie drop-out cousin from the South.""

column1: Like last year's NASA: The Mixtape
column2: Blvcklvnd Rvdix 66.6 (1991) is obsessed with the earliest
column3: ugliest Three 6 Mafia releases (particularly <i>Underground
column4: Vol. 1: 1991-1994) and follows that tradition of creepy club music while slyly updating it as well. ""Possessed""
column5: Blvcklvnd's intro track
column6: is lo-fi Lex Luger that tops the oppressive feeling of all those ""B.M.F.""-style beats
column7: but toys with their pop appeal
column8: thanks to a catchy
column9: simple hook that is screamed like a black metal vocal.

column1: Further separating his style from anything resembling conventional hip-hop
column2: Spaceghostpurrp doesn't care for proper mixing (you might go insane listening to this on headphones) and he piles on video game sound effects and dub reggae-like noises. ""Captain Planet"" is a contemplative bouncing moan
column3: like some lost Oval track; hypnotic synth blasts turn the ridiculously titled ""Suck a Dick For 2011"" and hazy stripper anthem ""Grind on Me"" into something transcendent. By the way
column4: there is lots of stuff like ""Suck a Dick For 2011"" on here
column5: which means Spaceghostpurrp is also very into 90s rap's misogyny (lots of strip club talk and ""bitch"" shouts)
column6: so be warned.

column1: The last bunch of tracks climb out of the sizzurp murk and go for a 90s New York rap style. ""Legend of the East Pyramyds"" does moaning soul sample rap better than it has any right to
column2: and then it piles on Halloween sound effects. ODB tribute ""Osiris of the East Pyramids Blackland R.I.P. ODB"" consists of synth tones floating ominously
column3: merging the streetwise paranoia of New York and the verge-of-death doom of Houston. It's one of this year's most haunting songs even though it sounds like a mash-up of underground hip-hop from 15 years ago.

column1: Born in 1991
column2: Spaceghostpurrp's really just another one of those indie bedroom producers approaching the music of his earliest years
column3: pairing it with very of-the-moment sonic decisions
column4: and exposing the ways that once disparate arenas of sound mesh together. Blvcklvnd Rvdix 66.6 (1991) is a mess of Three 6 Mafia-chanting
column5: woozy Wu-Tang loops
column6: DJ Screw wheeze
column7: and Mortal Kombat and Godzilla sound effects
column8:
all paired with an off-the-dome rapping style that's equal parts Lil Wayne and Lil B. It's as if James Ferraro Lawnmower Man-ed his way into a rap rarity message board and soundtracked the journey.

Leading up to Death Cab for Cutie's last record
column2: 2008's Narrow Stairs
column3: guitarist/producer Chris Walla claimed that they were taking inspiration from Brainiac and ""heavy
column4: sludgy
column5: slow metal
column6: and that the record contained a ""10-minute long Can jam."" But nothing on the record sounded remotely similar to those references; the jam in question
column7: ""I Will Possess Your Heart""
column8: actually ran a bit over eight minutes
column9: and I don't think anyone mistook Ben Gibbard for Damo Suzuki. Leading up to the band's latest effort
column10: Codes and Keys
column11: the name-dropping returned
column12: when Gibbard told SPIN that it was keyboard-heavy and ""not guitar-based
column13: citing Brian Eno's Another Green World as a hint of what to expect.

column1: The claims of extended experimentation
column2: though exaggerated
column3: aren't as spurious this time around. Codes and Keys does sound different from the rest of the band's catalog. Soft pitter-pattered beats rustle underneath sparse melodies
column4: while layers of extra instrumentation are placed atop already-busy arrangements. Two songs (the metronomic ""Doors Unlocked and Open"" and the unmoored piano meditation ""Unobstructed Views"") run well over the five-minute mark; swaths of gentle noise surround even the most straightforward cuts. If you come to this record looking for something as directly engaging as ""Cath..."" or ""I Will Follow You Into the Dark""
column5: you're going to walk away empty-handed.

column1: Death Cab still sound like Death Cab
column2: but Codes and Keys is undoubtedly the least ""pop"" record they've made since breaking through to the mainstream with their last indie-situated effort
column3: 2003's Transatlanticism. So there's new territory for the band explored here
column4: and Walla
column5: along with mixing maestro Alan Moulder
column6: applies a label-money sheen that provides a decent frame for the record's sonic idiosyncrasies. But for a band so identified with exploring feelings and the details of relationships
column7: the record comes off as chilly
column8: diffident
column9: and emotionally distant. The texture-heavy excursions (""Doors Unlocked and Open""
column10: ""Unobstructed Views""
column11: ""St. Peter's Cathedral"") are adrift and without direction
column12: while early singles ""You Are a Tourist"" and ""Underneath the Sycamore"" sound like generic versions of the band from an earlier era.

column1: Indeed
column2: even when the band revisits past glories on Codes and Keys' few highlights
column3: Death Cab weirdly sound like they are imitating themselves. They borrow the baroque Brian Wilson-isms of Narrow Stairs' ""You Can Do Better Than Me"" for ""Portable Television""
column4: copy the upward-moving bridge of The Photo Album's ""I Was a Kaleidoscope"" for the same structural change in ""Monday Morning""
column5: and lift the basic structure of Plans opener ""Marching Bands of Manhattan"" for ""Underneath the Sycamore"". Anyone who's spent the last decade following along will get some warm fuzzies from these flashes of familiarity
column6: but they tend to get stale with repeat listens.

column1: The rudderless quality might owe something to the album's sporadic recording process-- eight different studios were employed
column2: and the members of Death Cab rarely sound like they're in the same room together. Most remote of all is Gibbard. His vocals are frequently treated with effects
column3: creating an alienating space that
column4: excepting the moony-eyed closing hymn ""Stay Young
column5: Go Dancing""
column6: robs him of his trademark intimacy. Lyrically
column7: he largely plays it safe
column8: engaging in nonsensical rhymes (""When you scream/ Love you seem"") and sweeping declarative generalizations. Gibbard's evocative narratives and incisive commentary
column9: always overlooked with this band
column10: are mostly missing.

column1: Over the last decade
column2: both Death Cab and the landscape around them have changed considerably; while they've signed to a major label and topped the charts
column3: the sensitive-guy Pac NW indie rock archetype they launched a decade ago has receded from the conversation. Another sound that Gibbard had a hand in introducing
column4: however
column5: still reverberates: the gentle
column6: electronic bedroom-pop that he and producer Jimmy Tamborello made as the Postal Service. Those sounds never really infiltrated Death Cab until now
column7: but Codes and Keys doesn't approach that project's level of emotional engagement. Here
column8: Death Cab sound miles apart from each other and
column9: ultimately
column10:
from us.

If you include the soundtrack album he recorded for Into the Wild
column2: Ukulele Songs is only Eddie Vedder's second solo album. Considering the size and devotion of his cult
column3: coupled with Pearl Jam's ""No
column4: you really shouldn't have"" over-generosity when it comes to releases
column5: it's remarkable he hasn't put out five by now. This makes Ukulele Songs even more of a curiosity: As its title makes clear
column6: the album consists of 16 tracks of Vedder pawing the tiny
column7: four-stringed Hawaiian instrument and warbling love songs. That's it. In a way
column8: it's as clear-cut a proposition as you're going to get these days. You either instantly know you need 35 minutes of this in your life or are already backing slowly away.

column1: The songs themselves date back
column2: in some cases
column3: 10 years or more-- presumably from around the same time Vedder wrote ""Soon Forget""
column4: the two-minute ukulele ditty from Binaural. The rest of the songs occupy that same headspace. They are casual
column5: sweet
column6: and disarmingly unaffected
column7: and you can practically smell the campus green wafting off them. That Vedder is putting Ukulele Songs out during this Big Blowout Year of Pearl Jam (Documentary! Festival! Reissue! Tour!) makes it seem even less of a solo project and more like a a souvenir for longtime Pearl Jam fans. It works best that way.

column1: Indeed
column2: in small doses
column3: Ukulele Songs is lovely. Vedder has always been affecting when he's lovelorn
column4: and here he's more or less curled up in a ball of bewildered hurt. ""As I move myself out of your sight/ I'll be sleeping by myself tonight
column5: he croons on ""Sleeping By Myself"". The album's best moments-- ""Sleeping By Myself""
column6: ""Without You""
column7: ""Longing to Belong""-- tap the same quietly wounded melancholy as Paul McCartney's 1971 proto-indie pop masterpiece Ram.

column1: Alas
column2: 34 minutes is a perilously long time for most to to spend  alone with just Eddie Vedder
column3: a ukulele
column4: and his feelings for company. Vedder's precious side has never been his best one (see: No Code's ""Sometimes"")
column5: and Ukulele Songs is so determinedly twee and relentlessly self-effacing that it can feel like watching a grown man attempting to morph into a baby koala before your eyes. By itself
column6: hearing Chan Marshall playing Bernadette Peters to Vedder's Steve Martin for the duet ""Tonight You Belong to Me"" is winning and funny; in the context of a full ukulele album
column7: it is slightly cloying. Vedder has said he wants this record to inspire people to pick up the instrument and sing with their friends
column8: an old-fashioned sentiment impossible not to be charmed by. Like a lot of Vedder's experiments
column9: the spirit is easier to admire than the final product. The ukulele might be a great campfire instrument
column10:
but sometimes what works best at the campfire should stay there.

It took me a while to warm to Lone's excellent 2010 LP
column2: Emerald Fantasy Tracks. It's not that the album's charms were particularly subtle
column3: it's that I had no idea where Lone fit in the evolving
column4: chatty conversation that is electronic music. EFT's influences were certainly clear enough: late-1990s Warp beatniks like Boards of Canada and Plaid; Detroit techno; the lite-rave thrum of 808 State. For the first time in his career
column5: Lone had combined them in a way that seemed both clever and obvious. He wasn't so interested in interacting or responding to his peers
column6: but he wasn't sulking in the corner
column7: either: more like industriously building his own fort in it.

column1: Echolocations is a six-song EP that feels very much like an extension of EFT. It's natural that
column2: finally having exacted a sound of his own
column3: he would want to refine it. On the whole Echolocations is quicker and more aggressive than his past work
column4: though I'd hesitate to call it more dance-oriented. Lone used to trade in Dilla-style breakbeats
column5: but his drum programming has grown more complex as his tracks have gained steam. Echolocations features his most detailed
column6: strident work to date. Lone fills an impressive amount of space with his percussion. Far from the sparse
column7: digital grooves that dominate techno
column8: Lone organizes his rhythms into flowing streams of hi-hats and snares
column9: interrupting them only to occasionally release his twirling synths upward.

column1: Lone has always had a way with keyboard melodies-- it's the Warp influence-- and Echolocations sounds busy
column2: as if his superior drums are trying to ring his superior synths
column3: and vice-versa. The opening track
column4: ""Coreshine Voodoo"" is like watching two cats fight: lots of tussling with no one looking to deliver the killer blow. He smartly contrasts this with leaning
column5: pulsing organ sounds that function more as stabilizing forces than melodic ones.

column1: Echolocations doesn't have the breadth of Emerald Fantasy Tracks
column2: but it's probably not supposed to. It plays like an annex to that album
column3: offering a slight
column4: specific variant. But the strength of Echolocations isn't that it offers variety
column5: just that it offers more. EFT was a coming-of-age
column6:
and Echolocations is proof that Lone is crafty enough to build upon it without abandoning his new-found identity.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16576/homepage_large.393343de.jpg|Zayna Jumma|27817.0|Group Doueh|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sublime Frequencies']|2011-06-01 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:30.595307|"

A glorious kind of chaos infiltrated the earliest recorded output by the Western Saharan act Group Doueh (pronounced ""Doo-way"") on the Sublime Frequencies label. Much of the material spanned several decades of recordings culled from the tape archives of band leader Doueh (also known as Salmou Baamar). His disregard for time and trajectory was mirrored in the chopping up of styles from different eras that the band cultivated in their home in Dakhla. Doueh's childhood worship of Jimi Hendrix and James Brown could be keenly felt
column2: but so could traditional forms of Saharoui and Gnawa music. Group Doueh is a family affair
column3: with Doueh employing his wife Halima on vocals
column4: and his sons El Waar (organ/keyboards) and Hamdan (drums). Doueh himself alternates between a three-stringed lute called a tinidit and an electric guitar. Like the prior Beatte Harab
column5: this album was recorded by Sublime Frequencies' Hisham Mayet
column6: who dampened the band's earlier lo-fi recording techniques while maintaining the raw heart of the Group Doueh sound.

column1: There has been some notable sonic evolution since Beatte Harab. The tinny percussion of that album is replaced by more boisterous playing from Hamdan
column2: and Doueh is prone to more regularly swapping out the tinidit for his electric guitar. In short
column3: the rock and pop melodies that have always been present are given greater clarity
column4: although Zayna Jumma still rests firmly within that pan-global mash-up of cultures they've ingeniously threaded together. It begins in a place of abstract euphoria
column5: through the casually faltering rhythms of the title track. At times it feels like the tinidit is falling out of sync with Hamdan's beat
column6: but that slackness in the playing functions as the root of the song's slow-build arc into abandon and elation. By the end of the track
column7: Halima and her co-singers are shouting the words as they get all caught up in that frenzied spot they've been teased into by the increasingly maniacal playing.

column1: That steady shift into vocal exultation is a common event on Group Doueh recordings
column2: but they also know how to temper those urges
column3: putting the brakes on at just the right time on restrained tracks like ""Met-Ha"" and ""Aziza"". Doueh breaks out some chunky wah-wah guitar to ease in ""Ishadlak Ya Khey""
column4: which might be their most ""rock"" recording to date. But it retains vital components of the band's sound
column5: such as the looseness in the playing that droops at just the right weight between the players. It's a credit to Mayet's work that he made these recordings sound as ""live"" as possible-- on ""Zaya Koum"" it feels like you're sitting in on a cozy session in Dakhla
column6: where Doueh is happy to noodle his way into guitar oblivion while his family works around him. Similarly
column7: on the sputtering ""Jagwar Doueh""
column8: the vocal lines feel like wild one-off improvisations that would have taken on vastly different forms had they been recorded in another time and place.

column1: Repetition is a key trait in the Group Doueh sound
column2: and they use it wisely throughout this record. Often it will be a thudding beat that cycles tirelessly in place
column3: allowing Doueh to layer his flanged and wah-ed guitar over the top. At other times
column4: such as on the closing ""Wazan Doueh""
column5: a stringed instrument of some type will loop over and over to form the rhythmic hook. That track is the most trance-like piece here
column6: and its airy delivery demonstrates the band's remarkable versatility. The lightness of touch forms a neat contrast to the raucous close in the opening ""Zayna Jumma"". Doueh seems like a humble man
column7: who'll continue to run his cassette store and work in Group Doueh's primary outlet as a wedding band regardless of the focus afforded to this album. In fact
column8: he resisted all attempts to release his music until Mayet trekked across a large part of northwest Africa to meet him after hearing a few of his songs on the radio. Thankfully that mixture of modesty and reticence didn't endure
column9:
because Zayna Jumma is a densely layered piece of cultural cross-pollination that consistently spills over into outright joy.

"|15461.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15461-zayna-jumma/|7.6|Nick Neyland

""Not Entertainment"" is the closing track on Bachelorette's self-titled third album
column3: and if you take project mastermind Annabel Alpers' lyrics at  face value
column4: it's also her swan song. Baldly she admits
column5: ""Nothing  Bachelorette makes ever sounds the way I'd like it to
column6: and despite  cherishing ""the number of believers in the independent music scene
column7: Alpers concludes
column8: ""I'd rather watch the others enjoy themselves/ And just be happy that I'm not a part of it.""

column1: The song may reflect a struggle on Alpers' part to find motivation and meaning in Bachelorette
column2: and her new album itself often seems to  suggest a low-burning flame. As with past Bachelorette ventures
column3: Alpers layers her vocals in all sorts of pretty but unemotional ways to  present brainy lyrics atop artily mannered synth tones
column4: grooves
column5: and  loops. Her work has an appealing intellectualism
column6: but Alpers often fails  to locate the human connection that makes other artists of her ilk  great. Her style owes something to Laurie Anderson
column7: but Alpers lacks  Anderson's humor. Meanwhile
column8: Stereolab is no less arch
column9: yet they've also  made fun
column10: massively grooving pop music. Even contemporary artists who  are plying a similar approach
column11: like Sufjan Stevens
column12: Max Tundra
column13: and St.  Vincent
column14: find means through hooks or noise or pure emotional expression to make a palpable communion with their audience.

column1: If you're willing to fully take Alpers on her own terms
column2: however
column3: there's  value in Bachelorette. Specifically
column4: there are a few songs here with  lovely vocal melodies and harmonies
column5: namely the stirring
column6: hymn-like ""The  Light Seekers""
column7: the utterly gorgeous ""Sugarbug""
column8: and the trilling ""Tui Tui"". You can't help but think that if Alpers lavished more attention on pure sound she wouldn't be far off from producing something similar to Julianna Barwick's The Magic Place. But her sonic backdrops never quite take hold
column9: and modestly buzzy
column10: bloopy tracks like ""Blanket""
column11: ""Polarity Party""
column12: and ""Digital Brain"" only barely compel interest.  Meanwhile
column13: Alpers' lyrics are almost uniformly delivered without emphasis and often are wholly indecipherable.

column1: Even though wordy
column2: tech-obsessed Alpers leans too heavily at times on 10-cent  verbiage
column3: occasionally a meaningful or moving phrase will poke through
column4: like her confession on ""Blanket"" that ""The only way to see you is  through the hole in my chest."" Otherwise
column5: lyrical opacity is just  another way in which Bachelorette tends to keep you at arm's length. If  Alpers' unease on ""Not Entertainment"" reflects a desire for a change
column6:
here's hoping she'll pursue avenues that better take advantage of her gifts.

My Morning Jacket have always been something of a mythic outfit. Back in 1999
column2: when the band released its debut LP
column3: The Tennessee Fire (and again in 2001
column4: after the release of At Dawn)
column5: its legend was whispered quietly
column6: like a ghost story: Kentucky
column7: grain silos
column8: reverb
column9: that high
column10: liquid voice. As 2001 was the apex of a certain kind of dark
column11: New York City cool-- with the Strokes and Interpol slouching around the Lower East Side in threadbare t-shirts and tiny ties-- My Morning Jacket were steeped in a warm
column12: eerie other-ness that culminated
column13: cathartically
column14: with Jim James howling ""All your life/ Is obscene."" Well
column15: sure.

column1: In the ensuing decade
column2: the band became legendary for its heroic live show (in 2008
column3: they stormed through a near-four-hour set at Bonnaroo)
column4: but its studio work has always been a little less triumphant. On record
column5: My Morning Jacket can sometimes sound like a band struggling against its own best interests
column6: purposefully eschewing the exact thing-- huge
column7: ghostly
column8: terrifying rock'n'roll-- it does so disarmingly well. Accordingly
column9: the reigning press narrative surrounding Circuital
column10: MMJ's sixth LP
column11: has been focused on the band's supposed ""return to form
column12: a response that feels like a direct reaction to its title (or
column13: more likely
column14: to 2008's falsetto-addled Evil Urges
column15: easily the band's most divisive record).

column1: But what are they returning to
column2: exactly? My Morning Jacket’s early discography is rooted in oddball experimentation: Despite the open-mouthed riffing
column3: impenetrable reverb
column4: and whipping hair
column5: they’ve never really been a straightforward rock band
column6: especially on record. Jim James' penchant for psychedelic soul is constantly manifesting in new ways
column7: and while Circuital is closer
column8: certainly
column9: to 2005's Z than Evil Urges
column10: it doesn’t feel like a step backwards
column11: or even like a lateral hop.

column1: The record opens with James tooting a half-serious introductory ""horn"" riff that belies a goofy sense of humor. James has always been something of a jokester (cue the whispered ""Shaaa!"" at the end of ""Circuital"" or the line
column2: ""They told me not to smoke drugs
column3: but I wouldn't listen/ Never thought I'd get caught and wind up in prison
column4: from ""Outta My System"")
column5: but his voice is so naturally dramatic that even silly bits can sound like earnest proclamations. That's why-- and this is unique to MMJ-- he often sounds best when he's delivering vague platitudes.

column1: Still
column2: anyone who's ever heard James wail in concert is likely to be frustrated by the eternal underuse of his voice in the studio
column3: even when the songs were ostensibly recorded live. There are a few tracks here where producer Tucker Martine captures it in all its intoxicating splendor-- the acoustic lament ""Wonderful (The Way I Feel)"" especially-- but most only hint at what James is capable of delivering in person.  His falsetto (contentious since the days of ""Highly Suspicious"") comes back for ""Holdin on to Black Metal""
column4: a bizarre bit of jam-funk that alternates between pleasantly spirited and genuinely stupid (it's a cautionary tale about not growing out of black metal fandom
column5: and ends with a shout of ""Let's rock!""). On ""Slow Slow Tune""
column6: James sounds remarkably vulnerable
column7: singing to his future progeny over a barely there
column8: bubblegum guitar figure that recalls the Everly Brothers before transitioning into a Flaming Lips-style burnout.

column1: Like nearly all of their studio albums
column2: Circuital may not reach the heights of the band's live show-- a good MMJ concert can recalibrate your gut
column3:
it can change you-- but it’s a remarkably solid step for a band that's never stopped evolving.

column1: The Vaccines

column10: the Jesus and Mary Chain
column11: or

column1: It's easy enough to imagine the Vaccines' slower songs going over well with an outdoor crowd drunk on sun and beer. Previous NME favorites Glasvegas already have the ""swooning anthems with girl-group beats"" thing pretty much covered

column6: which builds to an embarrassingly neutered wall-of-noise crescendo. In a final possible reference to Best Coast

but they might."" An old ""MADtv"" sketch comes to mind: ""Lowered Expectations"".

column2: from old-time string bands and traditional folk ballads to jazz to 20th century classical. Last September in Durham

column1: During the Sounds of the South premiere

column3: he had a gracefully leaping sense of melody

column7: banjo
column8: and growling resonator; perhaps a dash of harmonica for color. Cook's Feat are actually just his feet
column9: lightly whomping on a homemade stompbox. He's alone and yet not
column10: conversing with a pantheon of American innovators who favor expressivity over flash: people such as slide guitarist Ry Cooder
column11: the fingerstyle guitarist John Fahey
column12: and the shapeshifting Bill Frisell.

column1: The album opens with the welcoming breeze of ""Frazee
column2: Minnesota""
column3: whose lead melody strongly resembles the vocal part of Arthur Russell's ""Maybe She"". While almost certainly coincidental
column4: it gives you an idea of how melodically lucid Cook's writing is. The fluent ""Juniper"" is just as eminently hummable
column5: to an almost crazy degree for instrumental music. These are simple
column6: bucolic themes
column7: brought to life with a deft assortment of bends
column8: slides
column9: and evolving transpositions. Offsetting the earworms are groove-and-atmosphere focused tracks such as the gently galloping
column10: clawhammer banjo tune ""Waiting 'Round the Oven Buns"" and the Cooder-esque ""Ballad of a Hungry Mother"". Overall
column11: it's a great chance to hear the subtle and relaxed touch Cook brings to Megafaun unadorned
column12: save for the barest four-on-the-floor beats here and there.

column1: Still
column2: let's be clear: This is not a Megafaun record. There are no freak-outs or electronic interventions or field recordings. It's eight casual-feeling songs in just under 20 minutes
column3: though it's quite diverse within those narrow confines
column4: flowing easily from the moony blues of ""Sparrowander"" to the cockier swagger of ""The Last Steam Engine Train"". Hungry Mother Blues shows us some of the basic underpinnings beneath Megafaun's gritty inventions

it helps to be deeply coversant with the old.

'Jazz']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Chemikal Underground']|2011-05-31 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:34.363834|"

Aidan Moffat has always seemed older than his years. Even his first album with Arab Strap
column3: The Week Never Starts Round Here
column4: felt drawn from an acerbic place in someone with a few more creases in their brow. Moffat was in his early twenties around then
column5: and has since made a career by siphoning his unseemly soliloquies into song. The aging process has often been on his mind throughout; the opening verse from ""The Night Before the Funeral"" from Arab Strap's 1998 record Philophobia reads: ""Too drunk and getting old."" Now he's teamed up with a fellow veteran of the Scottish music world
column6: multi-instrumentalist Bill Wells
column7: to really hammer that point home by titling this record Everything's Getting Older. The duo may have sprouted a few new gray hairs during its making
column8: as the album took some eight years of sporadic recording to reach completion.

column1: Much of this record documents Moffat's attempts to reconcile his past and present lives. ""Let's Stop Here"" sets the tone by having him fend off the advances of a former object of his desire
column2: principally due to the fact that he's settled down. But Moffat is happy to show off his fallibility
column3: noting that a younger version of himself is still ticking away inside somewhere
column4: possibly anguishing over his actions as he utters the title of the song. Wells demonstrates his versatility throughout-- ""Let's Stop Here"" is all somber
column5: violin-driven balladry
column6: while the following ""Cages"" is propelled by urgent piano stabs. The latter acutely captures Moffat's current mindset
column7: with reminisces of his lifestyle from Arab Strap's ""The First Big Weekend"" coupled with words on the wretched mundanity of his present existence. Even Moffat's beloved watering holes are aging-- ""the pub's once brilliant copper roof has oxidized over the years and now it's a dull
column8: pastel green
column9: he muses in ""The Copper Top"".

column1: So Moffat is pretty much where you'd expect him to be as he settles into his late thirties
column2: plagued by innumerable doubts and insecurities. Where Everything's Getting Older loses focus is in the desire of the two players to constantly canter through great stylistic shifts. Perhaps that's not surprising considering the long gestation period of this material. It's been patched together over vast stretches of time
column3: and it shows. Moffat sounds like he's struggling to find his place in the disjointed rhythms of ""A Short Song to the Moon"" and the lite-funk riffing of ""Glasgow Jubilee"". It's when the pair keeps it simple that they stumble upon a space in which they can operate effectively. The basic piano backing of ""Ballad of the Bastard"" and ""The Copper Top"" afford Moffat plenty of room to sink into his particular brand of lyrical discomfort
column4: helping both tracks to become wonderfully drab centerpieces to the album.

column1: After those peaks this sags into a marginal piece from both players. The lost spy-thriller theme ""Dinner Time"" and the stripped-down ""The Sadness in Your Life Will Slowly Fade"" are Moffat on autopilot
column2: straining for insight. In the latter he circles back to the album's predominant theme
column3: recalling another night out that made him feel old. But 10 songs into the record
column4: we've now already got the point. Perhaps that's the idea
column5: with Moffat keen to cast himself as an aging bellyacher slumped over the bar
column6: recalling his youth and cursing his advancing years until someone hears him out. It's easy to romanticize such a figure after a one-off encounter
column7: but here it feels like you're being forced to spend time with him on a daily basis. Fortunately Moffat is able to move beyond that with the last two tracks
column8: which find him looking to the future as a father
column9:
albeit one with an inclination toward creepy lullabies in ""And So Must We Rest"". It's just a shame he could only chance upon scattered moments of inspiration while coming to uneasy terms with aging elsewhere on Everything's Getting Older.

Eight years ago
column2: Pulseprogramming's mind was on the future. On their 2003 full-length
column3: Tulsa For One Second
column4: the Chicago-based group-- which bills itself as a multimedia arts-collective
column5: instead of a rock band-- made glitch-pop. They used laptop computers to marry somber melodies to knock-and-bump rhythms wrought from abstract electronic noise.

column1: Nowadays
column2: they're a little more interested in the past. On Charade Is Gold
column3: Pulseprogramming-- now staffed by singer/composer Marc Hellner and vocalist Chanel Pease-- have swapped software for hardware
column4: ditching their laptops for old-school drum machines and MIDI cables. Nearly a decade down the road from their last release
column5: the band has chosen to head backwards in time
column6: delivering a record heavily informed by the electronic music of the 1980s.

column1: With its rattling lo-bit snares and lush synth-strings
column2: album opener ""Perfect Problematic"" sounds like it leapt straight out of the decade of Swatch watches and sweatbands
column3: even if the lyrics are a tad dour. ""It's easier to fall apart than to heal/ To suffer the ache of age with nothing left to feel
column4: sings Hellner. It sounds like OMD jamming with Ian Curtis after a week of overcast days. Ultimately
column5: it's the sounds of synth-pop Pulseprogramming are interested in-- the woozy new-age chords
column6: the twinkling analog arpeggios-- and not the genre's sunshiny sentiments. As a frontman
column7: Hellner shies away from the soul music-informed delivery favored by his new romantic forebears. Instead he keeps his emotions pitched down and focused
column8: for the most part
column9: on disconnection
column10: disappointment
column11: and acceptance. ""Even though we wait patiently
column12: the truth is
column13: we live with what we get
column14: he sings on ""So Right Words Strike Me""
column15: his words frozen in a snowdrift of digital strings.

column1: Pulseprogramming's synth-pop ideal is dystopian
column2: rather than utopian-- more Gary Numan than the Human League. Pease and Hellner use the stiff and gridded rhythms of primitive electronics to evoke the endless repetition of workaday life. For groups like Washed Out and Toro y Moi
column3: who are also mining Reagan-era sounds
column4: the past-- as evoked through swoony synths and Roland rhythm boxes-- is a place of bliss and innocence. On Charade Is Gold
column5: Pulseprogramming's take is more moody. They've been around longer and
column6: perhaps
column7:
have a clearer memory of the decade's dark side.

Ideas For Songs came together in 1997
column2: after Canadian label Granted Passage asked Dan Bejar to contribute a song or two for a cassette compilation; instead of sending just one
column3: Bejar shot off 20-some home recordings
column4: figuring they'd do the choosing for him. They didn't
column5: and this release
column6: originally on cassette and now re-mastered and re-issued digitally and on vinyl
column7: was born. Largely comprised of little more than single-or-double tracked acoustic guitar and Bejar's vocals
column8: the sound of Ideas For Songs isn't so much lo-fi as low-rent. The occasional adornment-- wheezy keyboards
column9: a bit of lead guitar-- lends the set a certain amateurishness
column10: but Bejar's vocals aren't shy in the mix
column11: and there's a clarity to every sound
column12: however shambolic their arrangement. Though there are fewer chords and leaps between sections than
column13: say
column14: Rubies
column15: you can hear the shuffling grandiosity of some of Bejar's better-realized later compositions coming together here.

column1: Despite a few hints of Bejar's rickety indie-rock idols
column2: his early music still feels somewhat unprecedented
column3: due largely to his emergent vocal style. Even on these early recordings
column4: his distinctive
column5: sometimes divisive rasp carries much of its current impact
column6: and
column7: as on the spacious Kaputt
column8: it's especially striking over this stripped-down setting. This meta-songcraft and wizened imagery
column9: though still coming together on Ideas
column10: feels much more akin to his later work than the same era's murkier
column11: more experimental We'll Build Them a Golden Bridge.

column1: The set begins with a classic Bejar turnaround; over descending strums
column2: he describes ""a boring nation at war with itself
column3: but not really at war with itself"" and ""a giant among smaller giants."" His fondness for the disarming images and direct address is all over Ideas; there's the ""afterbirth too red to mention"" in ""Forget America""
column4: and he closes ""Songs About a Girl Up to a Point"" with the bracing ""my dear
column5: fuck you and fuck August."" Now as then
column6: these sharply rendered left-field ruminations are the things Destroyer songs are made of
column7: and Ideas is often withering
column8: full of keenly observed
column9: uniquely Bejarian takedowns. It has more than a few references that seem to find Bejar grappling with getting his lyrical ideas into the music; ""I couldn't find the words and then I found the words
column10: he repeats throughout the unusually catchy ""Untitled""
column11: and the grammar-policing ""Marrying the Hammer"" ends with a bit about the ""divorcing the chords to marry the hammer."" As inscrutable as Bejar's words can seem
column12: it seems pretty clear that he's talking process here
column13: about getting the two halves-- the ideas and the songs themselves-- to agree with one another. Matched up to Ideas' threadbare arrangements
column14: his knotty lyrics untangle more easily.

column1: Ideas' best tune is probably its last
column2: ""Why Banacek Doesn't Love""
column3: which moves calmly and confidently back and forth between verse and chorus. Its refrain-- ""I'm seceding from a love I don't believe of""-- is his strongest to that point. But the key lines on ""Banacek"" come earlier
column4: when Bejar sings of ""a string of broken entries"" and castigates someone for ""quoting and stealing and quoting"" and so on. Bejar naysayers often go after his overly allusive lyrics and his too-reverent genre dabbling
column5: but here
column6: while still carving out a musical identity of his own
column7: he digs into himself
column8: operating almost outside of influence
column9: laying much of the groundwork for what would become his inimitable style. Ideas For Songs may be a glorified demo
column10: but rarely do early sketches feel this well-rendered
column11: and however unintended its release as a full-length
column12: this is a vital document in Destroyer's development. Next to later compositional triumphs like Streethawk: A Seduction or Kaputt
column13: the musical side of these Ideas For Songs may leave a little to be desired. But Destroyer has long been about getting as many smart
column14: startling lines into the music as possible
column15:
and all that starts here.

The Very Best's singer Esau Mwamwaya very rarely sings in English
column2: so Westerners who make up most of his group's audience have to rely on feeling alone
column3: and Mwamwaya's got plenty of that. It's probably a gross oversimplification to call Mwamwaya a happy singer
column4: but there's a sense of pure liquid joy in almost every one of his vocal performances; you can practically hear his grin through the microphone
column5: and that level of giddy enthusiasm is about as infectious as it gets. On the group's 2008 debut mixtape
column6: Esau Mwamwaya and Radioclit Are the Very Best
column7: the European DJ duo Radioclit threw all sorts of pan-global dance and pop tracks at Mwamwaya
column8: and he elevated nearly every one of them with that keening
column9: high-pitched wail. You could do plenty of cultural-studies theorizing about all the levels of appropriation at work in that first mixtape-- white DJs snatching Vampire Weekend's quasi-African indie pop and refashioning it for an African singer. But actually listening to the final product
column10: all that was beside the point. This wasn't a mental exercise; it was a joyously physical full-length
column11: a gifted singer sliding across the pop landscape with a border-transcending glee.

column1: The Very Best followed that mixtape up with a triumphant debut album
column2: 2009's Warm Heart of Africa
column3: and now they're back with another free mixtape
column4: one released to the Internet on Mother's Day after little more than a week of notice. But things within the group are different now. They've spent nearly three solid years on the road and in the studio
column5: and now they're down to a duo; Radioclit has broken up
column6: and one of those Euro DJs
column7: Etienne Tron
column8: is off to focus on other projects. It's tough to say what effect those new circumstances had on the group
column9: but the new Super Mom is a markedly different piece of work from that first mixtape. The group's debut thrived in part on its sense of momentum; it let up only when it reached the suite of dizzily gorgeous ballads at the end. But even though Super Mom has more than its share of huge
column10: swooping choruses and amped-up utilitarian dance beats
column11: it's more of a trudge than its predecessor
column12: and the tracks haven't been chosen with the same near-perfect sense of velocity and timing.

column1: Consider
column2: for example
column3: the group's version of Kanye West's ""Runaway""
column4: which comes only five tracks into Super Mom. ""Runaway"" is a great song and all
column5: but here it's a total momentum killer
column6: more than six minutes of midtempo millionaire self-pity in the middle of what had been a dance party. Remaining producer Johan Hugo leaves the track almost untouched
column7: letting Kanye and Pusha T deliver their verses in full and limiting Mwamwaya to intro and outro appearances and mid-verse ad-libs. It's a ballsy attempt at a hijacking
column8: but Mwamwaya sounds awkwardly shoehorned into a song-- the sort of song that simply can't accommodate him.

column1: When Mwamwaya and Hugo are fully locked-in
column2: there's still plenty of the sunburst happiness of that first album and EP
column3: and putting Mwamwaya over a refashioned version of Tom Petty's ""Don't Come Around Here No More"" was an inspired choice. But more often than not
column4: Hugo leaves giant chunks of the original songs intact
column5: and nobody needs to hear Billy Idol's ""Eyes Without a Face"" when Mwamwaya only halfway gets to take it over. Another issue: An absolute horde of guest vocalists appears on the tape
column6: few of them displaying anything like Mwamwaya's verve. It's a lot of fun to hear Mwamwaya alongside Senegalese legend Baaba Maal on ""Miracle""
column7: but he barely gets a word in edgewise amid all the rappers
column8: singers
column9: and chanters on the jackhammer dance track ""Secousse"". Mwamwaya's voice is clearly the greatest thing the Very Best have going for them
column10: and it's a bit weird to hear all these other people crowding him out.

column1: Of course
column2: Super Mom is more of a quickie release than a fleshed-out artistic statement
column3: and it's easy to imagine time constraints causing its relative thinness. The two entirely original tracks on the mixtape go a long way toward proving the duo still has gas left in its tank. The tape-opening title track shows everything anyone ever loved about the group in the first place
column4: Mwamwaya airily belting over absurdly catchy
column5: melodically fluid synth riffs. And the even more propulsive ""Ndekha"" builds up for two and a half minutes before the beat fully kicks in; when the hammer finally drops
column6: it's glorious. Super Mom doesn't showcase the group at its best throughout. But as long as they're still capable of magic moments like these
column7:
they'll be impossible to write off.

For D. Charles Speer
column2: a veteran of New York's No-Neck Blues Band
column3: there's not much difference between the honkytonks of the American South and the tekedes of early 20th century Greece. They may be geographically and culturally divergent
column4: but both are centered around drugs-- alcohol and pot in honkytonks
column5: hashish in tekedes-- and both are associated with very specific musical traditions. Speer explores these two worlds on his two new albums
column6: revealing a common guiding principle: namely
column7: a disdain for hard song structures in favor of inquisitive spontaneity.

column1: The primarily instrumental Arghiledes is a solo record in every sense: Speer played and overdubbed all the instruments
column2: treated the sounds
column3: and produced the record. He alternates between bouzouki and baglamas
column4: then adds percussion
column5: organ
column6: and occasionally electric guitar to create spiraling drones. ""Tsamiko Hijaz"" features some spellbinding percussion
column7: and in one of the more productive avenues
column8: ""The Heavy Heart of Ando-Yeap"" melds those traditional Greek ideas with psychedelic-rock sounds. The album works best when Speer lets these musical ideas play out patiently
column9: but it stumbles whenever he adds vocals. The guttural chanting on ""Harmanis"" is more cartoonish than narcotic
column10: and at times Speer grunts and huffs-- presumably in English-- like Tom Waits
column11: creating a commotion that distracts from graceful filigrees of acoustic guitar. Arghiledes sounds oddly aloof and self-indulgent
column12: as though alienation were Speer's goal. If so
column13: he achieves it too often.

column1: Leaving the Commonwealth is warmer in its appropriation of outlaw country
column2: although it's a similarly academic endeavor. Speer buys into the whole redneck-hippie ethos that catapulted country music into the mainstream during the 1970s; Willie Nelson is to this record what bouzouki master Markos Vamvakaris is to Arghiledes. So many years later
column3: however
column4: it's just as impossible to recapture that sound and especially that sensibility as it is to evoke the smoky atmosphere of the tekedes
column5: which makes Leaving the Commonwealth sound a bit too self-aware
column6: even kitschy at times. When Speer begins talking his way through the end of ""Cumberland"" and describing a stock Southern eccentric character
column7: he sounds more redneck-hipster than redneck-hippie.

column1: Although he hews a bit too closely to country's stock themes
column2: Speer's songwriting can be surprisingly adventurous and spry
column3: and his deep
column4: granular voice is ideally suited to the honkytonk. And whenever Leaving the Commonwealth begins to lag
column5: the Helix pick it up and keep it moving
column6: like any good bar band should. Hans Chew's piano sounds like a gremlin in the works
column7: constantly taunting the frontman
column8: while Steven McGuirl's drums keep everything moving at a quick clip. The Helix proves as diverse as it is agile
column9: moving from the straightforward honkytonk opener ""Razorbacked"" to the zydeco-inflected ""Le Grand Cochon"" to the more psychedelic moments on ""Freddie's Lapels"". The closing title track is a dense
column10: sharp-cornered guitar jam that
column11: much like ""Ando-Yeap"" on Arghiledes
column12: takes the album in a completely new direction right before it ends. Both are intriguing
column13: even exciting finales
column14: which suggest that Speer is at his best when he's working not within specific historical frameworks
column15:
but between them.

The Unthanks are an English folk group led by sisters Rachel and Becky Unthanks. That's their real family name. Though they were born
column2: seven years apart
column3: in the small
column4: Northern English county of Tyne and Wear
column5: they now call Northumberland home. They sing in a regional dialect and with regional accents
column6: and they also organize residential ""singing weekends"" through their website
column7: traditional holidays that include ""singarounds and workshops
column8: short coastal walks
column9: singing in the pub and food to write home about."" They're serious about singing.

column1: There is much cultural reference
column2: mystery
column3: and beauty to be found on Last
column4: a lot of which can't be untangled by Google. The opening ""Gan to the Kye"" is a beautiful example
column5: a piano-based standard about a plot
column6: cattle
column7: and a dead collie in the fields. Its titular refrain is a reference to an old plural word for ""cows."" Equally heart-breaking is ""The Gallowgate Lad""
column8: a flowing
column9: six-minute tale of a wayward militia man
column10: sung from the perspective of a concerned lover. And then there's the seven-minute ""Close the Coalhouse Door""
column11: a song whose slurry of fiddle and piano adds an ethereal sheet of light (""Close the coal house door
column12: lad/ There's bones inside"") to the darkness of the industrial tragedy at its center. It's an unforgettable vocal performance
column13: and while parts of Last can feel so rooted in tradition that it takes on a museum piece feel
column14: ""Close the Coalhouse Door"" is theirs alone. Here they seem less about purism and more about their own impressions.

column1: When they dip into jazzier fare in ""Give Away Your Heart"" or offer a string-laced cover of Tom Waits' ""No One Knows I'm Gone""
column2: Last verges on the staunchly traditional
column3: but their singing takes the music somewhere else. And it has to
column4: since both the instrumentation and the arrangements are stately and simple-- there's not much besides trumpet
column5: piano
column6: autoharp
column7: fiddle
column8: and strings. Rachel possesses a voice that's smooth and unfailing
column9: while her younger sister Becky's has much more grain to it. The revolving harmonies of ""Canny Hobbie Elliot"" are emblematic of how well they can work together. Though it's one of the few songs on Last that isn't sad and bleak
column10: their voices come together just so
column11:
and the result is mystifying and devastating.

As with many young songwriters prone to lyrically oversharing
column3: Manchester Orchestra's Andy Hull has often been paid the loaded compliment of being ""precocious."" It's a term that implies unfulfilled potential. But now that his latest album
column4: Simple Math
column5: aspires to be a culmination of his prior two bombastically titled and performed LPs
column6: I can revisit them knowing they were fully conceived steps towards the logical endpoint
column7: ""a story about a 23-year old who questions everything from marriage to love to religion to sex."" In other words
column8: a concept album about the experience of being Andy Hull
column9: written by Andy Hull.

column1: But hell
column2: if there's any Conor Oberst acolyte capable of making The Merrimack to Titus Andronicus' The Monitor
column3: it's Hull. As a frontman
column4: he does his peers proud-- while his astringent
column5: high lonesome warble immediately recalls the Jim James/Ben Bridwell dialect
column6: it's flexible enough to handle both rebel yells and vulnerable self-flagellation. Hull's got a thing for drunken fuck-ups who own up to their failures
column7: though he's far more interested in using it for autobiography rather than storytelling. His belief in his own profundity is kind of endearing as Manchester Orchestra's driving force. It's hard to imagine something like the title track
column8: which uses infidelity as a jumping-off point to question the entire basis of human existence
column9: even standing a chance without it.

column1: The problem lies in where Hull ends and Manchester Orchestra begins
column2: and it's a space populated by lesser sons of the south
column3: post-grunge good ol' boys like 3 Doors Down and Collective Soul-- tellingly
column4: the most immediately hooky riffs of the lot (""April Fool"") lay mere inches down the fretboard from those of ""Shine""
column5: and ""Leave It Alone"" flirts too briefly with a raw tenderness before diving headfirst into the sugary dross of truck-selling power ballad ""The World That I Know"".

column1: It's that ponderous alt-rock framework that makes Simple Math such a drag even as the lyrics and production feel like they're racing to out-sensationalize each other. While the burly guitars on ""Mighty"" and ""Pale Black Eye"" flex some swamp-rock muscle
column2: as a full outfit
column3: Manchester Orchestra simply plod instead of groove
column4: bogged down by Simple Math's favorite artificial flavor
column5: a charmlessly and coldly recorded string section. It's indicative of Simple Math's overcooking: Most of the time
column6: the band can't find a moment of empty space it doesn't fill with that extra guitar overdub
column7: more string cues
column8: or another intimacy-sapping vocal harmony. Or you get something like ""Pensacola""
column9: whose stein-swinging coda comes off like a fun idea they were dying to get in somewhere rather than an organic conclusion
column10: to say nothing of its clear resemblance to a Modest Mouse song that happens to be called ""Florida"".

column1: And then there's ""Virgin"". It clearly announces itself as Simple Math's ""ambitious centerpiece"" by going all in on the epic signifiers: daunting strings
column2: a horn section at the bridge
column3: massed vocals
column4: and
column5: of course
column6: a kiddie choir to drive the hook home. But melodically and tonally
column7: they're simply piling onto what
column8: at its core
column9: is an incredibly simple arrangement-- its juddering
column10: drop-D Alice in Chains riff is too repetitive not to be catchy
column11: but taken as a whole
column12: it's the most glaring example of a record that's too quick to cut corners and cheat its way toward unhinged transcendence despite so convincingly having its shit together. Which ultimately is where Simple Math falters despite its admirable ambition; as the saying goes
column13: ""men plan
column14: God laughs
column15:
and Simple Math is proof that your existential crises and epiphanies can't be micromanaged.
