""Guitar
column2: screaming
column3: and pounding."" That's how Jimmy ""Jay"" Lindsey credited himself in the liner notes of his first proper LP
column4: 1998's Teenage Hate. He also billed himself as Jay Reatard
column5: the pseudonym he would use on a staggering number of recordings until his death early last year. According to a transcript included with this deluxe reissue of Teenage Hate
column6: Reatard was a name taken on one night not long before the material was recorded
column7: during a live set comprised of Bay City Rollers covers. ""After our first song some guy with a big green mohawk yelled out 'you guys are fucking reatarded [sic]
column8: '"" he said. ""So at the next garage party we played
column9: I announced us as the Reatards kinda as a joke but the name fit so we kept it.""

column1: The name Reatard was both a self-deprecating goof and an homage to Ramones and Oblivians
column2: the latter being the Memphis-born garage-punk crew that served as his friends and mentors. Eric Oblivian's (née Friedl) Goner Records shop acted as Reatard's library
column3: just as the Goner imprint is responsible for Reatard's first releases
column4: including this one. Greg Oblivian (née Cartwright
column5: currently of Reigning Sound) sat in on drums for Fuck Elvis
column6: an added bonus collection of mostly solo four-track recordings originally released on cassette. As a first step
column7: both Teenage Hate and Fuck Elvis Here's the Reatards are astonishing. All the energy one could hear in Reatard's better-known work is here in it's rawest
column8: most volatile form. It's the same electricity he was able to funnel into his synth-punk adventures in Lost Sounds and later harness for 2006's Blood Visions
column9: not to mention his more polished work for Matador just before his death early last year. ""Guitar
column10: screaming
column11: and pounding"" was an accurate credit.

column1: We know that Reatard was prolific. But it's made especially clear here how whole-heartedly and violently he hurled himself into music from the beginning. Teenage Hate in particular has a hot
column2: fantastically gritty quality to it. It's a rough and rude sprint through Southern-inflected
column3: punk-driven garage rock. Reatards were a three-piece that included Steve Albundy Reatard (""Guitar
column4: Occasional Yells"") and Elvis Wong Reatard (""The Skins
column5: Hollering
column6: and Pickin'"")
column7: but it's quickly clear that Jay's presence is what sets them apart. You can hear it in the three-chord thwack of ultra-bleak opener ""I'm So Gone"" or the cyclonic sneer of ""I Love Living""
column8: and it only intensifies from there. ""It Ain't Me"" is a two-minute runaway train. The chorus of ""Quite All Right"" lands like a warhead
column9: as does the choir of howled ""motherfuckers"" on ""Down in Flames"".

column1: While the lyrical themes are standard punk fare (he's bored
column2: horny
column3: angry
column4: and lonely; he hates Memphis as much as he loves it)
column5: the screaming
column6: red-faced delivery makes them feel personal and true. On ""When I Get Mad""
column7: we get a look at the Jay Reatard who had a reputation for throwing punches. ""When I get mad
column8: I don't think/ Said
column9: I don't give a shit about anything."" Reatard talked a bit in interviews about growing up in Memphis
column10: where Elvis' legacy was inescapable. And though he takes on a few of Elvis' vocal tics here
column11: it's a young Kurt Cobain who comes through most
column12: particularly in the bloody coughing of ""Memphis Blues"". He screams so hopelessly that you'd swear he'd conk himself out from exhaustion. Through 18 tracks just as unfiltered
column13: he never quits.

column1: And though its recording quality renders it flat in comparison
column2: Fuck Elvis is a welcome addition as far as bonus reissue material goes. Many of its songs can be found on Teenage Hate with added muscle and clarity
column3: so it plays more like a cache of early demos. The aforementioned ""Memphis Blues"" makes a blurry appearance
column4: Reatard introducing it with a very appropriate
column5: ""Are you ready to rock'n'roll? Well
column6: here I go..."" There's a lot to dig into in the bonus material
column7: much of it still coming into focus but all of it stamped Reatard's own. Alongside covers of Fear and Buddy Holly
column8: Reatard offers herculean takes on Lil Bunnies' ""Carrot Belly Bunny Blues"" and early Beatles' B-Side ""I'm Down""
column9: a live recording tacked on to close the set. It's insanely sloppy and dissonant
column10: Reatard's screams barely audible over cymbal crash and sludgy guitar
column11: all the way to the finish. ""We're the Reatards
column12:
he says. ""Thanks."" People shout for encores.

Wale's short career has taken some weird and fascinating turns. When the D.C. rapper first came on the scene
column3: he was a hero to a certain kind of fan-- a conscious rapper who talked about sneakers just as easily as he talked about struggles
column4: and one who seemed comfortable rapping over different styles but who remained tied to his city's grassroots go-go scene. 2008's The Mixtape About Nothing took its ""Seinfeld"" theme as an unlikely jumping-off point and ended up on plenty of year-end best-of lists. But then Wale's hyped-up official debut album
column5: 2009's Attention Deficit
column6: was a stylistic jumble that bricked hard commercially and didn't make good on his promise with critics
column7: and his last few mixtapes have lacked a clear direction. Last year
column8: Wale randomly turned up on ""No Hands""
column9: a strip-club track from crunk revivalist Waka Flocka Flame; when Wale put the song on his mixtape More About Nothing
column10: he called it ""The Guilty Pleasure"". But ""No Hands"" became a massive rap-radio hit and probably saved Wale's career. In guest appearances since then
column11: he's been remaking himself as a snarly pimp
column12: a role that actually fits him pretty well. And then
column13: in a truly unlikely move
column14: surging drug-rap superstar Rick Ross signed Wale to his Maybach Music imprint.

column1: Rick Ross had a triumphant 2010. He scored the hit of the summer with the blaring gangsta anthem ""B.M.F. (Blowin' Money Fast)""-- this despite the fact that everyone now knows that he spent time pre-rap as a prison guard and that all his tales of kingpin life are straight theatrical bullshit. He's also greatly improved as a rapper since his inauspicious beginnings
column2: concentrating on his strengths and finding a decadent edge for his grunt-heavy
column3: larger-than-life delivery. His Teflon Don was one of rap's best albums of 2010. And after the year he just had
column4: he must feel like he can do anything; that's one way
column5: anyway
column6: to explain the roster he's assembled at Maybach Music.

column1: Right now
column2: the label features mostly promising young critic favorites who haven't shown the kind of charisma it takes to be an actual star; Wale is just the beginning. There's also Meek Mill
column3: a young and squeaky-voiced Philly rapper who carries the torch for ex-State Property guys like Peedi Crakk. There's Pill
column4: a raspy fast-rapping Atlanta mixtape guy. There's Teedra Moses
column5: a long-underrated R&B singer-songwriter who hasn't been anywhere near the pop marketplace since she released her strong 2004 album Complex Simplicity. All these artists have their strengths
column6: and all of them work best in very specific contexts. But on the group album <i>Self Made
column7: Vol. 1
column8: Ross pulls all of them away from their respective comfort zones and tosses them headfirst into the stormy
column9: orchestral arena-rap that he himself favors. The end result is predictable: they all sound lost.

column1: Wale
column2: Meek
column3: and Pill are all gifted technical rappers
column4: but technical rappers can disappear when they show up on something like Just Blaze's stormy
column5: cluttered title track. Even though all three MCs have distinct voices
column6: accents
column7: and deliveries
column8: they blur into one multisyllabic mush on songs like these-- dancing around the edges of these tracks rather than bulldozing through them the way Ross does. (Moses
column9: meanwhile
column10: is generally limited to cooing wordlessly in the background; she's sadly a non-factor here.) Of the three rappers
column11: Meek has the best moments; tough-talking hard on the street single ""Tupac Back"" (though his Pac impression could use some work). Pill shows no signs of any discernible personality here
column12: but his growl of a voice makes him a decent-enough supporting player on a few of these tracks. But Wale just sounds utterly confused
column13: kvetching about his past industry troubles and vowing that he's going to keep his integrity intact even though he sounds more interested in talking about clothes and girls than in displaying any of that vaunted integrity. At this point
column14: he seems to have no idea who he is.

column1: Ross mostly takes a backseat on the album
column2: but his brief appearances
column3: usually limited to hooks
column4: show why he's in a different universe from his  charges. A song like ""Pacman"" is clearly intended as a Pill showcase
column5: but Ross is tough and loose and funny (""All my power pellets
column6: turn you bitch niggas to ghosts!"") while Pill is serious and clenched and anonymous. When non-Maybach Music guests stop through
column7: the problem gets even worse. Jadakiss absolutely schools Wale on ""600 Benz""
column8: while J. Cole-- a rapper with an Internet-friendly mixtape pedigree just like the younger Maybach Music guys-- still whups everyone's ass on ""Fitted Cap"". Longtime Ross associate Gunplay only gets one appearance
column9: which is too bad; he conveys more verve and passion in his one verse than his new labelmates manage in all their showcases.

column1: If Wale
column2: Meek
column3: and Pill could find a way to focus on their own strengths
column4: maybe they'd sound more comfortable alongside their new boss. Instead
column5: they all sound like they're trying to become mini-Rosses
column6: and it doesn't work for them. <i>Self Made
column7: Vol. 1 is designed to demonstrate that Ross' new proteges can succeed in rap's major leagues
column8:
but it proves the opposite.

Nat Baldwin has an impressive résumé. He's studied under free jazz guru Anthony Braxton
column2: contributed to Department of Eagles' In Ear Park as well as Vampire Weekend's Contra
column3: and has been the bassist in Dirty Projectors. Over the course of nine years
column4: he's also recorded several solo full-lengths (not to mention a split collaboration with Extra Life) that are equally varied. People Changes
column5: his fifth
column6: is a rich addition.

column1: The recording writing process this time out took Baldwin to a remote cabin in Maine. That sort of setting may sound familiar
column2: and
column3: like Bon Iver's debut splash
column4: this is a record with a wonderful ambiance. Unlike most of 2008's Most Valuable Player
column5: People Changes finds Baldwin largely on his own: just his voice and bass
column6: with help from a few friends. Baldwin sings in a lovely melisma
column7: the same slippery style used by his Dirty Projectors bandmate Dave Longstreth. But while Longstreth's voice will often crunch itself up into grotesque shapes
column8: Baldwin keeps his airborne. It serves as a terrific juxtaposition to the spare arrangements of People Changes. The earthen tones of his double-bass act as both anchor and trampoline for Baldwin's voice
column9: an instrument that flutters and swoops as it pleases.

column1: On opener ""A Little Lost""
column2: an Arthur Russell cover originally played by its composer on cello
column3: they both begin high. Baldwin is often one to scratch his strings for dissonance
column4: but here
column5: he opts for softer textures-- a sort of bedding. This fits both the song's gentle lyrical gait as well as Baldwin's singing. Where Russell's original worked within a traditional pop template
column6: utilizing choruses and verses
column7: Baldwin's tends to embellish around those borders. It gives everything a wide-open feeling
column8: just as it does it does in closer ""Let My Spirit Rise"". On paper
column9: lines like ""Kiss me once for yourself"" might seem like material more suited for navelgazing singer-songwriters. But despite what the arrangement or lack of structure might suggest
column10: this is every bit the pop song. Its fantastic array of textures sets it apart all the more.

column1: Those only grow more interesting as People Changes unfolds. While woodwinds burble in the high-wire drama of ""Weights""
column2: Baldwin injects blasts of guitar
column3: sax
column4: and snare to the quiet of ""Lifted"". The brief ""What Is There"" is an instrumental exploration of his bass in which he conjures elemental groans and belches. And whether Baldwin is singing with his throat or his bow
column5:
there's a thrilling feeling of freedom to it all.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16596/homepage_large.ff1891a8.jpg|Future Accidents|3782.0|Sightings|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Our Mouth']|2011-05-26 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:40.420023|"

When I reviewed Mouthus' Divisionals two years ago
column2: I called them ""professionals."" Not every record they make is a masterpiece
column3: but they always deliver diligent
column4: worthwhile music. The same is true of Sightings
column5: whose latest LP happens to be released on Our Mouth
column6: the label run by Mouthus' Brian Sullivan. The two bands have lots of similarities-- each takes a workman-like approach to its music
column7: each has a patience that makes even its wildest moments sound thoughtful
column8: and each relies on a uniquely dissonant guitar sound and hybrid acoustic/electronic drumming. Most importantly
column9: both like to carve structures out of their noise. Their brittle feedback and clanging rhythms can be harsh
column10: but even their most abstract stuff is carefully shaped.

column1: On recent Sightings albums
column2: those shapes have become more prominent. 2007's Through the Panama even had some hummable tunes
column3: and 2010's City of Straw continued that momentum. On Future Accidents
column4: Sightings are less concerned with short
column5: sharp nuggets. There is one track-- the churning
column6: hardcore-tinted ""The Knotted House""-- that pours its energy into a five-minute burst. But the remainder of the album is more expansive. Its sounds as if some particular ideas were itching at Sightings
column7: and they decided to scratch away until music bled out.

column1: That may sound brutal
column2: but this is actually their mellowest effort to date. Other Sightings records
column3: particularly 2004's Arrived in Gold
column4: are sparser and more restrained
column5: but Future Accidents has the smoothest surface. Mark Morgan's trademark guitar sound
column6: a singularly metallic scrape
column7: is a bit more distant here. Think of it and his snarling voice as the supporting cast to the starring rhythmic loops of bassist Richard Hoffman and drummer Jon Lockie. It may be a stretch to call this Sightings' Krautrock album
column8: but there are some grooves here
column9: and the band rides them as if hypnotized.

column1: At least
column2: there's something Faust-like about the final track
column3: ""Public Remains""
column4: which at 19 minutes takes up about half of Future Accidents. However it came together
column5: it sounds chopped up and rearranged
column6: echoing some of the rattling
column7: broken-machine collages on The Faust Tapes. It's one of the most abstract things the band has ever done-- even their early attacks had songs buried at the bottom
column8: while this piece is more like audio sculpture. But it's also detailed and organized
column9: again bearing a methodical approach that
column10: for this group
column11: has become second nature. Which makes the album title kind of funny-- with Sightings
column12: it's hard to imagine anything being an accident
column13:
now or in the future.

"|15480.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15480-future-accidents/|7.0|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16539/homepage_large.bf7459be.jpg|Brave Irene EP|29672.0|Brave Irene|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Slumberland']|2011-05-26 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:41.037355|"

Brave Irene's debut EP represents a return for bandleader and indie pop veteran Rose Melberg. It's the first time in 15 years that one of her projects has seen release on Slumberland (the Bay Area indie previously put out a self-titled 10"" from her collaboration with All Girl Summer Fun Band's Jen Sbragia as the Softies.) It's also the first time she's fronted a band making this kind of racket since her days as a member of the early 1990s noise-pop outfit Tiger Trap. So for anyone who has been following along with her more low-key work in the interim
column2: the rocky blast that kicks off Brave Irene opener ""No Fun"" is both a surprise and a welcome look back at the past.

column1: That's not to say she's repeating herself here. Melberg has always been a shapeshifter. While Tiger Trap had a hand in drawing the clattering blueprint for a sound that's still beloved and imitated
column2: the Vancouver-based Brave Irene draws inspiration from a different world of underground rock-- specifically
column3: the rolling ""Dunedin Sound"" that came from esteemed New Zealand label Flying Nun in the 1980s and 90s. The Kiwi callback comes mostly in the form of Caitlin Gilroy and Jessica Wilkin's dual keyboard assault; their seasick lines dart in and out of the eight songs here
column4: providing a see-sawing motion to even the EP's least ""rocking"" song
column5: the sweet ""Bank Holiday"". Coupled with the rapidly precise drumming of Laura Hatfield
column6: Brave Irene's keyboard-heavy sound carries with it a hint of psychedelia.

column1: There's nothing distinctly ""trippy"" about Brave Irene as a whole
column2: though; these songs contain the same questions of the heart that fans of Melberg's output expect from her projects. She delivers those musings in her bright
column3: empathetic voice-- the same one that made the Softies' dreamy
column4: drumless songs so instantly inviting. Not a word is wasted
column5: from the long-distance heartbreak of ""River to the Sea"" to the fearless flight of ""Hit the Grass Running""
column6: pronounced with an arresting intimacy that feels refreshingly out of step with current indie trends. After all
column7: this is ""feelings"" music
column8: and if you can't parse the sentiments
column9: how do you relate?

column1: That directness is what places Brave Irene in the here and now. Obviously
column2: the ""Slumberland sound"" has been warmed over plenty of times by younger artists with impeccable record collections and keen ears for replication. But little of the recent revivalism has sounded this fresh and bright-- ironic
column3: given how long Melberg has been at it. There's plenty to like here
column4: whether you've been approaching indie pop through its new disciples or you're the kind of person wondering if Cub will ever make another record. For a band with such strong ties to the past
column5:
Brave Irene's future sounds especially appealing.

"|15426.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15426-brave-irene-ep/|7.1|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16589/homepage_large.68609ea3.jpg|Let Love In|26031.0|Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Mute']|2011-05-25 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:28:41.637391|"

The 1990s were very good to Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds. Where the previous decade saw Cave successfully transition out of the Birthday Party's combustible punk toward a more urbane
column3: theatrical brand of rock
column4: the 90s elevated him to the realm of archetype and institution. He successfully party-crashed Hollywood and ""Top of the Pops""
column5: all while the college-radio charts filled up with emergent artists-- PJ Harvey
column6: Tindersticks
column7: Afghan Whigs-- cut from the Bad Seeds' black-velvet cloth.

column1: The Bad Seeds' mid-90s pinnacle forms the basis of the latest round of Mute's excellent reissue series
column2: which include vividly remastered versions of the original albums
column3: along with a 5.1 surround sound mix
column4: B-sides
column5: official videos
column6: and the latest installments of Iain Forsyth and Jane Pollard's illuminating fan-testimonial documentaries
column7: Do You Love Me Like I Love You? The title of the film series is taken from the two-part song that opens and closes Let Love In
column8: an authoritative show of force that was perfectly timed for the Bad Seeds' insurrectionary appearance on the 1994 Lollapalooza tour. The Bad Seeds had always traded in high drama and dissonance
column9: but never before had they sounded this imposingly heavy-- the lecherous intimations of ""Do You Love Me?"" explode into a torrent of chain-gang vocals and drummer Thomas Wydler's machine-gunned snare rolls
column10: while ""Loverman"" triggers its quiet-to-loud eruptions so masterfully
column11: Metallica would later cover the song to the surprise of no one.

column1: But amid Let Love In's ballast
column2: you can hear Cave's increased adeptness at exploring his fascinations using sly
column3: pitch-black humor instead of transgressive shock tactics. ""Red Right Hand""-- the future theme song of the Scream film franchise-- sets its serial-killer narrative to a seductive swampy groove
column4: and the beautiful piano ballad ""Nobody's Baby Now"" is a work of such wry
column5: understated elegance
column6: Cave originally thought of giving it to Johnny Cash.

column1: As Let Love In's signature tracks proved
column2: Cave's love songs could easily  turn into death songs
column3: so it was inevitable that he'd devote an entire album to exploring that symbiotic relationship. Murder Ballads has a title so obvious and self-defining
column4: it's amazing that it took the Bad Seeds nine albums to use it. And the last thing you could accuse Cave of is false advertising: Dozens of characters lose their lives over the course of the album
column5: which updates infamous folk tales like ""Stagger Lee"" with enough profanity and gratuitous violence to satisfy the bloodlusty standards of the post-gangsta rap/Quentin Tarantino era.

column1: But the Bad Seeds' most lyrically depraved record is also their most musically ornate and accessible
column2: with the band expanding to accommodate Dirty Three violinist Warren Ellis and former Cramps/Sonic Youth stickman Jim Sclavunos (as second percussionist)
column3: plus a pair of smoldering duets with PJ Harvey (""Henry Lee"") and Kylie Minogue (the unlikely MTV hit ""Where the Wild Roses Grow""). In fact
column4: with its densely detailed storylines
column5: heart-racing epics (""Song of Joy""
column6: ""The Curse of Millhaven"") and cheeky curtain-closing cover of Bob Dylan's born-again anthem ""Death Is Not the End""
column7: it's hard not to imagine Murder Ballads as some perverse
column8: alternate-universe West End musical production. But look past its comically over-the-top presentation and you realize Cave isn't simply indulging in some subversive genre exercise. He was examining the very idea of poetic license
column9: pushing the limits of what an artist can get away with in a song when writing in character.

column1: The Boatman's Call is Cave's plea for redemption
column2: an album every bit as dignified as its predecessor is deranged. After spending much of his career spinning yarns out of other people's misery
column3: Cave-- emerging from a divorce and a highly publicized but short-lived affair with PJ Harvey-- comes clean about his own. On the stirring piano-based hymns ""Into My Arms"" and ""There Is a Kingdom""
column4: he looks to religion less as a convenient dramatic device and more as the genuine refuge for the lonely soul. Cave had flirted with tender balladry many times before
column5: but whereas previous turns like ""Straight to You"" and ""The Ship Song"" were shot through the Bad Seeds' widescreen lens
column6: here
column7: the atmosphere is so spare and intimate

There's a song on Friendly Fires' eponymous 2008 debut that's called ""Jump in the Pool"". The lyrical concerns are pretty straightforward (hint: jumping and pools are involved)
column3: but what makes it one of the LP's standouts is how its chorus takes the titular advice and just goes for it
column4: changing from peppy polyrhythms to fast
column5: charging lushness in a matter of seconds. It's a melodic shift that's as over-the-top as it is impressively delivered-- but that's kind of the point. Friendly Fires was best when playing to the rafters with romantic electro-gaze textures (""Skeleton Boy"") and big
column6: cheesy gestures (""Paris""). They're sensualists who excel under a lack of restraint.

column1: Wisely
column2: the band's sophomore effort
column3: Pala
column4: wastes no time submerging itself into its own indulgent environment. The multi-layered neon pop of album opener ""Live Those Days Tonight"" only hints at the LP's sonic ambition
column5: as the band's immense co-production with buzz-bin consigliere Paul Epworth lends extra depth to its colorful sonic detail. There's been three years between Friendly Fires and this thing
column6: and they've clearly spent it well by jewelling every last detail with careful precision (the B-movie blast that spools off ""Blue Cassette""'s final reel
column7: ""Helpless""' backseat chatter and Boards of Canada keyboards).

column1: To an extent
column2: Pala also clears these guys' name on the ""rockist dance-dilettante"" list. From the galloping UK funky rhythm in ""Chimes"" to the filtered
column3: bleeping funk of ""Hurting""
column4: there's an array of styles tried on and
column5: for the most part
column6: successfully worn. Those successes speak as much to the band's listening habits as they do to a sense of maximalist adventurousness.

column1: However
column2: all the signifiers in the world don't change the fact that Friendly Fires are a rock band first-- and a particularly emotive one
column3: at that. The band's three members got their start as teenagers in the never-known vocal-less ""post-hardcore"" (read: emo) outfit First Day Back. Anyone who's ever had a taste for that stuff knows that once it enters your blood
column4: it tends to stay there
column5: and Pala's high-stakes framework reflects that. Hearts are set on fire regularly (no
column6: not like that)
column7: while impassioned pleas ""Show Me Lights"" and ""Pull Me Back to Earth"" are exactly as sweeping as you'd expect. It's when the band gets too entrenched in maudlin
column8: dark-hued dramatizing (the too-slow-burn of the title track
column9: ""Chimes""' bald-faced falsetto foolery) that Pala's deep-sea diving feels similar to drowning.

column1: Not to worry
column2: though-- they have a sense of humor too
column3: as ""Hawaiian Air"" proves. As the title suggests
column4: frontman Ed Macfarlane's lyrical concerns focus on a trip to
column5: you guessed it
column6: Hawaii-- only
column7: he spends the entire song detailing his escapades on the flight there (""watching a film with a talking dog
column8: ""skipping the meal for a G&T"")
column9: barely able to breathe in that tropical oxygen. It's a simple-pleasures zoom-in that belies the album's candy-painted sweep
column10: a sneaky yet sentimental grin amidst all the pleading and sincerity-- 'cause this stuff is supposed to be fun
column11:
right?

There's a fascinating dichotomy inside of Black Earth
column3: the first official album from Chicago quartet Implodes. Stylistically
column4: it's almost schizophrenic-- tracks alternate between shoegaze
column5: Krautrock
column6: post-rock
column7: experimental drone
column8: and acoustic ambiance
column9: and those modes don't often meet together in one place. Yet the overall mood is forcefully consistent
column10: with a weight approaching gravitational pull. That tone is captured somewhat in the cover art's stark silhouettes
column11: but even that image is a little too colorful for this hazy
column12: shadow-filled sound-cloud. Whenever I listen

column1: That may seem a bit overdramatic
column2: but Implodes sound like they take their music pretty seriously
column3: and they should. It's carefully crafted and wholly enveloping
column4: a kind of dream-state atmosphere where vocals shiver behind layers of fuzz
column5: rhythms detonate like underwater explosions
column6: and acoustic guitars drift in and out like flashes of déjà vu. Some tracks on their own might sound a bit derivative-- ""Marker""'s floating noise has a Slowdive tint

column9: skirting spaces between Labradford
column10: Bowery Electric
column11: and Jessamine. But when fused together by Implodes' assured sense of narrative thrust
column12: these songs are much more echoes than mimicry-- like an unfamiliar
column13: moonlit landscape dotted with fleeting glimpses of past ghosts.

column1: All of which makes for a pretty heavy listen. Dense
column2: dark
column3: and slow even when it's fast
column4: Black Earth can get murky and claustrophobic
column5: sucking in the air around it. There's a fine line between mesmerizing and depressing
column6: and while I find myself squarely on the entranced side throughout
column7: I can see where others might find the dimmer passageways more blinding than beckoning. But this is where the band's stylistic diversity helps. While a deep drone like ""Oxblood"" may burrow the center of the earth
column8: it's immediately countered by the motoring sway of ""Meadowlands""
column9: or the hymn-like buzz of ""Wendy""
column10: or the lilting blur of ""Experiential Report"". Which is why the most interesting thing about Black Earth is what it bodes for Implodes' future. If they can already mold this many sounds into the same tonal shape

For better and worse
column2: electronic music cares about process. You wouldn't ever congratulate a friend who spent months getting his oven to function as a refrigerator
column3: but anyone who can make a vacuum sound like an 808 can prepare for notoriety
column4: if not outright praise. Artists such as Matthew Herbert
column5: the Field
column6: and Matmos have diced sounds until their notable sources are barely detectable. So it goes with 2562
column7: whose third album
column8: Fever
column9: was inspired by disco music (hence the title) released in the late 1970s around the time of the producer's birth. It's probably a smart gambit for the producer: His first two albums
column10: while well received
column11: were more notable for expanding dubstep's geographical imprint (2562 is the postal code of the producer's home in the Hague) than its sonic one.

column1: Despite its roots-- every last sound here is sampled from disco records-- Fever is a fairly catholic dubstep set: Racketeering snares
column2: ominous chord structures
column3: and a vague melodic distension pervade the album. Still
column4: you can hear the fruits of his labor
column5: especially in comparison to 2009's Unbalance. Fever is warmer
column6: due both to its subtle vinyl crackle and the vague symphonic timbre that hovers whenever its minute samples are massed in melody. The persistent
column7: four-on-the-floor clacking that propels ""Brasil Deadwalker"" is a visceral reminder of how techno and house borrowed and digitized disco's rhythmic structure. The anthemic opener ""Winamp Melodrama"" (great title) grabs a Gamble & Huff hammer and bangs everything in sight. 2562 doesn't employ vocal samples very often
column8: but on the album-closing title track he gathers several into a dense fog and achieves a kind of beauty rarely attempted elsewhere on the album.

column1: About that: Fever
column2: like 2562's previous records
column3: is hard music. There is no wobble in the bass or flutter in the melodies; they are presented as-is
column4: with little space for the listener. Fever can sound plastic
column5: unpliable at times. I can hear the echoes of those old disco records in these sounds
column6: but I can't find any of the laughter
column7: silliness
column8: or goodwill that fueled them. 2562 spent a lot of time molding one genre of music into another: It's safe to say he cares about sound for sound's sake. Which is fine
column9: but it also means that the process that drove Fever's creation wasn't undertaken in an effort to illuminate the source material (it should be said that while most genres of dance music owe a healthy debt to disco
column10: dubstep is really more of a third cousin than a granddaughter) or forge new territory. It was done as an exercise.

column1: So parts of Fever-- the bone-on-bone thwacks that close ""Flavour Park Jam""
column2: for instance-- are essentially just 2562 going through the motions: the tedious
column3: musically rigorous motions. I adore the idea behind Fever
column4: and the attempt to artistically bind oneself to a process like this is brave. But in boxing himself in
column5: 2562 seems to have found just a new box
column6: a constricted area where several of his compositions suffocate. Those that escape are enjoyable as some kind of tonally curious
column7: hardscrabble bass music
column8:
which is where 2562 began in the first place.

It's not hard to draw a line between the music on Coma Cinema's third proper release
column3: Blue Suicide
column4: and the pains it took to make it. Mat Cothran
column5: the sole member of the South Carolina downer pop project
column6: spent time in between sessions carrying microphones around
column7: looking for the opportunity to record on equipment he stumbled upon. Lacking funds and created against the backdrop of the belly-up mill town he grew up in
column8: Blue Suicide is expectedly blue. Perhaps not as expected is how ambitious and arresting this album can be
column9: taking its emotional cues from the lovesick and bored American Gothic landscapes it was conceived in
column10: and its musical touchstones from just about anywhere Cothran's determination allowed.

column1: There's a moment on ""Greater Vultures"" that helps put this process-- and the end result-- into perspective. Instead of amping up the poignancy on this dirge-like wallow by employing a weepy string part
column2: Cothran brings in a sort of monster-movie synth line that's both oddly placed and a little disquieting. It's possibly a move made out of necessity
column3: but it's these limitations and what Cothran does with them where the magnetism lies. When he creatively skirts these hindrances
column4: it's often what keeps you on the hook. In the case of ""Greater Vultures""
column5: it allows the song to take on a much deeper desperation. As Cothran murmurs
column6: ""Are you willing to eat what the vultures will not?"" it's pretty clear that this acceptance of a less than perfect situation is a valuable part of Cothran's approach
column7: as well as Blue Suicide's appeal.

column1: Which isn't to say it doesn't succumb to mere convenience at times. There are plenty of songs that seem comfortable just floating by in ways that clash with Cothran's larger ambitions. But there's always something to hold onto
column2: no matter how shaky the foundation may be. Cothran-- by no means a flexible singer-- often alternates between a buzzing lilt and a dolorous hush throughout the album
column3: but he has an ear for melodic hooks
column4: often testing his limits with surprising results. ""Lindsey"" sounds like a Siamese Dream-era Smashing Pumpkins demo
column5: with Cothran miming Billy Corgan at a dramatic extreme. ""Caroline
column6: Please Kill Me"" is equally pleasing
column7: boisterous and whiny with a radio-friendly enthusiasm. The fact that these bigger songs sound so homemade (though well-mixed and recorded) may prove detrimental to some
column8: but it's hard not to admire a guy who has the gall to flatly ignore his relative inexperience in favor of just going for it.

column1: There are moments that come close to real greatness. ""Her Sinking Sun"" is a devastating hymn that can barely scrape itself off the ground to greet you
column2: but Cothran isn't the kind of songwriter who gets off on sulking. ""Sinking Sun"" harnesses the gloom in such a visceral way
column3: it has the strength to puncture. ""Eva Angelina"" is even better
column4: mostly because it's the most self-assured offering here-- a patient
column5: slow-blooming heartbreaker that gets under your skin. More importantly
column6: it's proof that there are truly impressive songs in Cothran. With some luck
column7:
enough people will get their hands on Blue Suicide to give him the chance to really prove us right.

The first words you're likely to hear in relation to Thurston Moore's Demolished Thoughts are ""acoustic"" and ""folk."" Indeed
column3: the Beck Hansen-helmed album was made mostly with six- and 12-string acoustic guitars
column4: harps
column5: violins
column6: bass (sometimes upright)
column7: and drums. But to call this record ""folk"" or ""acoustic"" is to mistakenly suggest that it's relaxed comfort music from an aging dude who still sings about teenage riots with his hoary rock band. Rather
column8: Demolished Thoughts is as immediate and form-warping as Moore's work with Sonic Youth
column9: comprising nine anxious
column10: charged songs about fleeting time and failing happiness
column11: played with veteran resilience. Jokes about old men and their Martins need not apply.

column1: The essentials of this project might recall Trees Outside the Academy
column2: Moore's song-oriented solo album from 2007. (The ""song-oriented"" distinction is necessary if reductive
column3: as Moore seems to release between one and
column4: oh
column5: 47 experimental discs every year.) Violinist Samara Lubelski is the only Trees alumna on Demolished Thoughts. Moore returns with a consistent
column6: cohesive band-- Lubelski
column7: harpist Mary Lattimore
column8: guitarist Bill Nace
column9: Hansen and his regular collaborators
column10: drummer Joey Waronker and bassist Bram Inscore. As such
column11: this is a much more rigorous and singular album

column13: deliberate sonic approach that his previous solo work has foregone. Trees had its moments
column14: but
column15: as a whole
column16: it was uneasy and unsettled
column17: as though Moore finally made it into a studio to record ideas he'd tucked away in notebooks during Sonic Youth tours. Demolished Thoughts feels less like a side-project of afterthoughts
column18: more like a careful album cut with a smartly assembled band.

column1: Instruments aside
column2: Demolished Thoughts isn't built like typical folk music
column3: or even the chiseled chamber folk of the last decade or so. The hazy
column4: nearly seven-minute ""Orchard Street""
column5: for instance
column6: gets through its lyrics in nearly half its running time; the second
column7: instrumental half sounds like an acoustic reinvention of the glorious codas from Sonic Youth's Murray Street
column8: the role of the pounding drums taken by battered guitar strings
column9: the squall of the electric guitars replicated with harp runs and violin trills. The album's other longer stretch
column10: the appropriately titled ""Space""
column11: moves in perfectly expanding and contracting waves. Moore enters with the tone of someone who's given up on patience: ""I used to have all the time in the world/ Cruising galaxies in search of gold
column12: he sings
column13: the unease in his voice dismissing any back-porch associations. Even at their prettiest
column14: like the slow-rolling and sad-eyed ""Benediction"" or the gently exhaling closer
column15: ""January""
column16: these songs move in unexpected ways
column17: whether it's the players pushing into unlikely patterns or the production embellishing some unseen aspect. As with his other band
column18: Moore succeeds by folding great ideas into otherwise good songs.

column1: Beck's production is actually as essential and interesting as these tunes. He stretches Moore's songs without polishing them
column2: giving them a pop number's scope and ambition without seeming obvious or pedantic. ""Circulation"" is a nervous collage of busy images-- needles hitting records
column3: friends on the move
column4: speakers
column5: lights
column6: cries
column7: shots. Hansen pushes the core pieces of the song close together
column8: so that Inscore's bass lashes violently against Moore's layers of heavy-handed strums. And on ""In Silver Rain With a Paper Key""
column9: Hansen adds a trail of echo to Moore's plaintive tone
column10: allowing the words to float like dust among guitars and string parts. Not lo-fi per se but purposefully damaged
column11: the recording mimics Moore's loneliness and disorientation if only by way of atmosphere.

column1: Moore
column2: who will turn 53 this summer
column3: is several years older than many of the bandleaders to emerge as indie rock luminaries with his success and staying power-- J Mascis
column4: Henry Rollins
column5: Frank Black
column6: for obvious examples. That's reason enough to be sidetracked by the talk of mellow folk vibes. While Moore's been putting out records for three decades now
column7: Demolished Thoughts feels vital and purposed
column8: more like a debut than an encore. It's the work of a restless artist fighting successfully through his own skin to not only outstrip our expectations of how he sounds but also of the sort of music acoustic guitars and harps can make. With Demolished Thoughts
column9: Thurston Moore solo albums have become more than fields of noise throwaways spiked with the occasional gem
column10: more than Sonic Youth stopgaps. A lot of people retire after 30 years
column11:
but Moore has added another great line to an overwhelming résumé.

column8: in part because his songs never even attempt universal truths or gushing emotion. He has never seemed on the verge of breaking out

even when he deserves it.

Most countries have some sort of music industry. It may be small or a little ramshackle but it's there
column3: helping to make recordings available in some sort of semi-orderly fashion. It promotes performances
column4: broadcasts music
column5: talks about music in publications. Mauritania's Beydane and Haratine music has no industry to promote it-- the country is one of the few places in the world with no private or even state system in place to capture and disseminate music. The music happens live
column6: played by musicians hired by an audience; it could be a wedding party
column7: an official function
column8: or just a group of friends who want to do a little dancing. The majority of the musicians live and work in Nouakchott
column9: the sprawling
column10: mostly improvised capital city

column1: Mauritania is a vast country
column2: bigger than Texas and New Mexico combined
column3: but in much of that space there are no people. Nearly every one of the country's roughly three million people lives in the Southwest
column4: near the coast and the Senegal River
column5: and a full third of them are in Nouakchott. The Beydane (who we call Moors) and the Haratine are Mauritania's dominant ethnic groups
column6: and their language
column7: a dialect of Arabic called Hassaniya
column8: is the most widely spoken (along with French
column9: which is used mostly in official contexts). To describe Mauritanian Beydane and Haratine music is superficially simple: It consists primarily of singers
column10: improvising based on poetry
column11: hand percussion
column12: and guitar or a similar local stringed instrument-- guitar has since 1976 largely supplanted the tidinitt lute (played by men) and the ardin harp (played by women).

column1: The guitar is electric
column2: I should add. This
column3: in a city where electricity service is not comprehensive
column4: to say the least. There have been a few attempts to record Beydane guitar music over the years in a controlled
column5: high-fidelity environment
column6: and one could get the impression from listening to these that the music is pretty sedate
column7: but this is misleading. As one listen to Wallahi Le Zein quickly shows
column8: this is music of immense energy. Trying to record it in a studio robs it of the primary engine that drives it
column9: which is audience response. The musicians crank it up when the audience steps it up
column10: and cool it down when the audience gets tired. Matthew Lavoie
column11: the set's compiler
column12: at first attempted to make some of his own recordings in specially arranged sessions with an audience
column13: but to hear him tell it in his extensive liner notes
column14: the lack of a proper music-making occasion resulting in sterile recordings that got the technical bits right but missed on the spirit of the music.

column1: But Lavoie was truly in love with this music
column2: and wouldn't be deterred. Over the course of years and many visits to Mauritania
column3: he collected privately recorded cassettes of performances until he had a massive archive to draw from. It's not unusual for the people paying the musicians to record a performance for a souvenir-- as you can imagine
column4: though
column5: the quality of those recordings is often abysmal
column6: so sorting for a set of tracks that both captured the spirit of the music as it's normally performed and satisfied even some very rudimentary standards of fidelity took some work. The compiler's passion for the music and knowledge of its history
column7: performance and underlying theory is on full display in the thick booklet that comes with this set-- expanding it into a book wouldn't be out of the question.

column1: Without getting too far into the specifics of it
column2: all of the music on this set is built around a very basic modal structure. There are a set number of modes in the music
column3: which must be played in a certain order
column4: and each mode has two different rhythmic characters (one legato
column5: one staccato)
column6: to be played in a specific order. But beyond that
column7: it's wide open. Tempo
column8: the actual melody played within the mode
column9: the play of voice against guitar
column10: the rhythm

column7: psychedelic edge and free-floating intensity that makes me think of Hendrix playing ""The Star-Spangled Banner

column10:
Casablanca Nights only gets you out of 2011 for a few sweet minutes.

Boris have never been one for hedged bets or bridled ambitions. In the past 15 years
column3: the Japanese trio has released more than 20 albums of heavy eclecticism-- stoner bludgeons and thrash blasts

column5: gong-banging drummer with one of those arena-rock

column1: Accordingly

column8: then

column4: gnarls of noise

column6: while the other 12-minute-plus tune

column8: growls and swells before drifting off into a piano-and-distortion haze. For fans of Boris
column9: the material is a double-edged sword: It's the sort of motley metal that brought you to the fold one way or another

column11: from the massive soundscapes on Pink to the dynamic sizzle in Amplifier Worship-- several times before. Here

column2: Wata takes lead vocal. Her consistent presence offers an atmosphere of patience

column4: she leads the band through several different looks
column5: from the tense
column6: pretty opening title track to the dance-metal anthem ""Party Boy"". During ""See You Next Week""
column7: she drifts like a ghost between a world of broken drum machines and guitars meant more for texture than melody. There's a ruminative instrumental for acoustic guitar
column8: and ""Spoon""
column9: a blustery tumble that-- Wata's willowy vocals aside-- favorably suggests the sound of 1990s American modern rock radio. What's best

column2: sort of

column6: thrash

Whether it's the elegiac folk singer heading for stacks of finely orchestrated keyboards or the black metal band backing its melee with a pure and purposed disco-punk throb
column9: a whole crop of young acts now seem open to the possibilities within their forms. Their audiences largely seem interested in tagging along
column10: too. After all
column11: we obtain and hear music in radically different ways and contexts now than in 1996
column12: when Boris were making their recorded debut as a noisy sludge-metal band from Tokyo. Boris' post-modern eclecticism is
column13: in theory
column14: perfect for this moment. But pastiches and piss-takes-- by and large
column15: the sort of material that's scattered between Attention Please and the second Heavy Rocks-- can only satisfy so much. Boris seem to be racing to stay current
column16: to show that they can change as rapidly as these hyper-wired times. With each new addition to a catalog that's becoming more adulterated each year

we're learning that maybe they can't.

column11: new heavy music

column1: Accordingly
column2: there are few release-day gestures more rock star than issuing two albums at the same time
column3: as Boris will do with the slight electropop-and-shoegaze departure Attention Please and the requisite metal grab bag Heavy Rocks. What's more
column4: this is the second Boris LP to sport the title Heavy Rocks; the first was released in 2002
column5: and nearly a decade later
column6: it still stands as one of Boris' best efforts
column7: a landmark distillation of stoner metal and noise rock built with enviable precision and aggression. This moment
column8: then
column9: is not only Boris' look-how-popular-we-are exclamation but also their look-how-much-we've-grown assertion; essentially
column10: Attention Please and Heavy (Heavier?) Rocks are logical next steps for the Boris legacy. But riddled as this pair of albums is with confounding musical indecision and listless stylistic repetition
column11: they mostly serve as reminders of how remarkable and inventive Boris have been and often threaten to be. Heavy Rocks was sturdier back in 2002

column1: Heavy Rocks does the things you expect a Boris album to do: It explodes open with ""Riot Sugar""
column2: a brutal blues-metal march with a rote
column3: ragged riff and background grunts from the Cult's Ian Astbury. ""Missing Pieces"" alternates between spare guitar drift
column4: gnarls of noise
column5: and an epically forlorn crescendo
column6: while the other 12-minute-plus tune
column7: ""Aileron""
column8: growls and swells before drifting off into a piano-and-distortion haze. For fans of Boris
column9: the material is a double-edged sword: It's the sort of motley metal that brought you to the fold one way or another
column10: but that means you've already heard it-- all of it
column11: from the massive soundscapes on Pink to the dynamic sizzle in Amplifier Worship-- several times before. Here
column12: it's all offered like a mixtape
column13: with no narrative arch or musical momentum.

column1: Attention Please at least offers something fresh for Boris. For the first time in the band's long run
column2: Wata takes lead vocal. Her consistent presence offers an atmosphere of patience
column3: plus a cohesiveness that Boris have long since foregone. Sure
column4: she leads the band through several different looks
column5: from the tense
column6: pretty opening title track to the dance-metal anthem ""Party Boy"". During ""See You Next Week""
column7: she drifts like a ghost between a world of broken drum machines and guitars meant more for texture than melody. There's a ruminative instrumental for acoustic guitar
column8: and ""Spoon""
column9: a blustery tumble that-- Wata's willowy vocals aside-- favorably suggests the sound of 1990s American modern rock radio. What's best
column10: the trio doesn't give up on its heavy metal experience; though this album suggests a stylistic mix of new wave and Mazzy Star
column11: Boris play with the rumble and roar of a loud rock band. The bass line during the chiming ""Tokyo Wonder Land"" is a menacing throb
column12: the guitar solo an acid-damaged roar. ""Les Paul Custom '86"" emerges as a dance number through sheets of noise
column13: anchored by a riff that would have fit Earth in 1993. Those tell-all touches and Wata's command suggest that this is the better
column14: if unforeseen
column15: avenue for Boris' future. Though not fully developed
column16: this is a space where they might actually explore without the constraints of reputation and expectation.

column1: The heavy metal landscape of 2011 is tailor-made for (and
column2: sort of
column3: by) Boris. Sure
column4: the black metal kids are busy retrenching against boundary breakers like Liturgy and Altar of Plagues
column5: and a whole lot of older burly bros will tell you that stoner
column6: thrash
column7: and melodramatic metal were done better the first time. They're not necessarily wrong
column8: but those sorts of attitudes provide a welcome contrast for the tone of inclusion and acceptance for ideas that permeates not only some of the moment's most exciting metal but also music at large. Whether it's the elegiac folk singer heading for stacks of finely orchestrated keyboards or the black metal band backing its melee with a pure and purposed disco-punk throb
column9: a whole crop of young acts now seem open to the possibilities within their forms. Their audiences largely seem interested in tagging along
column10: too. After all
column11: we obtain and hear music in radically different ways and contexts now than in 1996
column12: when Boris were making their recorded debut as a noisy sludge-metal band from Tokyo. Boris' post-modern eclecticism is
column13: in theory
column14: perfect for this moment. But pastiches and piss-takes-- by and large
column15: the sort of material that's scattered between Attention Please and the second Heavy Rocks-- can only satisfy so much. Boris seem to be racing to stay current
column16: to show that they can change as rapidly as these hyper-wired times. With each new addition to a catalog that's becoming more adulterated each year
column17:
we're learning that maybe they can't.

Thanks to Odd Future

column4: Let's Wrestle are capable of tenderness. ""If I Keep on Loving You"" and ""I Am Useful"" are winsome pop songs; meanwhile

column1: For the most part

White Fang are the boisterously beating heart of Portland's DIY punk scene. They've played almost every basement within a 10-mile radius of the Willamette River. In addition to recently touring with hometown heroes the Thermals

column5: tambourines
column6: and anti-harmonized vocals. Though it serves as more of a sketch or interlude than a fully fleshed-out song (just like the original)

column2: as Gage sings
column3: ""I woke up today feeling kinda shitty/ Feeling kinda bad for myself

but it's also a testament to why grabbing a bunch of instruments with your friends and creating music-- whether it's in our basements or a $100-an-hour studio-- is so therapeutic for so many of us.

column3: strictly speaking

column1: Director's Cut transforms songs from 1989's The Sensual World and 1993's The Red Shoes. Sometimes crucial elements (rhythm tracks

The very different mix of Director's Cut changes not just the sound but the emotional kick inside many of these songs. What was once the work of a shy woman who came to roaring life on record is now just as often subdued
column4: reflective

column6: without necessarily replacing the albums it draws from.

column1: At the time of its release
column2: The Sensual World seemed both up to date and not of its time. The glossy studio-obsessive production sounded definitely of its moment
column3: fitting for the era of booming drums and reverb-soaked pop trifles from bands like Fine Young Cannibals and INXS. But the songs

column6: the jazz-tinged complexity of the Canterbury psychedelic scene
column7: the unashamed theatricality that led to Peter Gabriel dressing up like a giant daffodil. It made for a strange hybrid
column8: the smoothness of the Big 80s meets the complexity and expressionism of the prog 70s. Much of the record's tension came from wrapping shiny pop accessibility around songs that might burst into emotionally raw strangeness at any time. Bush played to the moment
column9: but couldn't be contained by it.

column1: By the time of The Red Shoes-- with its prog structures
column2: guest-star guitar heroics

column6: profitable
column7: and bland MOR singer-songwriter territory. Her moment hadn't so much passed-- though it'd be hard to point out anyone else making music that sounded like this at the time-- as she'd become a genre-of-one.  The fussed-over textures and genteel folk touches of adult contemporary peeled back mid-song to reveal naked eroticism

column9: joy
column10: Bush's voice spluttering out wordless weirdness or leaping into ecstatic ululations.

column4: too

Blu seems like the kind of rapper who's really proud of his DVD collection. I don't say this with any condescension or surprise; cinephilia might as well have supplanted graffiti or b-boying as one of hip-hop's four elements by the time Rae asked Meth where his Killer tape was. But it's clear from all the carefully assembled dialogue clips on Her Favorite Colo(u)r that Blu's interest in movies is just as personal as his ear for neo-backpack production and vibrant everyman-narrative rap. We get clips from Closer
column2: Punch-Drunk Love
column3: Buffalo '66
column4: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou-- indie-canon stuff rearranged into a pastiche of troubled romance and teeth-gritting soul-baring. If there's a nerdcore for people who collect Criterion editions
column5: Blu might've dropped its most essential release of the past couple of years.

column1: Catch is
column2: you have to go back those ""past couple of years"" to pinpoint when it was first released. Her Favorite Colo(u)r used to be a free mixtape back in 2009. Now it's an official release that costs the same as any other album you can get via online retailers. It can be dicey to run across an album on the pay-actual-money market a couple of years after it was offered as a no-charge download
column3: and it might be even dicier when the main selling point-- an ostensible ""remaster""-- threatens to defeat the purpose of the original article's charm. But reissue or not
column4: this is the first widely available full-length Blu album to hit stores since he had a couple of great guest verses on the Roots' How I Got Over
column5: and momentum's momentum even if he's advanced a bit stylistically in the two-plus years since this first dropped.

column1: If this release feels a little slight
column2: you could blame its EP length-- roughly 30 minutes. But a more identifiable culprit is Blu as he sounds on the mic-- or under it
column3: or across the room from it
column4: or wherever he is in relation to the mic that half-buries him beneath his own production. Exile collab Below the Heavens and his Mainframe teamup as Johnson&Jonson have proven how engaging he can be at length
column5: spinning narratives where he duels with his own worst personal impulses and pits them against more ground-level
column6: day-to-day concerns. But he doesn't assert himself much here
column7: letting the sampled dialogue pick up the slack between rushed verses and a backgrounded mic presence. Cuts like ""Amnesia"" and ""Since"" have an introspective quality to them
column8: but that does make them a bit less immediate. And if rap is all about performance trumping the page
column9: Blu's lyrics here have the unfortunate tendency to scan a lot better on paper
column10: though at worst that usually just means you'll need another few attentive listens to start catching the highlights.

column1: At least the production does its best to make that task worthwhile. Aside from the whole Sundance vibe
column2: the main draw of Her Favorite Colo(u)r is its dusty
column3: lived-in feel
column4: familiar loops of Billie Holiday and Jimi Hendrix and Curtis Mayfield worn threadbare and distorted into shitty-speaker resonance. And the remaster doesn't radically alter the album's original character for bad or good-- the bass is a bit crisper and richer
column5: but the lo-fi dying-transistor/janky phonograph atmospherics of his production still register the most vividly. It's not the most revolutionary stuff; these dusty soul loops and chopped-up vocal refrains aren't as timely (or as polarizing) as the junglist Galaga headrush of Flying Lotus' beat for Blu's recent single ""Everything's OK"". But the lovesick noir vibe is compelling in the right mindset-- maybe humidity
column6: alcohol
column7: and regret are crucial prerequisites to getting the most out of it
column8: but hip-hop production hasn't nailed the feel of scratched Formica bar-tops and dingy jukeboxes this well since the more reflective moments of Madvillainy. Cop this if you haven't
column9: revisit it if you have
column10:
and consider it the Super 8 short-subject prequel to what should hopefully be a widescreen feature-length future breakthrough.

Simplicity is arguably one of the most important virtues of indie pop
column3: and one that Seattle's Seapony take to heart on Go With Me: 12 songs in 34 minutes
column4: all written in major keys. Pillowy guitars (courtesy of Danny Rowland)
column5: humble basslines (Ian Brewer)
column6: and airy vocals (Jen Weidl) all float calmly over uncomplicated drum machine beats. Light touches of fuzz and reverb give it an overcast feeling
column7: making this summer record sound weirdly autumnal. Go With Me is filled with childlike melancholy and wonderment
column8: like a lot of twee records. But ultimately
column9: it leaves you to wonder what Seapony are actually contributing to the vast expanse of bands clutching Tiger Trap 45s and portable button makers.

column1: The album starts on the right foot with ""Dreaming""
column2: a jaunty
column3: infectious tune with a spiky guitar line and a simple-yet-irresistible vocal melody from Weidl. ""Into the Sea""'s easygoing surf-rock is punctuated by handclaps and a nimble-fingered arpeggio. ""I Never Would"" goes a long way with its permeating sense of wistful nostalgia. If Go With Me were an EP with just those three songs
column4: it would possess a great deal more replay value.

column1: Go With Me makes for wonderful background music
column2: but paying closer attention reveals its inherent flaws. The sameness of the songs causes them to bleed into each other
column3: never deviating from the same verse-chorus-verse template. This wouldn't particularly be a problem if the album weren't so safe
column4: if its pleasant happiness or pleasant sadness were disrupted by a more excitable sense of emotion. Weidl delivers the lyrics with the same wispy soprano on every song.

column1: It doesn't help that those words aren't very interesting. Injecting simplicity into pop songwriting isn't always a clichéd effort-- take Girls' ""Laura""
column2: for instance-- but banalities like ""Blue Star""'s opening couplet
column3: ""You sat by me/ You sat down by the sea
column4: sully an otherwise decent song
column5: and the chorus of ""So Low"" (""I miss you every day/ I wish you'd stay"") makes Rebecca Black look like Dan Bejar.

column1: The best indie pop always finds a way to marry a sense of individuality to its jangle and bounce-- the violent noise underscoring Black Tambourine's output
column2: or the literary flair and sometimes-subversive humor that marks Belle and Sebastian's. Think about the heart-wrenching
column3: lacerating sadness of the Softies
column4: or even the confrontational cuteness of Tullycraft. Unfortunately
column5: the vanilla innocuousness of Seapony loses them in the shuffle. This is not to say they have delivered an utterly charmless album. If your anorak pockets are stuffed with indie pop show flyers
column6: or you are a daily reader of Skatterbrain
column7: Go With Me has a place in your record collection. But until they can really stand out from the crowd
column8:
Seapony just come across as garden-variety twee.

"|15412.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15412-go-with-me/|5.3|Martin Douglas

The unclassifiable band 13 & God was formed because of the mutual admiration between Themselves and the Notwist
column4: and later came to include Anticon artists like Dax Pierson (Subtle) and Jordan Dalrymple (Antonionian). It's not hard to imagine what the American post-rap duo and the German electro-pop band saw in each other. Themselves created music of engrossing complexity
column5: but had little aptitude for lucidity and directness. Meanwhile
column6: the Notwist excelled at piercingly simple songs
column7: but seemed to struggle with too many moving parts. Musically
column8: all the two groups had in common were glitches
column9: though Themselves' disturbances were strident while the Notwist's were silky and mild
column10: and maybe that was the point. In combining their strengths
column11: would they also compensate for each other's weaker areas?

column1: On 13 & God's 2005 debut
column2: the answer was yes and no. It included some terrific songs
column3: but most of them just sounded like the Notwist
column4: or the Notwist with someone muttering to himself very rapidly in the background. The record didn't feel quite digested
column5: and perhaps it just couldn't have-- the clean gauze of Markus Acher's voice and Adam ""Doseone"" Drucker's Micro Machines Man patter are virtually nuts and gum. That's still the case on the long-awaited second album
column6: Own Your Ghost
column7: where we're zipped back and forth between their contrasting sounds so hectically that it causes musical jet lag. It's still a neat project with many moments of interest
column8: but it's disappointing that the second album doesn't cohere overall any better than the first. More than anything
column9: it makes you wish for a new Notwist album.

column1: Because wow
column2: there are some good Notwist songs here. The album starts on a high note with ""Its Own Sun""
column3: one of those instantly gettable acoustic numbers that Acher does so well
column4: which floats along amid softly coursing glitches and coos. It crashes into the hyperactively skittering ""Death Major""
column5: whose fast-rap magic tricks seem to have scurried in from an entirely different album. And then
column6: suddenly
column7: we're listening to another lovely Notwist song
column8: ""Armored Scarves""
column9: where Acher sinks one of his trademarked cryptic-but-loaded refrains into a flatteringly warm and purring environment-- at least until Dose's helium-voiced sing-song takes over in the second half
column10: blasting drum fills in tow. The dividedness of the record is especially plain here. Acher generally gets calm and luscious music
column11: and then all hell breaks loose whenever Dose shows up.

column1: There isn't really much to say about the lyrics on this album-- for Acher
column2: they're about bearing melody
column3: and for Dose they're about dicing up space and time. Like the group's odd name
column4: which apparently is a mysterious apostolic reference
column5: the many words on this album feel like fervent (even messianic) messages being transmitted in a dense code that no one could hope to understand-- except for true detail-oriented obsessives
column6: for whose diligent attentions Doseone's music is ideal. This microscopic way of listening is precisely the opposite of the dreamy semi-presence the Notwist inspire
column7: and those two extremes clash here. At the musical level
column8: the collaborative lines are much blurrier
column9: and from the syrupy woodwinds and drippy ""Whisper Song"" bass of ""Janu Are"" to the warmly squealing naïve-pop of ""Oldage""
column10: there are plenty of signs that these guys can make beautiful and coherent music together. If only they could find a way to make their two strong
column11:
sharply different vocalists sound as integrated and natural.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16527/homepage_large.97edffd4.jpg|Roadkill Rising... The Bootleg Collection 1977-2009|3369.0|Iggy Pop|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Shout! Factory']|2011-05-17 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:29:01.130110|"

For any other artist
column2: the idea of issuing four discs of moldy live recordings-- particularly for a performer who's been anthologized a couple of times already-- would reek of the worst kind of barrel-scraping
column3: fan-fleecing cash grab. But to summarize a career as unlikely as Iggy Pop's
column4: it makes perfect sense. Despite the enduring import of his first three albums with the Stooges and mid-70s collaborations with David Bowie-- the influence of which can still be heard today in everyone from Fucked Up to LCD Soundsystem-- those albums tell only part of the story.

column1: The real reason why Iggy's been able to carve out a career for 40-plus years-- going from certain drug casualty to potential ""American Idol"" judge-- without the benefit of a platinum record is his magnetic charisma as a live performer. And long before YouTube allowed us to attend concerts vicariously
column2: bootlegs played a crucial role in establishing that legend. Even without being able to see his wiry body slither across the stage
column3: the seemingly bottomless supply of unauthorized Iggy concert recordings reified his incomparable talents for baiting a crowd
column4: ad libbing
column5: and rewriting ""Louie Louie"" with new lyrics more vulgar than the FBI could've ever imagined. At an Iggy show
column6: what happens between the songs is just as entertaining and edifying as the songs themselves.

column1: This quality was first widely brought to light with the most (in)famous of Iggy-related bootlegs
column2: Metallic K.O.
column3: a delirious document of the Raw Power-era Stooges' dying days (circa 1973-74) and Iggy at his self-destructive zenith
column4: encouraging all manner of abuse (verbal or otherwise) from a bloodthirsty crowd. In contrast
column5: Roadkill Rising is like the extended post-script to that moment
column6: picking up the story in 1977
column7: after Bowie had effectively brought Iggy back from the dead with the still-potent double-whammy of The Idiot and Lust For Life. The set devotes each of its four discs to performances from a specific decade
column8: but even if you don't think Iggy has produced a front-to-back great album since 1979's New Values
column9: Roadkill Rising is still worth your time.

column1: No matter what era
column2: each disc is padded with period performances of Stooges and Bowie-era material and amusing cover-song desecrations (ranging from ""Hang on Sloopy"" to the ""Batman"" theme)
column3: while 80s/90s selections like ""Blah Blah Blah"" and ""Home"" hit with greater force when stripped of their dated productions. But more significantly
column4: Roadkill Rising functions less as a simple overview of Iggy's post-Stooges career than an elaborate portrait of the first punk who had to grow up in public
column5: and the difficult transition from self-mutilating spectacle into respectable artist. Early on
column6: at a Detroit show from 1977
column7: we hear Iggy trying mischievously to muscle his way into the classic-rock canon with a cover of Them's ""Gloria""
column8: wherein he uses the famous refrain to spell out his own name. But later
column9: at a particularly unruly Detroit gig from 1980-- the excerpts of which alone are worth the compilation's price tag-- we hear him paying the price for his own petulance: It takes Iggy no less than three tries to get through a subdued
column10: smoky cover of the Sinatra standard ""One For My Baby (And One More For the Road)""
column11: as he's forced to talk down an increasingly impatient crowd who'd rather he do away with the showtunes shtick and get back to ""Cock in My Pocket"".

column1: As Roadkill Rising traverses the 80s up through the 2000s
column2: you can hear the audiences getting larger and more receptive to his whims
column3: while Iggy becomes less concerned with antagonizing his audience than looking out for them; he cuts a 2003 performance of ""Dirt"" short to berate a bouncer for denying an over-eager fan's attempt to dance with him onstage. Inevitably
column4: for a set that sprawls over four discs and 65 songs
column5: Roadkill Rising is weighed down by blocks of inessential tracks from 1993's American Caesar and 2001's Beat Em Up
column6: at the expense of including certified classics like ""I Got a Right""
column7: ""Success""
column8: ""I'm Bored""
column9: and ""Fun House"" (the last of which is actually featured on the tracklist
column10: but incorrectly so; it's really ""1970""). But even as it catalogs numerous changes in style
column11: backing bands
column12: and recording fidelity-- climaxing with selections from the Stooges' riotous 2007 reunion tour-- Roadkill Rising invariably succeeds in presenting an Iggy Pop gig as an exceedingly exciting place to be
column13: where the line separating exhilaration and unrest is routinely blurred. And in the context of all that precedes it
column14: the closing string of songs from Iggy's jazzy French-chanson experiment
column15: Préliminaires-- complete with cordial
column16:
""VH1 Storytellers""-style between-song banter-- feels less like the WTF left-turn it seemed upon release in 2009 and more like a well-deserved reprieve from spending the past four decades sating his audience's desire to see him open up and bleed.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16520/homepage_large.60002cb8.jpg|The Double Cross|3833.0|Sloan|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Yep Roc']|2011-05-17 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:29:01.686273|"

The title of Sloan's new album is an oblique reference to the band's age. The Double Cross = XX = 20
column2: for the 20 years they've been a band
column3: the same four guys making records and touring together
column4: with all the attendant peaks and valleys of notoriety that come with that. They've been one of the world's great power pop bands that whole time-- hell
column5: they've just been a great rock band-- and that's an oddly thankless achievement. They've never matched up with the flavor of the moment
column6: or seemed to try to either
column7: and it makes them easy to overlook
column8: because people are always talking more loudly about something else.

column1: But they've made a lot of music with staying power
column2: records stuffed with great songs that sound good any time. Go back and listen to Between the Bridges
column3: Never Hear the End of It
column4: or One Chord to Another. They haven't aged a day. And here
column5: 20 years in
column6: they've made one of their best albums to mark the occasion. It comes three years after their last album
column7: which matches the longest gap of their career
column8: and even with all that time between to work on new material
column9: it's still their shortest full-length
column10: topping out under 35 minutes (longer with the iTunes bonus tracks). That brevity and focus turns out to be an asset
column11: though-- there is no fat at all on the album
column12: and every song is lasered into the shape that gives it the biggest impact. Four last less than two minutes and five seconds
column13: and yet nothing feels slight or too short.

column1: Part of the reason for that is that the album is expertly assembled to work as a seamless whole
column2: much like Between the Bridges and Never Hear the End of It were. It's not a random collection of songs they happened to have around. ""Beverley Terrace"" reprises ""Shadow of Love""
column3: and there are other call-backs on the album
column4: not to mention the fact that songs are sequenced so that opening and closing tempos match up
column5: and even the key changes sound good as one song turns into another. The band has also worked hard to broaden its sound. This is the lushest Sloan album
column6: with several keyboard-driven tracks and a couple of heart-stopping ballads to give it a more varied landscape.

column1: Though it's clearly structured to flow as an album and function as an absorbing start-to-finish listen
column2: The Double Cross is still the kind of record that makes you want to talk about every song individually. Nearly any of them could work as a single. ""The Answer Was You"" is built around what sounds sort of like a Mellotron flute figure
column3: with a hint of disco lurking in its rhythm guitar part. ""Laying So Low"" is the slow closer; it opens like an after-hours drag but quickly blossoms into something stirring. On ""Your Daddy Will Do""
column4: Sloan
column5: possibly by accident
column6: manage to sort of diagnose the reason they're still making great rock records even though they've never been in fashion doing it: ""They kind of lost touch with what's in and who's who."" ""Unkind"" is the sort of stomping power pop tune that made them hitmakers on their Canadian home turf.

column1: As great as all these songs are individually
column2: they sound best together
column3: and hearing them in relation to one another reveals things about them that are harder to catch when they're separated. That may seem paradoxical
column4: but I don't think it is-- making this kind of record is a peculiar talent of this band. That they sound this creatively fresh this deep into their career is a real treat for people who've stuck with them through the years. If you've never given them a chance before
column5:
this is a great time to get to know them.
