So many bands have recently taken steps away from their lo-fi roots-- Ariel Pink
column4: Vivian Girls
column5: Times New Viking-- that tape-hiss diehards probably wonder if anyone will actually stick to their scuzzy guns. Those fearful might look to self-proclaimed ""shitgazers"" Psychedelic Horseshit as the last line of defense. If even these snotty shamblers are willing to wipe their noses and tuck in their shirts
column6: then maybe lo-fi is just this generation's musical training wheels.

column1: Sure enough
column2: if you drag your needle quickly across Laced
column3: you'll probably think this Ohio band (now a duo) has cleaned up its act. There's less guitar muck
column4: less maxed-out tape noise
column5: and fewer moments of impenetrable chaos. But that doesn't mean the music is any clearer. These 11 songs are just as weird and demented as those that came before
column6: maybe even more. The weirdness just comes from different sources now-- bouncy electronic beats
column7: playfully psychotic synths
column8: and Matt Horseshit's hypnotic voice
column9: which has melted from brash and bratty down to stoned and endearingly subdued
column10: even if it still sounds like it's pouring out of his nose.

column1: All of which makes this edition of Psychedelic Horseshit more immediately enjoyable
column2: whether or not you dug them before. To be fair
column3: it's not a drastic turn-- 2009's Shitgaze Anthems was also pretty upbeat and relatively clean. But Laced takes those qualities to a new level
column4: one filled with memorable melodies
column5: bright atmospheres
column6: and tons of sonic exploration. When things do get cacophonous
column7: as in the overlapping drum stomps of the Black Dice-meets-Excepter ""I Hate the Beach""
column8: it's more about epiphany than obscurity. That's also the case with Horseshit's vocals and lyrics which
column9: as he rightly noted
column10: ""are more dreamlike. There's not a lot of pointed 'fuck this' and 'fuck that.' I got sick of that stuff.""

column1: Not too sick
column2: though. The band's notorious Wavves-bashing still shows up on Laced
column3: albeit more subtly. It's hard not to see the title ""I Hate the Beach"" as a veiled jab at both Nathan Williams and beach-obsessed chillwave. Same goes for the anti-summer lyrics of ""Tropical Vision""
column4: which begins with the couplet
column5: ""I don't need no waves/ Don't need no palm trees swaying."" But Psychedelic Horseshit aren't just tearing things down
column6: they're building something unique out of the rubble. The best example is the title track
column7: whose wavy synth glitter
column8: computerized rattle
column9: and Royal Trux-ish sing-speak form a bafflingly catchy hook
column10: like a sculpture chiseled from scrap metal. It's a smart self-revision-- Horseshit and partner Ryan Jewell are hacking at themselves as much as their supposed rivals. As Horseshit put it
column11: ""Sometimes you gotta cut the tree down to make it bigger.""

column1: Laced is indeed bigger and bolder than previous albums
column2: which is somewhat ironic since it has a more intimate
column3: made-in-the-bedroom feel than the band's earlier basement forays. And its rangy invention points to a wider future for an act whose schtick could've gotten stuck in a static cul de sac. That's not because this album is cleaner or that lo-fi is larval skin to be shed. Psychedelic Horseshit might next get more lo-fi or more hi-fi
column4: darker or poppier
column5:
better or worse. What I like most about Laced is it makes me excited to find out.

column5: lo-fi guitar acts making waves. As Pitchfork's Joe Colly noted at the time
column6: there was a chance they'd ""face similar (and probably misguided) backlash-driven criticism"" that would eventually befall similar cool-cred-chasing bands. But Nodzzz
column7: quite oppositely
column8: couldn't have been any less cool-- childlike
column9: clear-eyed
column10: and at times off-puttingly cheery
column11: their geeky earnestness set them apart
column12: and no amount of tape crust could hide it.

column1: Suffice it to say
column2: if you liked Nodzzz

column4: a follow-up that often proves almost indistinguishable from its predecessor. Still adhering to the same I-don't-wanna-grow-up mentality and sprightly
column5: brief songs

column7: paraphrased pointedly on ""True to Life"": ""If you must make a picture
column8: it should be true to life."" After all

Opener ""Always Make Your Bed"" uses a simple chore to frame the idea of retreating home when the world beats you down. ""(Low) Energy"" seems to be about needing a cup of coffee. So yes
column10: Nodzzz keep it simple and short (14 tracks at 23 minutes)
column11: and don't seem too interested in switching things up

column1: What has changed is the address
column2: as Nodzzz are now a part of the Woodsist roster. After playing with Woods and Real Estate last year
column3: the link-up seemed inevitable. Besides
column4: if there's one band that Nodzzz share a true kinship with
column5: it's Woods. The production has also been cleaned up a little
column6: leaving room for some excellent little guitar tricks that feel properly spotlit
column7: not showoff-y (dudes don't do ""showoff-y""). Nodzzz songs are categorically repetitive to the point of homogeneity
column8: so these little moments-- the weird tunings on ""Time (What's It Going To Do?)""
column9: the riffed-out ""Troubled Times""-- all display welcome finesse.

column1: Which isn't to say their whole affable
column2: Muppet-like bop can't get on your nerves. But for every silly dud (""Ye Olde Indian Towne"")
column3: there's something like ""Heyday Past Heyday Due""
column4: a rare minor-key track about the realization that life's party might be winding down. Innings might not be your cup of tea
column5: but there's little denying its charm-- as Atlas and Presley suggest
column6: ""If it don't got soul or spirit
column7:
no one will come near it."" Which is clearly not something they need to worry about.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16548/homepage_large.6ea02474.jpg|Rome|1186.0|Danger Mouse|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Capitol']|2011-05-16 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:29:04.121711|"

The ""soundtrack without a movie"" album
column2: an attempt to recreate the evocative sweep of a film score away from the screen
column3: has a long and mostly ignoble history. The concept was flogged so hard in the 1990s
column4: usually by dance producers desperate to break out of the club scene
column5: that it was almost left for dead. It didn't help that most of these records were limp pastiches of old-school Hollywood orchestration that paled next to 99% of either actual film scores or real-deal pop albums.

column1: All that bad product doesn't make the movie-less soundtrack a bad idea
column2: of course. It's just that few of these projects have had the talent pool
column3: or the commitment
column4: to pull off a Rome. You can hear composer Daniele Luppi's love and respect for the brooding romanticism
column5: fragile delicacy
column6: and almost psychedelic spaceiness of classic Italian soundtracks in just about every note. In his partner Danger Mouse
column7: he's found not only a similarly smitten collaborator
column8: but a producer who's made a career out of accurately capturing the atmosphere of old records without (usually) coming off sterile. And they've got the moody vibe of those 60s soundtracks down on Rome
column9: as much due to the vintage recording touches as to the Italian movie industry O.G.'s the duo drafted in to lend their hard-earned feel for this music.

column1: But Rome isn't just about faithfully recreating a much-loved period in film history. It'd be a much more boring
column2: if beautifully produced
column3: record if it were. In addition to his work as a composer for film
column4: Luppi's lent his talents as arranger and player to various pop acts
column5: and Danger Mouse has spent much of his career using his crate-digger's ear to craft retro-minded albums that still work for a modern rock audience. Rome's real coup is that
column6: despite its concept hook
column7: you don't have to listen to it as if it were a potential film score. What the duo's made is a beguiling and true hybrid
column8: halfway between pop album and soundtrack-minus-the-movie. If you've got no familiarity with the music Rome pays homage to
column9: you can take comfort that much of it sounds
column10: coincidentally
column11: very similar to the gentle-but-dark 60s psych-pop Danger Mouse makes with Broken Bells
column12: sans a singer. And while it's true that the bulk of the album is instrumental
column13: more concerned with mood than hooks
column14: it's sequenced masterfully
column15: including a handful of well-placed (if purposefully subdued) songs.

column1: Luppi and Danger Mouse cannily snagged two talented but obviously very different voices in Jack White and Norah Jones. White's natural eeriness and Jones' diffident eroticism certainly fit a sound built around mystical melodrama and chilly Euro heartbreak
column2: but their voices are such complimentary opposites that they turn out to be what gives Rome much of its distinctness
column3: keep it from being just another record collector (or film collector) exercise in getting everything period-perfect. And true to the album's slippery not-quite-an-album/not-quite-a-score form
column4: their contributions can either work as the big showcase moments for pop fans
column5: or just as part of the soundtrack-like flow. And whether or not the album succeeds for you as a score to your own invisible flick
column6: inducing images of fog-swept villas and sigaretta-chomping villains in fedoras as the organs swell and the guitars pluck mournfully away
column7:
it's purely gorgeous.

The title of Africa Hitech's debut album
column2: 93 Million Miles

column5: which dips its toes in everything from grime and juke to ambient field recordings and jazz.  There's a danger when taking on a wealth of different
column6: very clearly defined sounds that the result could sound like casual genre-hopping

column1: It's no wonder: Africa Hitech are longtime electronic fixtures Mark Pritchard (Global Communications

column3: two guys with the experience between them to make these sound clashes seem more fresh and edgy than merely reverent and knowing. That could come across as academic or chin-scratching
column4: but thankfully above all there's an energy and vibrancy at the heart of 93 Million Miles that evokes the feeling of two guys having a lot of fun exchanging ideas in the studio.

column1: Some of the most viscerally enjoyable moments come when the duo uses Chicago juke music as its platform. ""Out in the Streets"" uses a well-worn sample from Ini Kamoze's ""World-A-Music""
column2: and bends it in and out of shape
column3: chopping up the vocal and matching it to propulsive beats and pitched bass. Both the repetitive treatment of the hypnotic vocal and the 160 BPM beats are right in step with juke
column4: but the sample choice and use of fifths lend it a dancehall feel.

column1: If the album title 93 Million Miles were to be taken as a sort of conceptual journey toward the sun
column2: then ""Spirit"" ushers in its final descent. The track is bathed in warmth
column3: as gentle vocals and harmonies guide the song above the subtle ebb and flow of the rhythm-- a staple of UK funky music. It's one of the clearest indications of how the duo's technical expertise ensured that its conceptual approach turned out to be a conversation between styles rather than something more ungainly and forced.

column1: The final stretch of the album is also its strongest
column2: taking in late-album highlights ""Light the Way"" and ""Cyclic Sun""-- a pair of spectral tracks indebted to exploratory jazz; each also projects the same inviting warmth felt on ""Spirit"". ""Light the Way"" uses forceful
column3: live-sounding drums and pitched bass to wrap around a Sun Ra sample while ""Cyclic Sun"" jumps off from its title with revolving samples that weave around each other similarly to the way they tended to on early Four Tet productions.

column1: Perhaps most impressive
column2: considering the ground Africa Hitech cover on 93 Million Miles
column3: is how together the record sounds. An album taking in so many far-flung sounds could be forgiven for sounding disjointed-- and although the leaps are sometimes wild
column4: it hangs together beautifully
column5: sounding like a fully realized work with tracks that build on one another rather than rub against each other. It's no small feat to craft something this adventurous and eclectic and still have it turn out to share the cohesion of a DJ mix
column6: but Africa Hitech manage just that-- and despite all the left turns
column7:
you want to stick by their side every step of the way.

"|15399.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15399-93-million-miles/|8.2|Hari Ashurst

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16551/homepage_large.a9145221.jpg|Destroyed|2795.0|Moby|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mute'
column2:
'Little Idiot']|2011-05-16 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:29:05.002236|"

What do people want from Moby? It's a question worth asking not just because of the lukewarm reputation he carries among many music fans but because Moby himself has spent so much time trying to answer it. The answer appears to be
column3: resoundingly
column4: ""not what you've been giving us
column5: and I'll wager that it's not the ""innovative microsite"" or photo book that arrive concurrent to his latest album
column6: Destroyed. Recorded as he toured
column7: late at night and lonely
column8: the record finds Moby sober and living in Los Angeles (nice digs). He still possesses that particularly 1990s strain of self-loathing that doubles as egoism (he's @thelittleidiot on Twitter)
column9: and he's probably two facial tics away from being a living
column10: breathing David Lynch character.

column1: One of the disappointing things about Moby is that his records and ideas are very simple even when he thinks they're very complex. Moby is 45
column2: wealthy
column3: and has deep thoughts about religion and food and friendship
column4: but his umpteenth album is ""a soundtrack for empty cities at 2 a.m."" (his words). Do you find dark urban environments stark and eerie? Does air travel make you lonely? Have you ever felt isolated even when you are physically surrounded by buildings and people? You're either dealing with these questions privately or you're Thom Yorke. This is fertile territory
column5: though: Artists have been mining flickering desolation for decades. Moby's key error is that while he was inspired by these scenes
column6: Destroyed is the type of low-stakes atmospheric mush that lounges and airports and bars play to make you forget where you are (on ""The Low Hum"" a female voice intones
column7: ""Like a tourist in some strange hotel
column8: moving on before she can get to ""...listening to Moby""). It plays like a facile representation of these beautiful/melancholy environs instead of an exploration of them.

column1: Moby still has only a few building blocks: sawing strings
column2: hissy breakbeats
column3: cantering pianos
column4: dusty samples. He sings too
column5: but thankfully not often. It's a good mix
column6: actually
column7: featuring shades of Derrick May's symphonic fantasies
column8: the Orb's beatific ambience
column9: and Air's relaxed dens. It's not exactly a fashionable style these days
column10: and with a small amount of hustle it could become interesting again. Moby's more focused on Destroyed than on recent efforts Last Night or Wait for Me
column11: which is just to say he's less likely to play punk or indie rock dress-up. But this is a dry and flat recording
column12: which is inexcusable given both Moby's resources and how much even a Further-level return to form would benefit everyone involved. The strings flatten into the drums like hair kept too long under a hat. Those samples-- their sentiments unchanged since the late 1990s-- dully brush against the percussion. It's hard to believe that the feeble clacking that underlines ""Rockets"" took more than 10 minutes to program. There is no scrape
column13: no tension
column14: no noisy bullshit
column15: and Destroyed is eminently un-replayable as a result.

column1: In a recent interview with The Quietus
column2: Moby speaks to ""The humility that comes from being hated."" Moby's had his punk-ass moments
column3: but at this point he isn't detestable; he's ignorable. It's a trade-off that would break any true rock'n'roll heart. Moby's made it clear he doesn't have that inside him: Fine
column4: but we're still waiting for the moment when the wisdom
column5: experience
column6: and comfort he has earned manifest itself on record. We have lots of great music about the big
column7: lonely
column8: urban world-- some of it's by Moby. What we don't have is lots of music about the perils and contradictions of being a conscientious
column9: horny
column10: middle-aged millionaire. And if Moby's still wondering what people want from him
column11:
he's encouraged to start there.

On her own and under her own name
column4: Katie Stelmanis used to record synthetic art-pop. This was tense and jarring music
column5: music that jumped around and demanded attention. Austra
column6: Stelmanis' new band
column7: makes just as much use of her stretched-out yip and her theatrical instincts
column8: but the music is a lot warmer and more comfortable. Austra play a warm
column9: hazy sort of electro-goth. It's synthetic and repetitive
column10: and there's plenty of Giorgio Moroder in its DNA
column11: but it's not dance music. Instead
column12: it's music for a planetarium
column13: or maybe for a mid-1980s PBS science documentary. Austra's synth riffs don't pound or undulate; they flutter and envelop. And Stelmanis doesn't sing over the top of their tracks; she emits sound from somewhere in the thick of it.

column1: Feel It Break
column2: Austra's debut album
column3: is essentially made up of 11 minor variations on a single sound-- no complaint
column4: since they're good at that one sound. It's tough to talk about Stelmanis' icy
column5: high-pitched deadpan delivery without mentioning Kate Bush. By that same token
column6: it's tough to talk about the band's music without mentioning Witching Hour-era Ladytron
column7: or maybe Bat for Lashes. This is pretty and heady music
column8: music that can subtly change the air in the room where it's playing. Drums lightly percolate rather than thud
column9: and synth riffs hide inside each other like Russian nesting dolls
column10: gradually revealing themselves over the course of entire songs. And the group builds these things patiently. Often
column11: it holds back on introducing vocals or drums for more than a full minute
column12: letting the songs' feel develop before making any radical changes.

column1: These songs aren't entirely alike. First single ""Beat and the Pulse"" has a telescoping sort of push-pull to it; it's the closest the band ever comes to genuine dance music
column2: and even it doesn't come that close. On ""Lose It""
column3: Stelmanis gets a chance to stretch her huge
column4: tremulous voice over some minimally invasive synth backing
column5: and she sounds titanic: ""Don't wanna loooooose ya."" The bouncy art-pop piano on ""Shoot the Water"" has a certain twitchiness
column6: bringing Stelmanis partway back to her solo days. And closing tracks ""The Noise"" and ""The Beast"" do away with percussion entirely
column7: letting Stelmanis sing over miasmic synth fog on the former and floridly ghostly piano on the latter.

column1: Even with those variations
column2: though
column3: Feel It Break still works as a monochromatic album
column4: one content to stick with the same shade of glimmering darkness. Onstage at SXSW a couple of months ago
column5: Austra cut a stark figure-- Stelmanis backed by two stunning
column6: harmonizing twins
column7: the rest of the band half-hidden at the back of the stage. Even playing in the middle of an absurdly sunny day
column8: the band seemed to exist in some vague state of perpetual glamorous nighttime; that could've been them
column9: not Bauhaus
column10: serenading David Bowie and Catherine Deneuve during the great opening scene of Tony Scott's otherwise bullshit vampire movie
column11: The Hunger. On Feel It Break
column12: they've got that creeping cinematic synth-psych style down cold. Moving forward
column13:
I'm curious to hear what else they can do.

In addition to turning in three very solid albums of his own in the past few years
column3: Chad VanGaalen also produced fellow Albertans Women. The two albums he made with that band in his basement were distinctly homespun and lo-fi sounding
column4: but packed with some of his characteristic idiosyncrasies-- from recording on boomboxes to unexpected appearances of synth to flourishes of odd percussion. There was a sense that Women were being let into VanGaalen's world rather than the other way around.

column1: So it makes sense that he returns to the sound of the two Women albums on his fourth LP
column2: Diaper Island. VanGaalen's previous records are characterized by their eclecticism
column3: veering from acoustic folk songs to electronic synth workouts
column4: and they often sound like grab-bags drawn from his apparently prolific recording habits (he recently told an interviewer he had recorded 80 songs leading up to this record). Part of what makes Diaper Island a success is its cohesive sound and restraint. There's an economy in his instrumentation and recording that allows a set of well-written songs to take center stage.

column1: On Diaper Island VanGaalen internalizes feelings of restlessness into the fabric of his songs
column2: giving them more depth than before. The de-tuned guitars of ""Peace on the Rise"" hew close to the sound of 1990s indie-- bands like Sonic Youth and Pavement loom large here-- spinning a downtrodden riff that's also quite an earworm. But the song's melancholy tinge takes an unexpected nosedive halfway through the song in a beautiful
column3: droning mid-section that opens out with horns and rough textures. It's a characteristic left-turn
column4: the kind of unexpected shift that VanGaalen used to perform with production switches on previous records.

column1: But there's a lot of surface-level enjoyment too
column2: as VanGaalen's excellent riffs compete for the spotlight. The best of these comes on ""Burning Photographs""
column3: as glassy guitar propels zig-zagging verses in front of a loose
column4: ticking drum beat. There's a satisfying energy at the heart of many of these songs
column5: and VanGaalen allows them to sound slack and jammy as he launches into taut solos on ""Replace Me"" and ""Blonde Hash"".

column1: The record manages to be compelling even during some of its weaker moments
column2: such as spiky second-half cuts ""Freedom For a Policeman"" and ""Can You Believe It!?"". Both have an almost mean edge to them. VanGaalen sounds prickly on the latter song as he sings
column3: ""That fucking mind scanner/ That made me piss myself/ Now that I'm calming down/ I'm really thankful they erased it."" It's not the most instantly enjoyable track on the record
column4: but it shows a different side of VanGaalen's character and makes his songwriting feel more engaging on the whole.

column1: VanGaalen closes the record with the line
column2: ""Baby
column3: will you love me/ I'm really feeling ugly
column4: on a song called ""Shave My Pussy""
column5: and Diaper Island-- as hinted at with that title-- isn't the prettiest record he's ever made. Instead
column6: it's gritty and honest. Beneath the surface-layer thrill of some of these songs are subtle character shifts and brave one-liners
column7:
all of which confirm VanGaalen's status as gripping songwriter as well as a producer.

""It's about saying
column2: are you going to come in and listen or not? Because if you're not
column3: we're not going to accommodate you
column4: to let you be part of and involved in this intimacy."" That's Wild Beasts' Hayden Thorpe speaking to The Quietus this week on both Smother
column5: his band's latest
column6: as well as the unmanageable position in which they've found themselves at home in England over the years. When the relatively isolated Kendal four-piece first arrived on the scene in 2007
column7: their brand of flamboyant
column8: almost vaudevillian indie rock was peerless in a landscape dominated by Arctic Monkeys and post-Libertines lad rockers. Thorpe's voice in particular-- a song-carrying instrument that moves between frilly falsetto and bulldog growl-- divided at most turns. You were either compelled to hang on every jagged syllable or run the other way.

column1: And then they decided to streamline some: For the curvy art-funk of 2009's Two Dancers
column2: they reigned in their more baroque tendencies. Thorpe brushed his voice soft
column3: the lower register croon of bassist Tom Fleming was worked in further to act as anchor
column4: and a band that seemed too difficult and bizarre to shoehorn into the pop conversation was sorta kinda flirting with exactly that. Well
column5: that's how it looked from the outside.

column1: Despite the many critical successes of that album
column2: Wild Beasts have remained an act with no intention of blending in. Smother
column3: their third full-length
column4: is just as the above quote promises: completely uncompromising. And that's why it succeeds. Thorpe and Co. have continued down the path of Two Dancers
column5: paring their sound down even further. What they're left with is naked in arrangement
column6: nocturnal in tone
column7: and deeply
column8: deeply sensual. And that
column9: actually
column10: seems to be the ""intimacy"" to which Thorpe intimated in conversation with The Quietus. From the first moments of ""Lion's Share""
column11: an opening
column12: piano-led crescendo: ""I wait until you're woozy
column13: I wait until you're lame/ I take you in my mouth like the lion takes its game.""  It's a line he delivers in a very controlled
column14: sympathetic manner
column15: one that would have stumbled out of his mouth four years ago.

column1: And while the dimpled electronic grooves of Smother do make for close listening
column2: Thorpe's overtly sexual couplets provide a slinky analog to the sonics at play. In ""Bed of Nails""
column3: a melodic marvel in its own right
column4: he uses a skittering bridge to proffer a few grunts
column5: howls
column6: and moans. But again
column7: what makes this all work so well is the remarkable amount of restraint and rhythmic know-how these four employ. This band has come long way in that regard-- it's not easy to integrate the sounds of sex into song without coming off like the kind of guy with a favorite tree from which to creep.

column1: Additionally
column2: all of these songs undress very beautifully on their own terms as well. The ribbons of guitar that bind ""Loop the Loop"" together at its halfway point are stunning
column3: praises that can also be sung for the acupunctural textures of closing beauty ""End Come to Soon"". Wild Beasts have never been an especially easy outfit to connect to either forebears or contemporaries
column4: but here they've found certain amount of kinship in the dusky
column5: liberated grooves of Talk Talk's Mark Hollis. You can hear it in the somber tick-tocking of ""Invisible""
column6: just as much as the orbit of single ""Albatross"". But that's about as strong a link as you're likely to find
column7: a feat in its own right. This is gloriously layered music that opts to celebrate its quirks and cowlicks rather than suppress them. Organically. There's a great amount of comfort that comes in hearing something like that. Thorpe delivers a unforgettable line in the circular prowl of ""Plaything""
column8: a new age sex jam if there ever was one. ""New squeeze
column9: take off your chemise
column10: and I'll do as I please
column11: he quivers. ""I'm not any kind of heartthrob
column12:
but at the same time I'm not any kind of slob."" He makes a good point.

Hunter Hunt-Hendrix
column2: the creative force behind the Brooklyn-based black-metal band Liturgy
column3: has gone to extravagant lengths to ensure that the hardcore metal community utterly loathes him. The band performs black-metal festivals in jeans and street clothes
column4: instead of the normal corpse paint
column5: to heckling and jeers. In interviews
column6: he talks about metal's ability to induce ""disorientation from ordinary
column7: end-directed existence"" like some black-metal David Foster Wallace. He uses the music
column8: which has virulent opposition to Christianity encoded in its DNA
column9: as a vehicle to explore Big Ideas about
column10: among other things
column11: Christian redemption. Aesthethica
column12: their second album
column13: comes out on Thrill Jockey
column14: home to the Sea and Cake
column15: High Places
column16: Fiery Furnaces
column17: and absolutely zero other metal bands. Oh
column18: and if you ask
column19: he's also happy to share stories about hanging out with Ezra Koenig when they both went to Columbia University.

column1: He and Koenig would probably still get along-- they both seem to take a perverse joy insouciantly baiting the easily riled. The hatred Liturgy have incurred is white-hot and laser-focused
column2: as the Google search for ""Liturgy black metal hipster assholes"" eloquently attests. As it is with any genre
column3: black metal ""authenticity"" is basically a smell test: It's black metal if it feels like black metal. It's an unassailable
column4: indefinable
column5: and profoundly inarguable criterion
column6: but there it is. And it must be said that
column7: in the end
column8: Liturgy just don't feel like black metal. Somehow
column9: you can hear the jeans.

column1: Luckily
column2: this doesn't matter in the slightest. In fact
column3: it's Aesthethica's primary sense of strength. Without ""reinventing"" black metal
column4: Liturgy have successfully refashioned its basic components-- the thundering
column5: all-sixteenths assault of blast beats
column6: shredding tremolo guitars
column7: and boiled-pitch vocals-- in their own willful image and directed its energy toward the

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
ir own idiosyncratic ends. Hunt-Hendrix might be the kind of guy who says things like
column2: ""The meaning of black metal has something to do with a longing for ecstatic annihilation
column3: a perfect void
column4: in interviews
column5: but he's also the kind of musician who pursues these thoughts just as enthusiastically in his music. Aesthethica is inventive
column6: alive
column7: and shrieking with more ideas than many bands explore over an entire career.

column1: The idea of ""a perfect void"" can be heard in Liturgy's complicated relationship with momentum. Many songs here settle into a mesmerizing stasis as often as they barrel forward. Songs that seem to be gearing up for a stratospheric takeoff instead harden into a rhythmic lockstep. ""Generation""
column2: for instance
column3: grinds out a series of syncopations on a single thudding power chord for a mind-obliterating seven minutes. It resembles Steve Reich's 2 x 5
column4: in which two rock ensembles face off onstage and play highly mannered figures at each other
column5: more than the work of any metal band.

column1: The echo of Reich isn't incidental; even more than their debut Renihilation
column2: Aesthethica feels like black metal by way of the conservatory. Hunt-Hendrix
column3: it turns out
column4: studied composition at Columbia with spectralist composer Tristan Murail
column5: and guitarist Bernard Gann is the son of the post-minimalist composer and former Village Voice critic Kyle Gann. You can hear the sound of A-students getting loose in some of Aesthethica's wilder moments: the glimmering fugue of guitars buzzing like mechanized locusts on ""Sun of Light""
column6: for example
column7: or the perpetual-motion keyboard canon that opens ""Helix Skull"". Hunt-Hendrix's words
column8: which are utterly indistinguishable sans lyrics sheet
column9: point determinedly toward the same transcendence the music seems to be aiming for: ""Floating upwards/ Lungs filling up with air/ As God inhales me/ Into the impossible
column10: Hunt-Hendrix screams on ""True Will"".

column1: None of this will endear Liturgy to black-metal fanatics
column2: of course. But every insular scene needs its carpetbaggers and interlopers
column3: and Liturgy can hardly be accused of disrespect; you just don't make something this joyful out of music you hate. Without interested outsiders peeking their nosy way in
column4: we would have never seen David Bowie
column5: or Elvis Costello
column6: or the Beastie Boys
column7: or Bad Brains. Liturgy
column8: for their part
column9: seem more than willing to take their lumps for what they believe in. As Hunt-Hendrix recently told Time Out New York
column10: ""We are really willing to suffer being hated for doing what feels right aesthetically."" If that isn't fucking kvlt
column11:
nothing is.

Des Ark started as a queercore duo 10 years ago
column3: releasing their first LP
column4: Loose Lips Sink Ships
column5: in 2005. Since its inception
column6: the band has remained in a state of flux
column7: with members coming and going almost on a show-by-show basis. The mainstay has been Aimée Collet Argote
column8: a guitar player and songwriter currently based in Philadelphia. She spent nearly four years recording her second full-length
column9: and one would imagine that would give her plenty of time to think up a better album title than <i>Don't Rock the Boat
column10: Sink the Fucker.

column1: There is a curious incongruity between the presentation of the music and the music itself on Fucker. Scribbled across a radiant photo of Argote
column2: that title suggests a bumper sticker more than an album
column3: and ""My Saddle Is Waiting (C'Mon Jump on It)"" and ""Bonne Chance
column4: Asshole"" don't sound like songs called ""My Saddle Is Waiting (C'Mon Jump on It)"" and ""Bonne Chance
column5: Asshole"". Anyone expecting agitprop mallpunk or ironic cowpunk covers may be surprised by the shimmery pop sound of Fucker
column6: which creates a dynamic
column7: often dense sound out of a minimum of instruments.

column1: This is an album of compelling contradictions and frictions. Argote is an especially forthcoming songwriter
column2: penning incisive and cutting lyrics about female relationships that range from self-destructive (""I was fucking every girl who looked my way"") to accusatory (""when you find a lover that you want to keep
column3: I think you'll talk to her first
column4: before you tell her you don't love her""). She bares her soul on the lyrics sheet
column5: yet sings and mixes her vocals as if to obscure her words
column6: often bending her syllables or burying them in the mix. Rather than alienating
column7: however
column8: the tactic proves engaging
column9: as she makes the listener lean into the music and work to decipher it.

column1: Most of the time it's well worth the effort
column2: as Argote and her collaborators-- including guitar player Noah Howard and drummer Ashley Arnwine-- capture a loud sort of quiet
column3: emphasizing the softer passages to give the abrasive moments more weight. It's most effective on ""My Saddle Is Waiting (C'Mon Jump on It)""
column4: which begins with a gentle acoustic theme that repeats throughout the song. By the end
column5: it has changed completely simply by juxtaposition to other melodies and motifs
column6: and all the elements come together for an unexpectedly poignant finale. ""Howard's Hour of Shower"" is so spare that you can hear the speaker buzz behind her chiming guitars and vocals. On the other hand
column7: ""It's Only a Bargain If You Want It"" churns stridently as the instruments grind against each other and Argote sings
column8: ""You will always be my girl."" It's both reassuring and menacing-- a promise and a threat.

column1: Listening to Fucker
column2: it's difficult to discern Argote's intentions regarding that disconnect between the packaging and the music-- or if she even intended such a disconnect. The effect
column3: however
column4: is often intriguing
column5: suggesting a sleight of hand that slyly upends listener expectations about the sound and politics of gender
column6: sexuality
column7: lust
column8: love
column9: and indie rock. To her credit
column10: she never comes across as strictly political or academic
column11:
although surely she doesn't really buy into that title. Sinking the fucker is much too blunt; Des Ark rock with more nuance than that.

Omar Rodriguez-Lopez makes most of his peers look like slackers. In addition to five albums with the Mars Volta
column4: each a hyper-detailed slab of acid rock in their own right
column5: the guy's released more than 20 solo albums and collaborations over the past seven years
column6: ranging from meandering journeys through electronic ambience to noodling saxophone-driven fusion jams to frantic riff-heavy hard rock. On Telesterion you get a very large dose of all three modes. And yet
column7: even as wide-ranging summary of Rodriguez-Lopez's last decade of activity
column8: this compilation only offers a hint of the scope of his project.

column1: This is not necessarily a bad thing. Rodriguez-Lopez's creative outpouring has often felt from the outside like productivity-for-its-own sake rather than someone building a well-curated body of work. Like the Mars Volta's endless-seeming multi-part epics
column2: going overboard is sort of the whole point with Rodriguez-Lopez's solo career

So a compilation like Telesterion should be a much-needed chance to both edit out weaker stuff and allow curious Volta fans an easier in. Right?

Timber Timbre frontman Taylor Kirk's got style

column3: and his dark-hewed retro-rock tunes are spare and slinky; should David Lynch ever helm a ""Mad Men""
column4: Kirk and company could easily provide the score. Timber Timbre's latest
column5: Creep On Creepin' On
column6: is a dapper set of darkly atmospheric doo-wop and blues but possessed with a style all its own.

column1: Creep On's stark
column2: shadowy swing is nearly as distinctive as Kirk's voice. <span>With its emphasis on empty space and a fondness for acoustic instruments
column3: there's a twisted proto-rock'n'roll feel to it
column4: like the Everly Brothers if Susie'd never woken up. There's also a Grizzly Bear-like balance of spaciousness and swiveling parts
column5: although Creep On's tone is far bleaker than that of Veckatimest. These songs shuffle and sway before strings and saxophones (the latter from sideman-of-the-moment Colin Stetson) inevitably start to swarm
column6: sending bold streaks of color through the black-and-white filter of Kirk's midnight creep.

column1: Strange and startling
column2: these bursts of cacophony provide an unlikely counterpoint to Timber Timbre's stripped-back tunes. Though they're meant to heighten the desperation at the heart of these songs
column3: the two sides clash about as often as they complement each other
column4: the towering
column5: clamorous arrangements occasionally overpowering Kirk's melodies. But when it all comes together
column6: it's stunning; highpoint ""Woman"" starts out honking
column7: downshifts into an insistent croon
column8: and then ramps back up again to close
column9:
moving fluidly through its wildly disparate sounds. But a yearning ballad like ""Lonesome Hunter"" would've fared just fine without the 30 seconds of orchestral insanity that closes it out; same goes for the din that ends ""Do I Have Power"" or the out-from-nowhere instrumental midsection of opener ""Bad Ritual.""

At their loudest
column10: these dissonant blasts all but crowd Kirk out of his own record; a shame
column11: since his skewed takes on romantic obsession are a worthy focal point. Though Timber Timbre should be praised for attempting to bring these disparate sounds together
column12: they'd fare better with fewer instrumental freakouts
column13: clearing more room for Kirk's twisted tales of romance gone awry. Stylish as Kirk's songs can be
column14:
they aren't always well suited by Creep On's contrasting patterns.

Brooklyn's indie scene can feel like a series of bands each trying to be hipper than the next
column4: but thankfully nobody told Pete Silberman. In the dog days of 2009's deadbeat summer
column5: the Antlers frontman emerged from his bedroom with his third LP
column6: Hospice. On it
column7: he unfashionably embraced hackles-raising choruses and concept-album ambition
column8: and he pushed the button on emotional nuclear options: abortion
column9: cancer
column10: death
column11: all that fun stuff. Now a trio

column14: it's still tethered to a magnanimity and expressive clarity that makes it almost every bit as devastating.

column1: Lead single ""Parentheses"" didn't do much to show their hand; it's pretty misleading out of context. Sounding like a higher-BPM ""Climbing Up the Walls""
column2: the knockabout electronic percussion and tweaked piano ripples rightfully marked some connection to the post-<i>OK Computer
column3: pre-Kid A application of Mo' Wax and Warp textures to alt-rock song structures. But the aggression in Silberman's falsetto and the gnarly guitar distortion are revealed as total outliers
column4: and Burst Apart can actually be seen as Hospice turned inside out: Where before
column5: long swathes of calm white noise linked emotive outcries
column6: Burst Apart moves patiently through luxurious downtempo tones belying some serious romantic disturbance.

column1: Those well-versed in dream journal interpretation could gather that from the mere title of ""Every Night My Teeth Are Falling Out"" (a common symbolic manifestation of sexual frustration). After all
column2: Burst Apart does open with ""I Don't Want Love""
column3: a heartbreaking wallow in a numbing hangover from a singer who previously seemed doomed to feel too much. Its glistening melody at least helps it scan as pop
column4: but ""Parentheses"" and ""Every Night"" feel cut from the same cloth as the Walkmen's ""The Rat""
column5: holding onto sanity with white knuckles
column6: sexual congress seen as mutually assured destruction.

column1: Aside from those
column2: Burst Apart's atmosphere is nocturnal and desolate. Foreboding death-crawl ""No Widows"" fears for vehicular disaster; brief flickers of light are allowed full exposure on the gorgeous
column3: incantatory centerpiece ""Rolled Together""
column4: whose brushed drum work and silvery guitars could be heard as a studiously completed homework assignment on Agaetis Byrjun. Meanwhile
column5: the tender
column6: nearly beatless balladry of ""Hounds"" and ""Corsicana"" are wholly the Antlers' own and painfully pretty to behold-- however depressive Silberman's lyrics
column7: one can simply revel in the zero-gravity synth and vocal moans and feel some sort of uplift.

column1: Shame that it makes Burst Apart's missteps all too egregious. This isn't the sort of record that calls for a show-stopping power ballad
column2: but we get one anyway with ""Putting the Dog to Sleep""
column3: where needlessly histrionic vocals and an overwrought doo-wop progression come off more like last call karaoke than a fitting closer. If nothing else
column4: ""Putting the Dog to Sleep"" helps point toward the Antlers successfully making Burst Apart more about their growth as a band than a gripping backstory-- for all of Hospice's raw power
column5: it didn't leave much to the imagination
column6: and it either hit you right in the gut or not at all. The Antlers won't hold your hand through Burst Apart
column7: which will inevitably make it more of a grower
column8: but stick around-- it's all the more affecting for how it allows you to pick your own stumbling
column9:
lonely path.

column3: the Sea and Cake made a crucial decision around the end of the decade to get smoother. Not that their early records were ragged things. Not at all. Released when the first generation of lo-fi acts still defined (more or less) the very sound of indie
column4: 1994's self-titled debut and 1995's Nassau and The Biz were mostly gentle and very lush. The Sea and Cake made sweet and accessible music-- singer Sam Prekop's just-out-of-bed voice is one of the most immediately ingratiating in indie rock-- that was pristinely captured and expertly played.

column1: These were also guitar records
column2: though
column3: and the hint of raw electric amplification that remained was a faint reminder that these guys had their roots not in jazz clubs or world music festivals but in the 80s post-punk underground. By 1997's The Fawn
column4: any lingering fuzz and rock rambunctiousness had gone. Like the post-rock bands they always found themselves bracketed with
column5: the Sea and Cake drew from a broad range of sources beyond trad guitar rock
column6: but they also wrote hummable
column7: heartsick songs rather than instrumental jams or sound-art collages. Yet as they adopted late post-rock's loungey smoothness and melodic/rhythmic repetition
column8: their records threatened to become the same sort of avant-pop background music.

column1: The Sea and Cake have never seen that trajectory as a problem
column2: and indeed they've continued to release intermittently brilliant records in this vein. In his review of 2008's Car Alarm
column3: Pitchfork's Mark Richardson rightly claimed this same-ness as one of the band's virtues; if they never wildly experiment they also never stray from their strengths long enough to potentially fall on their faces. When you buy a Sea and Cake record
column4: you can be assured a certain amount of comforting familiarity (down much to Prekop's breathy delivery stamping every record with the band's trademark) and quality control (having a top-shelf producer for a drummer helps when making music where every element sounding crisp and placed just-right in the mix is key). But one of the nicest things about The Moonlight Butterfly is that it's the first record in a long time where the Sea and Cake seem to be stretching out and trying new things. They're also getting back to the warm sound of guys in a practice space rather than an antiseptic sound-lab.

column1: Make no mistake
column2: it's obviously a Sea and Cake album from the moment Prekop's just-louder-than-a-whisper voice comes on. They still make the kind of rare rock that's both inventive and so laid-back you feel like you should be supine while listening. Their music is most perfect first thing in the morning or late at night
column3: when you're too sleepy for something louder
column4: uglier
column5: or more complexly obtrusive. Opener ""Covers"" might be the platonic Sea and Cake tune
column6: split evenly between the lovely live-band jitters of their first three records and the slick programmed-sounding swoon of the stuff that came later. It's all there: Prekop's drowsy melodies delivered in that inimitable longing sigh
column7: the precise and sparkling interplay between the jangling rhythm guitar and heart-tugging little bits of melodic filigree
column8: and a lite motorik pulse that gives the whole song a frictionless
column9: soaring quality. ""Up on the North Shore"" is a dead-ringer for something off one of those first three rock-centric albums
column10: like the Feelies drained of all anxiety until just a joyful bounce remains
column11: with breaks for the closest this band ever gets to guitar heroics. (Not very close
column12: in case you were wondering.) ""Monday"" hearkens back to the jazz-pop and samba percussion that drove Prekop's classic 1999 solo debut
column13: and breathes in a way that much of the band's layered and synth-heavy post-Fawn work doesn't.

column1: But departures are more interesting and more striking than the chances for fans to reminisce about the old days. That doesn't always mean they're better
column2: of course. It's curiously fun to hear the band take a left-turn into instrumental Moroder-esque electro-pop on the title track
column3: but it's still feels like more of a one-off experiment than a new direction
column4: or even of a piece with the rest of Moonlight's more human touch. If they'd actually turned it into a song
column5: or developed this sound across the whole album
column6: it might be a different story. ""Inn Keeping""
column7: the album's 10-minute centerpiece
column8: is a much more assured swerve into new territory. It takes the Neu!-like rhythms all over different parts of Butterfly and stretches them into a true Neu! epic
column9: complete with an uneasiness that's surprising for this most buoyant of bands but sacrifices none of the prettiness.

column1: But at just six songs
column2: even with one really long tune
column3: there's a certain slightness to Butterfly. You may drift through recent Sea and Cake records more than you engage with them
column4: but you still tend to want to drift for longer than a half-hour. Nevertheless it suggests the band is still master of the niche it's carved
column5: and not out of new ideas just yet. Almost two decades into its career
column6:
those are nice surprises for those who've been following along the whole way.

The name ""Here We Go Magic"" implies two different approaches to music making: 1) Enter into the process with little more than raw talent and a belief in serendipity; and 2) Hit record
column2: shrug
column3: and lazily throw stuff at the wall. Luke Temple's solo project has always split the difference frustratingly between the two. On his self-titled 2009 record
column4: Temple seemed the epitome of the pop-song-loving basement tinkerer
column5: recreating for his own private amusement various strains of psych-pop. It was
column6: as a result
column7: only fitfully involving. On last year's brighter
column8: splashier follow-up
column9: Pigeons
column10: he recruited a whole band to flesh out his visions
column11: but the project meandered through a maze of styles with the same seashell-collecting abstraction.

column1: As a result
column2: Here We Go Magic has been a hard project to commit to; for every moment of tingly brilliance-- say
column3: the fluttering
column4: slow-building epic ""Collector""
column5: from Pigeons
column6: or the mesmerizing tangle of loops and drone that was the self-titled's ""Only Pieces""-- there were an equal number of momentum-squashing detours and mediocre genre experiments. The January EP
column7: by contrast
column8: is Temple's most cohesive release under the Here We Go Magic name. He sticks with one iteration of his kaleidoscopic command of styles: the narcotized
column9: childlike 60s folk-pop of Syd Barrett or the Move. Every song here has a surreal shimmer and sounds slightly warped at the edges. There are no towering achievements on the level of ""Collector""
column10: but The January EP is Temple's most consistently immersive listen yet.

column1: The first track
column2: ""Tulip""
column3: is a good example of Temple's effortless command of sense
column4: style
column5: and sound. He croons in a narcotic falsetto over a queasily shifting backdrop of guitar pop
column6: one that evokes SoCal psychedelia at one moment and slinky
column7: strutting Hall & Oates funk at another. ""Hands in the Sky"" deploys gorgeously rippling waves of planetarium synths to flatten a puffing drum-machine and a burbling guitar
column8: while Temple sings in a keening Pete Townshend imitation. ""Hollywood"" suspends acoustic finger-picking that falls like individual raindrops miles above an ominous bass groan and a dry snare shimmer. Every sound instantly arrests the ear
column9: and Temple pins it back in place neatly once it's there with his indelible melodic sense. There are still a couple of puzzling decisions-- ""Backwards Time"" is such a pitch-perfect evocation of the Police that it's actually distracting-- but The January EP succeeds where the other Here We Go Magic releases have mostly failed; instead of handing you a couple of shiny baubles
column10:
it provides you with an inviting headspace to fall into.

column3: guitarist Mark McGuire stepped away from the busy production schedule of cosmic drone-rockers Emeralds to craft Living With Yourself
column4: a fine and overlooked album that drew on autobiographical source material. It may have been the first time most people had considered McGuire in a solo context
column5: but he'd actually been equally busy in that realm as well
column6: issuing tracks on an assortment of limited CD-Rs
column7: cassettes
column8: and compilations. A Young Person's Guide gathers highlights from these small-run releases
column9: offering a nice overview of what McGuire's solo work is all about.

column1: Tracks here generally fall into one of a few different types. There are the spacey meditations where single notes are plucked to create a hypnotic effect that nods to minimalism and kosmische explorations that bring to mind in particular the landmark Inventions for Electric Guitar by Ash Ra Tempel's Manuel Göttsching. On tracks like ""Radio Flyer""
column2: ""Explosion Alarm""
column3: and ""The Marfa Lights""
column4: McGuire uses bits of delay and overlapping patterns of cleanly picked tones to create music that feels weightless and airy and meditative.

column1: Other tracks use harder strumming and looping chords and veer closer to the world of rock proper
column2: and here the focal point is exploring the possibilities of a single chord progression. ""Dream Team"" has a steady pulse
column3: harmonized leads bathed in distortion
column4: and distant vocals
column5: and the way it builds and gradually shifts creates a mood of uplift and even triumph. ""The Path Lined With Colorful Stones"" takes an even simpler strummed pattern as its base
column6: which allows McGuire to spin out tendrils of melody on top that feel loose and ragged but without clear direction but that nonetheless manage to resonate. Here
column7: McGuire's music feels partway between the thick
column8: mantra-like approach of Roy Montgomery and the fluid melodicism of the Durutti Column's Vini Reilly. And then there are bright
column9: pastoral instrumentals like ""Icy Windows"" and ""Time Is Flying""
column10: which have a loose grounding in folk but take on a more mesmerizing quality through repetition.

column1: Tracks vary in length from interludes that last barely over a minute to the 17-minute ""Dream Team"". Many of the pieces fall into spaces between these loose categories
column2: but taken together
column3: over the course of two packed CDs
column4: they give a good idea of the range of McGuire's interests. It's not an especially wide range
column5: but it is executed very well. He knows where he wants to go and what it takes to get there.

column1: Is almost two and a half hours of guitar-based
column2: mostly instrumental music overkill? It's really not. The way McGuire's music functions
column3: I don't detect an upper limit for when it might grow tiresome. The longest tracks would also work fine even if they were longer; it's music that strives for endlessness in the best possible way. So this is the kind of record you can just put on at moderate volume when you are doing things and it fills a room nicely with warm
column4: inviting sound. And then
column5: when you're in the mood for more intense engagement
column6: you can add another quarter-turn to the volume knob and take in the full force of McGuire's arrangements. The music shows remarkable flexibility.

column1: Part of it is up to the fact that dynamic range is limited. There's little that is jarring or surprising. This is music that wants to wrap you in an affectionate embrace and serve as a companion
column2: to either some other activity or to a more focused journey into of the further reaches of consciousness. And where the dream-driven music scenes that McGuire sometimes finds himself lumped in with can feel like a bummed-out retro hangover
column3: this music is almost uniformly positive and optimistic
column4: seeming to celebrate the restorative possibilities of elemental chord changes
column5: repetition
column6: and carefully sculpted textures. It's music that wants to find its way into your life and do some good
column7:
and I can't think of any good reason to resist it.

column2: they're practically the spitting image

column3: genuinely fun rock'n'roll record powered more by the urgency of its forebears than any specific sonic similarities. It takes opener ""Sons of Stone"" a second or two to get going

column11: recreating not just an era's sound
column12:
but its spirit.

column2: Goblin is essentially a turn-of-the-millennium indie rap record-- abstract
column3: difficult for outsiders to locate a way in to
column4: and bled completely of anything that resembles pop. It features almost nothing that counts as a chorus
column5: making few gestures to the mainstream. It's a purist's record
column6: leaning on inventive production and Tyler's flow and meter. With hindsight
column7: then
column8: it makes sense that the rise of Odd Future started in the avant UK music mag The Wire
column9: which a decade ago was putting leftfield rap groups like cLOUDDEAD and Anti-Pop Consortium on its cover. In another world
column10: before the Internet was the music industry's central delivery system
column11: that might have been the limit of Goblin's reach-- it could have been a well-received indie hip-hop record to place alongside releases on Def Jux or Anticon. (Fittingly
column12: it comes via XL Records
column13: the imprint that last decade signed Dizzee Rascal
column14: another culturally omnivorous
column15: incredibly hyped teen rapper and producer who added a new wrinkle to independent hip-hop.)

column1: Of course
column2: Tyler isn't interested in the political questions that drove many of his indie-rap forbearers. Instead
column3: his primary mode of thought is negation. From the Stooges to Sex Pistols to NWA to Eminem
column4: telling the world to fuck itself can be a compelling
column5: even meaningful or necessary expression. Yet while each of those artists gave a multi-layered voice to specific disenfranchised groups
column6: Tyler sounds underdeveloped when he attempts to articulate for anyone other than himself. His takes on slash-and-burn
column7: knucklehead rap-- especially the ""kill people
column8: burn shit
column9: fuck school"" refrain of ""Radicals""-- is particularly cringe-worthy; stock phrases shouted with no larger purpose. Goblin is at its best when Tyler sounds isolated
column10: frightened
column11: and confused. It's the work of someone trying to figure out the world around him and his place within it
column12: someone who often doesn't like the conclusions he's drawing.

column1: To his core fans
column2: Tyler is accessible and approachable
column3: and not just on record. He's online constantly
column4: forging a unique bond with his listeners
column5: and is probably right now shouting down this and other Goblin reviews. He comes across as an everyday kid. He lives with his grandmother. He likes porn; he hates collard greens. This relatability and strong audience/artist bond
column6: and the diaristic nature of his rhymes
column7: make him as much emo as hip-hop. His place in the indie music landscape is oddly most reminiscent of Salem
column8: another gothic
column9: often-derided group beloved by a core of committed young listeners but shrugged off by those with a more developed perspective. In short
column10: he's made this record for alienated kids like himself. If you don't already like his music
column11: you probably won't like Goblin. And that's apparently the way he wants it.

column1: For everyone else
column2: the album remains an either/or prospect. For one
column3: the record could have used an editor-- it'd be stronger if it were 20 minutes shorter. Yet the highs are very high: ""Yonkers"" remains a potential frontrunner for song-of-the-year
column4: and tracks like ""Sandwitches""
column5: ""Analog""
column6: ""Tron Cat""
column7: and the Frank Ocean feature ""She"" work as standalones away from the album as a whole. Tyler's most inwardly focused songs-- the therapy-session set pieces ""Goblin""
column8: ""Nightmare""
column9: and ""Golden""-- are also fascinating portraits from an unmoored mind struggling to remain grounded.

column1: The record's feeling of drift and desperation also lends a very different tone to the controversial nature of Tyler's raps
column2: which even at their most sickening feel like the ramblings of a lonely outsider. His fantasies and lack of filter are still huge roadblocks for many if not most listeners. They're depraved and despicable
column3: tied in part to a long and unfortunate legacy of gangster and street rap. They're also one aspect of a larger
column4: character-driven story-- a license that we grant to visual arts
column5: film
column6: and literature but rarely to pop music. That's not to claim Tyler is making some broader commentary about the world
column7: or gender politics
column8: or adding multiple layers of complexity to his more violent thoughts; he's not. Instead
column9: his more reprehensible lines come across like a pathetic attempt for an underdeveloped
column10: disconnected mind to locate some emotionality
column11: control
column12: or simply attention.

column1: They certainly aren't jokes for his friends-- there's not a lot of humor on Goblin. The album really compartmentalizes the group's darkness and confusion
column2: which makes sense because Odd Future guys like Frank Ocean and Domo Genesis usually weren't expressing anger or violence anyway. You sort of get the feeling-- since they are officially a package deal now-- that the weed stuff or the laughing-with-your-friends stuff might come out in a group effort. And even here
column3: when other Odd Future members join Tyler
column4: they tend to let a little light into the album-- particularly the Hodgy Beats pairings ""Sandwitches"" and ""Analog"". The coziness and camaraderie between Tyler and his cohorts even meets with a nasty end on Goblin
column5: which concludes with a suite of tracks in which Tyler inexplicably kills his friends before suffering a total emotional breakdown.

column1: What is here is more promise than delivery
column2: yet it's still a game-changing record for indie hip-hop-- a singular and sonically complex album neither in hoc to 1986-88 ""real"" hip-hop nor created by rappers aiming to define themselves in opposition to the mainstream. (It takes about three minutes for Tyler to align himself with other artists here
column3: but he chooses Erykah Badu
column4: Pusha T
column5: and Waka Flocka Flame instead of Immortal Technique.) Alongside Lil B and Soulja Boy
column6: OFWGKTA are harnessing the Internet to communicate directly and often and pushing a new kind of indie hip-hop-- often rambling
column7: not always musical
column8: frequently surprising
column9: and absolutely beloved by some. It takes work to get through
column10:
and a lot of its success rests on cult of personality. Those two barriers are particularly why it's so successful: You have to commit to it in many ways. You have to want to be an insider. And that's a club that's quickly expanding.

"|15413.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15413-goblin/|8.0|Scott Plagenhoef

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16532/homepage_large.9e112ad8.jpg|Diotima|26785.0|Krallice|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore']|2011-05-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:29:13.630434|"

It must have been during the fifth or sixth listen when I finally realized that the appropriate reaction for Diotima-- the third album in four years from New York black metal supergroup Krallice-- was laughter. That's a surprising response to a record that lyrically keys on the transience of existence
column2: the failures of our best efforts
column3: and the high costs of man's lowly sexual instincts. But my chuckle was the delirious sort
column4: based on my own addled exhaustion. That's how Diotima works: Unapologetically extreme and intense
column5: it's the most relentless album from a hyper-dexterous band that's never been one to take it easy. Though it's not the longest Krallice album (that's Dimensional Bleedthrough
column6: slightly)
column7: Diotima forgoes the long-short-long tack of previous Krallice efforts
column8: creating marathons out of marathons that demand complete attention and destroy attention spans.

column1: During ""Intraum""
column2: from 2008's Dimensional Bleedthrough
column3: Krallice took a break from their four-piece hustle. Guitarists Mick Barr and Colin Marston ricocheted through quick
column4: countering riffs until the sound sublimated into a restless seven-minute drone. It's an off-ramp ahead of the album's appropriately titled 19-minute closer
column5: ""Monolith of Possession""
column6: a long-form roar whose pummeling is precise and seemingly perpetual. Halfway through
column7: you realize just how much that pause meant. Nearly 10 minutes into ""Telluric Rings""
column8: Diotima's penultimate track
column9: you can hear Krallice reaching for the same rest-stop trick. It stands to be a well-deserved rest
column10: too
column11: as ""Telluric Rings"" is the fourth and final consecutive track on Diotima to race past the 12-minute mark. What's more
column12: it's written as a lyrical sequel to the preceding ""Litany of Regrets""
column13: meaning that
column14: when Lev Weinstein's drums finally snap out here
column15: it ends a mostly seamless 22-minute cavalcade. But don't rest easy: Marston and Barr noodle and slink for about 80 seconds
column16: summoning a dark radiance with sheaths of distortion. Weinstein blasts back in
column17: and the track's last 90 seconds offer a raze as energetic and complete as any in the band's discography. So brutal and mean
column18: the track's closing blur is a perfectly executed nexus between grindcore and black metal
column19: as cathartic as it is crushing.

column1: Diotima's glory is often in its details. It has fewer stops
column2: starts
column3: and redirections than its predecessors. Rather
column4: the big shifts are now often misleadingly subtle and slight
column5: created more by the way the musicians move against and with each other than how the band moves as a unit. In theory
column6: it's not unlike studying a Steve Reich phase piece
column7: where patterns show themselves best when their relationships with one another change. Or
column8: as McMaster explained to Chad Bowar
column9: ""Essentially
column10: we wanted to have more unison parts
column11: to amplify the contrast between when we'd all play the same riff and when the guitars and bass would split off into independent lines.""

column1: Indeed
column2: this is the first album on which McMaster has written all of his bass parts
column3: and his unexpected risks make this thundering gauntlet worth hearing at high volume
column4: with high-end headphones. During ""Inhume""
column5: for instance
column6: the quartet is playing in strict unison when McMaster steps out of the pack
column7: adding low
column8: lumbering lines that sandbag the whole section. It’s a smart redirection
column9: a moment worth hearing again and again. It’s technical black metal that thankfully never puts its own technicality above the bold ideas in its songs.

column1: Diotima has broadly accessible glimpses: The central riff in ""The Clearing"" supplies all the majesty and power of a Sousa march-- memorable enough to hum
column2: triumphant enough for pumped fists. <a href=""http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/140330-krallice-diotima/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Writing for Pop Matters
column3: Adrien Begrand correctly called the title track ""genuinely catchy"" as it moves from ""a cruising sludge groove... [into] the frenzied blast beats we know so well from these guys."" But the album's emphasis on movement within the songs and within the parts makes it ultimately less dynamic and dramatic
column4: at least on initial listens; the obvious bloodlust of Dimensional Bleedthrough comes funneled into a full assault that might be mistaken for monotony
column5: especially compared to the latest by Brooklyn black metal brethren Liturgy. That's too bad
column6: though
column7: as Krallice's levels of composition and performance have never been higher-- so high
column8: in fact
column9:
it's laughable.

"|15419.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15419-diotima/|7.6|Grayson Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16534/homepage_large.77e71593.jpg|I'll Never Get Out of This World Alive|1283.0|Steve Earle|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['New West']|2011-05-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:29:14.194400|"

Empathy is Steve Earle's calling card. Many of the best songs Earle's written find him telling the story of some real or imagined person who has either endured an injustice or been widely demonized or misunderstood. A badass with a bleeding heart
column2: Earle has lent compassion to criminals (""Billy Austin""
column3: ""Tom Ames' Prayer""
column4: ""John Walker's Blues"") as well as given voice to the kinds of disenfranchised people who rarely have one (""Good Ol Boy (Gettin' Tough)""
column5: ""Taneytown""
column6: ""Home From Houston""). Almost all of these are protest songs to some degree
column7: yet by putting a face to an issue and getting you to sympathize with his subject's plight
column8: it never feels like Earle is preaching.

column1: The clear highlight of Earle's 14th studio album
column2: I'll Never Get Out of This World Alive
column3: is ""The Gulf of Mexico""
column4: and it fits this mold flawlessly. As you've probably guessed from the title
column5: the underlying issue is the Gulf oil spill
column6: but instead of soapboxing about corporate irresponsibility
column7: Earle illuminates the history of the region by sketching the lives of three generations of men who worked its waters. We meet the narrator's grandfather running a shrimp boat
column8: the father ferrying workers to and from the mighty oil rigs
column9: and then finally the storyteller himself
column10: working on the drilling floor and witness to the catastrophic explosion that ""spilled the guts of hell out on the gulf of Mexico."" As the three verses progress
column11: the water turns from blue to green to red.

column1: Earle seems to feed off this sense of righteous purpose-- on this album
column2: see also ""Little Emperor""
column3: a giddy skewering of American hubris. When his subject matter is more nebulous
column4: stylized
column5: or even personally intimate
column6: his songwriting tends to falter. ""Molly-O""
column7: ""Meet Me in the Alleyway""
column8: and ""The Wanderer"" lean too heavily on tropes of the outlaw
column9: the gritty urban denizen and the vagabond
column10: respectively
column11: while trading on the listener's recognition that Earle himself has been categorized in those roles. Conversely
column12: the gentle sentiments of ""God Is God"" and ""Every Part of Me"" are deeply felt but hardly profound. It doesn't help that Earle isn't a particularly strong melodist
column13: and rarely will surprise you musically-- here
column14: only ""Lonely Are the Free""
column15: delicately decorated with acoustic guitar fills
column16: truly measures up to his top-line lyricism. His most effortless mode is charging
column17: attitudinal roots-rock
column18: but only the opening ""Waitin' on the Sky"" really hits that strutting sweet spot.

column1: Earle's albums have been extremely uneven for some time now. Certainly that indicates he's put out a sizable amount of dross
column2: but it also means he's recorded a bunch of great songs that have gotten lost in the shuffle. It's particularly galling that no compilation of Earle's work released to date has included any post-1997 material. Perhaps the ideal representation of his artistry would be a collection of his best cause-minded story songs. It'd be like a musical version of Howard Zinn's A People's History of the United States
column3:
and ""The Gulf of Mexico"" would definitely be on there.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16510/homepage_large.2a4a14f2.jpg|Back and 4th|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hotflush']|2011-05-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:29:14.792308|"

After an initial burst of creativity
column2: dubstep has splintered into a number of camps. There's ""brostep
column3: of which nothing more need be said. Some artists took the ""dub"" mandate literally and constructed a world of midnight
column4: alienated electronic music
column5: best exemplified by the Hyperdub label. A third
column6: diffuse group borrowed the movement's rhythmic syncopations and set upon exploring the vast stylistic implications of bass in electronic music. Some of the finest music in the latter camp has found a home on Paul Rose's UK-based Hotflush Recordings; Back and 4th is Hotflush's second label compilation
column7: featuring a disc of unmixed hits of and another of new material from its still-small roster.

column1: The big names here will be recognizable to anyone paying a modicum of attention to UK electronic music: Mount Kimbie
column2: Joy Orbison (now Joy O)
column3: and Untold all feature
column4: as well as less prominent but still productive names like Scuba (Rose himself) and Pangaea. Hotflush's output has always felt warmer than their more claustrophobic peers
column5: and Back and 4th is inviting-- full of bobbing
column6: circular rhythms and august synths. On the whole
column7: it's more immediate than Hyperdub's excellent (and similarly constructed) 5; the mood is glum and contemplative
column8: but you won't need to uncrate your personal paranoia to best enjoy it.

column1: The hits disc cuts a limited swath through Hotflush's catalog
column2: but it's a boon both to those who haven't diligently collected tracks like Mount Kimbie's ""Maybes (James Blake Remix)"" and Joy Orbison's ""Hyph Mngo"" and anyone who hasn't been replaying them faithfully. A homespun mix of ashy
column3: melodic techno would hardly do better
column4: and the slightest bit of hindsight reveals

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
that these tracks have as much in common with late 1990s Warp and
column2: say
column3: Tricky as anything that could rightfully be called dubstep.

column1: The disc of new material is a mixed bag. Thematically similar
column2: the new tracks rely more heavily on corroded vocal samples and brisk tempos. Disappointingly
column3: there's nothing fresh from Mount Kimbie
column4: Untold
column5: or Joy O. Instead
column6: Hotflush showcases newer talent and signees
column7: rolling out tracks from dBridge (an artist involved in the awesomely named Autonomic movement that purports to be re-imagining drum and bass)
column8: FaltyDL (""Regret""'s widescreen arbors are a career highlight)
column9: and the promising George FitzGerald. Like Scuba's work
column10: the new material leans heavily on deep house conventions: sturdy
column11: insistent kick drums and lean
column12: melodic hooks. Incyde's ""Axis"" and Boxcutter's ""LOADtime"" play like dance music set through a brush of heavy burrs
column13: bristling and itching their way to release (a natural progression
column14: perhaps
column15: from Joy O's dense loops). The disc is a letdown only inasmuch as none of these tracks are likely to migrate to a ""hits"" disc on a theoretical future compilation.

column1: Not anchored by history
column2: the new disc meanders. Hyperdub's equivalent compilation was a synthesis
column3: something to rally around; Back and 4th promises something more-- a roster of expressionists redefining bass music-- but delivers less. Instead
column4: it reminds us just how formative and vital tracks like ""Maybes"" were
column5:
but it only hints from where Hotflush's next breakthrough will come.
