column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16528/homepage_large.e80e2119.jpg|Women's Studies|29495.0|Chrissy Murderbot|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Planet Mu']|2011-05-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:29:15.353359|"

Chrissy Murderbot is your friendly neighborhood Diplo: a pan-global dance synthesist who believes that backing an entire four-minute track with a looping police siren is a good idea. Unlike Diplo or even Girl Talk
column2: though
column3: Chrissy isn't interested in connecting his genre obsessions with modern North American hip-hop or  R&B
column4: meaning Women's Studies features no hint of pop crossover. It's the difference between believing something like dancehall deserves a wider audience and believing dancehall is just really fucking cool.

column1: Chrissy cut his teeth on rave
column2: and Women's Studies bears the marks of 1990s dance culture: airhorns abound
column3: as do the skittering 180-bpm rush of drum & bass and hi-NRG's gloriously tasteless synths. Genres are important to Murderbot (he's behind the outstanding yearofmixtapes.blogspot.com
column4: a site that featured a micro-genre DJ mix every week for a year); he's not interested in perfectly melding his influences into the Chrissy Murderbot Sound™. When he blows an airhorn
column5: he wants you to think of glowsticks
column6: or at least to think of an iPhone glowstick app (you're welcome). The video for lead single ""Bussin Down""
column7: which features Murderbot and DJ Spinn playing a dance-battle version of Street Fighter
column8: isn't exactly coy about Murderbot's 90s-culture fanaticism.

column1: The Chicago-based Murderbot has been an early
column2: vocal advocate for Footwork. He's curates an excellent monthly dance party (Loose Squares
column3: also the name of a label he's putting together) that regularly features Footwork and juke legends on the decks. Women's Studies borrows those hypnotic samples and Dance Mania's ruff vulgarity and is Murderbot's most focused work almost by default. Naturally he's not content simply mimicking
column4: so he sets Footwork against cheesy lounge-jazz (""Bussin' Down"")
column5: or late-90s Warp skittering (""Jiggle""). Not only is Murderbot not above deliciously boilerplate dance mantras
column6: they're basically his wheelhouse. Tracks ""The Vibe Is So Right"" and ""U Got Me Burnin Up (Club Cirque)"" fit him so well because he's so eager and utterly unashamed.

column1: The flip side to any discussion about how much energy Chrissy brings is how much energy it takes to listen to him. Women's Studies is relentlessly uptempo
column2: and Murderbot's idea of a pop hook is Warrior Queen's heavily accented
column3: aggressive cadence. The vocals and guests sometimes feel tacked-on
column4: perhaps in deference to original scenes and styles. (Even on a party record you know you're in trouble when Johnny Moog is dropping lines like
column5: ""What seperates me from y'all lames is I'm like Young Jeezy."" Oh. That's what.)

column1: It's easy to be cynical about this kind of musical colonialism
column2: but Murderbot is effectively a man without a genre/country
column3: and besides
column4: he approaches his source material with nothing but love. I finally feel like he's gotten a bit lucky
column5: with his most recent fascination (Footwork) coinciding with a rise in that fascination's profile. Women's Studies is a tiring listen by design
column6: and its 43-minute runtime is the only bone thrown at the listener. Murderbot could conceivably do more to smooth out his productions
column7:
but what he wants to do is duct-tape his record collection together and find pleasure at the resulting contraption. If you share his obsessions-- or are merely curious about them-- you're invited to smile and dance with him.

"|15415.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15415-womens-studies/|7.0|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16498/homepage_large.90a594e6.jpg|Past Life Martyred Saints|29348.0|EMA|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Souterrain Transmissions']|2011-05-10 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:29:15.512420|"

Erika M. Anderson has talked about finding ""true bliss and terror"" in the live performances of her former band
column2: Gowns. The pressure-cooker atmosphere she and her partner in that group (and in life) Ezra Buchla immersed themselves in had to crack at some point
column3: and it did
column4: fatally and finally
column5: at the beginning of 2010. Anderson's way of propping open an escape hatch from the bruised purging of Gowns was to retreat into herself
column6: by gathering her collective musical ideas and putting them out under her own initials. But it's immediately apparent on hearing Past Life Martyred Saints
column7: her debut full-length as EMA
column8: that she's still all tangled up in ""bliss and terror."" For the most part
column9: it's a white-knuckle ride. There's no pretense or pose here. No pulling back from the brink to foster an air of cool detachment. Anderson's music has the power to plummet to the depths and drag you right down there with her.

column1: There's a lack of timidity in the way this music is expressed. It's almost as though Anderson snoozed her way through the past decade and is picking up threads that have mostly lain dormant since the early-to-mid 1990s. The boldness in her language
column2: which thematically pings back and forth between emotional and physical duress
column3: has the same naked volatility as Kat Bjelland circa Spanking Machine or Courtney Love in her Pretty on the Inside phase. It's often terrifying
column4: distressing stuff. There's a feeling that you're watching someone in the midst of several life crises. It's a strange kind of testament to Past Life Martyred Saints that it often feels like a daunting proposition to listen to
column5: as if spending too much time with it will leave you as scarred as its creator.

column1: The lyrical fixations here frequently zoom in on Cronenberg-ian body horror
column2: with Anderson exploring the gnarly elasticity of the human frame when it's placed under threat. EMA songs often duck into little mantras; ""Butterfly Knife"" bears one of the most unnerving of those in its ""20 kisses with a butterfly knife"" line. ""Marked"" is similarly nauseating and obsessed with physical abuse. Over a noise that sounds like water chugging down rusty steel piping Anderson devolves into repeating: ""I wish that every time he touched me he left a mark."" It dwells in the same kind of unsettling territory as Goffin/King's ""He Hit Me (It Felt Like a Kiss)""
column3: and the bare-bones musical arrangement heightens the severity of the message just as Phil Spector's production did on the Crystals' song.

column1: That ability for her arrangements to acutely reflect her lyrical mood is one of Anderson's trump cards. She knows exactly when to add and subtract elements
column2: bringing ""Marked"" out of the doldrums at its close with a warm organ tone that she deploys whenever things get a little too heavy (see also: ""Milkman""). The opening ""The Grey Ship"" is one of her most ambitious conceits in that regard. It shifts in style several times
column3: from its earthy
column4: folk-y opening to a midsection where all the instrumentation vanishes suddenly as if the bottom just fell out of the world.

column1: It's a sign of her confidence and ambition that she can open the record with such a multi-faceted song
column2: full of odd diversions and unexpected twists that need multiple plays to really sink in. But the hit-rate here is high. ""California"" is among Anderson's best works
column3: a stream-of-consciousness rant about displacement and alienation set to a musical backing that feels like civilization collapsing around her. ""California"" shows off her enviable talent for finding a comfortable place where big-topic sloganeering and personal tales can coexist. It's that sweat-soaked head-rush of repulsion
column4: sadness
column5: anxiety
column6: and nostalgia you get when you feel the tug of home.

column1: Past Life Martyred Saints is a fiercely individual record
column2: made by a musician with a fearless and courageous approach to her art. Crucially
column3: the desire to let such raw emotion out in song never feels forced. It simply wouldn't work this well if there was a hint of artifice
column4: or a suggestion that Anderson hadn't regurgitated all these feelings of loss
column5: loathing
column6: and rejection from a pit of genuinely volatile emotion. There's a conviction to her delivery that leaves you in no doubt that this is something she needed to flush out of her system. Comparisons can certainly be drawn to artists such as Patti Smith or Cat Power
column7: and her dry
column8:
deadpan delivery occasionally orbits the same sphere as Kim Gordon's vocal work with Sonic Youth. But this is Anderson's own brittle unease. It hits as hard as a cold slap in the face-- and will leave its mark on you.

"|15386.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15386-past-life-martyred-saints/|8.5|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16529/homepage_large.2eaaaa1c.jpg|Rainforest EP|29547.0|Clams Casino|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Tri Angle']|2011-05-10 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:29:16.030081|"

The takeaway from Clams Casino's recent Instrumental Mixtape
column2: which featured his productions for rappers like Lil B and Soulja Boy
column3: was how well his beats stood on their own. You didn't need a ""based"" freestyle on top of a track like ""Motivation"" to appreciate all its great warmth and texture
column4: and in many cases the songs actually worked better without a rapper. Clams (real name Mike Volpe) even echoed this sentiment in a recent interview with us
column5: suggesting that he enjoyed doing vocal-less work more
column6: partly because of the logistical hurdles involved in linking up with MCs. ""The beats just sit around for months. It's frustrating... Now
column7: all I want to do is put out instrumental stuff
column8: he said.

column1: So it's no surprise that his latest release steps away from for-hire beatmaking to showcase original material
column2: five tracks that ""have always existed purely as instrumentals
column3: according to a press statement. Put out by the well-curated boutique imprint Tri Angle
column4: the Rainforest EP is centered loosely on a terrestrial theme (song titles ""Waterfalls"" and ""Treetop"" not-so-subtly reference nature) and carefully balances some very earthy
column5: textural sounds with more airy
column6: celestial ones. For example
column7: a track like opener ""Natural"" explores the tension between a tattered
column8: grainy arrangement and float-y
column9: angelic vocal samples-- you can feel it pulling you in both directions.

column1: These aren't groundbreaking techniques (this production style owes something to West Coast instrumental hip-hop as well as guys like Four Tet and Burial)

column7: ""Gorilla""

The Brooklyn duo Mountains like a big canvas. Their panoramic electro-acoustic music is made from slow layers of processed acoustic instruments and patient drones that slide against each other at independent paces and with the single-mindedness of natural processes. They usually avoid loops in favor of a continual unspooling
column2: so that the individual components of their tracks have no clear beginnings and endings
column3: just hitches and knots here and there. They portray a great deal of motion within superstructures that seem to stand utterly still. Negative space is diligently sought out and eradicated
column4: until we can hear the computer age gently swallowing folk music whole.

column1: Up through 2009's Choral
column2: Mountains used home computer software to transform their acoustic instrumentation
column3: which runs the gamut from spindly guitars and pianos to suffusing cellos
column4: accordions
column5: and melodicas. But for Air Museum
column6: they headed into a Brooklyn studio with an analog arsenal of pedals and modular synthesizers to record in real time. The result is a newfound energy and dynamism that comes at a price. At their best
column7: Mountains balance their systems so delicately that different layers float seamlessly to the top at different times. They pull that off here on songs like ""January 17""
column8: where a modem-like melody that recalls vintage electronic ambient rises and falls through a slow-motion landslide of long tones. But sometimes
column9: the new emphasis on hard-edged electronic pulses
column10: Growing-style
column11: upsets the equilibrium.

column1: I'm thinking specifically of ""Thousand Square"" and ""Sequel"". Both have mighty tectonic shifts to recommend them
column2: but their fat
column3: rubbery
column4: skipping electronics tend to run roughshod over the finer calibrations
column5: and the compositions lose something in subtlety and mystery. The walls don't just breathe; they hyperventilate. These songs really drive home the feeling that Choral
column6: where the electronics acted as enclosing suspensions for the instruments
column7: has been turned inside out
column8: and not to its benefit. On the other hand
column9: the stronger electronic presence works great on ""Blue Lanterns on East Oxford""
column10: where sharply angled but well-balanced motifs slice through each other with an almost dubstep wobble
column11: so no one part dominates the whole. And to be working on such a wide screen
column12: Mountains are great at maintaining tension-- their tracks never feel aimless or inert
column13: even at their most toweringly monumental
column14: like on Air Museum's ""Newsprint"". So if you liked Choral
column15: here it is with more of everything
column16:
for better and for worse.

It's been a long road to this point for Mick Harvey. He's been in bands since the mid-1970s

column4: arranger
column5: and multi-instrumentalist. He left the Bad Seeds in early 2009 for the usual reasons people leave bands at age 50-- more time with family
column6: simmering creative differences
column7: and a general desire for change and control. From the 90s onward
column8: Harvey has not lacked for work outside of Cave's sphere
column9: working with PJ Harvey
column10: producing other bands
column11: writing soundtracks
column12: and cutting solo albums
column13: but Sketches From the Book of the Dead is his first solo album recorded without the safety net of any members of the Bad Seeds.

column1: It's also his first solo album to feature only songs composed by Harvey himself-- until now

column1: The most fully fleshed-out of these characters is the title character of ""The Ballad of Jay Givens""

column5: his deep voice sometimes falling to a whisper. Aside from the up-tempo closer
column6: ""Famous Last Words""
column7: that's the feel that prevails across the album-- icy piano and organ infuse nearly every song with a hanging sense of dread and impending fate.

column1: The album's atmospheric consistency is generally a plus
column2: but it would work better if Harvey's songs had stronger melodies. The album's most memorable moments are mostly just that
column3: parts of songs that stand out for the way they briefly change things up
column4: such as the sudden
column5: haunting swell at the end of ""Frankie T. & Frankie C."". The best song on the album is the one that strings the most of these moments together: ""The Bells Never Rang"" has the strongest vocal melody on the album
column6: combined with a good arrangement that constantly shifts intensity to pull you through. It's a tantalizing glimpse of how great solo Harvey can be
column7: but unfortunately
column8:
a good deal of the rest of the album is simply unmemorable.

her than the self-conscious luster of hip-hop. Conceptually

column4: a tense
column5: jerky groove that's more intriguing when it threatens to explode than when it actually explodes.

I Am Very Far is ostensibly Okkervil River's first non-concept album in eight years. After Down the River of Golden Dreams in 2003

column1: For all its bluster

column5: even if they do revisit and expound on many of Sheff's pet themes. The thundering war stomp of ""The Valley""-- which opens the album like a pre-ritual incantation-- soundtracks a journey through ""the valley of the rock'n'roll dead
column6: which may be Sheff's idea of a summer festival. On ""Hanging From a Hit""

column9: she says of her husband. ""I limp from life.""

column2: and therefore a bit more oblique

column5: Sheff's songs never truly sound settled but remain lively and prickly
column6: especially as various images repeat throughout the album
column7: motifs instead of concepts that suture these songs together. There's a throat in every track
column8: either cut and open or bound to be cut: ""A slit throat makes a note like a raw winter wind
column9: he sings on ""The Valley""

column2: however

column4: creating a monolithic sound whose density resembles the thick block of prose-poem text in the chapbook. Perhaps emboldened by his work on Roky Erickson's last album

column8: but I Am Very Far benefits form the piecemeal approach
column9: which allows Sheff to give each song a distinctive personality and creates a strong dynamic in the sequencing. ""We Need a Myth"" shifts from subtle exotica to towering orchestral rock

column11: a trumpet solo recorded form out on the boardwalk
column12: and low
column13: lovely gospel harmonies

column1: Sheff favors a towering wall of sound on almost every song
column2: in most cases doubling the instruments in the line-up (two drummers
column3: two piano players

column5: I Am Very Far lags in the middle with the staircase-to-nowhere crescendo of ""White Shadow Waltz"" and the rambling ""We Need a Myth"". Sheff recovers with the gut-punch combination of the tense ""Show Yourself"" and ""Your Past Life as a Blast""

a quiet conclusion to a lyrically and musically feisty album.

Damon Krukowski and Naomi Yang are still most often celebrated as the rhythm section of Galaxie 500
column2: two decades after that beloved group's demise. Perhaps then it is important to note that False Beats and True Hearts is the fourth studio album the duo has recorded in collaboration with guitarist Michio Kurihara
column3: of the psych-folk Japanese powerhouse Ghost. This means that Damon & Naomi have now officially created more music with Kurihara than they ever did with Dean Wareham in Galaxie 500
column4: and over a considerably longer stretch of time. So it seems accurate to say that this
column5: then
column6: is their true music: hushed
column7: vibrant folk-rock punctuated by discreet electric guitar and quiet horns
column8: all of which bear only the most passing resemblance to vintage Galaxie 500.

column1: In the time since Damon & Naomi's previous studio album
column2: 2007's Within These Walls
column3: the duo has kept itself characteristically busy. They've toured the world
column4: released the video anthology 1001 Nights and the best-of compilation The Sub Pop Years
column5: and overseen a lavish reissue of the Galaxie 500 catalog on their own 20/20/20 imprint. Given all that activity
column6: it is somewhat surprising to hear how little has changed sonically on False Beats and True Hearts
column7: and the album can give the impression that Damon & Naomi have used the recording process as a way to exhale and re-center themselves creatively.

column1: It's interesting to observe the range of sounds that have now become a regular presence in the duo's work. There was a time when it would have seemed wholly out of character for a Damon & Naomi album to open with a trebly burst of psychedelic guitar
column2: or for one of their songs to feature a languid saxophone solo. But over the course of their past several albums
column3: these elements have become such a familiar component of their music that here at times the duo can sound a bit too comfortable. In addition to Kurihara
column4: the album features guest spots by Ghost's leader Masaki Batoh
column5: trumpet player Greg Kelley
column6: and multi-instrumentalist Bhob Rainey
column7: and there are points where Damon & Naomi's quiet vocals and thoughtful lyrics risk getting lost within their own lush accompaniment.

column1: Damon & Naomi's recent archival activity has provided listeners with an excellent opportunity to investigate their entire musical timeline. The tempos have always been slow
column2: and the volume still tends towards the hushed and intimate
column3: but the overall texture of their music has undergone a gradual change. In Galaxie 500's music
column4: Dean Wareham's voice and guitar
column5: Naomi's melodic bass
column6: and Damon's drums were each given a distinctive role to play
column7: and each stood out in relative isolation in the group's spare production. On False Beats and True Hearts
column8: however
column9: the instruments are allowed to casually blur into one another
column10: with acoustic guitars and piano and reeds uniting to create a single dense weave as Kurihara's hypnotic guitar soars in and out above everything. It's an inviting sound
column11: yet one that often sacrifices sonic fireworks in favor of a general atmosphere of enveloping warmth.

column1: Beneath the album's placid surfaces there is a subtle but persistent tug of melancholy. The Naomi-sung ""How Do I Say Goodbye"" is a direct song of loss and mourning
column2: and nearly every track on the album references the silent passing of time and the invisible power of memory and nostalgia. ""The past is who we are but not what we may become
column3: Damon sings on ""Ophelia""
column4: articulating the theme of acceptance that echoes throughout the album. In typical fashion
column5: Damon & Naomi's lyrics on False Beats and True Hearts read very well on the page but don't necessarily lend themselves to immediately memorable choruses or hooks. As with their other work with Michio Kurihara
column6: False Beats and True Hearts is a slow bloom
column7:
an album whose rewards can become fully apparent only through thoughtful immersion.

It's difficult to accuse Dominik Eulberg of grace. The German producer-- known primarily for his implicating of biology into techno-- has excelled as a singles artists but has gone to lengths to remind us that his vision of techno does not conform to the sterile
column2: self-serious club paradigm. My favorite work by him

column4: is a collection of his best 12""s strung unnecessarily together by hammy nature-doc chatter. His tracks feature recordings of wildlife. There are
column5: of course
column6: the album covers. A workhorse producer
column7: Dom's creations become overgrown when allowed time. Diorama
column8: his fourth album
column9: is different in this respect. Following an unusually protracted silence (he last dropped a new track in 2009)
column10: Eulberg delivers a comparatively composed and well-felt long player.

column1: Eulberg has always made his obsession with nature explicit

column3: say
column4: Boards of Canada (obsessed with weirdo library music) or Trentemøller (pure forest-rock)
column5: his application isn't stylized; it's clinical. (Said another way: BoC are interested in Kodachrome nostalgia; Eulberg in a butterfly specimen pinned to felt.) Once a part-time forest ranger
column6: Eulberg has dedicated each of Diorama's 11 tracks to a different aspect of ""domestic nature."" If we understand Diorama's title literally
column7: these are representations
column8: and I can get there: Diorama feels more detailed
column9: scripted
column10: and painterly than his previous efforts.

column1: No one should conflate Dom's extracurricular interests with an inability to get down: He specializes in four-on-the-floor techno with burr-patch bass and starry synths. At his best
column2: Eulberg produces low-cal trance. His tracks thrive on the friction between horny
column3: acidic low-end and panning
column4: bell-like leads. Rhythms are uncluttered
column5: and he lovingly tweaks them as his tracks begin to buzz and flutter. Diorama features plenty of this (""Das Neunauge"")
column6: but there is a greater sense of control. Opener ""Taeuschungs-Blume"" takes Four Tet's breakbeat-laden psychedelia and distends it over the course of five pillowy minutes. On ""Der Tanz der Gluehwuermchen"" he goes to great lengths to prepare us for the skyscraping synth melody that carries the track home; the next track (""Aeronaut"") is a beatific comedown.

column1: Though he crafts long
column2: arching pieces
column3: Dom's music has never featured a narrative
column4: just details. He builds to beauty but not necessarily to climax
column5: and close listening can be exhausting. Diorama is better paced than his previous albums
column6: but it's trance music both stylistically and functionally
column7: abstracted nodding for the thinkers. Nature is a perfect corollary: Delight in its peculiarities
column8:
because divining a greater purpose will make your head hurt.

but may have a harder time finding a place in your record collection during the year's colder months.

Gang Gang Dance started as free-form noiseniks; over the years
column2: they've managed to mellow out without moving to the center-- evolving into purveyors of pan-cultural body-music
column3: marrying club beats with lyrics about communing with the dead. Like Arthur Russell before them
column4: they give equal floorspace to the spiritual and the sensual. By those loopy standards
column5: Eye Contact-- the group's latest album-- is Gang Gang Dance's finest
column6: weirdest
column7: and most uplifting statement yet.

column1: Eye Contact doesn't kick off so much as it wakes up
column2: easing into existence via 11-minute opener
column3: ""Glass Jar"". Synth and piano arpeggios shine through the stereo field
column4: percolating through a filter of jazz percussion before settling into a propulsive Eastern groove. It's a song about reincarnation. It's ""Darkstar"" and Alice Coltrane and the Boredoms in one blissed-out burst of sound. They're not much of a singles band
column5: though. Gang Gang Dance's vision tends to require a larger
column6: album-length
column7: canvas. Since 2005's God's Money
column8: each of the band's records has played as a single piece-- each song slurring into the next
column9: building toward an ecstatic climax
column10: mirroring the feel of a concert performance or a DJ set. Eye Contact holds to that ideal. Seven songs are strung together into a single composition
column11: bound by abstract ligatures.

column1: But it's an improvement of the formula. On Eye Contact
column2: Gang Gang strike a better balance of song craft and atmosphere. The band's previous record
column3: Saint Dymphna
column4: had admirable futurist-pop ambitions-- collaging elements of hyphy
column5: grime
column6: techno
column7: and contemporary R&B into a psychedelic stew-- but it sometimes came off overcooked. The instrumentals were often bursting with soupy sonic details
column8: while Gang Gang's passes at honest-to-goodness pop-- other than Kate Bush-homage ""House Jam""-- were at times stiff and over-considered.

column1: Eye Contact is considerably more relaxed. It's a smooth and moody record. The composed parts are more memorable. The interludes are
column2: well
column3: shorter. Following Dymphna
column4: the band's original drummer
column5: Tim Dewit
column6: parted ways with the group. His distinctive
column7: stuttering rhythms are missed
column8: but his replacement
column9: Jesse Lee-- a steadier and harder hitting player -- brings a more consistent feel to the rhythm section. Ariel Pink bassist Tim Koh adds some quiet storm-style bass to the airy and melodic ""Chinese High"". Hot Chip frontman Alexis Taylor wanders onto the mic during ""Romance Layers"" to croon over some a new jack-era soul.

column1: And yet this is not a pop record
column2: per se
column3: but the stuff of pop records collected
column4: melted down
column5: and then dribbled Jackson Pollock-style onto a canvas. Singer Lizzi Bougatsos borrows melodies from Indian pop
column6: Brian DeGraw swipes some sub bass from the UK underground
column7: and guitarist Josh Diamond nicks some riffs from North Africa. But Gang Gang aren't just collecting exotic hooks for the sake of bragging rights. The band seems to consciously gravitate toward cultures and genres where music is still overtly tethered to spirituality. Maybe it's because they miss their friends. Eye Contact is a ghost-heavy record. Two songs are dedicated to fallen New York art scene comrades. ""Glass Jar"" pays homage to former band mate Nathan Maddox
column8: who was killed by a lightning bolt in 2002. ""Sacer"" is a shout-out to artist Dash Snow
column9: who perished in 2009
column10: from a drug overdose.

column1: Eye Contact dials back the aural fog
column2: at least by Gang Gang standards. It's a tighter and more focused record that pares back the band's habit for noisy embellishment and psychic jewelry to reveal taught rhythms and catchy hooks. ""In the past
column3: I imagined our music being more about closing your eyes and escaping
column4: explained DeGraw during a recent interview. ""This one felt wide-eyed
column5: as if we were just staring at the listener."" Whether they're comfortable with the outside world is less clear. ""Better call the neurosurgeon
column6:
sings Bougatsos on album closer ""Thru and Thru"". ""Our dreaming space it is open.""

Here's something amazing: Napalm Death are still an ongoing concern. That band-- formed by bored
column3: obsessive teenagers in mid-1980s Birmingham
column4: England-- sped up death metal into a chaotic
column5: borderline comical blur; their best-known early song is probably still the one-second John Peel favorite ""You Suffer"". The frenzied style that these kids pioneered came to be known as grindcore
column6: and their debut album
column7: Scum
column8: is now regarded as a stone classic in underground metal. But all the original members drifted away; the band remains a touring machine staffed by grizzled vets who regularly crank out more albums of still-potent bloodlettings. You have to wonder how it feels to be a grown man
column9: making your living playing in a band that was started by children
column10: children who no longer have any real connection to what you're doing. And you have to wonder how it feels to be one of those children
column11: moving on to other things in life and watching your childhood creation continuing to pound away.

column1: One of those children is Justin Broadrick
column2: whose post-Napalm Death body of work is a varied and fascinating thing. With Godflesh
column3: he built a brutal slow-thud form of electronic rock
column4: a sound so heavy you couldn't rightly call it metal. He's also made various forms of scraping noise under different names: Techno Animal
column5: Final
column6: Pale Sketcher. And for nearly a decade
column7: he's been the man behind Jesu
column8: where he's done something more startling than anything he did under his other guises: He's created beauty. Jesu's music is a kind of tidal slow-churn take on sad-bastard indie rock
column9: Broadrick burying his muttery one-note vocals under avalanches of guitar fuzz and slathering them in prettily reverbed synth figures.

column1: Jesu have released most of their music on Hydra Head
column2: a label that specializes in contemplative metal
column3: but lately they've been recording for Calo Verde
column4: the label founded by the Red House Painters' Mark Kozelek. Broadrick has cited the Red House Painters as an inspiration
column5: and it's easy to see how those two could form a mutual admiration society. Jesu
column6: especially on the new Ascension
column7: do a pretty incredible job evoking the feeling of depression through music
column8: its melodies buried under so many oceans of impossibly slow sound that you just barely notice they're there. Nothing Broadrick has ever done with Jesu would give you any clue he was ever in Napalm Death
column9: but on his last two albums
column10: a punishing riff or a gnarled roar would occasionally flare up out of nowhere. And there was also a punk-rock directness about the music; more than one critic compared Jesu to Jawbreaker. But on Ascension
column11: Broadrick never allows himself a moment of catharsis or hope; it's music for rocking back and forth in a fetal position.

column1: Nothing remotely rock even happens on the album until 90 seconds in
column2: when a titanic wall of guitar builds up behind the skeletal acoustic figures and muttery Slint-sounding vocals of ""Fools"". ""Birth Day"" has the gasping synths I've come to associate with witch house
column3: as well as all sorts of delicate guitar noodles that would've done Explosions in the Sky proud. A few songs rank as straight-up eight-minute crawls
column4: and the drama comes as the riffs glacially crash into one another
column5: all tragic grandeur. And all throughout
column6: Broadrick sounds like a shattered man
column7: barely ever raising his voice enough that you can clearly make out what he's saying.

column1: This is only Jesu's third album
column2: and their first since 2007's Conqueror
column3: but they've been regularly cranking out EPs since their inception. Those EPs tend to work awfully well; they give you enough of Broadrick's distinctive atmosphere without burying you in that aesthetic. But Ascension is his saddest work
column4: and he lets nothing glimmer through in its hour-long runtime. As an album-length wallow in bad feelings
column5: it's an impressive thing indeed. But I prefer Jesu when their music is about connection rather than isolation. Conqueror
column6: then
column7: still stands as the band's triumphant moment. Ascension is just the long
column8:
slow hangover that sets in after.

Cam'ron's debut album
column2: Confessions of Fire
column3: turns 13 this year. His commercial appeal and creative verve have dimmed over the years
column4: but he's still an enormously influential figure; it's tough to imagine
column5: say
column6: how Lil Wayne might sound if Cam hadn't paved the way for gangsta rappers who pile up left-turn lyrical absurdities with audible glee. Given all his years in the game
column7: his cult-favorite status
column8: and his impact on the genre
column9: it'd make a whole lot of sense for Cam'ron to do what most older rappers do: call in guest-verse favors and play the mature
column10: reflective elder statesman. But this is
column11: after all
column12: Cam'ron we're talking about. Even at this point
column13: he'd rather kick assholish punchlines: ""Now I'm shaving coke/ On an amazing boat/ 'Fuck you
column14: suck dick'-- I don't know what to say to folks."" The second Cameron Giles figures out what to say to folks
column15: he will cease being the Cam'ron we know.

column1: For the past couple of years
column2: Cam's been pairing up with Vado
column3: a younger Harlem dude with a husky
column4: unstable energy in his voice that recalls past Cam proteges Juelz Santana and Jim Jones. In his own way
column5: Vado's as much fun these days as Cam'ron is
column6: even though his lines aren't nearly as quotable. Vado's got a great array of ad-libs
column7: which he yells constantly

column9: Vado playing the eager and bloodthirsty henchman. Another relative newcomer
column10: the MPC-abusing producer AraabMuzik
column11: handles most of the production
column12: cranking out a succession of hard
column13: simple beats that transform classical string fanfares and 1980s action-movie soundtrack keyboards into utilitarian thuds. Araab's instrumentals can be dense
column14: hectic things
column15: but his beats here just get out of the way and give Cam and Vado room to go to work.

column1: No guests appear on Gunz n' Butta; Cam and Vado are the only rapping voices we hear. And they keep their focus narrow; they're not interested in doing much more than delivering an endless stream of amusingly worded fuck-you-up threats. Lately
column2: Cam's sounded most alive when he's indulging in goofy
column3: oddly gentle relationship talk
column4: as on the great recent single ""Girls Cry"". But ""Girls Cry""
column5: for whatever reason
column6: doesn't appear on the album
column7: and a couple of halfassed love songs buried at the end are the only slight indications that we're dealing with three-dimensional human beings here. Even their minor-hit club tracks
column8: last year's summer jam ""Speakin in Tungs"" and the more recent and still-catchier ""Hey Muma""
column9: only show up on the album after 11 tracks of amoral jokes. But the album works anyway because of Vado's energy and because Cam is still great at clowning people.

column1: Cam doesn't bring the same energy he had on the Diplomats' mid-00s run of mixtapes or on Purple Haze
column2: his 2004 masterpiece
column3: but he's still perfectly capable of putting together a ridiculously strong verse. Even his dumbest lines are a whole lot of fun to repeat: ""You got some gay friends? Me
column4: I got some lesbians/ And you ain't just a actor
column5: you a thespian."" There's just nobody else in rap who does deadpan silliness like that
column6: and Cam makes it sound like the easiest thing in the world. There's nothing even the slightest bit innovative about Gunz n' Butta
column7: but it does give us Cam
column8: Vado
column9: and Araab
column10: three guys with great chemistry
column11: doing what they do. It's a one-dimensional affair
column12:
but that one dimension is pretty awesome.

From Super Furry Animals to Sigur Rós
column2: it's inevitable that non-Anglo artists start singing in English as their international audience grows. But four albums in
column3: proudly Francophone Montrealers Malajube are still happy to get lost in translation
column4: even with two Polaris Music Prize nominations and several Stateside tours under their belts. That said
column5: in Malajube's case
column6: the language barrier is a porous one-- for one
column7: their songs often come with remedial titles that provide easily discernible emotional cues (e.g.: ""La Blizzard""
column8: ""Ibuprofène"")
column9: and
column10: much like the Super Furries before them
column11: the band has exhibited a knack for fusing psychedelia
column12: prog- and classic-rock
column13: disco
column14: and new wave into exuberant
column15: easily grasped big-tent indie pop.

column1: Neither as manic as 2006 breakthrough Trompe L'Oeil nor as knotty as 2009's appropriately titled Labyrinthes
column2: La Caverne sees Malajube settle into a lush
column3: soft-rockin' groove that
column4: true to their all-French songwriting policy
column5: suggests the band is completely content playing in its comfort zone; tellingly
column6: the album was recorded in a secluded
column7: custom-built
column8: geodesic-dome house located deep in the Laurentians. (In fact
column9: Malajube sound so blissfully self-contained here
column10: it's not unreasonable to think they're completely oblivious to how much the La Caverne's blue-vector cover graphics resemble those of Daft Punk's Tron soundtrack.) The relatively stress-free recording environment naturally manifests itself in the performances: whether it's smooth yacht-rockin' disco (""Synesthésie"") or upbeat
column11: glockenspieled pop (""Radiologie"")
column12: singer Julien Mineau's voice rarely wavers from a daydreamy sigh
column13: indicating he has little desire to challenge fellow countrymen Win Butler or Kevin Drew in the crowd-rousing
column14: master-of-ceremonies department.

column1: Clocking in at 10 tracks and a mere 32 minutes
column2: La Caverne can breeze by without your realizing it
column3: which is as much a comment on the songs' consistently pleasing
column4: shimmering surfaces as their tendency to come and go without much incident; while nocturnally tinted songs like ""Sangsues"" and ""Le Stridor"" hint at a creeping tension
column5: the album is decidedly lacking in a curtain-raising dramatic flourish like Labyrinthes' ""Ursuline""
column6: or an emotional centerpiece à la Trompe's epic star-gazing ballad ""Étienne D'août"". Perhaps La Caverne's streamlined simplicity is an inevitable retreat from Labyrinthes' structural complexities
column7: and with songs as immediately engaging as the power-pop rush of ""Cro-Magnon"" or the gorgeously tranquil ""Mon Oeil""
column8: it's hard to fault that approach. But a big part of Malajube's initial appeal was how willing they were to upset their joyous melodies with shocks of screaming or bizarro electronic intrusions. Malajube's admirable dedication to singing in their native tongue already suggests a certain lack of compromise in making themselves more accessible to the masses; with La Caverne
column9:
you just wish that same sense of daring was reflected a little more in the music.

When people talk about a British band ""breaking America
column2: it usually implies a level of success at home
column3: and a hope to match those sales abroad. With the Wave Pictures
column4: it's a bit more mundane. They're just trying to get over here: If You Leave It Alone and Instant Coffee Baby were respectively their seventh and eighth LPs
column5: and thanks to a distribution deal with Moshi Moshi
column6: in 2010 they were packaged as a double album to become their first commercially available release in the U.S.

column1: But mundanity is fitting for the Wave Pictures
column2: since the characters in Dave Tattersall's verbose but musically unadorned short stories do very mundane things: spend days at the seaside
column3: scoop ice cream
column4: get involved in go-nowhere relationships. If this recalls Art Brut or the Streets
column5: you're not far off
column6: since the Wave Pictures are most definitely a lyrics-first act and a distinctly British one. That's usually a tough sell to begin with
column7: but the problem with Beer in the Breakers isn't one of culture or slang so much as a narrator who is almost wholly forgettable-- their stories are boring.

column1: The key distinction is that these songs are more often being told to you as opposed to shared
column2: even if the first lyric (""I swam out to greet you"") suggests a conversation happening with the listener. Tattersall fires off some nice images and bon mots-- ""Who are you to tell me that I look depressed/ You wouldn't even know if I'm at my best"" is particularly pithy-- but they merely sit in place hoping to be admired rather than meeting the listener halfway.

column1: Tattersall's British wit may be appropriately dry
column2: but the Wave Pictures' arrangements are basically deserted
column3: little more than sprightly Stratocaster chords and a polite rhythm section that could easily hold residency at a local coffee shop. ""Little Surprise"" at least lives up to its name with a brisk quasi-Afro-pop riff
column4: and elsewhere the more upbeat numbers recall the ultra-clean guitar work of Orange Juice. But anytime the tempo slows
column5: they lapse into a tedium that becomes irritating-- particularly on the title track
column6: where the vast pockets of space in the production almost allow you to hear the Wave Pictures losing interest in real time.

column1: Unless the Mars Volta have a new album in the works
column2: I'm not sure if I'll hear a record with more guitar solos this year (credit ""Blue Harbour"" for at least having a bass solo). And they appear at nearly the same point at every track
column3: played with a technical precision very rare in indie circles
column4: but after the initial surprise wears off
column5: you can mostly imagine Tattersall pulling off those slow bends and sustained vibrato while rocking his best G.E. Smith face. Rather than anticipating a crescendo or introducing an intriguing melodic turn
column6:
they simply kill time-- the most mundane activity of them all.

If you want an example of the wide-ranging nature of dance music in 2011
column3: look no further than Nguzunguzu
column4: the Los Angeles production and DJ team of Asma Maroof and Daniel Pineda. The duo
column5: which got some attention hosting the popular (and now-dormant) Wildness party series at the L.A. club Silver Platter
column6: incorporates most every strain of domestic and global music into its beats-- from Chicago juke and footwork to UK bass
column7: mambo
column8: reggaeton
column9: and cumbia. But they also celebrate the familiar: For all the exotic sounds in an Nguzunguzu track
column10: there are usually elements of chart hip-hop and R&B offsetting them.

column1: Nguzunguzu have two EPs to their name-- Mirage and a self-titled one
column2: both from 2010-- but the best introduction to their sound is The Perfect Lullaby
column3: an album-length mixtape made for the online art magazine DIS. (It's available for a free download here.) On this
column4: Pineda and Maroof (it's worth mentioning that the latter recently served as M.I.A.'s tour DJ) build a bouncy
column5: dreamy mix that takes specific inspiration from the Angolan dance genres of Kizomba and Zouk. These styles are generally slow and seductive and have a grimy
column6: percussive undercurrent
column7: and Nguzunguzu match that with the similarly sultry vocals of artists like Brandy and The-Dream. The combination is pretty ingenious.

column1: A big part of the reason the mix works so well is simple execution-- Nguzunguzu blend these far-flung sounds together in a way that just feels natural. They often leave source material intact (vocals are rarely tweaked or mutated
column2: as they are in some recent indie-leaning R&B)
column3: so it's less about intricate remixing than careful beat matching. For example
column4: early in the set (it's not divided into individual tracks)
column5: they put R. Kelly's verse from Ja Rule's ""Wonderful"" over a Zouk instrumental by DJ P&P Productions that flips the context of the source but maintains something essential about it
column6: too. The same goes for Amerie's classic ""1 Thing""
column7: set here to a grimy beat by France's DJ Lo
column8: placing the original's high-energy clamor on a humid slow boil.

column1: In a recent interview with DJ /rupture on his WFMU show
column2: Mudd Up!
column3: Maroof talked about a Nguzunguzu track combining a Wiley instrumental with the Nicki Minaj remix of Drake's ""Best I Ever Had""
column4: saying
column5: ""She kind of raps like a grime MC on it... I want her to be a grime MC
column6: so I just kind of put the two together."" A simple statement
column7: but it gets at what the group does so well-- sort of a wide-eyed
column8: creative reshuffling of au courant music. So even with the R&B bent of this mix
column9: the group seems more in line with folks like DJ /rupture and even M.I.A. than the crop of urban-pop revisionists that has sprung up recently. But for Nguzunguzu
column10:
it's not about politics-- these two are just trying to build the global discotheque of their dreams.

Man Man are full of contradictions: They make great studio records that can't compare to the intensity of their physically demanding live show. Oh
column3: but you really gotta pay attention to the lyrics. And their best songs are the slow ones. Their facepaint
column4: percussion
column5: and piano-pounding portray them as wild men
column6: but Honus Honus' junkyard-dog howl is the projection of an old soul. This duality is more pronounced than ever on their fourth LP
column7: Life Fantastic. On one end
column8: it's by far their most tasteful and well-produced record to date. But it contains the darkest
column9: most frightening lyrics Honus has written-- which is really saying something.

column1: It makes sense that the band brought in Saddle Creek house producer Mike Mogis
column2: not just for his mastery of reining in orchestral bric-a-brac but also for his experience with the most caustic emotional bloodletting. But not even early Bright Eyes can hold a candle to the absolutely scorching self-immolation of Life Fantastic. Leadoff ""Knuckle Down"" casts Honus as an all-too-willing supplicant in an emotionally and sexually draining relationship. But at least someone's getting their rocks off there-- more typical is the atomic ""Dark Arts""
column3: which details an accident Honus suffered before the Life Fantastic sessions.

column1: The autobiographical details are a bit stifling at times
column2: but Honus' other lyrical subjects are no better off: Within the subtly hooky vocals of the title track
column3: children find a corpse at a picnic and are informed by their parents that ""the world is dying."" If there's a better marimba-led tango about a killer who turns his victims into household items (""The fireman is an ashtray/ The DJ spins as fan blades"")
column4: I haven't heard it. And in the tradition of OutKast's ""Toilet Tisha""
column5: don't let a silly title (""Spooky Jookie"") distract you from a harrowing and grotesque account of a life slipping away to drugs (""She broke her teeth/ On an unsheathed piece of hard-tasting candy"").

column1: While Honus continues to prove himself one of rock's best working lyricists
column2: Life Fantastic contains as many musically compelling moments as Rabbit Habits and Six Demon Bag. They've dialed down the wacky factor-- not as many cartoon voices
column3: no kazoos-- though it's not a simple matter of having a ""real producer"" for the first time. Clearly
column4: Mogis cleans them up nicely
column5: importing lovely string sections for the title track and ""Oh
column6: La Brea"". But for every song such as ""Knuckle Down"" that packs a sturdy
column7: forceful melody
column8: others struggle to fit the contours of Honus' syntax. Pay too much attention to the words and the songs can bleed into each other
column9: or recall older Man Man material.

column1: That's not a sin
column2: considering Man Man have created a niche that's wholly theirs. It's natural for them to embrace this established identiy
column3: most clearly expressed on closer ""Oh
column4: La Brea"". Settling in Los Angeles after a few itinerant years
column5: Honus finds himself disenfranchised by the west side (""Sepulveda and Pico
column6:
what the hell do they know about me?"") as well as the artsier east side. He finds comfort in the thoroughfare sharing its name with a tar pit-- fitting for a pitch-black record that reveals as many skeletons as you're willing to dig for.

column3: standing in Lil Wayne's shadow during that man's historic mid-00s run
column4: striking out on his own and building himself to cult-favorite status on a series of weed-and-sneaker-addled solo mixtapes
column5: inhabiting Ski Beatz' sumptuous psychedelic-soul production on last year's two great Pilot Talk albums. And now that he's established himself as one of the stars of an ascendant Internet-friendly stoner-rap scene
column6: he's giving himself a new challenge
column7: pairing up with the producer Alchemist for the online giveaway Covert Coup.

column1: Alchemist has had a tumultuous career of his own. He's a Beverly Hills native who came to prominence crafting Tunnel anthems for New York roughnecks like Mobb Deep and Jadakiss. These days
column2: he specializes in a broken
column3: warped form of rap production-- classic New York boom-bap refracted through prisms
column4: the loose-and-shaggy Stones Throw cratedigger style turned ominous and bloodthirsty. His tracks for Covert Coup aren't far removed from the stuff he did on Gutter Water
column5: an overlooked 2010 album that found him teaming with the West Coast underground stalwart Oh No
column6: the two of them bouncing their queasiest
column7: most unsettled head-nodders off of each other. On Covert Coup
column8: his decayed guitar loops and creeping drum breaks remind me of the shattered post-apocalyptic New York that Snake Plissken had to escape. It's a different kind of weed-rap
column9: one Curren$y hasn't really tried to do. And yet he slip-slides through it with the charming
column10: effortless ease that's become his trademark. Nothing fazes this guy.

column1: Curren$y's been calling Covert Coup an EP
column2: but it's 10 tracks in 28 minutes
column3: longer than plenty of punk and indie full-lengths I own. The mixtape follows what I guess you'd call the Madvillainy model-- 90-second stretches of dense lyricism

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
usually without a chorus-- before the rapper fades out and the woozy
column2: evocative track takes over. Curren$y's verses aren't punchline marathons; they're stoned reveries
column3: and it can be riveting to hear him depict certain situations with loose
column4: unhurried narrative precision: ""Let the little homey kick it in the auto shop with us/ Long as he can make store runs and keep his mouth shut/ Same way I came up.""

column1: As a rapper
column2: Curren$y's greatest asset is his delivery
column3: the way his pinched
column4: nasal Louisiana drawl slithers its way through the track. But he's also great at coming up with sharp
column5: unexpected ways to address standard rap topics. On his weed-smoking capacity: ""The toxic air that I'm breathing would leave a average man weakened."" On his own charisma: ""If you looking for that nigga
column6: I is him/ All eyes in this direction/ A burden and a blessing."" On his home life: ""White carpets in my Scarface house/ No undergarments on my Scarface spouse."" On how high he is right this second: ""Playa all Himalaya-ish."" His lyrics are full of slick little tricks like these
column7: tiny turns of phrase that sneak up on you after multiple listens but which dazzle in their economy when you parse them out.

column1: A few well-selected guests turn up on Covert Coup
column2: and all of them make strong foils for Curren$y's conversational calm. Freddie Gibbs' focused on-fire double-time on ""Scottie Pippen"" stands in stark contrast to Curren$y's style
column3: and the two extremes work well together. Alc's just-out-of-prison blood brother Prodigy plays a tough
column4: raspy uncle figure
column5: showing a sense of hardhead style that emerges too rarely on P's own recent online offering
column6: The Ellsworth Bumpy Johnson EP. Curren$y's puff-buddy Smoke DZA breezes right through ""Life Instructions"". And fellow New Orleans vet Fiend has a great moment on ""Blood Sweat and Gears""
column7: letting off a couple of lines in a bluesy moan-sing before snapping into an excellent grown-man verse. These guest spots do what they're supposed to do. They don't overwhelm Curren$y or clash with his style; they just bring some new dimensions out of his songs. They're there for chemistry reasons
column8: not name value
column9: and they work great.

column1: Curren$y let Covert Coup out into the world on 4/20
column2: a fun but unnecessary attention-grabbing stunt. There's plenty of zoned-out atmosphere on the tape
column3: but it's a strong
column4: focused
column5: unified piece of work
column6:
not just a lava-lamp soundtrack. It stands on its own.

"|15385.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15385-covert-coup/|7.9|Tom Breihan

Unlike Joan Wasser's first two efforts as Police Woman
column2: The Deep Field doesn't feature any CD-sticker-worthy cameos from folks like Rufus Wainwright or Antony Hegarty. That's not to disparage her current collection of collaborators
column3: which includes former Shudder to Think guitarist Nathan Larson and  troubador Joseph Arthur
column4: as well as producer Bryce Goggin
column5: the  go-to guy for most of Matador Records' mid-90s output. You still get the sense she's trying to make the type of mature and  sophisticated pop music that can stand comfortably with these and  other like-minded contemporaries. Unfortunately
column6: while she aims for such critically  acclaimed heights
column7: her shots often land in a  middle-of-the-road
column8: adult-contemporary wasteland.

column1: On a purely musical level
column2: The Deep Field handles its business in a professional manner. The songs can settle into a uninspired groovy shuffle at times
column3: ""The Magic"" being the key offender. And there are elements that tend to over-announce their presence at the cost of drowning out everything else-- usually it's the faux-funky organ
column4: but the background singers making like human didgeridoos on ""Human Condition"" deserve a special mention.  Still
column5: it's hard to fully disregard a songwriter who can conjure up the haunting Talk Talk-like ambiance of ""Flash""
column6: or gracefully send off ""The Action Man"" on a bed of strings
column7: woodwinds
column8: and percussion. It's when Wasser puts her voice front and center that The Deep Field collapses in on itself.

column1: Wasser trades in all sorts of vagaries and generalizations
column2: taking an entire track to convey an idea that could be succinctly expressed in a single verse. If Wasser were a stronger vocalist
column3: she might be able to get by with this sort of shoddy writing; put these songs in Adele's golden throat
column4: and they'd probably be chart-toppers.  Wasser's voice is a decidely more subtle instrument.  It has character
column5: but its wispy
column6: semi-sultry charm isn't robust enough to sell an outright dog like ""Chemmie""
column7: a shameless slow jam that requires the bombastic pipes of Larson's former bandmate
column8: Craig Wedren
column9:
to make it even remotely palatable. It's sadly appropriate that this misfire of a song-- about a couple with undeniable chemistry-- epitomizes an album that comes off as hopelessly inert.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16501/homepage_large.58a1e7c9.jpg|Flora|28633.0|Fredrik|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kora']|2011-05-05 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:29:28.313985|"

The third album by the Swedish band Fredrik is cut from same cloth as Trilogi
column2: their beguiling second release. They like finely textured guitars and electronics
column3: quasi-classical embellishments
column4: miniature clockwork percussion
column5: and windy vocals placed high in the mix. Flora definitely has that Fredrik feel
column6: which is like a Scandinavian Radiohead
column7: or the Notwist at their duskiest. But while Trilogi was rooted in folk and trip-hop
column8: Flora seems to take more cues from dance music
column9: in its distant post-rock way. The motif at the beginning of ""Rites of Spring"" passes within spitting distance of Culture Beat's ""Mr. Vain""
column10: and you'll hear a greater emphasis on pittering snares
column11: hand percussion
column12: and arpeggiated synths than before. Where Trilogi was more focused on rococo leaps and hesitations
column13: Flora draws out a stiffened pulse.

column1: The record opens with the kind of sonic foliage that was allowed to flourish more freely on Trilogi: ""Ylva""
column2: where an otherworldly voice lifts out of chimes. But the first proper song
column3: ""Vattenfront""
column4: takes a crashing turn. Waves of horns course through a tight circuit of bass and snippy percussion
column5: establishing a feint-and-attack pattern that carries on into the Knife-like ""Chrome Cavities"" and several other songs. This new approach is kind of a trade-off. The downside is that the subtleties feel flatted by all the smoke and thunder; the upside is that some adrenaline pumps into Fredrik's even-tempered sound. But a couple of the most unequivocally appealing songs clear out more space around the singing. On ""Inventress of Ill (and Everything)""
column6: the kind of squeal that steamrolls some songs is relegated to a more helpful role
column7: coloring a quiet melody in

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
the background. There's some room to breathe and sink into this pulse Fredrik are exploring. You want to lean in
column2: rather than back.

column1: For all of its good qualities
column2: it's hard to pinpoint what makes Flora a little less satisfying than Trilogi overall. I think it has to do with a certain softness that is diminished in favor of a chest-beating tone. Certainly
column3: there are a few mechanical issues: Some songs that aim to trance out just wind up feeling repetitive
column4: and more than once
column5: I found myself wishing that whoever was banging on metal stuff so relentlessly would just cut it out. (""The North Greatern"" combines both of these flaws.) But the real difference is that Trilogi earned and offset its more blustery moments with haunting respites like ""Milo"". While Flora exceeds Trilogi in pageantry
column6:
it never feels as effortless or humble as that little tune did-- the two qualities that distinguish Fredrik's best work from haughty post-rock boilerplate.

"|15388.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15388-flora/|6.5|Brian Howe

column2:
'Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Capitol']|2011-05-04 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:29:28.478023|"

It's hard to imagine pop culture in the 1990s without Ad-Rock
column3: MCA
column4: and Mike D. During those years
column5: the Beastie Boys didn't sell the most records or grace the most magazine covers
column6: but they brilliantly articulated how a constellation of obsessions-- early hip-hop
column7: hardcore
column8: trash culture
column9: 70s TV
column10: vintage sneakers
column11: skateboarding
column12: vinyl records-- could be pulled together into not just a coherent aesthetic but a way of life.

column1: Looking at their arc from a purely musical perspective
column2: you could divide their career in half at the midpoint of that decade-- at some point between 1994's Ill Communication and 1998's Hello Nasty. Their first four full-lengths came in less than eight years
column3: and during this stretch
column4: they were hungry and on the move
column5: restlessly searching for new avenues of music expression. They're just now getting to their third proper album (fourth
column6: if you want to count 2007's instrumental LP The Mix-Up) in the 17 years since. The Boys became men
column7: and now they're gliding respectably into middle age
column8: living honorable lives and playing music only if and when they feel like it. (This album was originally supposed to come out in 2009
column9: but MCA has been battling cancer and the re-jiggered version was labeled Part Two.) They broke their ground
column10: and now they have nothing to prove and no pop scene to become part of. Which means that they can focus on being the Beastie Boys
column11: and let the fans decide if they want to engage with them on that level.

column1: In this case
column2: being the Beastie Boys means returning to the thicker
column3: heavier sound they ushered in with Check Your Head and Ill Communication. Hot Sauce Committee mixes live instrumentation and samples into the kind of soupy production first unleashed on the world with ""Pass the Mic"" and furthered with songs like ""So What'cha Want"" and ""Sure Shot"". It's a very different feel from 2004's To the 5 Boroughs
column4: their post-9/11 love letter to New York that found them more or less stripping down and letting simpler beats and straight-ahead vocals do the talking. These songs are dense with sound effects and heavy on the bottom end
column5: and the vocals are processed with a mixture of distortion and EQ that obscures the details of their rapping and the content of their lyrics but also gives the music a bit of snarl. They're good at this sound.

column1: The song titles suggest that the Beastie Boys feel comfort in their position
column2: addressing culture that was already retro in 1986 (""Lee Majors Come Again""-- he was the Six Million Dollar Man
column3: kids)
column4: paying tribute to the music of their youth (""Nonstop Disco Powerpack"")
column5: and offering a bit of inspirational uplift (""Long Burn the Fire""). These and other tracks reference earlier work in ways even more direct. ""Lee Majors"" is the latest in the line of ""Remember
column6: we used to be a hardcore band"" songs that stretches back to their 1992 cover of Sly Stone's ""Time for Livin'"". ""Long Burn the Fire"" has vocals from all three
column7: but starts off feeling like a ""state of MCA"" dispatch in the vein of ""Stand Together"" or ""A Year and a Day""
column8: this time delivered with a touch of weariness. Both ""Fire"" and ""Say It"" have an overloaded end-of-bar sound effect that brings to mind ""Pass the Mic""
column9: ""Gratitude""
column10: and ""Sabotage"". And ""Nonstop"" once again has rhymes about macaroni and cheese and keeping on until the break of dawn.

column1: Other echoes from earlier songs abound
column2: but you don't come to the Beastie Boys for something new
column3: which is perfectly fine
column4: even a little admirable. Beginning with Paul's Boutique
column5: part of their appeal has been that they've built a little clubhouse in their G-Son studio and invited everyone inside. They've gone off on their own trip
column6: returning to the same pop culture obsessions and building their own context rather than integrating into the musical world around them.

column1: On two songs here
column2: they do in fact invite in notable guests. First is ""Too Many Rappers""
column3: which debuted online in 2009 and finds Nas trading rhymes with his hometown pals. While it doesn't come close to the silly and stoned riffing of the 1994 Q-Tip feature ""Get It Together""
column4: it's going for something entirely different-- a spiky aggro feel that finds their fellow New Yorker sounding a bit distant and indistinct. ""Don't Play No Game That I Can't Win"" features Santigold on the hook of a track with a reggae lilt
column5: and the pairing feels natural and obvious-- you could argue that the Beastie Boys' polyglot approach in the 90s helped clear the way for her style
column6: which mixes an ear for the sound of other cultures with a touch of Lower East Side artiness.

column1: Taken together
column2: these 16 songs
column3: which seem to touch on just about everything the Beastie Boys have said and done
column4: may not add up to something amazing
column5: but they do the job. And listening to Hot Sauce Committee
column6: it's hard not to reflect on how long the Beastie Boys have been together and how
column7: unusually
column8: their musical partnership still seems grounded in friendship rather than just business. There's still something inspiring in the idea of the Beastie Boys that transcends any single release. So while this may not be a great album or even a top-tier Beastie Boys album-- I'd place it somewhere between Hello Nasty and the inferior 5 Boroughs
column9:
neither of which can touch those first four-- anyone who cares about these guys will be glad it exists.

column9: adding an occasionally eerie feel to Cat's Eyes.

column1: Consequently

Cat's Eyes is the rare side project effort that feels as (if not more) fully realized than the band from which it borrows members.

column3: you'd have an easier time rattling off all the kinds of music Portland instrumental rockers Grails don't make than the kinds they do. They have not

column1: From stoner sludge to swirling desert rock to meditative mood music
column2: Grails run an impressively wide gamut on Deep Politics. Less heavy and histrionic than 2008's grisly Doomsdayer's Holiday
column3: Deep Politics has a rugged but decidedly habitable feel

column5: each constituent part
column6: too
column7: is thrilling. So much post-rock leaves the listener waiting around for the good bit to kick in; Grails' constantly changing sound makes every moment arresting
column8: not simply the big crescendos. For all its sparseness and delicacy
column9: nearly every moment on Deep Politics is suffused with a sort of looming dread. And when it hits

column1: You can take your pick on Deep Politics' most stunning segment; the gnarled tangle of guitar and strings on opener ""Future Primitive""
column2: the towering symphonic blast of ""All the Colors of the Dark""
column3: the punishing back half of ""I Led Three Lives"". The many quiet moments prove just as rich and striking
column4: suffusing the disc with rays of light to help offset the wide swaths of darkness. They push sounds nimbly in and out of the mix without ever risking overload
column5: and while there's plenty of virtuosity bubbling under the surface-- particularly on the trickily fingerpicked closer ""Deep Snow""-- there's little flash to be found
column6: all instruments joined in service of the overall picture. From swirling Eastern-tinged psych to ruddy widescreen metal to lilting modern classical-inflected strings
column7: the dynamics are constantly in motion

column2: but it's the moment on Deep Politics that misses its mark. Just the same
column3: though
column4: it's as easy to imagine the smoky backlight poster vibe of the mildly funky ""Daughters of Bilitis"" or one of their sidetrips into heavier realms turning some other listener away. That's the risk you take when you take on so much music in the course of three-quarters of an hour

column6: the quietly virtuosic Grails only occasionally overreach. And even as they fold more sounds into the mixture
column7: they find a place for nearly all of them. All encompassing and utterly engrossing
column8:
Deep Politics proves yet another stirring triumph from one of rock's great unsung ensembles.

column1: On Talahomi Way he's subtly twisted the High Llamas' aesthetic once again. It again feels like O'Hagan has rifled through his record collection and immersed their sound in its esoteric element. It's led to an uneven career

the lush harp of ""To the Abbey"" resembling the soundtrack to a sumptuous Technicolor melodrama. ""Fly Baby
column2: Fly"" sounds directly extracted from 70s AM radio.

column1: O'Hagan calls this a spring album

column3: one of the weakest components of the High Llamas' sound-- O'Hagan's wholegrain vocals-- is significantly dampened by some well-placed multi-part harmonies and several instrumental tracks. At times it lapses into unwelcome pastiche; the rustic harmonica on ""A Rock in May"" could be ripped from the soundtrack to the long-running CBS snoozefest ""The Waltons"". The standout track
column4: the opening ""Berry Adams""
column5: seems to have been politely set at the start of the running order to get it out of the way in case it actually grabs someone's attention. In it
column6: O'Hagan weaves a tale of a workingman down on his luck and with crushed dreams in mind
column7: while a string arrangement that will sound instantly familiar to anyone who has followed his career blooms up around him.

column1: From there it's a pleasant amble through the rest of the record
column2: which carries a dainty air partly shaped by the exclusion of intrusive drum patterns on most of the songs. The preponderance of long instrumental passages suggests O'Hagan is acutely aware of both his shortcomings as a songwriter and his strengths as an arranger. ""Wander
column3: Jack Wander"" is set in motion by some delightfully parping trumpets and beautifully filmy strings
column4: while ""Angel Connector"" is a slight return to his Turn On-style attraction to analog circuitry. Those two tracks
column5: both entirely instrumental
column6: find a little more space to breathe than the vocal-heavy passages elsewhere on Talahomi Way. Perhaps with a stronger singer and lyricist this band may have gained more momentum throughout its career
column7: but it's unlikely that's what O'Hagan has ever had in mind. He seems perfectly content to let these small-wonder songs shuffle out unobtrusively into the world
column8:
and it's come to feel like a comforting spot to return to every couple of years or so.

Jason Forrest's mid-decade breakthrough was a coup when it came to the sampling arts. 2004's The Unrelenting Songs of the 1979 Post Disco Crash and 2005's Shamelessly Exciting hit during a post-2manydjs/pre-Girl Talk lull in mash-up culture
column2: and these albums were singularly deranged acts of joyful violence against musical familiarity. You like having your music-nerd buttons pushed by recognizable snippets of canonical rock and pop favorites? Well
column3: here they are crumbling to scraps
column4: rattling around like superballs in a laundromat tumble dryer or burning like overheated film stock. Whether they were specific moments of instantly identifiable songs or a more generalist interpretation of certain genres
column5: the way these loops were fed through Forrest's unpredictable yet danceable breakcore rhythms was invigoratingly grotesque.

column1: The Everything isn't quite as manic
column2: however
column3: and it doesn't have as many dramatic moments where well-known decades-old pop context gets flayed to bits. Instead
column4: the album is driven by a wide-ranging eclecticism that doesn't get much footing in one overarching style
column5: often swapping out Forrest's most well-known tendencies towards smithereen-reassembling genre clashes for a more analog breakbeat sound. It's not a bad idea-- there are plenty of intriguing possibilities for what a Jason Forrest track could sound like without the K-tel-in-a-woodchipper approach at work
column6: since half the fun was what he did with the bass and drums that didn't rely on reinterpretive trickery. But the branching out necessitates a bit of an identity crisis

column2: though for different reasons. ""Italian Lessons"" pulls together a disorienting synthesis of disco
column3: prog
column4: and suspense film scoring that plays out like an elaborate suite. The sprawl of ""Archive"" is a bit less focused-- you could blame the beat's attention-deficit wandering from Chicago juke to hardcore jungle with a few gratuitous breakdowns thrown in-- but it could just be that the same hyperactive pattern-switching that worked so well on Unrelenting Songs and Shamelessly Exciting feels less convincing when it's overlaid with cheap
column5: tinny keyboard horns instead of finely-diced samples.

column1: Some inspired sample-based tracks do still show up
column2: thankfully
column3: even if they're not the same hilarious corruptions of famous hits that made Forrest notorious. ""Raunchy"" and ""Keys to the Door"" take a couple different tacks-- the former
column4: a choppy splice-job of twangy guitars that shambles its way from straightforward big-beat blues to a torrent of  catastrophic noise
column5: the latter a bit of vibes-heavy fusion-jazz loopwork that feels like a lost highlight from one of MF DOOM's Metal Fingers beat records. But it's clear that Forrest doesn't need to lean on glitchy loop-tweaking to create tracks that stick in your mind. The snarling guitar on ""Crime of the Century"" had to have come from some hard rock nugget somewhere
column6: but it doesn't drive the track as prominently as the beat does
column7: a snaky dubstep pulse that sounds like Distance with a grudge. And the title track's simply a crowd-pleasing take on mid-80s Mantronix-style boom-clap beats-- albeit one that gradually overwhelms itself and disintegrates into waves of synthesized decay. Stylistically jumbled and overambitious as The Everything is
column8: it's successful enough in its adventurousness. And even if the one big trick of Forrest's mid-00s work had a lot of life in it

it's good to hear he's got a few more in the bag.

column9: paradoxically
